column2: Madewell mimics the look of a traditional American dry goods store, though many of the clothes are made in China.
Use the plumpiest shrimp you can find in this easy risotto.

In describing itself, the iRobot Corporation says it ''designs and builds robots that make a difference in people's lives.'' And that is true -- in more ways than one. The company's consumer products, which include the Roomba vacuum cleaner robot and the Scooba robotic mop, certainly make a difference by taking care of household chores.
An article on Friday about the brutal heat in certain sections of the country misstated the high temperature on June 7 in Minneapolis. It was 103, not 102.

Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, has written a letter to President Obama rebuking him for not pressing Congress to create some restrictions on guns and gun ownership. Mr. Lautenberg has filed three amendments on gun issues. One seeks to reinstate a ban on high-capacity gun magazines; another would close the so-called gun show loophole, which permits some people who buy guns at gun shows to avoid background checks otherwise required by federal law; the last would close gaps in the law that prevent the government from stopping suspected terrorists from buying firearms or explosives.

CLARK--Elias. Professor Emeritus at the Yale Law School and Master of Silliman College (1962-1981) at Yale University died June 11, 2011 at home. He is survived by his wife Ann, and their large family. A memorial service will be held at Yale University's Battell Chapel on Friday, June 24, at 11:00am.

From ''Pulp Fiction'' to bedtime stories? Samuel L. Jackson, the actor probably best known for his performance as Jules, the menacing assassin of ''Pulp Fiction,'' has recorded the audiobook of ''Go the -------- to Sleep,'' the parody children's book that reached No. 1 on the New York Times best-seller list. In a voice that alternates from gravelly to soothing, with tinkly lullaby music in the background, Mr. Jackson reads the book, which is written in the style of a children's book but is meant for weary parents who don't mind a lot of profanity. ''The windows are dark in the town, child,'' he reads. ''The whales huddle down in the deep. I'll read you one very last book if you swear you'll go the -------- to sleep.''

BEATON--Betty. We deeply regret the passing of Betty Beaton, wife of our former Chief of Surgery, Dr. Howard Beaton. She was a source of inspiration and courage during her long battle with illness. We will always remember her smile, her beauty, and her dignity during those difficult years. May Howard and their children be comforted with all other mourners in Zion and Jerusalem. Jeffrey Menkes, CEO Dr. Mordechai Hoschander, President, Medical Board & Entire Medical Staff of New York Downtown Hospital

FISCHER--Walter. The Board and Staff of the Jewelers' Security Alliance mourn the passing of our former Chairperson and generous supporter who was a leader in the watch industry having served as CEO of Rolex Watch USA. We extend our sympathies to his family, friends and former co-workers. Sheldon Kwiat, Chairperson John J. Kennedy, President

9 P.M. (13) BOXING GYM (2010) ''For some a gym is a home, a refuge, a safe place to escape to from the turbulence of the streets, a place where parents bring troubled children,'' Richard Lord, a former professional fighter, says of the establishment he founded 20 years ago in Austin, Tex. ''A gym is also a one-room schoolhouse where the teacher, a trainer or coach, teaches on a one-to-one basis.'' This latest documentary from Frederick Wiseman observes Lord's Gym, where age, race, sex, ethnicity and social class blur in the pursuit of the sport of boxing; where some students seek to become professionals, others are satisfied to remain amateurs, and all hope to fulfill a dream. ''You notice the women in the documentary right away (at least I enviously did), partly because of their coiled strength and confidence,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''But you also notice that none of the men seem to be checking them out. Boxing is a gravely serious business at Lord's, where everything looks battered, not just some of the faces.'' Of Mr. Wiseman's filmmaking, she said, ''This kind of fly-on-the-wall style of documentary can create a sense that you're watching the unmediated truth, a fantasy belied by every camera position and each edit.'' Ms. Dargis added: ''He might be quieter than Michael Moore (literally and cinematically), who throws everything (found footage, interviews, himself) at the screen, but Mr. Wiseman says plenty in his work.'' At 10:30, ''New York Fight Clubs'' looks back at the city's once-popular pastime. 7 P.M. (Showtime) COLOR ME KUBRICK (2005) John Malkovich, below, plays Alan Conway, a real-life British con man who hustled his way across England by impersonating the reclusive filmmaker Stanley Kubrick. Gay and an alcoholic, Conway, who died in 1998 (three months before Kubrick himself), would try to seduce young men with the promise of work on forthcoming projects. But he wasn't always careful in his research, and his knowledge of Kubrick's films was so spotty that he was unmasked more than once and forced to flee. He crossed paths in London with Frank Rich, then the chief theater critic of The New York Times, who encountered Conway, posing as Kubrick, in a restaurant. When Mr. Rich looked further into the man's identity, he discovered the ruse and in 1993 wrote a column about it. Directed by Brian Cook, who was an assistant director on the Kubrick films ''The Shining,'' ''Barry Lyndon'' and ''Eyes Wide Shut,'' and written by Anthony Frewin, who was Kubrick's personal assistant, ''this arch, episodic movie is really an affectionate sequence of in-jokes conceived as a posthumous homage to Kubrick by two knowing insiders,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. ''The sharpest satire is reserved for the fools who swallow an act that seems transparently fake. Anyone who has watched a TV star besieged by gawking and drooling fans knows what encounters with fame can do in a culture of blind celebrity worship.''

A picture caption in some editions on Tuesday with an article about the Turnesa family of golfers misidentified the state in which Canoe Brook Country Club, where Jim Turnesa was photographed playing in 1965, is located. It is New Jersey (in Summit), not New Hampshire.

LONDON -- From time to time we all like to check in on places or things that, across the years, come to mark the passage of time. At the National Gallery here, in a room where the crowds tend to thin, hang Rembrandt's two Trips: There's Jacob, the grumpy Dordrecht merchant, with that eyebrow raised and that vaguely disapproving, deadpan glare. And there's Margaretha de Geer, his wife, next to him, looking through those pale brown eyes as if into some abyss. I imagine that Jacob used to be the sort of vain young man accustomed to getting lots of attention. But Margaretha's the one I always focus on. I note how her head perches improbably above that elaborate ruff collar, like a raisin on top of one of those inflatable airplane neck pillows, which even at the time the picture was painted, in 1661, was already decades out of fashion. Swallowed inside her chair, she clutches a huge white handkerchief. It always looks to me as if she were holding a dead ferret.

BRANDON--Donald E.,MD, of Bronxville, on June 15, 2011. Husband of Joyce and the late Janet E. Brandon; father of Richard, Leslie and the late Donald, Jr. Grandfather of Randall, Paul, Barbara, Beauregard, Gaige, Pierson and Tate. After serving in the South Pacific with the U.S. Army during WWII, he graduated from the University of Denver, where he earned induction into the Phi Beta Kappa Academic Honor Society. Dr. Donald Brandon went on to graduate University Texas Southwestern Medical School in Dallas, TX. He then maintained a private practice in Internal Medicine in Manhattan, until 2008. He was a Physician to the United Nations and The Medical Director for the Associated Press. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY between the hours of 6-9pm on Friday, June 17.

GUARASCIO--Louis J. On June 14. Beloved husband of Natalie. Loving father of Susan, Sandra, Natalie, Maria, Louis, Karen and Laura. Adoring grandfather of Joseph, Katherine, Hayley, Richard, Robert and Natalina. WWII Marine. Reposing Victor Quirolo & Sons Funeral Home, 3176 E. Tremont Avenue, Bronx, NY 10461. Visitation Thursday 7-9pm. and Friday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, 9:45am, St Theresa Church, Bronx., NY. Entombment St Raymond Cemetery.

JONAS--Barbara, of Boca Raton, FL on June 15. Beloved wife of Alan, mother of Daniel and Lori. Mother-in-law of Robert Kruger and Mimi Hoang. Grandmother of Ilene and Julia Kruger. Donations can be sent to Hospice By The Sea of Boca Raton.

FLAUM--Mitchel. The Board of Trustees and the Staff of the Robert Mapplethorpe Residential Treatment Facility of Beth Israel Medical Center mourn the loss of our long time board member, Mitchel Flaum. We are grateful for Mitch's dedication and support for our mission to provide exceptional long term care to patients with HIV/AIDS. He will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family and loved ones. Carol Maslow Chairman, Board of Trustees Gail Donovan, Trustee Harris Nagler, MD, Trustee Michael Stout, Trustee Mary Walsh, RN, Trustee Ellen Birenbaum MD Medical Director
An article last Thursday about a sale at Christofle misstated the store's phone number. It is (212) 308-9390.

BRITT MAREN, model. WHAT I'M WEARING NOW The dress is Alexander Wang. I got it for doing Alex's show. He helped start my career, but I loved his stuff even before that. Most of what I have from him is black, so I was excited to get a few new pieces with color. My Balenciaga sandals are from my agent, Heather. They were hers.

GRASSLEY QUESTIONS S.E.C. Senator Charles E. Grassley, left, Republican of Iowa, has peppered the S.E.C. with letters asking it to explain its response to 19 reports of suspicious trading at SAC Capital Advisors. Now, Mr. Grassley has escalated his confrontation with the S.E.C., saying it received 65 reports. ''This substantially expands the number of referrals in the S.E.C.'s possession to 65 which, thus far, you have provided no evidence that the S.E.C. has investigated or acted upon,'' he wrote in a letter to Mary L. Schapiro, the commission chairwoman.
8:31 p.m. | Updated Sobriety has returned to the market for new Internet companies - at least for one day.
UFFNER--Henry. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. We miss you and will love you always. Your Loving Family

I just learned (first from a friend, then from the many comments people posted on my previous post) that what I've been looking for from Gmail (reposting of received messages at a future date) actually exists in the form of Boomerang-a free Gmail plug-in that does exactly what I described. I just installed it and it works perfectly-messages can reappear in my inbox (marked as unread, starred and/or at the top of my inbox) at a date or time I set. Boomerang also lets you schedule delivery of e-mails you are sending. If you're working on something late at night and want it to appear in someone's inbox when they get to work, you can set your message to be sent at a specific date. This is also good for what I like to call V.O.P. (virtual-office presence), if you want to appear hard at work when you are otherwise sleeping or carousing.

MITGANG--Edward, on June 14, 2011 in Del Ray Beach, FL. Beloved husband of the late Eleanor. Dear father of Joyce and Robert Bartolomeo, and Steven. Adored grandfather of Bradley, Jamie and Adam. Visiting today, 7-9pm and services Friday, 10am at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, LI.

How many times do you have to add seven plus two? I have no problem with doing homework, but that put us both over the edge. I got to the point that this is enough. DONNA CUSHLANIS,of Galloway, N.J., on the amount of homework assigned to her son, a second grader. [A1]

Earlier this month, as the prospect of a shortened N.F.L. season loomed, so did the pessimism about the state of labor negotiations as owners and players awaited a critical court ruling in their fight over how to divide billions of dollars. More recently, people briefed on the state of negotiations have noted real progress, along with an optimistic whisper that a deal might be completed sooner than expected, perhaps by July 4. The sides met again Wednesday in Maryland, and one person briefed on the negotiations described both parties as having their respective ''noses to the grindstone.'' The parties are discussing a deal that could run 8 to 10 years, and the crux of the negotiations remains what percentage of revenue should go to the players and how players might share in an anticipated boost in television revenue -- the largest chunk of the roughly $9 billion a year the N.F.L. generates -- when new network contracts are negotiated later this decade. When all owners convene for a meeting in Chicago next Tuesday, the N.F.L. would like to give them as much information as possible, in broad strokes, about the framework for a deal. Still, a vote to ratify a final agreement in Chicago remains unlikely, as does the idea of an agreement in principle. The meeting will more likely aim to update the owners on where the league stands with players and get clubs comfortable with how a deal may look. ''I'm cautiously optimistic,'' said Jay Feely, the player representative in Arizona. ''Any time there are negotiations and meetings, it's better than anything happening in the courts.'' The league would like the deal finished around July 4. That date would allow for several weeks of free agency so teams could sort out their rosters in time for training camps in late July. More at nytimes.com.

WACHSPRESS--Marcia (nee Singer), age 89, passed away June 14, 2011. Beloved wife for 57 years of the late Morton Wachspress, MD, mother of Joseph (wife Lyn) and Ruth, grandmother of Michael, Lauren, Emily and Lian, sister of the late Arthur Singer and Harriet Glantz. Far Rockaway HS class of '40, Queens College class of '44, M.S.-ESL-NYU. Worked at U.S. Embassy, Moscow, 1945, early UN employee, editor, teacher. Ahead of her time, world traveler, New York City culture enthusiast, memoirist, amateur photographer, tennis and ping pong hustler. We will miss your endless energy, sense of humor and zest for life. Funeral service Friday, June 17, 2011 at Cedar Crest Chapel in Pompton Plains. Burial to follow at Mt. Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, Queens. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to American Jewish World Service 45 West 36 St., 11th Floor, New York, NY 10018-7904.

This year, at least, the city's slaughtered geese will not go to waste: They will go to feed hungry Pennsylvanians. Last summer, much of the outcry prompted by the roundup of hundreds of geese in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, in the name of airline safety focused on the fact that after the geese were gassed, their bodies were dumped in a landfill, leaving literally tons of tasty, high-protein free-range meat (an adult goose can weigh 25 pounds) to rot in garbage heaps. The authorities said the state had not established safety protocols for processing and consumption of wild goose meat.

Weird Al Yankovic continues to find his way into the hearts and minds of America's youth, and this time there's nothing that Lady Gaga can do to stand in his way. On Wednesday, HarperCollins Children's Books said an application would be released for Apple iPad, iPhone and iPod Touch devices based on Mr. Yankovic's best-selling children's book, ''When I Grow Up.'' The original book, written by Mr. Yankovic (who, in a rare career move, did not declare himself to be ''Weird'' on its cover) and illustrated by Wes Hargis, follows an 8-year-old boy named Billy as he considers grown-up career options, such as becoming a doctor, firefighter, giraffe milker or snail trainer. The ''When I Grow Up'' app, which is developed by the Web design company Bean Creative, offers interactive games and features based on the book, including the option to have Mr. Yankovic read it to you, and opportunities to practice some of Billy's more fanciful future occupations, such as shaving a tarantula or massaging a gorilla. Mr. Yankovic said in a statement that when he was a child, ''I dreamed of one day helping to produce a cross-platform app that would be sold in the iTunes Store.'' He added: ''I was a very prescient kid.'' The ''When I Grow Up'' app will cost $2.99 for download. For slightly older listeners (who still think like children), Mr. Yankovic's new album ''Alpocalypse'' will be released on Tuesday.

UFFNER--Henry. We at Goldberg Weprin Finkel Goldstein LLP extend our deepest sympathy to our partner and friend, Steven Uffner, on the loss of his father, Henry. Henry survived the Holocaust and relocated his family to South America and then to New York. Throughout, he retained an intellectual, soft spoken and gentle way. It was and is a privilege to know him, and to have his son as our partner. Our condolences to the entire Uffner family.

When the Harvard psychologist and psychedelic explorer Timothy Leary first met the Beat poet Allen Ginsberg in 1960, he welcomed Ginsberg's participation in the drug experiments he was conducting at the university. ''The first time I took psilocybin -- 10 pills -- was in the fireside social setting in Cambridge,'' Ginsberg wrote in a blow-by-blow description of his experience taking synthesized hallucinogenic mushrooms at Leary's stately home. At one point Ginsberg, naked and nauseated, began to feel scared, but then ''Professor Leary came into my room, looked in my eyes and said I was a great man.''

When Representative Gerald E. Connolly, Democrat of Virginia, tried to send a taxpayer-paid newsletter to his constituents this month, the Republican majority had a few edits first. Instead of calling the Republican budget proposals a plan to ''eliminate Medicare as we know it and replace it with a privatized system,'' the group that oversees House mailings insisted on making it ''change Medicare and revise a government program with support from private insurance companies.''

The legal protection of self-defense, it seems, has been extended to noodle-related strife. On Wednesday, Judge ShawnDya Simpson of Manhattan Criminal Court found Marcella Caprario, 37, an opera singer and English-as-a-second-language teacher, not guilty on charges of attempted assault in the third degree and harassment in the second degree.

The Friars Club in Midtown Manhattan, known for its provocative celebrity roasts, was the unlikely, if fitting, backdrop for the latest development in the tragicomedy that has become Representative Anthony D. Weiner's political life. Ginger Lee, an exotic dancer and former pornographic film actress who said she had received sexually explicit messages from Mr. Weiner, stood wide-eyed and largely silent before a bank of microphones on Wednesday, as her lawyer, Gloria Allred, told reporters that Ms. Lee wanted ''to speak the truth about her relationship with Congressman Anthony Weiner.''
DURST--Shirley. The Durst Organization mourns the loss of Shirley Durst, the wife of Roy Durst. A feisty, inquisitive, loving and generous woman who will be missed by all who knew her.

HERTZ--David Bendel, 92, died on June 13 in Miami, FL. Dr. Hertz was a Professor Emeritus at the University of Miami, where he served as a Distinguished Professor of Artificial Intelligence, director of the Intelligent Computer Systems Research Institute, and professor of management science as well as law. He was a director and general partner of McKinsey and Company, Inc. in New York City for 20 years. He was a professor at Columbia University, where he earned his BA, BS, and PhD; he also earned an MS from the U.S. Navy Postgraduate School and a JD from New York University Law School. Hertz was internationally renowned for his work in artificial intelligence and neural networks, and was a specialist in operations research, systems and risk analysis, and computer law. Dr. Hertz was a founding member and president of the Operations Research Society, as well as president of the Institute of Management Sciences and the International Federation of Operations Research Societies. He published extensively and authored several books throughout his career. He also served as a Commander in the U.S. Navy during WWII. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, Barbara Valentine, their daughters Barbara Burr and Valentine Kass, four grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. A private memorial has been held. Van Orsdel Funeral Home-Kendall.

DURST--Shirley, devoted wife of Roy Durst, loving mother of Peter, Stephen and Leslie, proud grandmother of six and great-grandmother of one great-grandchild, died peacefully at the age of 92. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation in her name to the Purchase College Foundation, Attn: Development Department, 735 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase, NY 10577.

WHITE--Eugene B.,79, originally of Englewood, NJ, died peacefully in his home on June 15 under the wonderful care of Levan Alex and George. Loving father of Claudia, Frederic, Adam and Jason, grandfather of Ariel, Alexander, Jonah and Eli, brother of Enid, father-in-law to Joseph and Judy, uncle, great uncle, patient and friend. Funeral service, June 17, at 10am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. Donations to East End Hospice
SEVIN--Malvin Peace. Malvin dear, I cherish the warm memories. Miss your love, miss you! Always, Audrey

To the Editor: In Penelope Green's useful ''Light Bulb Saving Time'' (May 26), I was surprised to find repeated mention of consumer misunderstanding of the legislation regarding incandescent bulbs, yet no discussion of consumer wariness. Perhaps some of the bulb stockpiling is also due to suspicions that manufacturers, seeking to reduce costs and multiple inventories, will choose to make only one kind of bulb. Robert Peluso

An article in some editions on Tuesday about the Boston Bruins' 5-2 victory over the Vancouver Canucks in Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals misstated in some copies the number of shots that Bruins goalie Tim Thomas faced in that game. He faced 38 shots, not 28. (He stopped 36.) The article also misstated his save percentage through the finals' first six games. It was .962, not .967.

The final residence of John Coltrane, a ranch-style home in Dix Hills, N.Y., where he composed his masterpiece ''A Love Supreme,'' is now among the 11 most endangered historic places in the country, the National Trust for Historic Preservation is to announce on Wednesday. The property was bought in 2006 by Friends of the Coltrane Home in an effort to turn the house into an education center after a decade of vacancy and deterioration. But those plans have stalled from a lack of funds. According to the trust's president, Stephanie Meeks, the potential of the house, despite its modest nature, is what makes it a prime candidate for preservation. ''The home itself is one you might find in any suburban neighborhood,'' she said in a telephone interview. ''It reinforces the idea that great history happens all around us and there is a preservation opportunity around every corner.''
International SOCIAL MEDIA HELP SUSTAIN

Q.Ever since I upgraded to Firefox 4, the browser no longer remembers the tabs I had open just before I quit the program. Is there a way to restore this feature? A. Mozilla's default start page for Firefox 4 includes a Restore Previous Session button you can click to reopen all the tabs you were using before you closed the browser. But if you have changed your default home page to something different, the Restore Previous Session button does not appear.

THERE were so many resort presentations happening at Milk Studios on Monday that the building, which bumps up against the High Line park, began to feel like a department store. First floor: Marc by Marc Jacobs. Second floor: Céline, Nina Ricci, Erin Fetherston. Farther up were Lanvin, Givenchy and Pedro Lourenço. At Céline, the models walked out and formed a lineup, and then the editors, who were sitting in an informal front row, were invited to walk over for a closer examination of the clothes. There were some pop colors, floral prints and exuberant jacquards that were something of a surprise in an eye-catching collection from Phoebe Philo. A belted leather jacket with a grid of multicolored patches actually made me think of a light-up disco floor. But there was a lot of variety here as well, since Ms. Philo sets out to offer a complete wardrobe in every collection. This one included a number of sheer dresses, alternately cinched at the waist (a black one with a pilgrim-size belt buckle) or loose and relaxed (a hot pink shirtdress with extra-long cuffs), and some smartly striped pajama-type separates in between.

Goldman Sachs appears to be trying to clearits name. The compelling Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations report on the financial crisis is wrong, the bank says. Goldman Sachs didn't have a Big Short against the housing market.

BETHESDA, Md. -- The United States Golf Association announced Wednesday that Shinnecock Hills would host the 2018 United States Open, the fifth time the event has come to the Long Island club. The tournament was first held there in 1896. ''We are thrilled that our national championship will return to one of our country's most-storied venues,'' the U.S.G.A. president, Jim Hyler, said. ''We are confident that Shinnecock Hills will provide a true challenge for the world's premier players, as it has for more than a century.''

Adele returned to the top of the Billboard album chart this week, supplanting Lady Gaga after two weeks. But the biggest news is what's at No. 3: the cast recording of the Broadway show ''The Book of Mormon.'' According to Billboard it is the highest-charting Broadway album since 1969, when ''Hair'' was No. 1 for 13 weeks. ''The Book of Mormon'' sold 61,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It was surely helped by hype for the Tony Awards on Sunday, where it won nine prizes. (Sales for ''The Book of Mormon'' album were so low the week before that it did not make the Billboard 200, the magazine's standard album chart.) But there's a slight catch to the success. Like Lady Gaga's ''Born This Way'' two weeks ago, ''The Book of Mormon'' benefited from a huge markdown by Amazon, which sold the digital version of the album for $1.99 for the four days leading up to the Tonys. As a result, 85 percent of the sales were digital downloads, a much higher ratio than usual. Also on this week's album chart, Adele's ''21'' sold 114,000 copies, bringing it to No. 1, and Lady Gaga's ''Born This Way'' fell to No. 2 with 100,000 sales. The rapper Tech N9ne opened at No. 4 with 56,000 sales of his album ''All 6's & 7's'' (Strange Music), and Ronnie Dunn, of the country duo Brooks & Dunn, bowed at No. 5 with 45,000 sales of his self-titled debut album, released by Arista Nashville. -Album sales so far this year have been holding steady. The tally as of Sunday was 136.9 million, up about half a percent from last year's sales to the same point (136.2 million). That may be a minuscule increase, but it is the third week in a row that weekly album sales have improved year over year, and for an industry accustomed to negative numbers, it's good news.

NAUTICALLY striped rompers, playful and leggy, are proving a popular alternative this summer to the forever-in-fashion navy-and-white tops. Chloë Sevigny has been spotted on the street wearing hers from Opening Ceremony; Rag & Bone's rendition, striped with contrast gray bottoms, quickly disappeared from shops; and Forever 21 is doing a brisk business with several pairs for under $20. Nancy Gibson and Jennifer Murray, the designers behind the Edith A. Miller romper here, discovered their destiny when they showed up at a party wearing identical Robert P. Miller striped men's T-shirts. Before long, they had contacted the century-old rural Pennsylvania knitting mill behind the shirts, a company historically known for making military thermals, and after some coaxing, the Edith A. Miller sister collection of reimagined tees and scoop-neck summer tank dresses was born. (The name Edith had a nice turn-of-the-century ring to it, they thought.) The inspiration for the romper was ''girls on bikes,'' Ms. Murray said. ''You always want to wear a cute outfit to ride a bike. It's the perfect thing.''

A headline on Monday with an article about efforts by El-Sayyid A. Nosair to gain a retrial in a 1995 terrorism case erroneously attributed a distinction to Mr. Nosair. As the article stated, he was convicted of seditious conspiracy and the murder of Rabbi Meir Kahane, not of being an agent for Al Qaeda. The error was repeated in a headline with a news summary on Page A2.

BILL BOWERMAN, a founder of Nike, created the sole for the Waffle Racer, introduced in 1974, by pouring rubber onto his wife's waffle iron. He destroyed her iron but whipped up a groundbreaking lightweight sole with traction. Today J. Crew, in a new collaboration with Nike, is releasing three sneakers that Mr. Bowerman, also a legendary track coach, designed in the early '70s. Its Nike Vintage Collection includes replicas of the Waffle Racer; the Tennis Classic AC, a shoe originally designed for clay courts and now available with custom-colored accents; and the Cortez, the first shoe to feature the Nike swoosh and a full-length mid-sole, which changed the approach to comfort and shock absorption, now with throwback touches like '70s-grade nylon. From top: Nike Cortez sneakers, $75; Waffle

LEVINE--David L.,died peacefully on June 14, 2011 at UniHealth Post-Acute Care - Athens Heritage in Athens, Georgia, at the age of 91. He was a proud graduate of DeWitt Clinton High School, Bronx, NY, winner of the New York Times Essay Contest on the United States Constitution in 1937, and graduated from the City College of New York in 1941. David received his Masters of Social Work from the University of Pennsylvania in 1943 and in 1953 his Doctorate in Social Work from the University of Minnesota. He then began his academic career at Florida State University (1953-1967), followed by two years as the Associate Dean of the School of Social Work at the University of Syracuse (1967-1969), and then as Professor at the University of Georgia School of Social Work (1969-1994). David was active in each community in which he lived and served on the Board of Directors of the mental health centers in Leon County, Florida, and Athens-Clarke County, Georgia. He was an appointee to the Georgia Council on Aging, the advisory body to the state on aging issues, from 1987 until the time of his death. He was a founding board member of the Athens Community Council on Aging and was named Honorary Director, a lifetime position, in 2000. He was proclaimed the Distinguished Older Georgian for 2009 by resolutions of the Georgia General Assembly and the Georgia State Senate. He was named Georgia Champion for Aging by the Southeastern Association of Area Agencies on Aging in 2010. He participated in the White House Conference on Aging for three decades and received countless awards from various professional groups reflecting his tireless commitment to advocacy for those who could not advocate for themselves. David was an educator and a social worker, but he thought of himself as a social work educator. Hundreds of his former students throughout the country and particularly in the Southeast passionately carry on his legacy. He was an active and dedicated member of the National Association of Social Workers and was serving on the Georgia NASW Ethics Committee at his death. David was pre-deceased by his wife Laura (nee Kaplan) in 2006 and is survived by his daughters Deborah L Davis of Philadelphia, PA and her spouse Tad and their children Sarah and Ben; Elizabeth Levine of Decatur, GA and her partner Ann Baker; Helen Levine of St. Petersburg, FL and her spouse Katee Tully; and his son Edwin, of Athens, GA and his partner Mary Anne McGuire; and long-time family friends Dottie Pettes and Charlon Seegar. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, June 26, 2011 at 2:30pm at Congregation Children of Israel, 115 Dudley Drive, Athens, GA 30606. In lieu of flowers the family asks that donations be made to the Athens Community Council on Aging, 135 Hoyt Street, Athens, GA 30601, or the charity of your choice. Services by SouthCare Cremation Society and Memorial Centers in Marietta, GA (770) 420-5557.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Brian Lenihan, a former finance minister of Ireland, erroneously attributed a distinction to Mr. Lenihan in parliamentary elections there this year. He was the only member of the Fianna Fail party's Dublin-area delegation to retain his seat, not the party's only member to do so. A correction in this space on Tuesday misstated the size of the party's Dublin delegation at the time; there were 18 members, not 47.

PARIS -- On a recent Sunday afternoon, the Champs-Élysées was packed with people enjoying this city's most famous boulevard -- window shopping, sipping wine at sidewalk cafes and strolling toward the river with ice cream cones. Then there were the 150 people waiting to get into an American retail chain store. And that was one of the shortest lines since the store, Abercrombie & Fitch, opened here last month.

KAHAN--Jack J.,passed away on June 14, 2011 at the age of 89. He was a resident of Rye, NY. Jack was the president of Interstate + Lakeland Lumber Corporation. He is survived by his loving wife Erna, son Sheldon (Joanne), daughter Judy Berman (Jan). Jack was predeceased by his sister Beatrice Tanny and he is survived by his sister Miriam Charney and brother Herbert Kahan. His grandchildren are Rachel, Daniel, Benjamin and Lauren. Services will be held at Congregation KTI in Port Chester, NY, Thursday at 11am.

Here are some first reactions to Sony's $250 PlayStation Vita (PSVita), the former NGP, unveiled Monday at E3 in Los Angeles, and in stores later this year. On first glance, PS Vita (the short name) looks like a wide-body version PSP, with a bright (OLED), large (5-inch) touch screen. The familiar analog sticks and shoulder triggers work as expected. But when you mix in not one, but two multitouch surfaces (on the front and the back), six-axis motion sensing for lifting or tilting, front/back cameras for things social, gaming or augmented reality and a microphone, you have lot of controls to tame. In other words, this thing can be tricky.

An article on Wednesday about the narrowing of the race for managing director of the International Monetary Fund to candidates from France and Mexico referred imprecisely to the reason that the candidacy of Stanley Fischer, the governor of the Bank of Israel, was rejected by the I.M.F.'s governing board. It was because he was over the age limit of 65, according to the board's executive director, A. Shakour Shaalan, not because he missed the application deadline of June 10. (Mr. Fischer met the deadline, Mr. Shaalan said in an email after the article was published.)

Facebook has had a mobile app for some time, but iPad users have had to go without a native iPad app. Yes, you could access Facebook through the iPad's Safari Web browser or used the iPhone app on the iPad, but both of those options come with compromises: Facebook's Web site is not optimized for a touchscreen and the company's iPhone app is simply magnified (and blurrier) on an iPad.

Those unhappily married couples of Stephen Sondheim's legendary musical ''Follies,'' who long for their younger, happier days revolving around New York theater, will have another shot at Broadway this summer. The Washington revival of ''Follies'' at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts will transfer north to the Marquis Theater for a limited run that is expected to begin performances in August, the president of the Kennedy Center said in an interview on Wednesday. Casting is not set, but it's fair to assume that the two stars of this ''Follies'' - Bernadette Peters as Sally Durant Plummer and Jan Maxwell as Phyllis Rogers Stone - will be sought to continue in the Broadway run, said Michael M. Kaiser, the Kennedy Center president. He said contract talks with the actors had yet to begin, and added that he was not certain which members of the cast would be available to continue to Broadway.

Intriguing women populate Series B of the Ensemble Studio Theater's 2011 one-act play marathon. Their backgrounds may be diverse, but the shared depth and detail of their personal histories makes their stories spill beyond the frames of the short works in which they appear. There's Elise (Delphi Harrington), an imperious 90-year-old Hungarian-Jewish Holocaust survivor, given to withering assessments of anyone she deems boring. There's Mrs. Jones (Uzo Aduba), a blind African-American sharecropper's daughter in the long-ago Deep South. There's Lila (Beth Dixon), a refined actress whose qualities have been habitually underappreciated. And there's Rene (Lizan Mitchell), a hard-bitten black security officer at an immigrant detention center in Flint, Mich., determined not to slip to the bottom of the totem pole.

One of the advantages The Times Magazine has over its competitors is that our print edition comes tucked into the newspaper, and we are therefore liberated from playing celebrity musical chairs with our cover. However, this also means we miss out on the opportunity of watching our magazine fly off the newsstand (to the extent that ever happens with any magazine anymore). We never get that rock-solid indication of a cover’s popularity. Instead, we have to rely on anecdotal feedback in the form of reader mail, Twitter feeds and Web sites like Coverjunkie (which we love, by the way; thank you for your support).

This Minimalist recipe comes from July 2001, an age of relative innocence (and youth!), or so it seems to me now. The column was on weeknight entertaining, made possible by a menu of make-ahead dishes, including white bean and garlic dip, green salad with fresh mild herbs and hazelnut oil, puréed fresh pea soup, salmon with cherry tomatoes en papillote, and coeur à la crème (that creamy French concoction that’s often chilled in heart-shaped molds and served with fresh fruit). Of these, only the salmon and dessert strike me as dated — the former because salmon no longer seems nearly as good and guilt-free as it did a decade ago, and the latter because these days I rarely indulge in desserts that are 80 percent full-fat dairy and 20 percent sugar, as coeur à la crème is.

You don’t become a parent until you have a child. No class can really prepare you, and no conversation can truly make you ready. That said, having a child is just the start. What you think you know the moment they are born will change by the hour.

The Dalmatian ham with Pag (a salty sheep cheese) that my parents and I ordered recently on the Croatian island of Mljet came with loads of olives. Fourteen, by my count. My mother, who likes olives, took four. My father, whose hatred of olives I’ve inherited, took none. Since I had challenged myself to eat every olive I could this summer in an effort to appreciate what so many of my friends love in them, that left me with 10.

Come November, when resort hits the stores, you’ll see lots of head-to-toe pattern worn in one of two ways: You can either belt a matching top and bottom, à la Marc Jacobs, to look like a pseudo-jumpsuit, or you can wear your patterns all mixed up, à la Thakoon. Either way, this is one trend that can be activated right now with a pair of printed mini shorts, like the cotton ones from Etoile Isabel Marant ($225; go to net-a-porter.com), and an equally busy tank top from your closet. Just remember to stick to the same palette. Or, you could revive that printed onesie you were hoping never to wear again. Courage, girl.

New Yorkers went to bed on Sunday and woke up on Monday buzzing — and posting — about the Tonys (also #tonyawards), where a strong slate of nominees, a much-talked about and much-nominated “The Book of Mormon” and a disarming host — that would be Neil Patrick Harris or @ActuallyNPH, as he is known on Twitter — restored the theater awards to a place of unlikely hipness.

The Senate dealt the ethanol industry a rare defeat on Thursday when it voted 73-27 to end the annual $6 billion tax break given to blenders of ethanol, along with a tariff on foreign ethanol intended to protect the domestic industry from Brazilian sugar ethanol imports. The vote was on an amendment to a bill with a very uncertain future, but it did suggest that Congress will be looking at ethanol when it takes an ax to federal spending to get the budget deficit and national debt under control later this summer.

Hollywood filmmakers have been treating cars as disposable props for more than a century. Cars, like everything else in a movie, serve the story, and if that means they must be destroyed in the process, so be it. Even the cars that survive filming are treated poorly; they often pile up on studio back lots after their moments of cinematic glory and sit until they’re weathered down to scrap.

“The crowd is ecstatic!” shouted the fashion historian Valerie Steele. She was referring to the more than 2,000 fans at Tuesday’s preview opening of “The Fashion World of Jean Paul Gaultier: From the Sidewalk to the Catwalk,” the designer’s first major solo exhibition, at the Montreal’s Musée des Beaux-Arts. (It opens to the public today.) The guests had lined up for hours in front of the museum to catch a glimpse of the show and, with luck, of the man insiders call “fashion’s enfant terrible.” That proved nearly impossible; every room was packed, with visitors struggling to reach a bar or a faraway friend.

At No. 1 on the hardcover list this week is “Wonder Woman: Odyssey,” in which the superheroine wakes up to find that someone has altered her past. She sets out – in a new costume – to find out what went wrong. This is the first half of the journey, written by J. Michael Straczynski and illustrated by Don Kramer. About halfway through the story, Mr. Straczynski departed to work on a sequel to “Superman: Earth One,” an interpretation of the Man of Steel’s origin for today’s audience. The first installment of that story hit No. 1 in our hardcover list in November. Phil Hester, who took over the Wonder Woman story, has two installments in “Odyssey” that were helped along by the original writer’s notes. Of course, they’ll likely be more tinkering with the Amazing Amazon’s origin in September when DC Comics restarts the majority of its superhero series with new number ones.

BOSTON — Talk about musicians who work hard for the love of it: at 11:30 on Wednesday night, Quicksilver, a period-instrument sextet, took the stage at Emmanuel Church to play a program of vigorous, texturally rich sonatas from the dawn of the Baroque era. The lateness of the hour was not so unusual: the Boston Early Music Festival, which presented the concert, has always offered late- night performances, and the concept has taken root elsewhere too (at Lincoln Center, for example, which has offered refreshing late performances, particularly after Mostly Mozart concerts, in recent years).

Woody is going wide. Sony Pictures Classics said Thursday that it planned to increase the number of theaters showing Woody Allen’s new time-traveling comedy “Midnight in Paris,” to 1,038 screens, the widest release of any of Mr. Allen’s films. “Midnight in Paris,” which has been well-received by critics, has earned more than $16 million in the United States and more than $18.3 million overseas, where in recent years Mr. Allen has found a much bigger audience than he enjoys at home. (His last critically successful film, “Vicky Christina Barcelona,” earned $23.2 million in the United States and $73.2 million internationally, according to boxofficemojo.com.)

The ability of search engines to calculate basic arithmetic right in the search box is well known, but some can handle higher math as well. Both Bing and Google can perform trigonometric functions like sine, cosine and tanget when the sin, cos and tan operators are typed into the search box. For example, typing “sin 45 degrees” and hitting the Enter key brings a result of 0.707107 — with no digging around for a calculator. Microsoft has a full list of mathematical operations that work with Bing here; a similar list for Google is here.

BETHESDA, Md. -- A spectator at the United States Open collapsed just off the 11th Thursday morning, suffering what his companions and medical workers at the course said was very likely a seizure rather than a heart attack. Ryan Codd, 29, of Taylorsville, Md., had walked three holes of the course at Congressional Country Club when he suddenly fell onto one of the three men he was with, then onto to a paved walkway, where he lost consciousness, said Francis Condon, one of Codd's companions.

REDLICH--Norman. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our good friend and Director Emeritus Norman Redlich. Norman was a great leader of Greenwich House as a member of the board for 26 years, providing invaluable counsel, leadership and support in numerous ways. We will miss his wisdom, vision and expertise in the law. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Evelyn Grobow Redlich, their children Bonny, Carrie and Edward and their entire family.

An Op-Ed article on June 15, about the travel writer Patrick Leigh Fermor, misidentified the German general he helped capture during World War II. It was Heinrich Kreipe, an infantry commander operating in Crete, not Werner Kreipe, a Luftwaffe commander. The article also incorrectly stated the school from which Mr. Fermor was expelled. It was the King's School, Canterbury, not the Royal Military Academy at Sandhurst.

Wall Street plans to get smaller this summer. Faced with weak markets and uncertainty over regulations, many of the biggest firms are preparing for deep cuts in jobs and other costs. The cutback plans are emerging even as Wall Street firms have mostly recovered from the financial crisis and are reporting substantial profits again. But those profits are not as big as they were before the crisis, and it is expected that in the coming months it will be even more difficult for firms to make money. Worries about debt in Europe and the shape that the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul rules will ultimately take, combined with the usual summer doldrums, are prompting banks to act.

PRICING PANDORA With the post-I.P.O. Pandora halo fading, the Deal Professor grades the underwriters of the initial public offering: Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup. Pandora managed to sidestep the debate over underpricing an I.P.O. Pandora's underwriters raised the final sale price to $16 a share, from a range of $7 to $9. The shares finished their first day at $17.42. That gain is in the average range for I.P.O.'s and a particularly good result considering the recent broad decline in the stock market. Notably, Pandora's shares then fell 23.9 percent on Thursday to $13.26, below the offering price.

The New York Police Department said it is investigating the account of a man who said that he was involved in a 1994 shooting and robbery of the rapper Tupac Shakur, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Shakur was wounded in that incident and was robbed of jewelry he was wearing; he was killed in a 1996 shooting in Las Vegas.

TURNER--Dana. Dana Turner uniquely navigated the worlds of civil rights law, public theater activism and computerized research. She was born October 13, 1954 in Gary, Indiana, grew up in California and graduated from Georgetown Law School. After working at the Library of Congress she moved to New York City to practice law on behalf of the transgender and HIV+ communities. She used her lively sense of humor, magnetic personality and strategic insight to pioneer the use of public theatre for civil rights activism. This was famously achieved with her organization of, and starring in, the first ever Drag Show on the Mall at the 1992 March on Washington for Gay & Lesbian Rights. She later starred for several years as the "Mz Liberty" persona on behalf of oppressed people in New York City Gay Pride events. Her work for the International Conferences on Transgender Law & Employment Policy helped put the "T" in the GLBT alliance, as well as deepen its sensitivity to issues of race, class and gender. Ms. Turner was an expert in online research, often finding key information that other lawyers missed. She also served on the board of the World Against Racism Foundation, provided legal support to the Sylvia Rivera Law Project and starred in the award-winning 2006 documentary "Cruel & Unusual" about transgender women in men's prisons, several of whom she represented. Dana was admitted to Roosevelt Hospital in New York City on April 26th with atrial fibrillation and passed in her sleep at 4:11am on April 28th. Her warmth, charm and generosity created a large family of loved ones in Oregon, San Francisco, New York City and beyond. A public visitation will be held at the Terasem Movement Transreligion Ashram at 2 Park Place, in Bristol, Vermont (30 miles south of Burlington, VT on Rte 116), from Noon 1pm on June 19th, 2011, followed by a 2pm burial at the nearby Maplewood Cemetery in Lincoln, Vermont. Donations in honor of Dana Turner, Esq. may be sent to the Sylvia Rivera Law Project, 147 W. 24th St., 5th Floor, New York, NY 10011, www.srlp.org.

LIANYUNGANG, CHINA -- The six massive silos standing beside this industrial port in northeastern China hold seemingly contradictory promises: They could help improve the quality of China's polluted air, but they might also contribute to faster global warming. The silos, which are scheduled to start operation in July, are designed to blend cleaner-burning imported coal with China's own high-polluting domestic coal, which is contaminated with sulfur and dust.

FULD--Elaine Gerstley, died peacefully at home on June 16, 2011 shortly before her 91st birthday. She lived a long, wonderful life, sharing more than 65 years with her loving husband, James Fuld, who predeceased her. She will be missed enormously by her three loving children, Joan Strauss, James Fuld Jr. and Nancy Neff, and thie spouses Frank, Lisa and Dan, her six adoring grandchildren, Jonathan and his spouse Elizabeth, Jennifer, Jamie, Michael, Ryan and David, and her recent great-grandson Jack, her sister Nancy Rosen, and many nieces and nephews. She was born in Philadelphia and graduated from Swarthmore College, where she played on the Varsity Field Hockey and Tennis teams. She married Jim Fuld during the war in 1942 and thereafter devoted her life to her family, her philanthropic activities and collecting. Her life-long commitment to UJA-Federation included Chair of the Women's Division from 1968-1971, Chair of Special Gifts and Co-chair of the Women's Cabinet. She was also founder and president for five years of Thrift Shop East, and a long time board member of the New York Society for the Deaf. She collected Dr. Wall China and miniature antique furniture pieces that adorned her home for decades. Her family and friends adored her and will dearly miss her warmth, style, and remarkable disposition. Contributions to UJA-Federation of New York in her memory. Services Sunday, June 19, 10:30am at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave. and 65th St. Shiva will be observed Sunday and Monday from 5-8pm.

FISCHER--Walter. Walter Fischer, 75, died on June 13, 2011 in New York City following a two year battle with Melanoma. He is survived by his wife, Jill; children, Stefanie Sibilly and Dr. Gregory Fischer, M.D.; sister, Ursula Fischer-Hartmann; grandchildren, Caroline Sibilly, Josephine, Niels, and Nathaniel Fischer; son-in-law, Milton Sibilly; and daughter-in-law, Daniela Fischer. He emigrated from Switzerland to St. Thomas in 1962, joining the retail organization Little Switzerland, where, after assuming increasing responsibility within the organization, he was promoted to President and CEO. In 1967, he became a U.S. citizen, and in 1993 Walter joined the Rolex Watch Company in Geneva, with responsibilities for overseeing marketing and sales activities for Rolex in the Caribbean and Central America. In 1998, Walter was appointed President and CEO of Rolex Watch U.S.A. and retired in 2005. He was an avid sailor, former Commodore of the St. Thomas Yacht Club, member of the New York Yacht Club and was proud to have served as Chairman of the Board of St. Christopher's Inn. A private funeral service for the family has been planned. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to the St. Christopher's Inn, 21 Franciscan Way, Garrison, NY 10524, Phone (800) 424-0027.

A Manhattan architect who designed a piece that is featured in the Museum of Modern Art's permanent collection died on Thursday, less than a month after he was robbed and beaten on the Upper West Side, the authorities said. The architect, Gerald Abramovitz, 82, was visiting a friend's home near West 89th Street and Central Park West on the evening of May 25 when he was brutally attacked from behind, the police said. Mr. Abramovitz had rung the buzzer and was waiting to be let in when a mugger approached and struck him on the back of the head, causing him to collapse to the ground, the authorities said. The robber snatched his wallet and then fled.

Even as the number of tablet computers, electric vehicles and Internet data centers multiply rapidly, electricity demand is barely growing. Low-power processors, smarter manufacturing plants, rooftop solar panels and other technologies are keeping a lid on electricity use. The slowdown is spurring a fresh cycle of deal-making among publicly traded utilities. Not unlike the wave of consolidation that came after deregulation in the 1990s, major electricity players are looking to get bigger to protect their bottom lines.

About 15 minutes after police detectives from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey pulled Dominique Strauss-Kahn off a Paris-bound flight, he told them he had diplomatic immunity, according to a document filed by prosecutors on Thursday. Then, after he was handcuffed, Mr. Strauss-Kahn -- at the time the managing director of the International Monetary Fund -- asked to speak to someone from the French consulate and requested that his handcuffs be secured in front of him rather than behind his back. When it became clear that he would miss his flight, he asked to make a call so he could let people know he would not be at a meeting the next day.

Three years after a bitter offstage fight derailed its plans for Broadway, the new musical comedy ''Nice Work If You Can Get It'' is back on the drawing boards for a spring 2012 opening, with a new leading man, Matthew Broderick, in his first Broadway musical since ''The Producers'' in 2001. ''Nice Work,'' about a playboy who gets mixed up with bootleggers in the 1920s, and featuring songs by George and Ira Gershwin, will open on Broadway in spring 2012, the show's producers announced on Thursday. The Tony Award-winning director and choreographer Kathleen Marshall, now represented on Broadway by the hit revival ''Anything Goes,'' had been developing the musical around Harry Connick, Jr. - whom she helped make a musical theater star with ''The Pajama Game'' - when the production melted down in 2008.

Scientists have designed a brain implant that restored lost memory function and strengthened recall of new information in laboratory rats -- a crucial first step in the development of so-called neuroprosthetic devices to repair deficits from dementia, stroke and other brain injuries in humans. Though still a long way from being tested in humans, the implant demonstrates for the first time that a cognitive function can be improved with a device that mimics the firing patterns of neurons. In recent years neuroscientists have developed implants that allow paralyzed people to move prosthetic limbs or a computer cursor, using their thoughts to activate the machines. In the new work, being published Friday, researchers at Wake Forest University and the University of Southern California used some of the same techniques to read neural activity. But they translated those signals internally, to improve brain function rather than to activate outside appendages.

In 2007 I posted an animated portrait of my son Buster’s first years called “You Won’t Remember This.” “You Won’t Remember This Either,” covering the toddler years but featuring my younger son, Oscar, followed in 2009. This new film continues the series and features Buster from ages six to 10. While these films portray childhood, the perspective is parental. If Buster had made this film it would be all baseball, and the actual point of view, looking up at grownups twice his size, would surely feature more chins and nostrils. The angle might seem a small thing, but it can alter the feeling in subtle ways. Looking at children, our perspective is angled down and as they look up, we see eyes, those big ones, looking up like lasers. And, like every portrait, these films are double portraits, simultaneously reflecting the sensibility of who made them as well as who they picture.

On June 21, 1997, the Liberty and the Los Angeles Sparks took the court at the Great Western Forum in Inglewood , Calif., for the first game in the W.N.B.A. There were 14,284 fans in the stands to see the Liberty win, 67-57. Penny Toler, who had played professionally overseas for eight years, was the Sparks’ starting point guard, and she scored the first points in the league’s history. The W.N.B.A., in its 15th season, is recognizing the anniversary of the game Tuesday night with a matchup between the Liberty and the Sparks at Staples Center in Los Angeles. Toler, 45, will be there for the anniversary. She is in her 12th season as the Sparks’ general manager and has built two championship teams.

An editorial on June 6 about inadequate regulation of for-profit trade schools in New York State incorrectly described the source of financing for the office monitoring such schools. 8 P.M. (HBO) INCEPTION (2010) Leonardo DiCaprio, above, stars as Cobb, a specialist in corporate mental espionage who, using a combination of drugs, wires and other Matrix-y methods, penetrates the minds of his sleeping targets to extract information. Ken Watanabe is Saito, the wealthy client who has hired Cobb and his associates (Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Ellen Page, among others) to undertake the trick known as inception, which involves planting an idea in someone's mind that will come to fruition in the real world. Their mission: to induce a young man (Cillian Murphy), whose father (Pete Postlethwaite) is a business rival of Saito's, to break up the company he is about to inherit. Meanwhile, Cobb can't stop thinking about his wife (Marion Cotillard). '' 'Inception,' Christopher Nolan's visually arresting, noir-tinged caper, is as packed with allusions and citations as a film studies term paper,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Admirers of Ridley Scott's 'Blade Runner' and Stanley Kubrick's '2001' will find themselves in good company, though 'Inception' does not come close to matching the impact of those durable cult objects. It trades in crafty puzzles rather than profound mysteries, and gestures in the direction of mighty philosophical questions that Mr. Nolan is finally too tactful, too timid or perhaps just too busy to engage.'' Still, Mr. Scott said of the film, which won Oscars for cinematography, sound mixing, sound editing and visual effects, ''A lot of this is -- what is the critical term of art I'm looking for? -- pretty cool.'' NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Michele Moody-Adams, the dean of Columbia College of Columbia University, discusses the history and future of America's liberal arts colleges. Ms. Moody-Adams says she ''resists the thought that an education has to be preprofessional or vocational in some deliberate way in order to prepare students for a challenging and very brutal moment economically,'' adding that ''in preserving the best intellectual tradition, we're also giving students a set of skills and cognitive capacities that will suit them well, whatever line of work or profession they choose.''

Silgan Holdings and Graham Packaging have terminated their $4.1 billion deal, clearing the way for Reynolds Group Holdings to acquire Graham. Reynolds, a subsidiary of Rank Group of New Zealand, has also agreed to increase its offer for Graham to $25.50 a share in cash, from $25. That values its deal at $4.5 billion, including the assumption of some $2.8 billion in Graham's debt.

BOWLES--Sarah, passed away in her sleep at home in Essex, CT, on June 5. She will be remembered for her irreverent wit, generosity, love of life even in illness, trenchant critiques of what she considered erroneous political ideas, and lifelong commitment to public service. And also for her hilarious holiday gifts to the children of her extended family of Bowles, Bennets, Coombs and others. Sally (as most people knew her) was born April 26, 1938 in New Haven, the daughter of Dorothy Stebbins Bowles and Chester Bowles, a former governor of the State of Connecticut, Under Secretary of State under John F. Kennedy and Ambassador to India. She was educated in the Sidwell Friends School (in Washington, DC), Essex Elementary School, Noah Webster Elementary School (in Hartford), the Delhi Public School (in India), the Milton Academy and Smith College, where she was coxswain of the college crew and head of student government. She was among the founders of the Peace Corps as Sargent Shriver's right hand in the early 1960s and went on to be New York Mayor John Lindsey 's education advisor during the tumultuous late 1960s and early 70s. She met with African National Congress leaders Nelson Mandela and Walter Sisulu as part of a Rockefeller Foundation initiative supporting the struggle to end apartheid in the 1980s. She also served as Deputy Commissioner of Welfare and in other capacities for the State of Connecticut. During the 1990s she left public employment to become a national leader in the management of private philanthropy and a member of the board of directors of several nonprofit foundations focusing on learning, positions that she continued to hold until her death. In recent years, despite a serious respiratory illness, her signature enthusiasm and energy touched everyone in her orbit. Many who knew her only on the telephone (from which she was never far) were unaware that she was ill. She said she would live a life in full as long as it went; and she did. She leaves her brothers Sam and Chester, sisters Cynthia Aguilar and Barbara Coolidge, stepson Jody Rosen and a circle of lifelong, loving friends that stretches from the lower Connecticut Valley to India and across the world. The family has asked that in lieu of flowers, donations in her memory be sent to the Connecticut Nature Conservancy or the World Press Institute. A memorial service is planned for September.

FULD--Elaine Gerstley, died peacefully at home on June 16, 2011 shortly before her 91st birthday. She lived a long, wonderful life, sharing more than 65 years with her loving husband, James Fuld, who predeceased her. She will be missed enormously by her three loving children, Joan Strauss, James Fuld Jr. and Nancy Neff, and their spouses Frank, Lisa and Dan, her six adoring grandchildren, Jonathan and his spouse Elizabeth, Jennifer, Jamie, Michael, Ryan and David, and her recent great-grandson Jack, her sister Nancy Rosen, and many nieces and nephews. She was born in Philadelphia and graduated from Swarthmore College, where she played on the Varsity Field Hockey and Tennis teams. She married Jim Fuld during the war in 1942 and thereafter devoted her life to her family, her philanthropic activities and collecting. Her life-long commitment to UJA-Federation included Chair of the Women's Division from 1968-1971, Chair of Special Gifts and Co-chair of the Women's Cabinet. She was also founder and president for five years of Thrift Shop East, and a long time board member of the New York Society for the Deaf. She collected Dr. Wall China and miniature antique furniture pieces that adorned her home for decades. Her family and friends adored her and will dearly miss her warmth, style, and remarkable disposition. Contributions to UJA-Federation of New York in her memory. Services Sunday, June 19, 10:30am at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave. and 65th St. Shiva will be observed Sunday and Monday from 5-8pm.

Human nature won out, for good or bad, that day in 1994, and all the eyes on the Brooklyn corner turned down to the fallen mother and her little girl in white sandals beside her. People wanted to help, and so no one looked up, northbound on Fort Hamilton Parkway, at the vanishing white truck. Another mother who had looked out her third-floor window on the corner moments after the hit and run climbed in a police car and scoured the neighborhood with officers, pulling over every white box truck: Is that the one? Is that the one?

An obituary on Friday about Marion Fuller Brown, who sponsored legislation banning billboards in Maine, misstated the year she was appointed to the National Highway Beautification Commission. (Mrs. Fuller Brown helped create the coalition in 1982.)

RUDDICK--Joseph Perry. ("Perry") of Palm Beach Gardens, FL and Nantucket, MA and formerly of Cedar Grove, NJ died comfortably in his home surrounded by family after a prolonged illness on Wednesday, June 15. He was 75 years old. Mr. Ruddick was born in Montclair, NJ on March 28, 1936 to the late Girard Bliss Ruddick and Marcia Perry Ruddick Cook. He attended Montclair Academy and graduated from The Phillips Exeter Academy in 1954 and Princeton University in 1958. Mr. Ruddick received his M.B.A., with distinction, from The Harvard Business School in 1961. Mr. Ruddick, and his wife, Susan, were married on July 29, 1961 in Akron, OH. Mr. Ruddick's 30 year Wall Street career was spent entirely at Smith Barney. He first joined the firm as a Summer Associate in 1960, became the youngest partner at the time in 1968, and retired as Vice Chairman and Chief Administrative Officer in 1991. During his career he moved from international and domestic investment banking to securities trading, operations, finance, administration and asset management, allowing him to participate in almost every aspect of a business that he truly loved. After retiring, Mr. Ruddick undertook increased conservation activities as a board member and President of the Sconset Trust and a board member of the Nantucket Conservation Foundation, where he continued his efforts to help control the development of land activities on his beloved island, Nantucket. In 2008, Mr. Ruddick and his wife led the Sankaty Head Lighthouse Campaign, raising over $4 million to support the move of the lighthouse off the bluff and into a new spot where future generations can enjoy it for decades more to come. He also served as a member of the board of trustees at Nantucket Cottage Hospital. Mr. Ruddick was a sports enthusiast and an accomplished athlete, playing on his high school and college tennis teams, as well as various club tennis and paddle tennis teams. But his true passion was golf! He was a member of the Sankaty Head Golf Club in Nantucket and the Old Marsh Golf Club in Florida, and a former member of the Montclair Golf Club in New Jersey and the Nantucket Golf Club. Highlights of his golfing career include playing in the Bing Crosby Pro-Am for several years, playing on the U.S. Seniors Amateur Golf Circuit and scoring a hole-in-one at Ventana Canyon. Mr. Ruddick combined his business acumen with his love of sports when he served as a board member and President of the Sankaty Head Golf Club and the Sconset Casino Association (tennis club) in Nantucket, and on the Advisory Board of the Old Marsh Golf Club in Florida. In addition, he was a founding member of the Nantucket Golf Club. Formerly a long-standing member of the University Club of New York, Mr. Ruddick also enjoyed meeting there with his friends and business associates alike. Mr. Ruddick will be remembered as a man dedicated to his family, friends and communities and one who was extremely successful in all he attempted. He is survived by his devoted family, including his wife, of almost 50 years, Susan; his three children, Julie Meade of Bronxville, NY, Pam Holding of Wellesley, MA and Girard Ruddick of Warren, RI; his seven grandchildren, Perry and Tommy Meade, Will, Chase and Abby Holding, and JP and Read Ruddick; his sons-in-law, Charlie Meade and Bill Holding and his daughter-in-law, Erin Ruddick. Women generally make up two-thirds of the audiences for Broadway shows, and they are more likely than men to buy the tickets for a night at the theater. The television actor Blair Underwood (''The Event,'' ''L.A. Law'') is known to be popular with the ladies. ''Plus he is a great actor,'' the theater producer Stephen C. Byrd said on Thursday. ''One plus one plus one. And even better news is, this role is a great fit for him.'' The role is Stanley Kowalski, the muscled, semiclothed brute in Tennessee Williams's classic drama ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' which Mr. Byrd said he will mount on Broadway next spring with Mr. Underwood making his debut there. The lead female characters, Blanche DuBois and her sister (and Stanley's wife) Stella, will be black as well, Mr. Byrd said; no actresses are lined up for either part, he added. A white or Hispanic actor will be cast as Blanche's gentleman caller Mitch, he added, while a mix of whites, Hispanics, and Asians will play the poker players and neighbors who crowd in and around the Kowalskis' New Orleans flat.

Leonard Green & Partners and CVC Capital Partners have teamed up with to buy BJ's Wholesale Club, which announced earlier this year that it was exploring a sale. The two private equity firms said in a regulatory filing on Friday that they had submitted a joint proposal to buy the retailer. They did not disclose a specific bid price.

BETHESDA, Md. - Patrick Cantlay, who just finished his freshman year at U.C.L.A., has plenty to be proud of after finishing his second round at the United States Open. As one of the qualifiers at the Open, he shot four-over-par 75 Thursday and four-under 67 Friday, smiling wide as he finished his final hole. At even par 142 for those two days, he looks headed to make the cut for this weekend's final rounds.

Jerry J. Borg was a bit-part actor and a small-time inventor, but his day job was as an accountant for New York State. On Sept. 11, 2001, he was working in an office a block or two from the World Trade Center. When the towers were attacked, Mr. Borg and his colleagues were evacuated, and he walked home to his apartment on West 51st Street. A couple of months later, he began having trouble breathing and sought treatment at the World Trade Center Environmental Health Center at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan, one of several programs to treat people sickened by the attacks.

For the British player Robert Rock, jetlag and anxiety from arriving at 3:30 a.m. the day of his first tee time turned out to work in his favor. After shooting a one-under-par 70 Thursday, Rock returned to his hotel and went to bed at 9 p.m., exhausted from his 11-hour flight from England. Yet he rallied, stringing together another strong round Friday. Even though the last several, hectic days had blurred together, he finished at one-under 141 after the first two rounds to make the cut.

An article on Page 30 this weekend about gay people who prefer to keep their sexuality secret misstates the second word in the name of the organization that in 1973 removed homosexuality from its manual of disorders. It is the American Psychiatric Association, not Psychological.

Woody is going wide. Sony Pictures Classics said Thursday that it planned to increase the number of theaters showing Woody Allen's new time-traveling comedy ''Midnight in Paris,'' to 1,038 screens, the widest release of any of Mr. Allen's films. ''Midnight in Paris,'' which has been well-received by critics, has earned more than $16 million in the United States and more than $18.3 million overseas, where in recent years Mr. Allen has found a much bigger audience than he enjoys at home. (His last critically successful film, ''Vicky Christina Barcelona,'' earned $23.2 million in the United States and $73.2 million internationally, according to boxofficemojo.com.) ''Midnight in Paris,'' which stars Owen Wilson and a crowded bistro's worth of well-known actors - Adrien Brody, Rachel McAdams, Kathy Bates - follows a perpetually dissatisfied Hollywood screenwriter working in Paris who makes nightly excursions back into the 1920's Lost Generation version of the City of Light, communing with the likes of Hemingway and Salvador Dali. A. O. Scott, in The New York Times, wrote that the movie ''has the inspired silliness of some of Mr. Allen's classic comic sketches,'' shot through ''with the rueful fatalism that has characterized so much of his later work.''

M&T Bank is now offering its online-banking customers access to their credit score for a monthly fee. M&T account holders can opt to pay $2.99 a month, which allows them to get their score from Equifax, one of the three major credit bureaus.

An article and a headline in some copies on Friday about the death of Gerald Abramovitz, a Manhattan architect who was robbed and beaten on May 25, misstated the interval between the attack and his death. It was three weeks and a day, not two weeks.

An article on Tuesday about contributions to the GAVI Alliance, an international effort to vaccinate poor children, misstated the amount pledged by the British government. It is $1.3 billion over five years, not $266 million. The article also omitted a new pledge of $1 billion by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. (As it correctly noted, the foundation has already given $1.5 billion.) And it misstated the amount of past contributions by the United States. The government has given $647 million, not more than $650 million.

Many prepaid cards are known for charging fees at every turn -- fees to activate the card, fees to make a purchase, even fees to call customer service. But American Express is coming out with a reloadable prepaid card on Tuesday that appears to right many of the industry's wrongs: You can order the reloadable card online at no cost, and there are no hidden fees lurking in the fine print. And even more impressively, you can use the card overseas and you won't be charged any of the pesky foreign exchange transaction fees that most American Express credit and charge cards usually hit you with.

Debt has become a way of life for American college students. The average student loan debt among graduating college seniors was more than $23,000 in 2008, according to FinAid.org. In addition, the student lender Sallie Mae says the average graduating senior with at least one credit card had $4,138 in debt on the card. Yet, instead of feeling stressed about owing all that money, many students actually feel ''empowered,'' says a new study from Ohio State University, based on data collected for the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The study, published in the journal Social Science Research, surveyed 3,079 students, the majority of whom were in their early- to mid-20s.

BENTONVILLE, Ark. -- The era of the world-class museum built by a single philanthropist in the tradition of Isabella Stewart Gardner, John Pierpont Morgan Jr. and Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney may seem to have passed, but Alice L. Walton is bringing it back. Yet her mission is unlike those of her predecessors, or of more recent art patrons like Ronald S. Lauder and his Neue Galerie. They set out to put great works on display in cultural capitals like New York and Boston. Instead, Ms. Walton's Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art -- the first major institution in 50 years dedicated to the vast spectrum of American art, to be housed in a building more than twice the size of the current Whitney Museum of American Art -- seeks to bring high art to middle America here in this town of 35,000 that is best known as the home of Wal-Mart.

BELL--James Halsey, June 14, 2011. Beloved husband of Patrice; devoted father of Phebe, Halsey, Elizabeth and Anastasia; cherished grandfather of Eliza, Zoey, Addy, Maia, Griffen, Cole, Chloe, Cortland, Annick and Petra. Alumnus of Phillip's Academy Andover, Christ's Hospital, Yale College, and Harvard Law School. Lifelong corporate lawyer, most recently for Satterlee Stephens Burke & Burke. Lover of opera, traveling, photography, grandparenting, pecan pie, and all things Russian. Jim, you were a fantastic husband and a true gentleman. Your kindness, generosity of spirit and loyalty to the things that matter in life one's family and personal relationships underpinned your character and integrity. We miss and love you and will think of you every day of our lives. May you rest in peace. Happy Father's Day to an amazing man. Private funeral; a Memorial Service to be announced for September.

Micro air vehicles may seem like the stuff of science fiction, but, as our colleagues Elisabeth Bumiller and Thom Shanker report, they are a very real part of a drone explosion that is transforming the way America fights its wars. So as these “spy flies” — once found only in “Get Smart” and James Bond movies — are now being developed for espionage and the battlefield, The New York Times asked three spy novelists to speculate on the future of spy drones and military gadgetry.

Drones are playing an increasingly important role in the American military. Only 10 years ago, the Pentagon had about 50 drones; now there are 7,000 drones in its inventory, ranging in size from large blimps to tiny Hummingbirds. Here are 10 drones currently on the battlefield or on the drawing board.

By now, the idea that television serials like “The Sopranos” or “The Wire” are the great popular novels of our time feels like a cliché rather than an insight. But HBO’s adaptation of George R. R. Martin’s fantasy saga is one of the few high-profile attempts to take the cliche and try to literalize it, by faithfully translating a big fat teeming novel into a 10-episode television season. With exceptions like “True Blood,” which is based on Charlaine Harris’s vampire novels (though how closely I’m not sure, as a non-fan of the show and books  alike), few of the major cable dramas have been adaptations of existing stories. From Al Swearengen to Walter White to Stringer Bell, the great characters of television’s dramatic golden age have sprung from the imaginations of TV writers, rather than the printed page.

At TerraCycle, consumers can interact with our business in two crucial ways. First, they can send us garbage (postage paid), and for each piece of waste they collect, we typically give 2 cents to the charity or school of their choice. Today, more than 21 million people in the United States are actively involved in our collection programs, and there’s another 2 million participating outside of the United States. The second way to interact with TerraCycle is for consumers to buy the products that are made from the waste we’ve collected. These products are typically available at major big-box stores, including Wal-Mart and Target.
