We only come to intimately know a handful of families in a lifetime. There’s the one we were raised in, and the ones we form on our own. WANG--Olia (nee) Ai Yinghui, an ethnic Manchu, and a descendant of the Qing Dynasty, clan of Aisingioro, was born on February 28, 1926 in Beijing, passed away peacefully in Manhattan on June 15, 2011 at age 85. She was the loving wife of Dr. Dalton Wang. Cherished mother of Serena Van Harmelen (Jim), Liana Wu (Nelson), and Jackson Wang (Mimi). Olia was the proud and devoted grandmother of four grandsons, Layton, Dylan, Timothy and Warren. Funeral services were private.

Body of Collyer Is Found Near Where Brother Died Langley Collyer was found dead yesterday in his old brownstone home at 2078 Fifth Avenue. His body, wedged in a booby trap set to keep out intruders, was lying in the same room where his blind brother, Homer, had been found dead on March 21. The time of his death was not fixed by the medical examiner pending an autopsy today at the morgue, but the police were sure that the 61-year-old recluse had died at least three weeks ago. The cause of death was unknown, but he apparently starved or suffocated, unable to get out of his own trap.

HOLMES--David L. David L. Holmes, 67, most recently of Delray Beach, Florida, died peacefully in his sleep on Sunday, May 29th. David was born and raised in Mineola, NY, but spent most of his working and family life in New Haven, CT. There he served as the Director of Downtown and Harbor Development during the city's most vigorous period of growth in the 1970s and 1980s and was responsible for more than $750 million in development. Holmes was widely known as a force of nature outspoken, passionate, and tenacious in his quest to bring sustainable development to the City. Prior to that appointment, Holmes was a leader in the completion of the landmark Long Island Sound Study. Holmes spent several years at the Lawrence Investing Company of New York where he began his second career as an executive with that real estate development firm. This period was distinguished by the design, financing and construction of Audubon Court, an award-winning, $35 million mixed-use project in New Haven, CT. From Lawrence Investing, Holmes returned to public service with the City of Yonkers, NY, where he served as the Commissioner of the Department of Planning and Development. Among his accomplishments were the settlement of a nationally famous housing desegregation case and the transformation of the City's downtown and waterfront districts. Leveraging his unique experience in both private and public sector development, Holmes also made his mark in military base redevelopment as President and CEO of the Plattsburgh Airbase Redevelopment Corporation. Under his leadership, the 5,000-acre former Strategic Air Command (SAC) base in New York was thoughtfully converted for civilian use, creating thousands of jobs and millions in annual rent. In recent years, under the auspices of his own Holmes Development Group, along with Joel Schiavone, David connected once again to New Haven on projects for the Quinnipiac River Village neighborhood and the Chapel West project next to the Yale campus. David received his BA in Economics from Rockford College and studied City Planning at Yale University and Urban Geography at Southern Connecticut State University. He leaves behind his daughter Jessica Evans and son-in-law, Laran Evans of San Mateo, California, and his son Michael Holmes, of Seoul, Korea. David will also be missed by his grandchildren, Milo and Charlotte. He is survived by his sisters, April Holmes and Jill Holmes, and brother, Gary Holmes, all of the Charlottesville, VA area. David had hundreds of friends throughout the country who relished his larger-than-life persona, tremendous wit, irrepressible sense of humor and relentless curiosity. His life will be fully celebrated at a joyful gathering at 11:00am on Saturday, June 25th at the Neighborhood Music School, 100 Audubon S., New Haven, CT. An informal reception will follow. Please RSVP to Mike Watt at mike.watt@americanavc.com. In lieu of flowers, David's family requests that donations go to CARE: www.care.org

PEPPER--Carol. Born on February 21, 1952, died after a long illness at her home in New York City. She is survived by her sister Susie Delgado and her nephews, Andres and Nicolas Delgado; her brother Nathan Seifrit and her sister Nance Kalinowski. She is predeceased by her husband Carl Pepper and her sister Mary Hunsicker. Dr. Pepper received her PhD in Clinical Psychology from the graduate Center CUNY, a nursing degree from Berkshire Community College, a MA of Divinity from Yale Divinity School, a MA in Philosophy from Notre Dame University and a BA in Philosophy form Ursinus College. She served as the pastor of Pilgrim Memorial Church in Pittsfield, MA., and was chaplain at Williams College, Williamstown, MA, the first woman to hold this appointment. She was also a fellow of the William Alanson White Institute where she served as Supervisor of Psychotherapy. A Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 145 West 46th St., NYC, on Thursday, June 30 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Austen Riggs Center, www.austenriggs.org or the William Alanson White Institute, www.wawhite.org.

THE NEWS Anthony D. Weiner, the high-profile New York Democrat who publicly apologized on June 6 for carrying on lewd online exchanges with several women and then lying about it, resigned his seat in Congress. BEHIND THE NEWS First he tried to ride out the scandal in office, saying that he had been stupid but had broken no laws; then he floated the idea of a leave of absence for counseling. But one top Democrat after another told him he had become an embarrassing distraction and should just go. A move in the House to strip him of his committee assignments made it clear the jig was up.

PEPPER--Carol, Ph.D. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute and Society mourn our untimely loss of Carol Pepper, Ph.D., courageous, principled, compassionate friend and colleague, on June 16. Carol served the Institute as a member of our Council of Fellows and faculty of our psychoanalytic training program and was Treasurer of the Society. Carol's extraordinarily faithful and humane work with underserved populations, including international victims of torture, political, and sexual oppression embodied our shared values. We will miss her wit, her passion, and her incisive mind. Jay S. Kwawer, Ph.D., Director, White Institute; Seth Aronson, Psy.D., President, White Society; Mitchell Kosh, President, Board of Trustees

The minor league phase of the Rule 5 draft is generally the final item on the agenda at baseball's annual winter meetings. It is such an afterthought that most executives scatter before it begins, gathering their bags to check out of the hotel after days of strategy sessions. In December 2005, Jon Daniels was new to his job with the Texas Rangers; at 28, he was the youngest in baseball history to hold the title of general manager. He was so open to new ideas that he bought an unusual sales pitch from A. J. Preller, a top scout he had known since their days at Cornell.

THE dinner conversation turned to perfect destinations for a seaside weekend near Paris. At the mention of Deauville, our hostess snapped, ''Deauville, c'est trop bling-bling.'' Cadaques, on the Costa Brava in Spain, received murmurs of approval but requires a plane ride and a car rental. All agreed that a weekend place should be only a train ride away. How about Le Touquet? I asked, and the room went silent. France being one of the most visited countries in the world, the natives like to keep a few places to themselves. Le Touquet is a tiny jewel on the English Channel about two and a half hours north of Paris by train. It has a majestic forest right in the heart of town and an array of villas that form a kind of primer on changing bourgeois taste. There's also a wonderful Art Moderne market and the Westminster Hotel, a beautiful Edwardian pile that regulars call Le West. What the North Fork is to Manhattan, Le Touquet is to Paris. Peugeot station wagons, not Porsche Cayennes, if you catch my drift. ALEXANDER LOBRANO

It was May 22 at 5:42 p.m., and we were out in the backyard. We knew it was going to rain; we could hear the thunder. You know when you go to the movies, and you hear the sound all around you? That's just what it was like. You don't ever hear thunder like that in Missouri. I put the television on and checked the Weather Channel. The ticker across the bottom said there was a tornado four miles north of Riverton, and we were in its path. And about that time I heard the siren go off. I was headed toward the door to tell my husband, Lloyd, and the siren sounded again and stopped. Apparently, the tornado had already hit the west of town and knocked the emergency center out.

MILLER--Albert Abraham, 83, passed away on June 2, 2011 in Tampa, FL, formerly a long-time resident of Valley Stream, NY. Al was born in the Edgemere neighborhood of Far Rockaway, NY, on December 27, 1927. He began work at his parents' local grocery store, frequented in the summertime by Babe Ruth and other notable beach vacationers. Al graduated from Far Rockaway High School and enlisted in the Army, where he served in Alaska's Aleutian Islands during WWII. Upon his return, Al proposed to his high school sweetheart, Bernice "Bunny" Finkelstein, and they were married in 1951. After graduating Hofstra and earning his professional license, Al embarked upon a CPA career in Manhattan which spanned over five decades, first as a partner with Dahut, Penn and Miller, then managing partner of Miller, Hershey & Co and later Miller, Levine & Co. Al was well known for treating his clients and friends like family and many remember with great fondness, when in need, the extraordinary help and sage counsel he provided. He loved his work and never intended to retire. Al was a member for many years and served as President of the 101 Club of New York. He loved sailing and skiing, and maintained a lifelong devotion to playing tennis--always attending the US Open. A loyal fan of both Giants teams, baseball and football, he happily recounted his day in the centerfield bleachers of the Polo Grounds when his favorite player Willie Mays ran towards him to make "The Catch" in the first game of the 1954 World Series (Al can be seen in the much publicized photograph fifth row, third from the left aisle). Al harbored a passion for learning and was an avid reader and movie buff. He and Bunny enjoyed the theater and nightlife of New York City, and they traveled extensively throughout the world. Al is survived by his beloved wife Bunny, his son Michael (and Sheryl), daughter Caryn Russ (and Andy) and grandchildren Caroline and Elizabeth Miller and Laura, Alexander and Benjamin Russ. Al was predeceased by his sisters Gertrude and Shirley, and son Kenny. Donations in Al's memory may be sent to Alzheimer's Association (www.alz.org) or Lifepath Hospice in Tampa (www.chaptershealth.org).

An article on June 5 about the riot grrrl musical movement and its legacy misidentified the original song containing the lyrics ''boy girl revolution.'' It was ''Her Jazz'' by Huggy Bear, not one by Kathleen Hanna, who was in the band Bikini Kill. The article also misidentified the singer who first performed the song ''I Wish I Was Him.'' It was an Australian musician, Ben Lee, not Ms. Hanna. The article also misstated the ages of the teenage musicians Coco Moore and Aziza Akhmatova. Ms. Moore is 16, not 15; Ms. Akhmatova is 15, not 16.

As spring ends, we grieve what has been lost and cherish what has been gained. We measure the rise and fall of our hopes in the Middle East and remember the catastrophic earthquake in Japan -- a natural disaster erupting into a human one. As we enter a new, uncertain season, our destination is unknown, yet we travel against the flames of fear toward the promise of a better future ahead. These images are stills from my video imagining this journey, which can be found on nytimes.com/opinion.

CHO--Jai Poong, was born in Seoul, Korea on November 23, 1937 and resided in Camas, Washington and Clearwater, Florida. He came to the US in 1961 as a post-graduate exchange student after earning his bachelor's degree in business from Yonsei University in Seoul. Mr. Cho earned a second bachelor's degree, also in business, from Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah. Following in the footsteps of his father, Mr. Cho spent his career working in the pulp and paper business, spending most of his professional life at Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, headquartered in Portland, Oregon, until his retirement in 1995. He was pronounced dead at 6:59pm Friday, June 17, 2011 at Southampton Hospital in Southampton, New York, a place he loved. Memorial service and burial is scheduled for Tuesday, June 21, 2011, 12:30pm at Evergreen Memorial Gardens in Vancouver, Washington. Viewing is scheduled for Monday evening, June 20, 2011. Mr. Cho was a beloved husband of 43 years to Youngja Cho, and father to Alina Cho and the late Diana Cho. He leaves behind his mother, Hyo Jai Min of Seoul, Korea. He is also survived by a brother, Jai Hang Cho, of Tampa, Florida, and a sister, Hee Kyung Cho, of Seoul, Korea. He loved to travel, play golf and spent his honeymoon fishing. A kind soul, he never once in his life raised his voice. The family asks that friends keep them in their prayers.

OMER--Mordechai, Professor. The Board of Directors, officers, staff and friends of the American Friends of the Tel Aviv Museum of Art are saddened by the loss of Professor Mordechai Omer, the Director and Chief Curator of the Museum. He was a great teacher and writer on art, as well as the visionary behind the creation of the Museum's new building, scheduled to be inaugurated this fall. Professor Omer was involved in every aspect of the planning, financing and construction of this magnificent building whose innovative design will enhance the cultural life of Israel. Professor Omer studied under Meyer Schapiro at Columbia University. His commentaries on paintings forever changed how we view and interpret them, whether it was works at the Museum or in our own homes. We will miss him greatly.

GEY--Steven G.,a nationally recognized scholar of constitutional law and longtime champion of civil liberties, died on June 9, 2011 at his home in Tallahassee, FL after a nearly five-year struggle with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, Lou Gehrig's disease. He was 55. Professor Gey began his career in New York City. He received his law degree with honors in 1982 from Columbia Law School, where he was articles editor of the law review. He practiced with the law firm of Paul, Weiss and was a key participant in the historic Sullivan V. Wainwright death row appeal. The New York City Bar Association named him recipient of the Thurgood Marshall award in recognition of his pro bono representation of death row inmates. Gey strenuously defended the freedom of expression of clients all along the political spectrum and frequently served as pro bono publico counsel in cases involving political and civil rights, often with the ACLU and Americans United for the Separation of Church and State. He served as a member of the Board of Trustees of the latter for several years. The National Center for Science Education awarded Professor Gey the Friends of Darwin Award in recognition of his work to protect against the encroachment of religion into the classroom. During the contested 2000 Presidential election, he served as a consultant to ABC News and appeared regularly as a constitutional law expert on the Nightly News with Peter Jennings. At his death, Gey was the David and Deborah Fonvielle and Donald and Janet Hinkle Professor of Law at the Florida State University College of Law, where he joined the FSU faculty in 1985. Gey is survived by his wife of 29 years, Irene Trakas; his father and a sister.

BETHESDA, Md. - Hole after hole at the United States Open on Saturday, Jason Day tried not to smile too widely or celebrate too much. But on the inside, hidden from the cheering crowds at the Congressional Country Club, he was thrilled with how his tournament was unfolding. Day, a 23-year-old Australian, started the third round at one over par, then boosted himself up the leader board with a terrific round. He shot six under par 65 with six birdies and nary a bogey. With only one round left, he is five under, tied for third place.

IT'S hard to imagine that Omaha's lively North Downtown neighborhood -- or NoDo, as it's known locally -- was nothing but abandoned rail yards five years ago. Hugging the Missouri River, the area thrived as early as the 1860s as Union Pacific's transportation hub, before a merger sent the company packing in the 1980s. Since then, the land had sat relatively untouched -- until developers, taking cues from artists who reclaimed the warehouses as cheap studios, started pumping money back into the area. Now, the new TD AmeriTrade Park (currently hosting the N.C.A.A. Men's College World Series) and national chains like Urban Outfitters sit along- side locally owned clubs, bars and boutiques, making it a new cultural town square. STEPHANIE DAVILA

BECKER--Dr. Donald R.,noted vascular surgeon and medical educator at three universities died May 28 at age 88 in San Francisco. He was a veteran of two Wars; WWII and Korea. He is survived by his wife Nancie, three children, two stepchildren and three grandchildren.

TERDIMAN--Allen M. MD, 78 passed away on June 16, 2011 from kidney cancer. Dr. Terdiman was a gifted psychiatrist in New York City for over 30 years. A life long student and collector of Japanese prints he retired in 1993 and devoted himself to writing haiku, tanka and haibon. He was the first American to win a prize from a Japanese society for writing a trytypt in haiku. In 1996 he co-founded Next Step, a support group in Westchester for retired men. A person of sensitivity and imagination he was devoted to his patients and his family. He will be profoundly missed by his wife of 51 years, JoAnn and his children Jonathan, MaryAnne, Kathryn, Mika, Steve, Mark and his six adored grandchildren, Cecily, Philippa, WIlliam, Jennifer, Mira, Joya. Services 11:00am on Tuesday June 21 at Temple B'nai Yisrael in Armonk, NY.

BETHESDA, Md. - For Webb Simpson, an American playing in his first United States Open, the third round on Saturday brought him nearly to tears but also made him laugh. On the 13th hole, Simpson addressed the ball before it mysteriously moved, which meant a one-stroke penalty. Nearly the same thing happened to him last month at the Zurich Classic in New Orleans, and it likely cost him his first P.G.A. Tour victory. Because of his one-stroke penalty there, he was forced into a playoff with Bubba Watson and lost.
GERSON--John. June 16, 1923 - June 20, 1997 Forever and always missed. Edith

A review on June 5 about ''Infamous Players,'' Peter Bart's memoir of his career as a production executive at Paramount Pictures, included a quotation from the book that misstated Herbert Ross's role in the film ''Funny Girl.'' He directed the choreography, not the film itself -- its director was William Wyler.

One man died and eight other people were wounded when gunfire erupted at a party in Brooklyn early Saturday, the police said. Neighbors and the police described a bloody, chaotic scene, with wounded victims and other party-goers spilling out of the three-story brick townhouse where the shooting occurred, at 325 Wyona Street in East New York just after 3 a.m., and into the street and the backyard.
Rome has the Colosseum, Florence has Michelangelo's ''David,'' Venice has canals, and Naples has pickpockets and uncollected trash?

O'Neil, beloved mother of our friend and partner, Jack O'Neil. We express our deepest sympathies to Jack and all other members of the family

The Stanley Cup finals that ended Wednesday were among the strangest ever, apart from what happened in the streets of Vancouver afterward. The Canucks were favored, having won the regular-season title with the league's most productive offense, its most efficient defense, very good goaltending by Roberto Luongo and excellent special teams. After a big scare in the first round against their bete noire, Chicago, they won 8 of their next 11 games to get to the finals.

Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday in the Evening Hours column about the New York City Outward Bound awards dinner on June 7 misstated the amount of money raised. It was about $1,117,000, not $117,000.

NEW YORKERS went to bed on Sunday and woke up on Monday buzzing -- and posting -- about the Tonys (also #tonyawards), where a strong slate of nominees, a much-talked about and much-nominated ''Book of Mormon'' and a disarming host -- that would be Neil Patrick Harris or NPH, as he is also known on Twitter -- restored the theater awards to a place of unlikely hipness.
STERN--Thelma, wife of the late Judge Nathan. Devoted mother of Allan and Janet Schechter. Dear grandmother of Jessica, Andrew and Brian. Services were held.

BETHESDA, Md. - Luke Donald, the top-ranked player in the world, continued to stumble at the United States Open, shooting a 3-over par 74 on Saturday to bring his 54-hole total to 7-over par 220. Donald, a British player known for his consistency, said the pressure and expectation of coming into the Open as the world's No. 1 has made it more difficult to play well. But, he said, his hectic schedule in the weeks before the Open hasn't helped much, either.
FEINERMAN--Samuel Louis. April 4,1923 -- July 6, 2009 For every joy that passes... Something beautiful remains... You are so very very missed. Adele, Fara, Bennett, Devon and Jerry

COPELAND--Pearl Lusk, formerly of Harrison, NY, passed away at her home in Palm Desert, CA on May 24th, surrounded by family. Pearl was the beloved wife to the late David Elliot Copeland, mother to Beth Copeland Williams and Amie Copeland Stark, mother-in-law to Steven Stark, and grandmother to Mia Stark. Her devoted partner William Carlton Ritchey, III also survives her. Pearl enjoyed a rewarding career at Manhattanville and Iona Colleges. Surrounded with many friends, she will be remembered for her beauty and charm. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

SCHARF--Sydelle. The Board of Governors and members of Brae Burn Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member, Sydelle Scharf. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her entire family. Michael Barasch, President William Schultz, Secretary

An article on June 5 about Guy Laliberté, a co-founder and the owner of Cirque du Soleil, misstated the source of a $1.3 million grant to the company to present a show as part of the celebration of the 450th anniversary of the discovery of Canada. It was the provincial government of Quebec, not the Canadian government.

FOR some parents, an engraved pen set just won't cut it as a graduation present. It seems so insubstantial, so unoriginal. Anyway, the kid will just lose it. So how about a New York apartment? Real estate brokers say that in the last year, they have seen more parents shopping for apartments for their grown children, hoping to take advantage of low mortgage rates and apartment prices that are still about 20 percent down from the market's peak.

9 P.M. (TV Land) AFI LIFE ACHIEVEMENT AWARD: A TRIBUTE TO MORGAN FREEMAN One of the top-grossing actors of all time -- his films have earned more than $3 billion in ticket sales -- Mr. Freeman, right, is known for work infused with a quiet dignity. In this ceremony held on June 9 in Los Angeles, Mr. Freeman's cultural contributions were honored by the American Film Institute and friends and peers, including Betty White, who stepped out of a limousine in a spoof of ''Driving Miss Daisy''; Rita Moreno, who recited a love poem; Helen Mirren, who presented a poem on aging; Don Cheadle, who introduced film clips from ''Glory''; and Forest Whitaker and Tim Robbins, who discussed ''The Shawshank Redemption.'' Clint Eastwood, who directed Mr. Freeman in ''Unforgiven,'' ''Invictus'' and ''Million Dollar Baby,'' for which Mr. Freeman won an Oscar for best supporting actor, presented the award. ''I'm glad I'm an actor,'' Mr. Freeman said at the end of the evening, ''but for this one night you've made me feel like a star.'' 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Chris Wallace interviews the outgoing Secretary of Defense, Robert M. Gates, and Jon Stewart of ''The Daily Show.''

IN a week, I told myself, Lady Gaga's vintage Versace studs (seen in her new ''Edge of Glory'' video) will be history. If that. ''Never be afraid to dream,'' she tweeted to her followers, but I had already unfollowed, like a skiff breaking from its moorings. Goodbye! My thoughts drifted to ''In Dreams Begin Responsibilities,'' the great Delmore Schwartz story, written over a summer weekend in 1935, and I wondered where my copy might be lurking, or, more lazily, if I should dip into my Kindle to retrieve the sensational burst of the story's last moments.

He graduated from the Ecole Polytechnique (Paris) and the Ecole Superieure d'Electricite. The burial will be in Paris.

We will miss her very much. Alan, Patricia, Adam and Josh Abramson

Because of a production error, a map last Sunday with the continuation of an article about efforts to circumvent Internet censorship by governments around the world misidentified the level of government control of the Internet in Taiwan. Because Taiwan was not included in a survey by the OpenNet Initiative that was the basis for the map, it should have been shaded gray, indicating that no data was available; not gold, which indicated pervasive government filtering of the Internet. (''No data'' did not necessarily indicate that the government did not filter content.)

Weeks after a tornado ripped a 20-mile path through Joplin, Mo., many residents have retrieved the possessions that are in good-enough condition to keep -- and have left the rest to be carted off as garbage. But something is still being extracted from the ruins: a financial assessment of the damage. That is the job of hundreds of insurance adjusters, who are working long hours, including weekends, fanned out across devastated neighborhoods. They climb rooftops, peer through twisted window frames and stretch out lengths of measuring tape as they try to attach a dollar figure to what was lost. The adjusters work alongside utility employees, emergency management teams and clean-up crews in the disaster zone, where flies swarm in clouds and the stench of rot wafts from broken refrigerators. The adjusters operate from motels or mobile offices in the area, handing out checks and also refreshments, trash bags and children's toys to displaced residents, many of whom are living with family and friends or staying in hotels and other temporary housing. Risk analysts have estimated losses in Joplin at $1 billion to $3 billion. While it may be too early for a final tally, there is one statistic that already defines the catastrophe: at least 151 people were killed, making it the nation's deadliest tornado since 1947. CHRISTINE HAUSER

An article last Sunday about the ways that technology has become a new means for politicians to engage in sexual misconduct misstated the details of an affair Alexander Hamilton began with Maria Reynolds in 1791, when he was secretary of the Treasury. He was blackmailed by Reynolds's husband, James. Hamilton did not blackmail James Reynolds.

IN October 1971, when Harry Benson was sent by Life magazine to photograph Bobby Fischer, the brash American chess champion, Mr. Benson had photographed many of the world's most famous people but knew nothing about the game. Mr. Fischer was also a difficult person -- often wary and dismissive of other people. Mr. Benson knew how to get close to his subjects, however, so when he met Mr. Fischer, then 28, who still lived in Brooklyn in the apartment on Lincoln Place where he had learned to play chess when he was 7, he began talking about Joe Namath and other members of the New York Jets, whom he had just photographed.

Brewery Tours in the Midwest and West My fiancé and I are planning our honeymoon in July, and would like to add a few days in a part of the United States we've never visited before (mostly Midwest to West). We are open to exploring cities (museums, good food, etc.) or vast expanses (but prefer hotels to camping). Bonus points to good places to run or a high concentration of breweries. Anthea, Boston

TURNER--Dana. Dana Turner uniquely navigated the worlds of civil rights law, public theater activism and computerized research. She was born October 13, 1954 in Gary, Indiana, grew up in California and graduated from Georgetown Law School. After working at the Library of Congress she moved to New York City to practice law on behalf of the transgender and HIV+ communities. She used her lively sense of humor, magnetic personality and strategic insight to pioneer the use of public theatre for civil rights activism. This was famously achieved with her organization of, and starring in, the first ever Drag Show on the Mall at the 1992 March on Washington for Gay & Lesbian Rights. She later starred for several years as the "Mz Liberty" persona on behalf of oppressed people in New York City Gay Pride events. Her work for the International Conferences on Transgender Law & Employment Policy helped put the "T" in the GLBT alliance, as well as deepen its sensitivity to issues of race, class and gender. Ms. Turner was an expert in online research, often finding key information that other lawyers missed. She also served on the board of the World Against Racism Foundation, provided legal support to the Sylvia Rivera Law Project and starred in the award-winning 2006 documentary "Cruel & Unusual" about transgender women in men's prisons, several of whom she represented. Dana was admitted to Roosevelt Hospital in New York City on April 26th with atrial fibrillation and passed in her sleep at 4:11am on April 28th. Her warmth, charm and generosity created a large family of loved ones in Oregon, San Francisco, New York City and beyond. A public visitation will be held at the Terasem Movement Transreligion Ashram at 2 Park Place, in Bristol, Vermont (30 miles south of Burlington, VT on Rte 116), from Noon 1pm on June 19th, 2011, followed by a 2pm burial at the nearby Maplewood Cemetery in Lincoln, Vermont. Donations in honor of Dana Turner, Esq. may be sent to the Sylvia Rivera Law Project, 147 W. 24th St., 5th Floor, New York, NY 10011, www.srlp.org.

The Yankees' Brett Gardner recorded the 100th stolen base of his career on Tuesday, and he noted afterward that he was in his fourth season; in four-plus seasons with the Yankees, he said, Rickey Henderson swiped 326. That was in the 1980s, a decade in which Henderson and Vince Coleman each compiled three seasons of at least 100 steals. Since 1993, only one player has stolen more than 70 in a season: the Mets' Jose Reyes, with 78 in 2007.

An article last Sunday about day trips just minutes from downtown Jerusalem, including the village of Ein Karem, now a secular Jewish artists' colony thought by many Christians to have been the birthplace of John the Baptist, erroneously attributed a distinction to former Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon. Mr. Sharon did not participate in the 1948 massacre of more than 100 Arab civilians by Jewish paramilitary forces in the village of Deir Yassin, near Ein Karem. The article also misstated part of the name of the organization that controls the Jerusalem Forest. It is the Jewish National Fund, not the Jerusalem National Fund.

An article on Friday about a brain implant that improved lost memory function in laboratory rats misidentified the journal in which the research was published. It is The Journal of Neural Engineering , not The Journal of NeuroEngineering and Rehabilitation.

THE words and images on these pages come from an online experiment in participatory art criticism. Part of my assignment to review the Venice Biennale involved a new interactive project called ''Everyone's a Critic.'' The plan was that while making the rounds in Venice I would select individual works of art and write a brief conversational introduction to each that would conclude with a few questions. These would be put online, where readers could weigh in with responses of enforced brevity -- no more than six words. They could do this by simply clicking on words in my review or by using their own. What words of mine they chose would be highlighted in my review and also assembled in a cloud, in order of frequency of use.

TOYOTA says its Prius accounts for 52 percent of the United States hybrid market. It's no surprise, then, that the company would want to give the car some siblings. Toyota brought a preproduction fleet of its latest hybrid, the Prius V, to Westchester County on Wednesday and offered test drives. The V is closely related to the regular Prius under the skin, so it did not offer many on-road surprises. What's new is its size.

INSPIRED by the success of design fairs in Miami, San Francisco, et al., Los Angeles now has one of its own. The L.A. Design Festival, through June 30, includes architecture tours, open studios, lectures and exhibitions. At the A+D Museum, in the middle of the city, the exhibition ''Come In! 2'' includes designers from all disciplines, including the graphics whiz Ashkahn Shahparnia, whose print ''i don't understand half of the things you say but i laugh anyway'' is shown here. Go to ladesignfestival.org. BROOKE HODGE

For many years, Robert Jay Lifton has been recognized as a leading ''psychohistorian,'' or as he prefers to define his vocation, a ''historically minded psychiatrist.'' Psychohistory is the field of inquiry that explores the psychological motives of individuals and groups of historical actors, as well as the psychological impact of historical events. Lifton is perhaps best known as the author of ''Death in Life: Survivors of Hiroshima,'' published in 1967, which received a National Book Award. In that book, he described how the hibakusha, those residents of Hiroshima who survived the atomic bomb on Aug. 6, 1945, lived with deep and shameful feelings of being ''inwardly poisoned'' by their experience, as well as an embittered ''sense of special knowledge'' that set them apart from those who had not witnessed the horrors of the attack. ''Witness to an Extreme Century'' is a memoir of Lifton's life and career, and as one is forewarned by its title, he doesn't offer readers many laughs. Still, one passage toward the end did make me smile. ''Dad,'' he reports his daughter, Natasha, once asking him, ''have you ever considered taking up more cheerful subjects?''

It is not unusual for a player to flirt with the Triple Crown, but Matt Kemp of the Dodgers, who is at or near the top of the National League in batting average, home runs and runs batted in, is doing so with the added flourish of 16 stolen bases. Of the 13 modern-era players to win the Triple Crown, only Ty Cobb had more steals than the 37 Kemp is on pace for. Statistics through Friday.''

IMAGINE that two powerhouse teams come to Broadway, each determined to put on a musical. Both have known success, but some of the artists are also newcomers to live theater. One team -- which includes Trey Parker and Matt Stone of ''South Park'' --creates ''The Book of Mormon,'' a naughty-but-nice comedy that opened to acclaim in March and won nine Tony Awards last week. The other team -- which includes Bono and the Edge of U2 -- creates ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' which limped through months of devastating reviews, creative upheaval and aerial acrobatics that went scarily wrong on a few occasions, and finally reached opening night last Tuesday.What made the difference between boffo success and brutal struggles? Here are a few thoughts. PATRICK HEALY
Classical Daniel J. Wakin

BY design, in-car telematics systems are a two-way street. Only after collecting data about a driver's coordinates can they offer the location of the nearest gas station or pizzeria. But as the owner of a Nissan Leaf recently discovered, once a service possesses a motorist's data, it is unclear how it might be used. Casey Halverson, a freelance security blogger who was profiled on Tuesday by the Web site of Computer World magazine, discovered what he thought was a security loophole in the Leaf's onboard communications and navigation system. He found that information about Leaf owners could be culled and transmitted without their knowledge.

Because of an editing error, a review last Sunday about three electric commuter cars misidentified the secondary drive system of another car, the Chevrolet Volt, which is a plug-in hybrid. The Volt has a gasoline engine to back up its batteries, not an electric motor.

Go Select, a customizable attraction pass for both the budget-minded and the discriminating, was recently started by Smart Destinations, a Boston company. Travelers build passes online by selecting two or more attractions, and can save up to 36 percent compared with the cost of individual tickets. ''Some people want to do a lot,'' said Cecilia Dahl, the president of Smart Destinations. ''Some people like to pick and choose.'' Go Select helps those who want flexibility in choosing the number and type of attractions, and in determining costs, she said. Attractions include must-sees, like the Empire State Building; off-beat choices, like a bike tour of Brooklyn; and higher-end options not traditionally included in passes, Ms. Dahl said, like helicopter tours and swimming with dolphins. You can also add attractions in more than one destination, and perks include skipping long lines.

In Chicago's Fulton Market meatpacking district, the hot restaurant of the moment is Next, where the chef Grant Achatz will change the entire concept behind the menu every three months. Instead of reservations, the owners are selling nonrefundable tickets to dinner, offered, in order, to potential diners who have signed up online. Those who tire of waiting for notification might consider heading just two doors down to iNG, the latest project from Homaro Cantu, Chicago's other cutting-edge chef. iNG, for ''imagining new gastronomy,'' which opened in March, is an experimental showcase of a very different sort: a casual atelier where prices are low -- if a meal at Next is a trip to a high-end salon, dining at iNG is more like a haircut at the beauty academy -- and the food, drinks and décor are all over the map, in the best possible way.

On June 21, 1997, the Liberty and the Los Angeles Sparks took the court at the Great Western Forum in Inglewood , Calif., for the first game in the W.N.B.A. There were 14,284 fans in the stands to see the Liberty win, 67-57. Penny Toler, who had played professionally overseas for eight years, was the Sparks' starting point guard, and she scored the first points in the league's history. The W.N.B.A., in its 15th season, is recognizing the anniversary of the game Tuesday night with a matchup between the Liberty and the Sparks at Staples Center in Los Angeles. Toler, 45, will be there for the anniversary. She is in her 12th season as the Sparks' general manager and has built two championship teams. Q. The first W.N.B.A. game is about to start. What was going through your mind?

A cover article this weekend about New York City Opera's financial troubles misstates the amount that the opera company's board contributed in the past year. It is $6.8 million, according to the opera, because the $1.9 million contribution cited in the article and listed in a May staff report to the board did not include $4.9 million contributed by board members during a special campaign.

Men's style changes at a snail's pace, so what counts is what men bring to it: their choice of tailors, colors, neckties and (on rare occasions) the dash of a hat, like a snap-brim fedora or a 1920s boater. When the younger generation experiments, bottom row, it's by mixing pieces and the occasional flash of color. For any radical sartorial surprises, one looks to Greenwich Village. Shown here, men on their way to work in late spring. Top row, Domenico Spano, observed over the last two weeks. His look is punctiliously classic, always including a fresh boutonniere. Mr. Spano headed the men's custom department at Saks and Bergdorf's, and now has his own shop on West 57th Street. A curiosity, far left, is the well-groomed man and his red bike. Is it transportation or an accessory?

COPPER, silver and gold have taken a recent hiatus from the wrist and settled near the sole. Silver ankle cuffs are the newest way to dress up a pair of sandals but hardly the only golden opportunity. Many of the season's best sandals look as if they've been dipped in gold dust -- a glimmer, not to mention a shimmer, of what's ahead for fall. Clockwise from top: Giuseppe Zanotti silver leather T-strap flat, $695; giuseppezanottidesign.com; Rochas wrap-around sandal, $995; barneys.com; Lanvin metal-cuffed leather sandal, $785; net-a-porter.com. RACHEL WALDMAN

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Clemente's 3,000th Hit Was Muted Milestone in Ambivalent City,'' June 12: As someone who grew up in Pittsburgh during Roberto Clemente's prime in the late 1950s and '60s, I was part of a horde of local fans who every day idolized him. That there were only 13,000 fans at Three Rivers Stadium on the day he nailed his 3,000th hit may have had more to do with the last chilly home game of the season than any slight to Clemente.

THE difference, for the traveler, between a first and repeated visit is crucial. To ''go back'' is not ''to go.'' Yet old, familiar places retain a kind of magic, and all the more so when the memories are shared. For our 40th wedding anniversary year, my wife, Elena, and I returned to the place where our marriage began: the South of France. We planned to visit old haunts, the area we'd once called home. Then, we had had all the time in the world; now we could spend a week. Too, there's a difference between 20-somethings living on a shoestring and tourists ''of a certain age'' who stay in fine hotels. ''Let's do it right this time,'' I said. ''Let's fly to Nice and stay where we couldn't afford to before. Let's ramble down Memory Lane.''
'At 37, this may have been my only shot, and I'm so happy I was able to take advantage of it.' TIM THOMAS,

SCHACHT--Lorraine. Passed away on June 17. A pioneer of the design world, and founder of Lorin Marsh, she lived her life to the fullest with passion and enthusiasm. She brought beauty, chic and glamour into all our worlds. She is survived by her partner of 36 years, Sherry Mandell and her loving children, Neil and Caryn Schacht, her son-in-law David Fox, and her granddaughter Sophia Fox. Funeral Services will be held on Monday at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, please kindly make a donation in Lorraine's name to either The Healthwell Foundation www.healthwellfoundation.org or The Calvary Hospice Fund www.calvaryhospital.org.

With the cost of gas on the rise again, some hotels this summer are doing their part to help ease the crunch for guests. Travelers staying at any of 13 Marriott properties in Colorado, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Utah through Sept. 6 receive a $25 gas card per night and breakfast for two. Participating hotels include Residence Inn in Santa Fe and Courtyard in Boulder. Visit marriott.com for more details.

Whether you are trying to find the best time to travel to a spot or have no destination in mind, a little-known travel tool, Kayak Explore (kayak.com/explore), can help you find the best flight deals. Explore is bundled with Kayak's online suite, which includes flight and hotel search options, and a useful list of airline fees. The concept is simple: enter a departure city and then select a time frame for travel. The results are displayed on a large Google map, with best fares plotted between your city and hundreds of destinations. Results can be filtered by region, price range, flight duration and desired activities (like going to the beach, golfing or skiing). If you adjust the month from August to September, for example, you will see drastic price drops for flights to Europe.

DURST--Shirley. The Purchase College community deeply mourns the passing of an extraordinary friend and advocate who was a generous supporter of the College's arts and humanities programs for over 20 years. Shirley supported many campus organizations and served as a board member of the Purchase College Foundation. Her dedication to the College's vision was evident in her creation of the Shirley and Royal Durst Chair in Literature, the Shirley and Royal Durst Endowed Scholarship Fund, and the Shirley Durst School of the Arts Endowed Fund. The School of Humanities Building is named after the Durst Family in recognition of her family's commitment to the College. Our deepest sympathy to the entire Durst family. We are grateful for her family's request that in lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to the Purchase College Foundation, 735 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase, NY 10577. Thomas J. Schwarz, President Purchase College

At the first tenure meeting I ever attended, a candidate for promotion was approved by a single vote, and it turned out that one of my colleagues in the majority had gotten mixed up and believed he was voting for someone else. (It was a very large department.) The decision stood because, it was said, a vote is a vote and the motivations behind it, including having been motivated by a mistake, were not to the procedural point. Voting was, by definition, a one-time affair, and if misgivings or second thoughts or the fact of confusion were enough to warrant a revote (“I now know who she is; let’s do it again”), there is logically no place to stop and the department’s business could never get definitively done.

Long before he was a star of the international art world and a target of the Chinese government, the artist Ai Weiwei was at the center of an obscure group of Chinese cultural emigrés in the East Village, a community that he documented in some 10,000 photographs in the decade that he lived there, from 1983 to 1993. Now, while Mr. Ai remains under detention in China, without formal charges, the Asia Society is preparing to open an exhibition of 227 of his New York photographs. They show not only important East Village events like Wigstock and local characters like Allen Ginsberg, but also humble gatherings in Mr. Ai’s Third Street apartment featuring people like the artist Xu Bing, the filmmaker Chen Kaige and the composer Tan Dun, all now major Chinese cultural figures who were then toiling in immigrant obscurity.

It’s here today, gone tomorrow for “Born Yesterday” as that Broadway play will close on Sunday, its press representatives said on Monday. This latest production of Garson Kanin‘s comedy about a brutish tycoon, his girlfriend and the tutor entrusted with her education drew praise for the performance of its star Nina Arianda, who plays the dopey girlfriend, Billie. (Jim Belushi plays the tycoon and Robert Sean Leonard plays the tutor.) Ms. Arianda was compared favorably to Judy Holliday, who portrayed Billie in the original Broadway production and the George Cukor film version of “Born Yesterday,” and she was nominated for a Tony Award for leading actress in a play. The revival, directed by Doug Hughes (“Doubt”), also received a Tony nomination for costume design but did not win in either category. The production, which opened on April 24 at the Cort Theater, will have played 28 previews and 73 performances when it closes, its press representatives said.

Clive Crook argues that we’re flirting with the possibility of a lost decade. I disagree — the flirting took place three years ago. I’ve written recently about what should be a well-known fact: Medicare spending has risen less than premiums on private health insurance. This shouldn’t be a controversial proposition; it comes straight from the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services health expenditure data. You can argue about why it’s happening and whether it’s sustainable, but the fact shouldn’t be up for dispute.

6:01 p.m. | Updated The PNC Financial Services Group is near a deal to buy the Royal Bank of Canada's American consumer banking operations for about $3.45 billion in cash and stock, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday. The transaction, which would allow R.B.C. to shed a division that has been hobbled by the housing crisis, could be announced as soon as Monday, these people said. They cautioned that final details were still being ironed out and that the deal could still fall apart. PNC beat out a rival, the BB&T Corporation, in a race for the unit, RBC Bank, the people briefed on the matter said.

Elena G. Bonner, the Soviet dissident and human-rights campaigner who endured banishment and exile along with her husband, the dissident nuclear physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, died Saturday in Boston. She was 88. The cause was heart failure, said Edward Kline, a director of the Andrei Sakharov Foundation. He said Ms. Bonner had been in the hospital since February.

SHEEHAN--Joseph E.,born October 13, 1931 died peacefully on June 17, 2011 at his home in Manhattan. Born in New York City, he earned his law degree from St. John's University and served in the U.S. Army before embarking on a 50 year career in the investment business starting with Shields & Company, then Allen & Company and finally as founder of J.E. Sheehan & Company. He served as Honorary Consul General of Austria in New York and was decorated by the Austrian government in 1993 for his work in furthering Austrian-American relations. He also served as a trustee of the American Austrian Foundation for many years. He is survived by his loving wife Rosa, his two children, Joseph III and Zita-Maria, and two grandchildren, Charles and William. His generosity, charm and love of life and family will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held in New York on June 21, 2011 at 11:00am at Saint Jean Baptiste Catholic Church at 184 East 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to The American Austrian Foundation.

Clarence Clemons, the saxophonist in Bruce Springsteen's E Street Band, whose jovial onstage manner, soul-rooted style and brotherly relationship with Mr. Springsteen made him one of rock's most beloved sidemen, died on Saturday at a hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 69. The cause was complications of a stroke he suffered last Sunday at his home in Singer Island, Fla., a spokeswoman for Mr. Springsteen said.

CHO--Jai Poong, was born in Seoul, Korea on November 23, 1937 and resided in Camas, Washington and Clearwater, Florida. He came to the US in 1961 as a post-graduate exchange student after earning his bachelor's degree in business from Yonsei University in Seoul. Mr. Cho earned a second bachelor's degree, also in business, from Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah. Following in the footsteps of his father, Mr. Cho spent his career working in the pulp and paper business, spending most of his professional life at Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, headquartered in Portland, Oregon, until his retirement in 1995. He was pronounced dead at 6:59pm Friday, June 17, 2011 at Southampton Hospital in Southampton, New York, a place he loved. Memorial service and burial is scheduled for Tuesday, June 21, 2011, 12:30pm at Evergreen Memorial Gardens in Vancouver, Washington. Viewing is scheduled for Monday evening, June 20, 2011. Mr. Cho was a beloved husband of 43 years to Youngja Cho, and father to Alina Cho and the late Diana Cho. He leaves behind his mother, Hyo Jai Min of Seoul, Korea. He is also survived by a brother, Jai Hang Cho, of Tampa, Florida, and a sister, Hee Kyung Cho, of Seoul, Korea. He loved to travel, play golf and spent his honeymoon fishing. A kind soul, he never once in his life raised his voice. The family asks that friends keep them in their prayers.
ZELLER--Barbara. Dear friend, compassionate human being, true lover of the arts and life. We will miss you. Marcia and Leonard Zigelbaum and Family

Bebe Neuwirth is going from the queen of freaks to queen of the fairies. Ms. Neuwirth, who plays Morticia in the Broadway musical ''The Addams Family'' through June 26, will portray Titania next spring in Classic Stage Company's production of Shakespeare's ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' the theater announced on Thursday. The production, directed by Tony Speciale, is to run from March 28 through May 6 at Classic Stage's Off Broadway theater in the East Village. Classic Stage's 45th season opens this fall with Chekhov's ''The Cherry Orchard'' (Nov. 9 to Dec. 18), with John Turturro as Lopakhin and Dianne Wiest as Ranevskaya, followed by Bertolt Brecht's ''Galileo'' (Feb. 1 to March 11), starring F. Murray Abraham and directed by Brian Kulick, the company's artistic director.

10 P.M. (13, 49) ABRAHAM AND MARY LINCOLN: A HOUSE DIVIDED He was a backwoods politician who was born in a log cabin. She was an aristocratic Southerner born into wealth in Kentucky. In this six-part edition, ''American Experience'' chronicles the troubled marriage of Lincoln and Mary Todd -- a couple who loved each other passionately, quarreled intensely and frequently mourned -- and reflects on how their lives paralleled that of a nation at war. The saga begins as Todd sets her sights on capturing the heart of the awkward Lincoln. ''He'll be president of the United States one day,'' she said later. ''If I had not thought so, I never would have married him.'' 8 P.M. (Current TV) COUNTDOWN WITH KEITH OLBERMANN Mr. Olbermann, right, who left MSNBC in January, returns to the airwaves with this new weeknight commentary show, featuring regular contributors including the filmmakers Ken Burns and Michael Moore; Nicole D. Lamoureux, executive director of the National Association of Free Clinics; the comedian Richard Lewis; and Markos Moulitsas, the founder of Daily Kos. In ''Vanguard: Gateway to Heroin,'' at 9, Mariana van Zeller examines a heroin epidemic fueled by OxyContin in and around Boston.

ZITOMER--Bernard. November 30, 1919-June 18, 2011. Bernie and his wife, Regina, worked together to build a unique and successful store in Manhattan at 75th and Madison. Although he enjoyed his retirement to Florida in 1992, New York was always his home. He was a kind, unselfish, and generous man. He had the ability to make all in his family feel unconditionally loved and, despite his busy schedule, was always available for them. We will miss his strength, his humor, his warmth and his sense of style. He was proud to serve as a navigator in WWII, and his plane was the first one into Japan after the war. He leaves behind his wife Regina, his son, Richard (Margye), his daughter, Ellen (Kim) Podolnick, his grandchildren, Joseph (Donna), Joshua (Nicole), Rachel (James) Dutko, Peter, Lauren and Adam. He smiled whenever he saw his great-grandchildren, Samantha, Talen and Riley.

Shopobot opened to the public Thursday with an undisclosed amount of funding from Google Ventures and AOL Ventures.

Ratings for the Olympic Games are driven by compelling athletes, nationalism and time zones. Michael Phelps, above, practicing at the Santa Clara Grand Prix swimming competition on Friday, said he will not try to repeat his record-setting achievement of eight individual gold medals at a single Olympics at the 2012 Games. NBC, which is counting down to the London Games at NBCOlympics.com, paid $4.4 billion for the rights to broadcast the Olympics through 2020. NBC also said it will offer every event live, on TV or online, starting with the Winter Games in 2014. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times The partners at Felix Investments, from left, are John Bivona, Frank Mazzola and Emilio DiSanluciano. Felix has been buying shares in Facebook, Twitter and others.When others were questioning whether Facebook was really worth $10 billion in February 2010, two Wall Street investors were quietly buying chunks of its shares at a $15 billion valuation. The investors, Frank Mazzola and Emilio DiSanluciano, principals of Felix Investments, a Manhattan-based broker-dealer, are not part of Silicon Valley's elite. Dressed in crisp wool suits, the two New Yorkers are more comfortable navigating the narrow streets of Lower Manhattan than on tree-lined Sand Hill Road in Menlo Park, Calif., well known for its venture capital residents.

LEITNER--Jerome M. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the loss of a beloved colleague, teacher and friend, Professor Emeritus Jerome Leitner. Over the course of nearly four decades of service on the Law School faculty, teaching and writing in the areas of Torts, Trial and Appellate Advocacy, and Estates law, he touched the lives of thousands of students. Although his presence will be missed, it will always be felt by the colleagues and students who knew and cherished him. We extend our deepest sympathy to his sons, John Henry and Joshua, and to his entire family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board Joan G. Wexler, President Michael A. Gerber, Interim Dean

LOS ANGELES -- An all-hands-on-deck effort by Warner Brothers to turn ''Green Lantern'' into a box office superpower fizzled over the weekend. Made for an estimated $200 million (and backed by a $100 million marketing campaign), ''Green Lantern'' was No. 1 in North America, but its $53 million in ticket sales fell below pre-release expectations. About 45 percent of that total came from 3-D screenings, a low percentage. Negative reviews and superhero gridlock in theaters likely played a role.

LEKOWSKI--Mary "Pat". 76, of Brooklyn, NY, Toms River, NJ and Charlotte, NC died June 17, 2011 in Charlotte after a long illness. She was a graduate of Long Island College Hospital School of Nursing and earned her MA in education from Columbia University, NY. She was employed by Beth Israel Hospital, Kings Highway Division, Brooklyn, NY (1966-2003) and retired as Director of Patient Care Services. During her 50 year career in nursing she was committed to staff education and quality improvement. She was later associated with Kimball Medical Center, Toms River, NJ in the Department of Education and Quality (2004-2009) and was active with the Kimball Auxiliary. She is survived by husband, Robert Lekowski, Sr. Charlotte, sons, Robert, Jr. and wife Rebecca Harvey Lekowski, Boston, MA, Thomas Lekowski of Weddington, NC, William and Stephanie Branch Lekowski, Brooklyn, NY, sister, Peg O'Shea, Chicago, brother, Thomas Morley, Allendale, NJ, nine nieces and nephews and countless friends and colleagues. WASHINGTON - A recent Republican Party news release about President Obama, Democrats and the economy declared simply: ''They own it.'' As a matter of politics, that's indisputable. The burdens or benefits of economic conditions go to incumbents - an iron law of elections that makes Mr. Obama vulnerable in 2012.

AileyCamp, a full-scholarship summer day camp with classes in dance technique for urban students, will come to Newark this summer. The announcement was made by officials at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, the Newark public schools and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. The six-week program will be held at the Newark Arts High School, from July 5 to Aug. 12 for 100 middle-school students ages 11-14 from Newark schools. On Aug. 10, the students will perform an original work showcasing their skills at the arts center's Victoria Theater. The camp's classes, which include ballet, modern dance, West African dance and discussions on nutrition and conflict resolution, will be led by Ailey teaching artists with backgrounds in dance and education. The camp in Newark is supported by the Prudential Foundation. It joins nine other Ailey camps that will serve about 1,000 students in cities across the country this summer, including Atlanta, Chicago, Miami and Berkeley, Calif.

Special Agent James P. Hosty had a few dozen cases in his portfolio in October 1963 when his supervisor in the Dallas office of the F.B.I. handed him another. Mr. Hosty tried to find Oswald during two trips into the field in early November, without any luck.

Angela Bassett’s only experience working with Samuel L. Jackson was in the early 1980s when she was an understudy, and he a star, in a Negro Ensemble Company production of “Colored People’s Time,” a play of vignettes set between the Civil War and the Montgomery bus boycott. This fall the two actors will reunite on Broadway — as co-stars — for another play inspired by history, Katori Hall’s drama “The Mountaintop,” about Dr. Martin Luther King on the night before his assassination.

Last week professionals, collectors and amateurs of all things art flocked to Basel for the 42nd edition of Art Basel, the “world’s top contemporary art fair.” While the main fair was received with mixed reviews (too crowded, confusing layout, not enough outstanding pieces), an entirely different tune was sung over at Hall 5 of Basel’s venerable Messegelände, where only a day earlier Design Miami opened the doors to its annual sister fair, Design Miami/Basel, a satellite fair specializing in collectible design. There was a noticeable excitement in the air as this was the first Design Miami/Basel under the new directorship of Marianne Goebl. Her debut did not disappoint: a record 43 exhibitors showing everything from 20th-century classics to contemporary designers, intelligent design collaborations with corporate sponsors (take note, Art Basel V.I.P. lounge), a great bookstore (courtesy of doyoureadme?! from Berlin) and a well-curated series of talks (full disclosure: I moderated one of them). Design Miami/Basel may keep flourishing thanks to the cross-pollinating effect from the neighboring art fair(s), but judging by the increasingly educated and design-passionate public, it seems that the fair could very well stand on its own if it had to.

Remember how after 9/11, Osama bin Laden’s attacks on us could be linked to almost anything, from shopping habits to the rediscovery of Western values to carbon-pricing schemes?  Something similar appears to be happening with Bin Laden’s death. Jihadism sure isn’t what it used to be. After 10 years, it seems, the time has come to go home. Troops are and will be coming back to the United States from Iraq and Afghanistan. The military budget will be cut. The outgoing secretary of defense feels able to openly mock NATO because, presumably, he thinks he can afford to — because it doesn’t matter all that much. The global war on terror is being downgraded from Armageddon to something more out of Leviticus: a tricked-out police action, just as John Kerry, in this magazine, always said it should be. On Sunday, Helene Cooper and Mark Landler reported that “American success in the counterterrorism campaign would seem to bolster arguments for a swift withdrawal from Afghanistan.” By Tuesday morning, they were reporting that President Obama would announce his withdrawal plans on Wednesday. Meanwhile, a Harris poll revealed that 51 percent of Americans and 54 percent of Britons believed “the death of Bin Laden meant it was time to bring troops from their countries home.”

Before Jeremy Kost became a Polaroid-snapping phenom, he was working a day job as a manager for an Internet company in Washington. “I started taking pictures at the big parties I was throwing with Ed Bailey and John Guggenmos, but I eventually felt I had outgrown that city,” says Kost. He had already flirted with New York nightlife during business trips, and in 2006 he quit his Web job, moved to New York and began taking party photos full time. The result has been an oeuvre of Warholian portraits showing off his favorite nocturnal denizens. His first hardbound monograph, “It’s Always Darkest Before Dawn” (PowerHouse, $50), contains his typical club pictures, but blown up and and methodically assembled to show graphic detail. The book features a selection of cropped photographs and Polaroid collages (the result of a collaboration with Sam Shahid, a former creative director of Calvin Klein).

Kristoffer Diaz is the winner of the 2011 New York Times Outstanding Playwright Award for “The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity,” his satire of professional wrestling and the ethnic stereotypes and political imagery of that industry, The Times has announced. The award, created in 2009, recognizes an American playwright whose work recently received its professional debut in New York; “Chad Deity” was produced Off Broadway in 2010 by Second Stage Theater, drawing mostly positive reviews. (The play was also a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in drama that year.) Previous recipients of the Times playwright award, which comes with a cash prize of $5,000, were Tarell Alvin McCraney for “The Brothers Size” and Dan LeFranc for “Sixty Miles to Silver Lake.”

I can’t walk down the street anymore without seeing someone with a canvas tote. They have become the default choice for the environmentally conscious and have also provided fertile ground for graphic designers, illustrators and other creatives. I think I have at least 10 of them but only one of which I actually purchased. They just keep appearing either as gifts or freebies, which makes me wonder how earth-friendly they actually are if enough people have similar tote-bag-to-person ratios to my own. A couple years ago, Dimitri Siegel wrote an article on the Design Observer blog about this phenomenon and noted, “Just as the remarkable efficiency of the plastic bag ended up making it a menace to the environment, graphic design’s ability to generate options and choices may turn a sustainable idea into an environmental calamity.” It seems that sustainable design is not limited to just the materials that are used but also to the endurance of the design itself.

Even as Congress squabbles over who will lead the new consumer watchdog, the fledgling agency is gearing up to police Wall Street. Over the last several months, Republicans have scrutinized the early moves of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, introducing measures to slash its budget and ordering investigations into the scope of its authority. The attacks, which center on Elizabeth Warren, the Obama administration official setting up the bureau, have stymied the White House from naming a director.

It's here today, gone tomorrow for ''Born Yesterday'' as that Broadway play will close on Sunday, its press representatives said on Monday. This latest production of Garson Kanin's comedy about a brutish tycoon, his girlfriend and the tutor entrusted with her education drew praise for the performance of its star Nina Arianda, who plays the dopey girlfriend, Billie. (Jim Belushi plays the tycoon and Robert Sean Leonard plays the tutor.) Ms. Arianda was compared favorably to Judy Holliday, who portrayed Billie in the original Broadway production and the George Cukor film version of ''Born Yesterday,'' and she was nominated for a Tony Award for leading actress in a play. The revival, directed by Doug Hughes (''Doubt''), also received a Tony nomination for costume design but did not win in either category. The production, which opened on April 24 at the Cort Theater, will have played 28 previews and 73 performances when it closes, its press representatives said. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article on June 10 about a severe economic slowdown in Egypt and its implications for the revolution that deposed President Hosni Mubarak misstated the percentage amount of what is essentially a surtax proposed for all Muslims by the Muslim Brotherhood, the group formerly outlawed by Mr. Mubarak, in its economic platform to ease chronic poverty. It is 2.5 percent of income, not 7.5 percent.

Long before he was a star of the international art world and a target of the Chinese government, the artist Ai Weiwei was at the center of an obscure group of Chinese cultural emigres in the East Village, a community that he documented in some 10,000 photographs in the decade that he lived there, from 1983 to 1993. Now, while Mr. Ai remains under detention in China, without formal charges, the Asia Society is preparing to open an exhibition of 227 of his New York photographs. They show not only important East Village events like Wigstock and local characters like Allen Ginsberg, but also humble gatherings in Mr. Ai's Third Street apartment featuring people like the artist Xu Bing, the filmmaker Chen Kaige and the composer Tan Dun, all now major Chinese cultural figures who were then toiling in immigrant obscurity. In a telephone interview the director of the Asia Society Museum, Melissa Chiu, said that she had been planning the exhibition with Mr. Ai before his detention on April 3. He had selected the photographs and made a set of prints, but since those prints were stranded in his Beijing studio, which has been inaccessible since his detention, a new set had to be made for the exhibition, which will run from June 29 to Aug. 14. (A similar show was mounted in Beijing in 2009 by the Three Shadows Photography Art Center, which is helping the Asia Society organize the new show.) Asked how Mr. Ai's arrest had affected the show, Ms. Chiu said that she thought it was now more important than ever, since it sheds light on a period that was formative for him both artistically and politically. ''It also gives voice to an artist who has essentially been silenced since April 3,'' she said.

Harold Prince, who has won more Tony Awards than anyone in history - 21 - for producing and directing some of the greatest musicals of the 20th century, is planning a return to Broadway in the fall of 2012 with a new show that celebrates and re-examines some of the material from his theater career. Dancap Productions announced on Monday that the new musical, ''Prince of Broadway,'' is in development for a production to begin in Toronto in the summer of 2012 to be followed by a Broadway run. In a telephone interview on Monday, Mr. Prince said the production would draw on roughly 40 songs (and orchestrations of several more songs in the overture) from some of his best-known musicals over the last six decades, including ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' ''Company,'' ''Damn Yankees,'' ''Fiorello!,'' ''Follies,'' ''Grind,'' ''It's a Bird It's a Plane It's Superman,'' ''Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' ''Parade,'' ''She Loves Me,'' ''Show Boat,'' and ''Sweeney Todd.'' He and his collaborators will choose specific songs in the coming months, he said.

BLOOMBERG--Charlotte R. Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, mourns the passing of Charlotte R. Bloomberg, an inspiration to the Zionist movement, who died June 19 in Medford, MA. She was 102. In addition to having the Mother and Child Center at Hadassah Ein Kerem named for her, Mrs. Bloomberg was the oldest living alumna and generous supporter of Hadassah's youth program, now called Young Judaea. The Jewish people, Israel and Hadassah have lost a truly inspirational figure, a role model and a friend, said Hadassah National President Nancy Falchuk. We are tremendously sad at her passing but also incredibly grateful for the legacy she left and the rich, full life she shared with us. Our hearts go out to her son, Mayor Michael Bloomberg, and her daughter, Marjorie Tiven. Mrs. Bloomberg was associated with Hadassah almost her entire life, starting with Young Judaea in her teenage years to eventually endowing a scholarship fund, and providing scholarship money to Camp Tel Yehudah. She was also president of Hadassah's Medford chapter. At the 2003 dedication of the Mother and Child Center in her name and in honor of her 95th birthday, Mayor Bloomberg quipped, I don't know if there is a more sublime mitzvah than a Jewish son taking his mother and sister to Israel. Hadassah is a greater mitzvah. Hadassah is the gold standard of health care, a place that practices world class medicine and produces exceptional scholarship; a place that treats more than one million people a year; a place where every one of them is treated as a person. Falchuk said, The real mitzvah was our opportunity to know Mrs. Bloomberg. In her devotion to her family and to Israel, Charlotte Bloomberg represented the finest Hadassah tradition. She will be missed, but her name lives on in the center that bears it. May her memory be for a blessing and may her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem." Donations in Charlotte Bloomberg's memory may be sent to Hadassah: 50 West 58th Street, New York, NY 10019.

10 P.M. (ABC) COMBAT HOSPITAL Elias Koteas (above right, with Hamza Jeetooa), Michelle Borth, Luke Mably, Deborah Kara Unger, Terry Chen and Arnold Pinnock star in this ensemble drama, set in 2006, about a military hospital providing advanced surgical care in southern Afghanistan. The action begins as doctors and nurses report for duty at the NATO Role 3 Multinational Medical Unit at Kandahar Airfield -- a plywood-and-canvas building held together with duct tape -- amid rockets, shrapnel and hordes of wounded American Marines, Canadian soldiers, Afghan civilians and even a Taliban prisoner. 8 P.M. (13) HISTORY DETECTIVES Season 9 begins as mysterious parts from an airplane engine lead Eduardo Pagán, a history professor at Arizona State University, to a Hawaiian island, where he uncovers a story of heroism often overshadowed by the raid on Pearl Harbor. Elyse Luray, an art history expert and appraiser, tries to match metal shavings to the right cannon and determine their role at the start of the Civil War. And Wes Cowan, an appraiser and auctioneer, tries to figure out whether an early-20th-century saddle could have belonged to Yakima Canutt, the rodeo champion turned stuntman for Errol Flynn, Clark Gable and John Wayne.

A coming-of-age tale about struggling artists in the big city, ''Next Thing You Know'' is a sort of ''Rent'' for the Organization Kid generation. No one has AIDS, and there are no transvestites. Played by a small band that includes a violin and a cello, the music (by Joshua Salzman) is also softer and more contemplative. But, man, is there angst: youthful, idealistic, blissfully cathartic angst.

KAUS--Betty, a resident of Summit, New Jersey for 63 years, passed away on June 18, 2011 at the age of 90. A celebration of her life will be held at Central Presbyterian Church, 70 Maple Street, Summit, NJ on Friday, June 24th at 2pm. For further information or to send a message of condolence, please visit: bradleyfuneralhomes.com. Betty was a well-known figure in the community, where she devoted herself to a wide array of organizations and activities, including theatre, church, school, and business. A member of the Summit Playhouse since 1950, she served as President of the venerable theatre on four separate occasions, her most recent term ending in 2010, and acted in, directed, and produced numerous acclaimed productions over the past six decades. Among her many accomplishments, she also enjoyed a 30-year career with Burgdorff Realtors. Betty was the beloved wife of 32 years to the late Ed Kaus. She is survived by her son, Bob, of Millbrook, NY; her sister Barbara Mudge of Bethel Park, PA; her nieces Carol Griffith and Barbara Warren; and her nephew Tom Mudge. She is predeceased by her sister Rosemary Blackburn and her niece Eileen Adamek.

BLOOMBERG--Charlotte Rubens, mother of New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and New York City Commissioner of the NYC Commission for the United Nations, Consular Corps & Protocol, Marjorie B. Tiven, died Sunday morning at her home in West Medford, Massachusetts. She was 102 years old. She was an active community volunteer and known for maintaining a vigorous schedule until a few years ago. She served as co-president of her synagogue, Temple Shalom, when she was in her nineties. Mrs. Bloomberg frequently ate lunch out - Legal Seafood was a favorite - visited museums, and read The Boston Globe and The New York Times on a daily basis and participated in her monthly book club. She also delighted in new family photographs and enjoyed the visits of family, friends and neighbors. She was a crack Scrabble player and continued playing as recently as last month. Born in Jersey City in 1909, Mrs. Bloomberg earned a bachelors degree in accounting from New York University in 1929, a time when few women attended college. She moved to West Medford in 1945. In addition to family responsibilities and volunteer work, for several years she worked as an office manager in Boston. The Mayor was a devoted son and visited her frequently. A proud mother, Mrs. Bloomberg was an enthusiastic participant at the Mayor's swearing-in ceremonies in 2002 and 2006. Her daughter, Marjorie Tiven was her constant companion and advisor. Together, they enjoyed looking back and researching their family history, recognizing in particular the work ethic and devotion to philanthropy the family is noted for today. They proudly set standards for Mrs. Bloomberg's grandchildren going forward. With love and gratitude, the family made a donation in Mrs. Bloomberg's name to Hadassah for the Camp Tel Yehudah program on her 90th birthday, and also dedicated a Children's wing in her honor at the Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem in 2003 for her 95th. To commemorate her 100th birthday, they made possible the Charlotte R. Bloomberg Children's Center at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. It is scheduled to open in 2012 and she took great pride in watching its construction over the last few years. Charlotte Rubens married William H. Bloomberg in 1934. He died in 1963. She was the sister of the late Louis Rubens, Florence R. Tartalsky and Gertrude R. Hensher. In addition to her children, she is survived by five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Burial was private. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations in her memory may be made to the Medford Public Library, 111 High Street, Medford, MA 02155, Temple Shalom, 475 Winthrop Street, Medford, MA 02155 or the Medford Chapter of Hadassah care of Temple Shalom.

Although he is the tallest person to play Grand Slam tennis, Ivo Karlovic is attracting more attention at the moment for short messages. But then Karlovic has long been a man of surprising contrasts.
