Most people are well aware that companies compile credit scores on just about everyone. Now, one company is planning to rate how likely people are to take prescribed medication. Nearly three in four Americans do not follow doctor's orders for taking prescription drugs, a problem that is associated with 125,000 patient deaths each year, according to the National Consumers League. One in three patients never even fills the prescription. Others forget to pick up their drugs from the pharmacy, skip doses, take their pills at the wrong time or take too much or too little. And even for those who follow recommendations at the start, some eventually stop taking the medication altogether.

SOBEL--James Robert, M.D. April 30, 1941 -- June 18, 2011. James Robert Sobel, MD, son of Gerson and Pearl (Orloff) Sobel, passed away peacefully on June 18, 2011 at his home in Rockville Centre, New York surrounded by his loved ones; his daughter Lisa and son-in-law Mike Spinelli and his granddaughter Macy Jade; his son David and daughter-in-law Jenny Bagert and his grandson Hawkins Hart; and his partner in life, Adeline Quinn. He is survived by his father, Gerson Sobel, his brother Thomas (Margaret) Sobel, and his sister, Judith Bott. Jim was a retired family practice physician who devoted over forty years of his life to the primary care of his patients and to medical education. He believed in the dignity of his patients. As a medical educator at Hahnemann Medical School and Residency in Pennsylvania; Rutgers-Robert Wood Johnson Medical School and Residency in New Jersey; Bryn Mawr Hospital and Residency in Pennsylvania; Warren Hospital and Residency in New Jersey; and finally, Mt. Sinai Hospital and Residency in New York, where he continued to instill his students with the elegance of medicine. In retirement, he continued to practice medicine in underserved communities. A celebration of Jim's life will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 N. Long Beach Road in Rockville Centre, New York 11570 on Sunday, June 26, 2011 starting at two o'clock, with a memorial service at three o'clock. In lieu of flowers you may honor Jim's memory with a donation to the charity of your choice. Jim was a man who loved life, and delighted in its small blessings and tiniest details. He will be deeply and lovingly missed.

HAMMER--Lillian, age 101 of New York City, on June 20, 2011. Beloved sister of late Rose Edelson (and late husband, Jacob), Aunt of Phyllis Bogen (and husband William), Great Aunt to Julie Grunberger (and husband Ivan, sons Jacob and Lucas), Andrew Bogen (and wife Iriss Shimony and children Ezra and Daniela), and Maria Oskwarek (and husband John, children Isabel and Olivia), cousin to late Alan Streusand (and late wife Jane), and their children Barbara Lane (and husband Joseph), Douglas Streusand (and wife Esther, children Deborah and Rachel), and Virginia Goldman (and husband Stephen). She was a devoted New York City public school teacher who, ahead of her time, worked with special needs children in diverse educational settings and hospitals. For info regarding funeral arrangements, contact Eden Memorial Chapels (888-700-3336).

GAMBLE--Diane Elaine, community leader and accomplished business woman, died peacefully at her home on Tuesday, June 14. The cause was cancer. She was 73. At the incipience of the internet boom, Diane had a front row seat, serving as President and CEO of Link Resources, Inc., a market research firm specializing in emerging communications technologies. After Link was acquired by International Data Group, Inc. she served as an executive of various research departments in the Walt Disney Company and American Broadcasting Company. Prior to career in market research, she worked for the then Governor Nelson Rockefeller, both in Westchester County, New York City and Albany. She had a broad interest in her community, ultimately becoming President of the Junior League of Westchester on Hudson and President of the New Castle Historical Society. She was also very active in the formative years of what became the Westchester Symphony Orchestra. She is survived by her husband, Lex and son, Alex and his wife Carol; and 21 nieces, nephews and cousins.

An article on Monday about the weekend visit to Tucson by Representative Gabrielle Giffords misstated the name of the hospital where she was initially treated for a gunshot wound to the head. It is University Medical Center, not Tucson Medical Center. The article also misstated the type of vehicle that took her to the medical center from the supermarket parking lot where the shooting occurred. It was an ambulance, not a helicopter. And it misstated how she traveled from Tucson to Houston, to undergo further treatment and rehabilitation. It was by private plane, not by ambulance.

Consider the ''Don't Walk'' sign, that lost classic of the New York streetscape. It is a yin-yang traffic signal, a functional poem - ''Don't Walk/Walk'' - inside an iconic yellow box. Among the many novel ideas implemented at the New York Philharmonic since Alan Gilbert took the reins as its music director in 2009, one has come to loom larger than all the rest. ''Le Grand Macabre,'' a musically unorthodox, wickedly funny absurdist opera by Gyorgy Ligeti, represented a substantial risk when the Philharmonic mounted a series of performances of it at Avery Fisher Hall in May 2010, imaginatively and resourcefully staged by Doug Fitch, a designer and director with whom Mr. Gilbert had worked in opera houses. When the production was hailed as a stunning success among audiences and critics alike, ''Le Grand Macabre'' came to represent Mr. Gilbert's vision for the institution at its most audacious. But when you've brought down the house with the end of the world -- at least as Ligeti imagined it -- what do you do for an encore?

Though most knew the technology consultant as Winnie, some of her hedge fund clients called her the Poohster, after the bear always in search of a pot of honey.

The fate of the Bloomberg administration's plan to enable livery drivers to pick up street hails outside Manhattan was unclear on Monday, as versions of the bill were being weighed in Assembly and Senate committees in Albany. The plan proposed in Albany would create as many as 30,000 permits allowing livery drivers to pick up street hails in the boroughs outside Manhattan and in parts of Upper Manhattan north of Central Park. A federal appeals court ruled on Monday that investment banks could not stop a financial Web site from immediately publishing the research recommendations of their stock analysts, delivering a blow to Wall Street and a win for the investing public. Perhaps more significant, the decision was a victory for Internet companies whose business models depend upon summarizing and commenting on others' original content. Yet media businesses also cheered the ruling because it left in place legal protections against rogue competitors who copy and resell original news reporting at little or no cost.

In June 1861, George Perkins Marsh arrived in Turin to begin his appointment as envoy extraordinary to Italy from the United States of America. It was a fitting title. These were extraordinary times: that spring witnessed both the disintegration of the United States and the unification of Italy. The Lincoln administration, eager to buttress the Union’s European position against burgeoning Confederate diplomacy, immediately recognized the new Italian state. Whether Washington could build an actual alliance with Italy that could serve its war aims was a question Marsh had been sent to answer.

It’s early in the evening on a Tuesday, and Gabriel Rucker is in a winning mood. The chef and restaurateur, who first gained national attention in 2007 for his restaurant Le Pigeon in Portland, Ore., is this year’s recipient of the James Beard Foundation’s Rising Star Chef of the Year award, an honor reserved for chefs under 30. His work at Le Pigeon draws from classic technique, the ample larder of Oregon’s Willamette Valley and the character of Portland itself — equal parts divine and dingy, local and wild. Rucker’s latest venture, Little Bird, opened in late 2010 and is more of a classic bistro in style and setting, with a fascinating cocktail list, cheap beer selections and strokes of clever embedded throughout the menu; think enormous marrow bones with balsamic vinegar onions presented à la Fred Flinstone, or a sorbet and ice cream course served in pastel miniature egg cartons.

Can a moderate Republican win the G.O.P. nomination? That’s the question everyone’s asking with regard to Jon Huntsman, who formally announced his candidacy yesterday, and the answer is a resounding yes. From George H.W. Bush and Bob Dole through George W. Bush and John McCain, the modern-day Republican Party has a long tradition of picking nominees whose records and positions place them to the left of True Conservatism, at least as defined by movement institutions, talk radio and the like. Even in the age of the Tea Party, there’s reason to imagine this pattern persisting: Many Republican primary voters hold heterodox positions (for instance, on tax increases on the rich) relative to the official conservative line, several of the crucial early primaries allow independents to cross over and vote, and in races against incumbent presidents there’s a high premium on electability. It’s certainly possible for a Republican to be too liberal for the primary electorate, and often a moderate candidate has to flip-flop on a key issue (or six) to appease the party’s interest groups. But the historical record suggests that there’s more room between Rush Limbaugh and the center than many commentators (and politicians) seem to think.

LOS ANGELES — Tobey Maguire, who hit the jackpot with his starring role in the “Spider-Man” films, may have overplayed his hand at the poker table, according to a suit filed in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Central District of California here. The trustee for Ruderman Capital Partners is demanding that Mr. Maguire repay at least $311,200 in winnings from what it describes as unlicensed, high-stakes poker games between 2006 and 2009. Radaronline on Wednesday carried a report of the suit, which was filed here in March. According to the filing, Bradley Ruderman, who managed the fund and in January of last year was sentenced to 10 years in federal prison on various fraud charges, used investor money to pay off losses in the games, in which Mr. Maguire was among the winners.

All artists have their talismans and rituals. For Balthus the talisman was the tablier he picked up at the American Hospital in Paris during World War II, which he wore religiously. Balthus always painted in the smock, using it like a cloth to wipe his brushes clean. It was never washed and, over 60 odd years, it accumulated layer upon layer of pigment, becoming an artwork in itself. The artist Katerina Jebb, who uses scanners and copy machines in her work, has scanned the front and back of the tablier in 12-by-16-inch fragments to create a life-size copy of it on paper that will be shown at the Balthus Chapel in the village of Rossinière, Switzerland from June 25, 2011 through May, 2012. Jebb’s high-definition scan captures every speck of paint on the sturdy, dark blue cotton — you can almost pick out the colors from Balthus’s surreally erotic “Guitar Lesson.”

SLATER--Vivien Harvey, died peacefully at age 93 at her home in Newton, MA on June 13, 2011, surrounded by her loving family. Vivien was Pianist-in-Residence at Colgate University in Hamilton, NY and taught generations of students. She performed for over 55 years at Colgate and other venues in upstate NY and throughout Europe. Vivien was pre-deceased by her beloved husband of 62 years, Joseph Locke Slater, Professor Emeritus of Colgate. She studied piano with Severin Eisenberger at Cincinnati Conservatory and composition with Arthur Shepherd at Western Reserve University, making her Town Hall, NY debut in 1952. Vivien championed the works of Carl Czerny and published recordings of Czerny, Beethoven and Arthur Shepherd, and her own compositions for piano students, Tanglewood Tales and Birds of a Feather. Her wonderful music brought pleasure to her audiences just as her beautiful smile and gracious personality brought joy to all who knew her. She is survived by her daughter Lydia Slater and son-in-law Will Fisher of Hubbardsville, NY; and her son and daughter-in-law John and Ellen Slater and grandsons Joseph Slater and Thomas Slater of Needham, MA. A funeral was held at the Methodist Church in Poolville, NY. A concert in celebration of Vivien's life is planned for October 2011 at Colgate.

PISCO, the clear grape spirit of South America, is emerging from the mist of history and bringing rich freshness to cocktails. In New York and other cities, liquor stores and bars that carried no pisco a few years ago have several now and are adding more, making it the fastest-growing spirit in the country, according to the Distilled Spirits Council of the United States. The new piscos are a far cry from the famously rustic, hangover-inducing stuff that was previously available. Top-shelf piscos are being made for Peruvian connoisseurs, and these newer entries are feeding the growing export market, often with an assist from American expertise, passion and money.

An obituary on Monday about James P. Hosty, an F.B.I. agent who investigated Lee Harvey Oswald in 1963, misstated at one point Mr. Hosty's testimony before the Warren Commission. He did not tell the commission that he had received a letter from Oswald in the weeks before President John F. Kennedy's assassination and later destroyed it; Mr. Hosty did not publicly acknowledge receiving that letter until he testified before Congress in 1975.

WASHINGTON -- President Obama will talk about troop numbers in Afghanistan when he makes a prime-time speech from the White House on Wednesday night. But behind his words will be an acute awareness of what $1.3 trillion in spending on two wars in the past decade has meant at home: a ballooning budget deficit and a soaring national debt at a time when the economy is still struggling to get back on its feet. As Mr. Obama begins trying to untangle the country from its military and civilian promises in Afghanistan, his critics and allies alike are drawing a direct line between what is not being spent to bolster the sagging economy in America to what is being spent in Afghanistan -- $120 billion this year alone.

CARTER--Peyton Franklin II. A long time resident of New York City, Bay Head, NJ, and Madison, CT, passed away on Saturday in Clinton, New York. He was 84. Born in Newport News, VA, his father, Benjamin F. Carter, was Director of Ship Sales for the U.S. Maritime Administration. His mother, Gretchen Upshur, counted among her illustrious ancestors U.S. Secretary of State Abel Parker Upshur. His only brother, Barton French Carter died in 1995. In 1950, Mr. Carter graduated from the University of Virginia. In 1956 he joined the J.P. Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. He was the Vice President in charge of running the firm's Madison Avenue Office in New York. Mr. Carter served as a Trustee for the Institute of International Education. In 1968, Mr. Carter married Elizabeth Ann Scott of Brookline, MA. They have one son, Peyton F. Carter III. The Carters spent their summers in Bay Head, NJ. After Mr. Carter retired in 1988, they resided in Madison, CT, Stonington, CT, and Needham, MA. Known as the consummate "Southern Gentleman", Mr. Carter was a member throughout the years of several social organizations including the Union Club, Holland Lodge, Bay Head Yacht Club, and Madison Beach Club. He is survived by his wife, Liz, his son Peyton of Scarsdale, NY, and two grandsons, Parker Upshur Carter and Peyton Franklin Carter IV. Interment will take place at Holyhood Cemetery in Chestnut Hill, MA. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Thomas More Church in New York City on June 28th at 10:00am.

A POWERFUL MESSAGE With the conviction of Winifred Jiau on Monday, the government's record is perfect so far on insider trading trials in which prosecutors relied on extensive wiretap evidence and other recordings. The folly of trying to defend these cases should now be clear, according to White Collar Watch, especially to those who might be the target of an investigation. The government's victories show just how enticing that type of evidence will be for prosecutors in future cases. PETER J. HENNING

A report on June 9 in the World Briefing column, about the trial of a Han Chinese coal truck driver sentenced to death for the May 10 killing of an ethnic Mongolian herdsman blocking a road in China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, referred incorrectly to the herdsman's death, which was a catalyst for large protests by other ethnic Mongolians in the region. It was a homicide, not an accident or a hit-and-run accident. The error was repeated in an article on June 11 about the tensions between ethnic Mongolians and Han Chinese in Inner Mongolia.

SCHIEFFELIN--Julia Cooper. Died June 19th in New York City. Born in New York City, she was educated at Madeira School. Radcliffe College and Columbia Law School. She spent her professional career first as a teacher and administrator at the Brearley School, then as a grant writer and development professional at cultural and civic institutions including Union Theological Seminary, the New York Public Library, Planned Parenthood and the Guggenheim Museum. Julie was the consummate New Yorker well educated, intellectually sophisticated, cultured and wickedly witty. Reading a sage, amusing, elegantly-written letter from Julie or experiencing her effortlessly-eloquent, clever discourse was an event to savor. She was passionately interested in arts, politics, and history, and developed a huge circle of friends who adored her for her big heart, rapier-sharp intellect, delicious sense of humor and astonishing range of knowledge. She treasured her friendship with Bill W. She leaves her beloved partner Betsy Tanner, her brother Lindsay Schieffelin and his wife Christina, her brother John Schieffelin and his wife Linda and five nephews and a niece. The Funeral Service will be at Saint James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, at 3:00pm on Tuesday, June 28th. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Fresh Air Fund, 633 Third Avenue, 14th Floor, New York, NY 10017.

WIMBLEDON, England -- The top three men's players in the world tennis rankings -- Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer -- each possesses a distinct style and, more surprisingly, a distinct racket. ''If you give Nadal's racket to Federer, I think he would struggle, and I think going the other way would be even a lot harder,'' said Roman Prokes, one of the leading racket customizers who has worked for the United States Davis Cup team and many top players. ''I really think Federer is one of those guys who can adjust the easiest to anything you give him, but Nadal's game, if you gave him Federer's racket, I think it would not be pretty.''

Hulu, the online video service, is weighing a possible sale of the company after it received a takeover offer from an unidentified suitor, people briefed on the matter said Tuesday. The unsolicited offer has prompted Hulu's board to consider its options, and the company is speaking to potential advisers, these people said. It may contact potential buyers, including other media companies and private equity firms that have wanted the chance to buy the service.

Kristoffer Diaz is the winner of the 2011 New York Times Outstanding Playwright Award for ''The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity,'' his satire of professional wrestling and the ethnic stereotypes and political imagery of that industry, The Times has announced. The award, created in 2009, recognizes an American playwright whose work recently received its professional debut in New York; ''Chad Deity'' was produced Off Broadway in 2010 by Second Stage Theater, drawing mostly positive reviews. (The play was also a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in drama that year.) Previous recipients of the Times playwright award, which comes with a cash prize of $5,000, were Tarell Alvin McCraney for ''The Brothers Size'' and Dan LeFranc for ''Sixty Miles to Silver Lake.'' The selection committee included the Pulitzer-winning playwrights Richard Greenberg, James Lapine and Lynn Nottage, as well as Times writers and editors. The committee chairwoman, Sylviane Gold, said in the statement announcing the award, ''The play appropriates both the comedy and cruelty of professional wrestling in order to explore the complex dance America does with its minorities.'' She added, ''We were floored by its swaggering language, vivid theatricality and sheer energy.''

Angela Bassett's only experience working with Samuel L. Jackson was in the early 1980s when she was an understudy, and he a star, in a Negro Ensemble Company production of ''Colored People's Time,'' a play of vignettes set between the Civil War and the Montgomery bus boycott. This fall the two actors will reunite on Broadway - as co-stars - for another play inspired by history, Katori Hall's drama ''The Mountaintop,'' about Dr. Martin Luther King on the night before his assassination. Mr. Jackson has been attached to play King for some time; Halle Berry was initially lined up for the other role, a maid at the Lorraine Motel named Camae, but dropped out because of her child custody battle.

Anthony D. Weiner's letter of resignation was a matter-of-fact two sentences, informing the New York secretary of state, Cesar A. Perales, and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo that come midnight Tuesday, he was stepping down. But his signature - an oversize looping squiggle, almost larger than the entire typed text of his statement - may offer some clues into his personality, at least according to handwriting experts. -''He's out of bounds; he's not within boundaries,'' said Dianne Peterson, a handwriting expert based in Tennessee. ''His emotional slant is that his head overrules his heart; his head is in control of his heart.''

Read Julie Bosman's report on ArtsBeat. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Rutgers Stadium will be known as High Point Solutions Stadium, Athletic Director Tim Pernetti announced. High Point Solutions Inc., an information technology supplier in Sparta, N.J., is paying Rutgers an estimated $6.5 million over 10 years for naming rights to its recently expanded 52,454-seat football stadium, Pernetti said. Including a deal made with Audi last year to sponsor premium seats at the stadium, Rutgers will bring in about $1 million a year from stadium sponsorships. More at nytimes.com/sports.

An obituary on Monday about Elena Bonner, the Soviet dissident and widow of Andrei Sakharov, described imprecisely the circumstances of Ms. Bonner's trip to Oslo in 1975 to accept the Nobel Peace Prize for her husband. She was in Italy for medical treatment and extended her trip to go to Oslo; she did not leave Russia to attend the ceremony. The obituary also misstated the year Ms. Bonner and Sakharov were married. It was 1972, not 1971.

It is undoubtedly useful to sort music by nationality, period, genre and style, but the actual experience of listening to music can often leave such categories in shambles. If I said, for example, that ''Passione,''John Turturro's galvanic tribute to the songs and singers of Naples, Italy, was a documentary about soul music, that might be confusing, since that term commonly refers to 1960s African-American music. But what else could you call the tradition that Mr. Turturro samples? The music in ''Passione'' combines sensual suavity with raw emotion, mixes heartbreak with ecstasy, acknowledges the hard realities of poverty and injustice and soars above them. I suspect that if artists like Marvin Gaye, Otis Redding or Aretha Franklin were to see this film, they would recognize their own art within it.
LUKASHOK--Alvin. The Plottel/Parisier/Stam families note with sadness the passing of Alvin Lukashok and offer their deepest condolences.

The Rangers will play the Flyers in Philadelphia on Jan. 2 in the Winter Classic, according to a league official briefed on the decision but not authorized to speak publicly. The location of the game and the teams involved will not be confirmed until the N.H.L.'s 2011-12 schedule is released, which could happen Thursday. The game is expected to be played at Citizens Bank Park. The N.H.L.'s first New Year's Day game was played in 2008 in Orchard Park, N.Y., with the host Buffalo Sabres meeting the Pittsburgh Penguins. The snowy game was an aesthetic success that drew a surprisingly large television audience on NBC. Television audiences and revenues associated with the game have grown annually. The second Winter Classic featured the Chicago Blackhawks and the Detroit Red Wings at Wrigley Field, followed by the Boston Bruins and the Flyers at Fenway Park. This past season's Penguins-Washington Capitals game was at Heinz Field in Pittsburgh.

COSTA MESA, Calif. -- City council elections in this Southern California city are usually sedate. Hot-button issues include whether libraries should stay open at night. Campaign budgets often don't top $10,000. Then Jim Righeimer, a conservative activist and real estate developer, jumped into the race last year.

KOBLICK--Freda. August 26, 1920-June 18, 2011. Sculptor Freda Koblick died June 18 at age 90 in her beloved native San Francisco. She leaves behind a large circle of loved ones and admirers who will always remember her loving friendship, wit, flair, and zest for life. Her beloved brother David Koblick, aged 95 briefly survived her. A pioneer in creating cast acrylic sculpture, Koblick was largely responsible for that material, called by some "plastic", being recognized as a medium suitable for fine art. Her pieces incorporated an imaginative and playful exploration of transparency and light. The Creative Arts League named her a "Living Treasure of California". A memorial will be held in Koblick's Mission District studio later this year.

GAMBLE--Diane Elaine, community leader and accomplished business woman, died peacefully at her home on Tuesday, June 14. The cause was cancer. She was 73. At the incipience of the internet boom, Diane had a front row seat, serving as President and CEO of Link Resources, Inc., a market research firm specializing in emerging communications technologies. After Link was acquired by International Data Group, Inc. she served as an executive of various research departments in the Walt Disney Company and American Broadcasting Company. Prior to career in market research, she worked for the then Governor Nelson Rockefeller, both in Westchester County, New York City and Albany. She had a broad interest in her community, ultimately becoming President of the Junior League of Westchester on Hudson and President of the New Castle Historical Society. She was also very active in the formative years of what became the Westchester Symphony Orchestra. She is survived by her husband, Lex and son, Alex and his wife Carol; and 21 nieces, nephews and cousins.

10 P.M. (Discovery) LIFE ON A WIRE Nik Wallenda, above, a seventh-generation member of the acrobatic family the Flying Wallendas, is on a mission to take his high-wire act to a new audience. In this sneak peek of a series that will have its premiere later this year, Mr. Wallenda, 32, demonstrates how he routinely cheats death as he balances on a wire without a safety net, through the use of engineering and wind-speed analysis conducted by a crew that includes his uncle Mike and his father, Terry. His feat here: to try to break two world records by crossing a wire between towers at the Atlantis resort in the Bahamas. On June 4 he and his mother, Delilah, successfully completed a walk at the Condado Plaza Hotel in San Juan, P.R., on a wire stretched 121 feet above the pavement -- the crossing that killed his great-grandfather Karl in 1978. Mr. Wallenda eventually plans to honor Karl Wallenda's memory by walking across the Grand Canyon. 9:30 A.M. (CUNY) CITY TALK In the first installment of a two-part edition, Doug Muzzio talks with the journalist and author Pete Hamill about the culture of drink as part of the newspaper life; Murray Kempton and Jimmy Breslin; the state of reporting; growing up in New York City; and the old Lion's Head bar in Greenwich Village. ''When I go anywhere,'' Mr. Hamill says, ''I go with the eyes of a New Yorker.'' The episode will be repeated at 4:30 and 9:30 p.m. Part 2 will be broadcast next Wednesday.

Kristoffer Diaz is the winner of the 2011 New York Times Outstanding Playwright Award for ''The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity,'' his satire of professional wrestling and the ethnic stereotypes and political imagery of that industry, The Times has announced. The award, created in 2009, recognizes an American playwright whose work recently received its professional debut in New York; ''Chad Deity'' was produced Off Broadway in 2010 by Second Stage Theater, drawing mostly positive reviews. (The play was also a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in drama that year.) Previous recipients of the Times playwright award, which comes with a cash prize of $5,000, were Tarell Alvin McCraney for ''The Brothers Size'' and Dan LeFranc for ''Sixty Miles to Silver Lake.'' The selection committee included the Pulitzer-winning playwrights James Lapine and Lynn Nottage; the playwright Richard Greenberg, who has been nominated twice for a Pulitzer; as well as Times writers and editors. The committee chairwoman, Sylviane Gold, said in the statement announcing the award, ''The play appropriates both the comedy and cruelty of professional wrestling in order to explore the complex dance America does with its minorities.'' She added, ''We were floored by its swaggering language, vivid theatricality and sheer energy.''

Fulfilling the expectations of everyone who predicted that her European tour would be short-lived, Amy Winehouse's European tour was short-lived. On Tuesday the troubled pop singer canceled the remaining dates of a planned 12-stop concert series after a Saturday performance in Belgrade, Serbia, in which she was seen meandering around the stage and struggling to remember her own songs, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Winehouse, 27, the Grammy Award-winning singer of ''Rehab,'' began her tour in the Serbian capital after a one-week stay at the Priory, a London clinic that offers treatment for addiction problems. But any hopes of her cleaning the slate and setting a good first impression were quickly dashed after video of that concert, in which Ms. Winehouse drifts in and out of her songs and at one point tosses aside her microphone, made its way around the Internet. The A.P. said the Serbian newspaper Blic had called the concert ''the worst in the history of Belgrade.'' Chris Goodman, a spokesman for Ms. Winehouse, said she ''is withdrawing from all scheduled performances'' included planned dates in Spain, Switzerland, Italy, Austria, Poland, Hungary and Romania.

Cholesterol-lowering drugs called statins, which have been shown to lower a person's risk for heart attack, can also slightly increase a patient's risk for developing diabetes, particularly at higher doses, new research shows. The findings, based on new analyses of five clinical trials involving 32,752 patients, raise new questions about how much we really know about the long-term effects of statins, which are the most widely prescribed drugs in the United States. The focus on the link between statins and diabetes comes at a time when some medical experts and pharmaceutical companies have pushed to broaden the use of the drugs beyond the 40 million at-risk patients who already use them to healthy people who would take the drugs for prevention of heart disease.

ARMSTRONG--Thomas N.,III. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with profound sadness the sudden passing of our beloved former director Thomas N. Armstrong III. Director of the Museum for 15 transformative years (1974-1990) his distinguished tenure was marked by seminal exhibitions by artists including Saul Steinberg, Richard Tuttle, Nam June Paik, Elie Nadelman, Red Grooms, Donald Judd, Richard Artschwager and Robert Mapplethorpe, as well as over 2,000 key acquisitions. So significant were the masterpieces acquired, including Jasper John's Three Flags and Alexander Calder's The Circus, that today the Museum's collection would be unimaginable without them. As Director he worked with three generations of Whitney women to lead the monumental transition from a family-run institution to the preeminent Museum that it is today. For Tom, the goal was to bring the best of American Art to the broadest possible public. He expanded the Museum's Branch program to include Philip Morris, Champion International, and the Equitable Center and established the National Committee, a patron group that brought together collectors from all over the country. He also conceived the idea and began the drive to expand the Whitney that recently got underway with groundbreaking on its future downtown building. We were pleased and honored that he joined us for this historic occasion. Much of what Whitney is today and what it will become in the future is a part of his legacy. With his broad smile and characteristic bow ties, Tom was a larger than life personality whose ebullience was infectious. He was a respected colleague as well as a mentor to so many in the Museum world. All who love American art, and all who are devoted to artists of our time are indebted to Tom. We will truly miss him. Our most sincere and heartfelt sympathies to his wife Bunty, his sister Susan, his children Thomas, Amory, Eliot, and Whitney, his seven grandchildren and his many friends and loved ones. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director

The exhibition galleries at the Smithsonian’s Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum will close on July 4 for a two-year renovation and expansion. The project, which starts this fall, is part of a $64 million capital campaign that includes a 60 percent increase in exhibition space, improvements to the National Design Library and an increased endowment. During the renovation of the Carnegie Mansion, scheduled to be completed in 2013, Cooper-Hewitt’s exhibitions, events and education programs will be staged at various off-site locations. The show “Design with the Other 90%: Cities,” for example, opens Oct. 15 at the United Nations and runs through Jan. 9, 2012. Admission to the museum will be free from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on July 4 to mark the closing of the final exhibition, “Set in Style: The Jewelry of Van Cleef & Arpels.” The museum’s terrace, garden and shop will remain open this summer without an admission fee.

“I am a magpie collecting things everywhere I go,” says Lizzie Fortunato, the designer behind her namesake Lizzie Fortunato Jewels line. Her finds have included antique whalebone poker chips in Montevideo, Uruguay, textiles from a Guatemalan village and vintage arrows at a flea market in rural Texas. This inspiration from travel is delightfully apparent in her resort collection, “Paradise Is an Island.” The assortment is a tropical concoction of polychromatic glass beads, winsome brass arrowheads and carnelian tusks, all strung together on gold chains and rope — the perfect colorful addition to an urbanite’s summer wardrobe. Despite each piece having names of exotic vacation hot spots, like “Easter Island Necklace,” the root of the label could not be more down-to-earth. For Fortunato, jewelry has always been a natural outlet. “By the time I was in college, I was fashioning statement necklaces out of industrial bolts and chains, glass beads that a friend toted back from South Africa and family heirloom pieces — literally anything I could get my hands on,” she explains. The results are a fusion of high and low, with thoughtful handiwork and smart combinations of pearls, colorful rope and shapely gold.

Jimmy “Cobra” Carbonetti is something of a downtown urban legend. A scruffy, smart-mouthed kid with a sharp wit — and memorable mutton chops — Cobra is yet another one of those natives seemingly too young to be as accomplished as he is. He is the proprietor of Cobra Guitars, a custom guitar shop in the East Village, and he strums his own creations in the acclaimed rock band Caveman. Rumor has it that the entire music industry is chasing after Caveman, waving record contracts, but the gaggle of mischievous man-boys, led by a singer with an I.Q. purported to be off the charts, refuses to sign anything. Obscenely talented, and airtight in performance delivery, Caveman is finally getting over its commitment phobia, releasing its first album, “CoCo Beware,” this fall. Should you cross paths with Cobra Carbonetti, in his uniform of shirt sleeves, vests and cowboy boots, beware of his back-snapping bear hug.

Two weeks ago, the international consulting firm McKinsey & Company threw itself into the rancorous partisan debate over the 2010 health care overhaul by publishing research that appeared to predict that many employers would dump their health insurance plans when the new law fully took effect in 2014. The new law offers subsidies to help low-income people purchase health insurance from state-run exchanges, and it also penalizes companies with more than 50 employees when they fail to offer those employees affordable coverage. As McKinsey notes, paying the penalty will cost less than providing the insurance, so companies could profit by socializing that cost.

Dry cleaning bags are not your friends. They may appear to be helpful, caring sheaths of plastic, but in the end, they do not act like friends would. In fact, they will yellow your designer clothing and linen tablecloths and, eventually, trap moisture, which leads to mold. Would a friend lead to mold? And those garment bags — the really thick ones from nice stores? They are just as bad, perhaps worse for appearing to be extra protective. Barbara Harman knows this, and it is part of the reason she founded the Butler’s Closet, a new Web-based business that specializes in covers for clothing, furniture, linens and other precious things. The covers, made from fabric that is free of chemicals, bleaches, sizing and dyes, meet the same textile conservation standards used by museum curators. They retail from $16 to $135.

Updated, 1:43 p.m. | Well that was fun, kind of. On Wednesday, we posted the ominous-looking photo at right and asked readers to tell us what and where it was. The artist Lisa Anne Auerbach likes to make statements, which are most often knitted. She is best known for her sweater-and-skirt works that feature clever, assertive slogans offering commentary and critique on issues that are important to her, whether political or personal. After receiving an M.F.A. in photography from the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, Calif., she no longer had access to the school’s darkroom and taught herself to knit instead. “Knitting was a way I could continue to make art,” she says. “It’s portable and I can do it anywhere. Now that I’m teaching photography at Pomona College, I knit on the train during my commute, and it’s a great way to pass the time in faculty meetings.” Auerbach, who lives and works in a space in downtown Los Angeles (which she shares with several other artists), still knits the old-fashioned way, with needles, but her studio also houses two computer-controlled knitting machines.

GOLDENHEIM--Ruth, in New York, June 22, 2011, age 97. A graduate of Barnard College 35, and Columbia University, M.A.'39, Mrs. Goldenheim served as President of the Barnard Alumnae Association and was awarded the Columbia University Alumni Medal for Distinguished Service. She was predeceased by her husband of 65 years, Lewis Goldenheim, and their daughter, Anne Creem. She is survived by her daughter, Sara Alperstein, and her son, Paul Goldenheim; grandchildren Linda Paseltiner, Jacob Creem, Janet Alperstein, Abigail Ruttenberg, and David, Catherine, William, and Julia Goldenheim; great-grandchildren Daniel, Matthew, and Isaac Paseltiner, Maia Creem, Max Alperstein, and Shira and Aliza Ruttenberg. Also surviving are her sister, Wilma Mendelowitz, and brother, Irwin Saberski, and their families. Funeral services are at 1:00pm at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Barnard College Fund, 3009 Broadway, New York, NY 10027.

THE ARTS A film review on Wednesday about ''Passione,'' a documentary about the songs and singers of Naples, Italy, misidentified a singer praised in the review. She uses one name, Misia; she is not Lina Sastri, another performer in the film.

Summers, below, the former Treasury secretary and chief economic adviser to President Obama, has joined the board of Square, a technology start-up. It's a notable addition for Square, a rising mobile payments company based in San Francisco that facilitates credit card transactions on mobile devices. Square is known for its roster of technology power players. EVELYN M. RUSLI

WELCH--Earlene Ynes Hornbostel Wirsching. Passed away on June 20, 2011, at the age of 59. She was the beloved daughter of Elizabeth Valdez Wirsching and Norbert R. Wirsching and cherished sister of Elizabeth del Alamo and Margaret Still, loving wife of Teed Welch, devoted mother of Theodore TJ Welch, and dear sister-in-law of Constancio del Alamo and Gary Still. Earlene was a beautiful, intelligent, and accomplished woman. She attended the American School in Manila, the Philippines, and graduated from the International School in Hong Kong. She received her Associate's Degree from Tobe-Coburn School for Fashion Careers, her B. A. in Economics from Columbia University School of General Studies, and her M.B.A. from Columbia University. Earlene worked for Nabisco Brands / Planter's Peanuts Division, Kiddie Products/The First Years, and for IBM's Marketing Communications Division. She retired in 1998 to become a full-time Mom. Her family loves her, and will always hold her dear in our hearts. Elizabeth, Norbert, Bunny and Margie

As part of an effort to trim $1.1 million from its budget El Museo del Barrio in East Harlem has laid off four staff members, including its press officer, out of a total staff of 51. El Museo is facing a potential 10 percent cut in its operating subsidy from New York City, as well as decreases in private support, the museum's interim director, Georgina M. Nichols, said in a telephone interview. In addition to the layoffs the museum has reduced its summer program and lengthened the amount of time that exhibitions will run, Ms. Nichols said. The museum, which just opened its largest-ever biennial exhibition, is also searching for a new director. The previous director, Julian Zugazagoitia, left last September to become director of the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo.

A divided Securities and Exchange Commission approved new rules on Wednesday that would impose sweeping disclosure requirements on large hedge funds and other private investment advisers, a first for an industry that has long eluded Washington oversight. The rules will require hedge funds, private equity shops and other advisers that manage more than $150 million to register with the agency and turn over crucial information, including the funds they oversee and their investors. Venture capital funds and some small hedge funds are excused from the rules, although these firms will still have to report some basic information to regulators.

A divided Securities and Exchange Commission approved new rules on Wednesday that would impose sweeping disclosure requirements on large hedge funds and other private investment advisers, a first for an industry that has long eluded Washington oversight. The rules will require hedge funds, private equity shops and other advisers that manage more than $150 million to register with the agency and turn over crucial information, including the funds they oversee and their investors. Venture capital funds and some small hedge funds are excused from the rules, although these firms will still have to report some basic information to regulators.

MADRID -- Crowds at the Prado, disgorged from tour buses, in couples and on private pilgrimages to the great art temple of Spain, jostle and murmur before Velázquez's large and labyrinthine masterpiece ''Las Meninas.'' Guides with headsets preach with one eye toward the picture, the other on crowd control. Just around the corner, in a nearby gallery, a tiny landscape, paperback-book size, painted by Velázquez as a young man in Rome around 1630, shows the gardens at the Villa Medici. Few tourists pause or notice it. It's a summer scene, gazing from the ground up at a workman looking down from a rooftop at a pair of chatting colleagues, distractedly holding one end of a rope he has apparently dropped for them. He stands on a broad, low, whitewashed building with a large arched entryway blocked by scaffolding. Caught in the early morning light, the rope he has dropped glints like the silver thread of a spider's web. It is almost imperceptibly fine. Draped absently over a balustrade, like bunting, a white sheet also shimmers in the sun, reflecting at intervals on the stonework like patches of spilled milk.

NATIONAL An article on Saturday about the departure of David Protess from the Medill Innocence Project misstated the time served by Donald Watkins, whose 2004 murder conviction was the subject of a recent investigative article by Medill students. He was convicted of murder in 2004 and sentenced to 56 years in prison; he has not served 56 years.

PERNICA--Joseph, 86, died peacefully on Wednesday, June 22. Born April 7, 1925, in Plumlov, Czechoslovakia. Joe received a business degree at the Czech University of Prague. He escaped from communism in 1949 and emigrated to Sydney, Australia where he received a Master of Economics degree from the University of Sydney. In 1958, he began a successful marketing research career in New York. He was a principal in the development of the "I Love NY" campaign and also conducted international banking research. Survivors are his wife Cecile (Otte), four nieces and nephews in the Czech Republic, brother-in-law David Otte, and family of Massachusetts. Friends may call from 5-8pm on Friday at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st St.) A funeral mass will be held at 10am on Saturday, at St. Catherine of Siena Church, 411 East 68th Street. Burial Private.

Shortly before she was hired in 2009 as the first female coach of Nigeria's powerful women's national soccer team, Eucharia Uche said at a seminar that she was troubled by the presence of lesbians on the squad, calling it a ''worrisome experience.'' Over the past two years, as Nigeria progressed toward the Women's World Cup, which begins Sunday in Germany, Uche said that she has used religion in an attempt to rid her team of homosexual behavior, which she termed a ''dirty issue,'' and ''spiritually, morally very wrong.''

ARMSTRONG--Thomas N.,III. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with profound sadness the sudden passing of our beloved former director Thomas N. Armstrong III. Director of the Museum for 15 transformative years (1974-1990) his distinguished tenure was marked by seminal exhibitions by artists including Saul Steinberg, Richard Tuttle, Nam June Paik, Elie Nadelman, Red Grooms, Donald Judd, Richard Artschwager and Robert Mapplethorpe, as well as over 2,000 key acquisitions. So significant were the masterpieces acquired, including Jasper John's Three Flags and Alexander Calder's The Circus, that today the Museum's collection would be unimaginable without them. As Director he worked with three generations of Whitney women to lead the monumental transition from a family-run institution to the preeminent Museum that it is today. For Tom, the goal was to bring the best of American Art to the broadest possible public. He expanded the Museum's Branch program to include Philip Morris, Champion International, and the Equitable Center and established the National Committee, a patron group that brought together collectors from all over the country. He also conceived the idea and began the drive to expand the Whitney that recently got underway with groundbreaking on its future downtown building. We were pleased and honored that he joined us for this historic occasion. Much of what Whitney is today and what it will become in the future is a part of his legacy. With his broad smile and characteristic bow ties, Tom was a larger than life personality whose ebullience was infectious. He was a respected colleague as well as a mentor to so many in the Museum world. All who love American art, and all who are devoted to artists of our time are indebted to Tom. We will truly miss him. Our most sincere and heartfelt sympathies to his wife Bunty, his sister Susan, his children Thomas, Amory, Eliot, and Whitney, his seven grandchildren and his many friends and loved ones. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director

What exactly results from a Broadway show featuring the works of Ethan Coen, Elaine May and Woody Allen? That vague if tantalizing proposition offered by ''Relatively Speaking,'' a triple bill of one-act comedies by those authors and directed by John Turturro, came into somewhat clearer focus on Wednesday with the announcement of its ensemble cast and other details. Press representatives for ''Relatively Speaking,'' which is now described as a collection of comedies that each spring ''from a different branch of the family tree,'' said it would be presented at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, with previews to begin on Sept. 20 and an opening night planned for Oct. 20.

CHESTMAN--Jerylin. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member, Jerilyn Chestman, and extend our deepest sympathy to her husband Harvey and their family. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Jeffrey Sands, President for the Board of Governors

The folks at Sony Ericsson have engaged in the sort of experimentation that got Victor Frankenstein in trouble. They have combined a phone and a PlayStation-style keypad to create a gaming phone. Here you may imagine an evil laugh and crash of thunder if you wish. The Sony Ericsson Xperia Play is a slide-out phone, but it replaces the keyboard typically on the slide out with a Playstation-style game controller, including the familiar four-button keypads.

Don Draper may not care for contracts, but the man who plays him apparently doesn't share his problems with commitment. Jon Hamm has signed a deal to stay on at ''Mad Men'' for three more years, according to Lionsgate, the production company that owns the series. The extension matches the length of the deal Lionsgate and AMC agreed to in March after protracted negotiations with Matthew Weiner, the series creator. ''Mad Men'' won't return to AMC until early 2012. Read more at Media Decoder. ... This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

2:36 p.m. | Updated A coroner's report said that Ryan Dunn, the ''Jackass'' star who was killed in a car crash on Monday morning, and a passenger in his car died from the impact of that crash and a resulting fire, The Associated Press reported. In a report issued Tuesday by the coroner of Chester County, Pa., the official causes of death listed for Mr. Dunn, 34, and the passenger, Zachary Hartwell, 30, a ''Jackass'' production assistant, were blunt force trauma and thermal trauma. A spokeswoman for the coroner's office told The A.P. that toxicology results will take four to six weeks to complete.

COHEN--Robert J.,82, of West Orange, NJ, and East Orleans, MA, beloved husband of Anne Silberstein Cohen for 58 years, father of Laura and Michael, and brother of Sylvia Gangursky and Ruth Newman. Grampa Bob was determined to be the grandfather he never had, and doted on, delighted and inspired his four grandchildren Leila, Stefan, Ariel and Julian. Bob was a gregarious man and an adventuresome world traveller with a passion for archaeology, theater and the arts. Born in Philadelphia to immigrant parents Phillip and Celia, he was a graduate of Central High School, Philadelphia (Class 185), attended Temple University, earned his C.P.A., and later, at age 50 returned to academia to earn a B.A. with Honors in Humanities from NYU. He served in the Army Counter Intelligence Corps during the Korean war, was advertising director of Hat Corporation of America, former president of the Philadelphia Men's Apparel Association, and, as CFO and Partner of Waterman Advertising of NYC, was one of the true Mad Men. He founded and was President of Video Monitoring Services of America, where he was mentor, leader, shrink and inspiration to his employees. He fulfilled a lifelong dream with his beach home on Cape Cod, and was honorary mayor of Pochet Beach. Donations may be made to the National Kidney Foundation or to a charitable organization of one's choice.

FRONT PAGE An article on June 6 about a confrontation between Israeli soldiers and pro-Palestinian protesters from Syria who tried to cross into Israeli-controlled territory misstated at several points the site of the confrontation. As stated elsewhere in the article, it was in the Golan Heights, which Israel seized from Syria in the 1967 war, and which remains an area of disputed sovereignty. It was not at the Syrian border. The error was repeated in headlines and a picture caption with the article.

Brian Haw, who day after day and night after night for nearly a decade maintained a vigil outside Parliament in London to protest the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, becoming an annoyance to some politicians and a stopping point for tour guides, died on Saturday. He was 62. Mr. Haw died in Germany, where he had been receiving treatment for lung cancer since March, his family told The Associated Press.

We are all creatures rooting in the gutter of appetite, but most of us are also looking at the stars. Or so it goes in Jason Grote's ''Civilization (All You Can Eat),'' a play whose conventional heart is not particularly well camouflaged by its postmodern bells and whistles. The third and final presentation of Clubbed Thumb's Summerworks festival at Here, ''Civilization,'' directed by Seth Bockley, ineffectively mixes the surreal with the banal, the hyper-serious with the comic. It features a talking hog (Tony Torn) who holds forth in a kind of porcine blank verse (''All see the three ones:/Food/Feces/Knife'') and unnecessary interludes of solemn dance-movement (choreographed by Dan Safer of Witness Relocation).

A report on Wednesday in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column, about the winner of the 2011 New York Times Outstanding Playwright Award, Kristoffer Diaz, erroneously attributed a distinction to the playwright Richard Greenberg, a member of the selection committee. While Mr. Greenberg has been nominated twice for a Pulitzer Prize, he has not won one.

FORRAY--Janice, on June 22, 2011. Beloved mother of Karen and Shari. She lived for her children, and they loved her dearly. She will be deeply missed. Rest in peace, Mom. Funeral service Friday, June 24, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St, New York City.

AT Verameat, Vera Balyura's new shop in the East Village, you will come face to face with the designer's eccentric childhood obsessions -- paleontology, anatomy, monsters -- sculptured into whimsical pieces of wearable, and affordable (in the $50 to $300 range), jewelry. In quaint digs, the front painted in Ms. Balyura's favorite blood orange, necklaces with centaurs, unicorns and embracing sumo wrestlers hang from casts of friends' hands mounted on the wall. There are two-finger rings with vampire teeth and a selection of animal rings, including a French bulldog ring that will make anyone coo. Ms. Balyura, a former model, began studying fine-art sculpture at the encouragement of a stylist friend. ''I already knew what I wanted to make,'' she said. ''I just needed to learn how.'' Now she has a following that includes Tilda Swinton, Dakota and Elle Fanning and at least one Kardashian (Khloé). Verameat, 315 East Ninth Street; (917) 353-3885; verameat.com.

LASER-CUT leather made an emphatic appearance this season, most memorably in Christopher Kane's neon-bright designs, the leather so delicate it looked like lace. Think, too, of Alaïa perforated cinch-waist belts, Louboutin cutout booties and the lacy Givenchy George V shopper, already sold out at Barneys. Finely detailed designer skins come at a price, though. For just a zap of the look, consider the summery white ''lace'' clutch that Ashley Baker and Carly Beck, childhood friends and fashion industry veterans, designed for Sedgwick, a new handbag company named for their hometown in Kansas; or a cutout clutch from Cleobella, with zip pockets and slots to keep you organized. Still lusting for a piece of Kane? Four wristlet clutches in happy Day-Glo colors have just arrived at Net-a-Porter. From top: Cleobella cutout clutch, $160 at cleobella.com; Sedgwick leather clutch, $286 at Elizabeth Charles, 639 1/2 Hudson Street, (212) 243-3201; Christopher Kane laser-cut

An article last Thursday about the fitness trainer Jillian Michaels referred imprecisely to the daytime television shows ''The Doctors,'' whose cast Ms. Michaels will join in the fall, and ''Dr. Phil,'' on which she will be a special correspondent. They are syndicated by CBS Television Distribution and can be seen on local affiliates of various major networks, not just those of CBS. The article also misspelled the Pennsylvania community of Cynthia Eyler, who used Ms. Michaels's weight-loss Web site as she lost 93 pounds. It is West Chester, not Westchester.

Lucas Jackson/Reuters Robert Khuzami, director of the S.E.C.'s enforcement division, in February.As regulators announced a settlement Wednesday with Morgan Keegan of charges that it defrauded customers during the financial crisis, its parent put the brokerage firm on the block. Morgan Keegan, a unit of Regions Financial, the big Alabama-based bank, agreed to pay $200 million to resolve a case brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission. It accused the brokerage firm and two former executives of mispricing risky mortgage-backed bonds in supposedly conservative mutual funds.

An article last Thursday about fans misstated the energy consumed by a good window air-conditioner and a three-ton central air-conditioning unit, a common cooling system. The window air-conditioner would draw about 1.2 kilowatts of power, not kilowatts an hour. (It would, as stated, cost 14 cents an hour to run at average utility rates, 12 cents a kilowatt hour.). The central air-conditioning unit would draw about 3 kilowatts of power, not kilowatts an hour. (It would, as stated, cost 36 cents an hour to run.) The article also misstated the volume of a basketball in describing the amount of air moved by one fan. It is approximately a quarter of a cubic foot, not one cubic foot.

WIMBLEDON, England -- Ian Ritchie, the chief executive of the All England Lawn and Tennis Club, has heard enough. Ritchie, who heads an eight-member executive committee that oversees Wimbledon, told The Daily Telegraph this week: ''We are one tournament in a global circuit. But we have made our views clear and we would like to see less of it.''Or hear less of it. Ritchie said that club members, spectators and television viewers had complained about the sounds.

SCHIEFFELIN--Julia Cooper. Died June 19th in New York City. Born in New York City, she was educated at Madeira School. Radcliffe College and Columbia Law School. She spent her professional career first as a teacher and administrator at the Brearley School, then as a grant writer and development professional at cultural and civic institutions including Union Theological Seminary, the New York Public Library, Planned Parenthood and the Guggenheim Museum. Julie was the consummate New Yorker well educated, intellectually sophisticated, cultured and wickedly witty. Reading a sage, amusing, elegantly-written letter from Julie or experiencing her effortlessly-eloquent, clever discourse was an event to savor. She was passionately interested in arts, politics, and history, and developed a huge circle of friends who adored her for her big heart, rapier-sharp intellect, delicious sense of humor and astonishing range of knowledge. She treasured her friendship with Bill W. She leaves her beloved partner Betsy Tanner, her brother Lindsay Schieffelin and his wife Christina, her brother John Schieffelin and his wife Linda and five nephews and a niece. The Funeral Service will be at Saint James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, at 3:00pm on Tuesday, June 28th. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Fresh Air Fund, 633 Third Avenue, 14th Floor, New York, NY 10017.

Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81st St., Friday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral service Saturday, 4pm. Interment Hillcrest Cemetery, Hamburg, NY.

WASHINGTON -- When President Obama expanded the Afghanistan war a year after taking office, Republicans fiercely criticized his deadline to bring troops home. But his decision on Wednesday to accelerate their withdrawal came with few reprisals, a sign of a remarkable shift in the politics of war. The president, who addressed the nation in a prime-time speech from the White House, stopped short of declaring victory, but he suggested that the mission had been a success and that it was time to turn to a new foreign policy and to place a greater focus on domestic concerns.

Interment to follow at Green-Wood Cemetery.

Dr. Greenbaum was a recipient of the University's Distinguished Teaching Award in 1990. A memorial for Dr. Greenbaum will be held at The New School in the fall. Michael J. Look Ma, no hands! Seeking to rid timepieces of those cumbersome hands and pesky numbers, Biegert & Funk, a German design company, has conceived an analog table clock that makes bold pronouncements about the passage of time.

PEREIRA--Sr. Camille, RSHM, 99, June 20, 2011, Neuilly, France. Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary for 76 years. After serving in Portugal for two years, she lovingly ministered to the students, parents, staff at Marymount School, Neuilly/Paris, France for 74 years. Funeral services and burial in Neuilly. Gifts in her memory may be made to the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary, 50 Wilson Park Drive, Tarrytown, NY, 10591.

RAJARAMAN--Viswanathan, 54, and Mary J. Sundaram, 50, of Franklin Lakes, NJ, died on June 19th in a single-engine plane crash in Ohio. Dr. Rajaraman, a renowned neurosurgeon and co-chief of neuro-oncology at Hackensack University Medical Center's Cancer Center, was one of the top doctors in New Jersey, specializing in brain and spine cancer. Dr. Mary Sundaram practiced obstetrics and gynecology in India and the UK. After relocating to the US with her family, Dr. Sundaram obtained a Masters in Health Administration, then worked as a medical director for Integrated Communications Corp. (ICC-Lowe) in Parsippany, NJ. Dr. Rajaraman and Dr. Sundaram met in Madras, India, where both were obtaining degrees from Stanley Medical College, and they married on July 9, 1984. They are survived by their daughter, Kaavya Viswanathan. They were loving to and beloved by many. Their warmth, generosity and compassion will endure through the lives they touched. Funeral service 10:00am on Saturday June 25, 2011 at the Hawthorne Gospel Church, 2000 Route 208 North, Hawthorne, NJ 07506. Friends may visit with the family at the church on Friday from 2-4 and 7-9pm.

8 P.M. (13) LUCIA DI LAMMERMOOR The French soprano Natalie Dessay reprises the role of Donizetti's fragile heroine, driven to madness, in this revival of the production by Mary Zimmerman originally presented by the Metropolitan Opera in 2007. Joseph Calleja (above with Ms. Dessay) plays her lover, Edgardo; Ludovic Tézier is Enrico, the villainous brother who forces Lucia into an arranged marriage for his own gain; and Kwangchul Youn is the chaplain Raimondo. Patrick Summers, the music director of Houston Grand Opera, conducts; Renée Fleming hosts. ''There is an empty space where Lucia ought to be,'' Zachary Woolfe wrote in The New York Times about this production, shown in movie theaters on March 19 and presented here by ''Great Performances at the Met.'' ''Ms. Dessay and Ms. Zimmerman have clearly, carefully considered every motion,'' he continued, ''and the result is a Lucia almost entirely blank. The main consideration seems to have been avoiding going over the top, being too 'operatic.' But in this version Lucia -- that supremely expressive Romantic character, the one who weeps, swoons, trembles and is often, as the libretto describes, simply 'beside herself with misery and fear' in a work dominated by passions and blood -- is so internal that the audience perceives her only as indifferent and detached.'' But he called Mr. Calleja ''sensationally ardent.'' 3:30 P.M. (IFC) AWAY FROM HER (2007) Fiona and Grant, a long-married couple played by Julie Christie, left, in an Oscar-nominated role, and Gordon Pinsent, confront Alzheimer's disease in the feature directorial debut from Sarah Polley, who also earned an Oscar nomination for her screenplay, based on an Alice Munro short story. ''There is, in Ms. Munro's mature work, a flinty wisdom about heterosexual love, a skepticism about romantic ideals that does not altogether deny their power or necessity,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''Ms. Polley, rather remarkably for someone still in her 20s, shows an intuitive grasp of this wisdom and a welcome, unsentimental interest in the puzzles and pleasures of a long, imperfect marriage.'' He added, ''I can't remember the last time the movies yielded up a love story so painful, so tender and so true.''

The Philadelphia Orchestra, which in April filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws, said on Wednesday it has drummed up $27.5 million in pledges and donations as part of its search for financial stability. Most of the money -- $16.3 million - came in the form of challenge grants that must be met by the end of the year. Gifts and promised gifts came from several local foundations and members of the orchestra's board. The donors include the William Penn Foundation, Wyncote Foundation and Neubauer Family Foundation, the orchestra said. Management sought reorganization under Chapter 11 two months ago and announced a plan to reduce subscription concerts by 15 percent, put international touring on hold and play some lighter fare. Fund-raising for the challenge grants would go alongside its regular campaign for donations, the orchestra said. Management has announced a five-year plan that includes raising $100 million in endowment money and $60 million for artistic purposes.

SPORTS An article on Friday about the Boston Bruins' victory over Vancouver in the Stanley Cup finals erroneously attributed a distinction to the Canucks in their Game 7 loss. They became the first team in a Stanley Cup finals to lose Game 7 in a shutout on home ice; they were not the first team to do so in any N.H.L. playoff series. (The Colorado Avalanche lost Game 7 by shutout to the visiting Edmonton Oilers in the first round of the 1998 playoffs.)

Judging by the last week, one could be forgiven for thinking that banking deals were back in vogue. Last Thursday, Capital One Financial announced that it was buying the American online banking business of the ING Group for $9 billion. Four days later, PNC Financial said that it would pay $3.45 billion for the Royal Bank of Canada's retail banking network. And on Wednesday, Regions Financial disclosed that it was exploring a potential sale of its Morgan Keegan brokerage firm.

Q.I can't open an ePub file on my computer. What is this file type and is there anyway to read one of these files on the computer?A.The ePub format is a standard used for electronic book files and allows for text that can be reflowed and resized on screen. Many e-readers can open and display ePub files, and there are programs for the computer that can also handle the format. So to read the ePub file, you should first get a program that can open it and install it on your computer. Then open the ePub file within that program to read it. These ePub-friendly programs include the free Adobe Digital Editions software, which works for most Windows and Mac OS X systems.

MAN-TAILORED pantsuits have made an unexpected showing for summer. There were plenty on the runways -- at Stella McCartney, at The Row -- and the look caught on for day and evening. At the C.F.D.A. awards this month, Kirsten Dunst wore a navy tuxedo by the men's-wear designer Patrik Ervell. Phoebe Philo, on hand to accept the international award, wore a sleek black suit, custom-made at Céline, with a collarless shirt. And the actress Leelee Sobieski (far right) chose a white linen suit inspired by Tom Wolfe and designed by her husband, Adam Kimmel, in his first foray into women's wear. ''It's so classic and becomes all about swag and not about showing your pretty dress,'' Ms. Sobieski said of the men's style. ''It felt clean and suave.'' Not that you need a bespoke tailor to pull off the look. Barneys has collaborated with Rag & Bone on a collection of sharp black suits, this shorts look included. And for his new line, BLK DNM, Johan Lindeberg designed spare suits with high-waist trousers in neutral shades. Unfussed-with and chic.

Q.I had purchases from the iTunes Store authorized on three of my computers -- one personal computer and two machines at work. The office I.T. guys swapped out my work computers but I forgot to deauthorize iTunes on them before they wiped the hard drives clean. Now what, since Apple only lets me authorize a few computers? A.Apple lets you ''authorize'' up to five computers at a time to play copy-protected music, movies and other content purchased with your iTunes Store account. (Music in the iTunes Plus format does not contain digital-rights restrictions, but songs purchased before early 2009 and most commercial videos have it built in.)

After years of carrying bags big enough to hold a bull mastiff, I thought that I might be ready to slim down a bit. That's why I was so refreshed when I saw the Nomadic WR-08 Wise-Walker A4 Shoulder Bag. This bag's Star Wars-esque name reflects the dimensions (but not the thickness) of an A4 sheet of paper and is a uniquely Japanese take on the traditional laptop bag. The Wise-Walker can hold a small and light 13-inch laptop as well as any number of folders, documents or envelopes. Mini pockets hold either business cards or Japanese-style transit cards and a charming illustrated hang-tag shows that you can place devices like CD players and circa-1999 Palm Pilots into the smaller pockets.

ARMSTRONG--Thomas N. III The directors and staff of the Garden Conservancy mourn the loss of our distinguished and beloved chairman, Tom Armstrong. Tom joined our board in 1991 at founder Frank Cabot's invitation, to strengthen the then-fledgling organization in our mission to preserve America's exceptional gardens. Today, the Conservancy has grown to encompass 16 major preservation projects from the Humes Japanese Stroll Garden on Long Island to the historic gardens on Alcatraz Island, an annual Open Days garden-visiting program across the country, and thousands of loyal members. Tom had tremendous respect for Conservancy staff and our network of partners, working energetically with them on a wide variety of projects to garner interest and support for garden preservation. The National Trust for Historic Preservation's recent Organizational Excellence Award to the Garden Conservancy is a tribute to his leadership. Tom's passion for the Conservancy was closely linked to his own fascination with the art of gardening. The development of his personal garden on Fishers Island and of the new glass house at its center was a creative obsession and a magnificent accomplishment. We send our deepest condolences to Bunty, Amory, Eliot, Tom, and Whitney and all his family and many friends. Francis H. Cabot, Chairman Emeritus Benjamin F. Lenhardt, Jr., Vice-Chairman Antonia F. Adezio, President Morris Cheston, Jr., Vice-President Howard G. Seitz, Secretary/Treasurer

NEW YORK An article in some editions on Sunday about the fatal crash of a small plane near Westchester County Airport described incorrectly the tower the pilot contacted for help. It was the airport control tower, not an emergency control tower.

FOREIGN The Saturday Profile article about Nikolai Alekseyev, a campaigner for gay rights in Russia, misstated the law on same-sex marriage in Switzerland, as well as Mr. Alekseyev's marital status and his citizenship. While Switzerland allows what it calls registered partnerships of same-sex couples, same-sex marriage is not legal, and registered partners do not have the same rights as heterosexual couples, including automatic Swiss citizenship to a non-Swiss in a registered partnership with a Swiss. It is not the case that Mr. Alekseyev ''is married to his Swiss partner and has citizenship in Switzerland.''

Administrivial Solving Tips Alert: The question of how to solve a puzzle that has rebus elements in it when you are solving on computer — whether you are on Mac or PC, solving in Across Lite or the applet — has come up, and I’d like to direct your attention to a new category on the right-hand side of the page in the Blogroll called Solving Tips. Our own Martin Herbach was kind enough to research and write up a new page about how to enter multiple letters for rebus entries, and there is an interesting article from puzzlemaster Will Shortz. Harriet Ross Tubman and Frederick Douglass, two of the best-known African Americans of the Civil War era, were both born into slavery on Maryland’s Eastern Shore, at roughly the same time. Perhaps because of its border-state decision to stay with the Union, Maryland and its slave-owning past are often forgotten today. And yet as the lives and scars of these two attested, slavery in rural Maryland could be as oppressive and isolated as the cotton fields of the Deep South. Swaths of white family-owned farmland were worked by thousands of enslaved people, who also worked on the water to bring back the rich catch of the Chesapeake Bay. And in no part of the state was slavery as brutal as the Eastern Shore — conditions exposed by the oddly parallel lives of these two famous Marylanders.

The mystique that surrounds the San Antonio Spurs is very real. Of all N.B.A. teams, none has a better record of finding truly unknown players and harnessing their talent. Tony Parker and Manu Ginobili provide notable examples, but they are only the most exceptional in a long line of unearthed gems. Alongside the Spurs’ core has been a never-ending stream of competent role players. Stephen Jackson, Malik Rose, Robert Horry, Hedo Turkoglu, Rasho Nesterovic, Bruce Bowen, Matt Bonner, Roger Mason Jr. and Gary Neal – not to mention the string of ring-seeking veterans on the last legs of their career – were all plucked from obscurity and thrown into the mix of a championship-contending squad to great effect.

Just when you thought winter was finally over, a cold front suddenly hits. The new video for “The Staircase,” by the synth pop group Xeno & Oaklander, which makes is United States premiere on The Moment today, epitomizes the cool aesthetic of the underground minimal electronics movement. The video has the quality of a Xerox, reproduced over and over, blown out and dark, and induces a sense of something lost. Sean McBride and Miss Liz Wendelbo, the duo behind Xeno & Oaklander, along with other members of the Wierd Records label, have been largely credited with the revival of minimal wave here in New York. Taryn Waldman of Boxmotion, who directed the “The Staircase,” and Patrick Stroub, its cinematographer, make references to Roman Polanski’s film “Repulsion,” as a slip of a woman, Xeno (Wendelbo), climbs the stairs of a claustrophobic 19th-century Brooklyn tenement building, seemingly unaware that the object of her affection and of her voyeurism, Oaklander (McBride), is right next to her. (Xeno’s stark, wintry eyes come courtesy of the master retoucher Pascal Dangin, known in fashion circles for his work for Annie Leibovitz, Patrick Demarchelier, Steven Meisel, Steven Klein, Craig McDean and others.) Alienation, disconnection, damage? Oh, city life!

Each summer, the treacherous coastal road in Italy linking picturesque Sorrento with postcardy Positano is jammed with cars and buses bringing tourists through the fragile hill towns of the Amalfi Coast. Long waits for a table and abominable prices on everything from dinky hotel rooms to mediocre pasta are customary. But just south of Amalfi is Cilento National Park, where a dollar goes further and the traffic and tourists are few and far between. The area encompasses dozens of coastal and mountain towns worth stopping for a stroll or an aperitivo. And throughout the summer you’ll find a smattering of cultural events: the London Festival Opera will perform Puccini’s “La Bohème,” “Tosca” and “Madame Butterfly” in Santa Maria di Castellabate, and the nearby temples of Paestum will play host to performances of Medea and the Decameron.

Windows 7 has a number of tools like Disk Cleanup to help keep your system running smoothly, and it also includes a System Maintenance troubleshooter. Although the program usually runs itself once a week, you can manually fire it up by going to the Start menu, clicking on Control Panel and typing the word “troubleshooter” into the Search box at the top of the window. Click Troubleshooting and in the System and Security area, click on “Run maintenance tasks.”

A revival of Paula Vogel's Pulitzer Prize-winning play, ''How I Learned to Drive,'' and a new comedy by Paul Weitz (''Trust'') will be part of Second Stage's 2011-12 season, the theater announced Thursday. The company's 33rd season begins in October with the New York premiere of the new musical ''The Blue Flower,'' written by Jim Bauer and Ruth Bauer and directed by Will Pomerantz. The show, which was produced at the American Repertory Theater in Boston last year, uses video, dance and music to tell the story of four friends living through the Belle Epoque and World War I.
