CHALLENGING RULES A growing number of lawmakers argue that some proposed rules could force Wall Street's derivatives business overseas. They also say that regulators are ignoring a crucial exemption to the rules spelled out in the Dodd-Frank financial regulatory law, which excused airlines, oil companies and other nonfinancial firms known as end-users from new restrictions.

10 P.M. (CMT) CMT CROSSROADS: THE DOOBIE BROTHERS AND LUKE BRYAN The Doobie Brothers, who have four gold records, three platinum albums, four platinum sets and a diamond record for more than 10,000,000 copies sold of ''Best of the Doobies,'' are celebrating their 40th anniversary this year. Luke Bryan (second from left above with the Doobie Brothers), whose singles ''Rain Is a Good Thing'' and ''Someone Else Calling You Baby'' have reached No. 1 on Billboard's Hot Country chart, will release his third studio album, ''Tailgates & Tanlines,'' in August. In this concert, taped before an invitation-only audience in Nashville, these classic rockers and this country crooner perform hits including the Doobie Brothers' ''Black Water,'' ''Long Train Runnin' '' and ''China Grove,'' and Mr. Bryan's ''Do I'' and ''Country Girl (Shake It for Me).'' 7 P.M. (Link TV) TO EDUCATE A GIRL (2010) A decade after the United Nations Girls' Education Initiative was founded to help provide equal access to education for girls by 2015, the filmmakers Frederick Rendina and Oren Rudavsky set out to learn what it takes to provide that schooling in the midst of poverty and conflict in the developing world. Produced with the support of the the education initiative and Unicef, the film examines the challenges through the eyes of female students fighting to stay in school, including Manisha, a teenager in Nepal who works the fields to allow her three younger sisters to attend classes, and Mercy, a 6-year-old from a poor family in Uganda about to begin school. Queen Rania of Jordan, the honorary chairwoman of the girls' education initiative, introduces the film.

SCHWEIKARDT--A. Craig, on June 21, 2011. Dear friend and companion to many. Former Senior Counselor at Frank E. Campbell - The Funeral Chapel for over 35 years. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81st St., Friday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral service Saturday, 4pm. Interment Hillcrest Cemetery, Hamburg, NY.

ARMSTRONG--Thomas N.,III. It is with great sadness that the Board of Trustees, students, faculty, and staff of the New York School of Interior Design acknowledge the passing of Board of Trustee member Thomas N. Armstrong III. Tom began his tenure on the Board in 2000 and served until his death. His commitment to the School was unwavering, as was his generosity to both students and faculty. In addition to his duties as a Trustee, Tom frequently participated in juries and critiques of student work. Tom could always be counted on to take on any task, big or small, such as sitting on the Board of Trustee's Institutional Advancement Committee. Of particular interest to Tom was raising funds for scholarships and other forms of financial aid. For Tom, the students always came first. We will miss him terribly. The NYSID community extends its sincerest condolences to Tom's wife Bunty, his sister Susan, his children Thomas, Amory, Eliot, and Whitney, and his seven grandchildren.

A report on Thursday in the Scouting Report about the first sunglasses from the unisex eyewear brand Warby Parker misstated the address of the company's showroom, where they are available. It is on the sixth floor at 13 East 16th Street, not 150 Varick Street.

WACHS--Lillian M.,1921-2011. Daughter of Eva and Isadore Jacobs. Sister to Bea and Sylvia. Wife to Paul (68 years married), mother to Dr. Steven and Gerald, grandmother to Joshua. Devoted to her family, beloved and cherished. She was a powerful and indomitable personality. Husband Paul, son Gerald, daughter-in-law Josefina and grandson Joshua are devastated by her leaving us but acknowledge the long, full, and well lived life that she shared. Mom, we love you and we miss you so much already. Thank you for everything. We will cherish all the wonderful years together. Love you always and may you rest in eternal peace. Your Loving Family

FRIGON--Henry F.,"Hank" Henry "Hank" Frederick Frigon, 76, of Scottsdale, AZ, Beaver Creek, CO and Westhampton Beach, NY passed away at his home in Scottsdale, AZ on June 18, 2011. Beloved husband of Anne Marie (McCarthy), devoted father of Megan, H. Christopher, Scott and Mark Frigon, Michele Spatzek and Stephanie Carreira, he is also survived by his brother, Donald Frigon, and 10 beautiful grandchildren. An international business executive and entrepreneur, Hank previously served as Chief Executive Officer of BATUS, INC, of Louisville, KY and Chief Financial Officer of Hallmark Cards, Inc. in Kansas City, MO. Hank's career included financial and management positions with Masco Corporation, General Housewares Corporation, General Foods Corporation and Chase Manhattan Bank. Board positions included: H&R Block, Packaging Corporation of America, Dimon Corporation, Tuesday Morning, Iams Corporation, CARSTAR Inc, Buckeye Technologies, Pulte Housing, Sypris Solutions and Nautilus International. Hank earned a BS in Engineering at Tufts University, an MBA from New York University, and graduated from Harvard's Advanced Management Program. He was a proud member of the Business Council at the University of Notre Dame, the Vail Valley Foundation, Legatus, and the American Association of the Knights of Malta. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Basilica of the Sacred Heart, University of Notre Dame, South Bend, IN on Wednesday, June 29th at 3:30pm. A visitation and rosary will be held in the Palmer Funeral Home-Hickey Chapel, 17131 Cleveland Road, South Bend, IN on Tuesday, June 28 from 4:00-7:00pm. In lieu of flowers, a donation can be made to the St. Clare of Assisi School in Edwards CO. More details may be found at palmerfuneralhomes.com.

HAIBLEN--Alfred, H.D.,of New York, born Cologne, Germany. Long-term resident of Montreal and Toronto. Beloved husband of over 64 years of Julia (nee Asch), passed away June 23, 2011. Graduate McGill University, 1946, Gold Medalist Electrical Engineering. Dear Dad of Jonathan (Trish) of Australia and Barbara (Micheal) of Alaska. Beloved grandfather of Joseph, Jess, Anna and Julia. Brother of Dorle (Germany). At the family's request, there will be no visiting hours. In lieu of flowers, donations of your personal choice or to Doctors Without Borders.

David Rayfiel, a screenwriter who in a long creative relationship with the director Sydney Pollack and Robert Redford collaborated on many of their most successful films, including ''Three Days of the Condor,'' ''Out of Africa'' and ''The Way We Were, '' but usually chose to keep his work anonymous, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 87. The cause was congestive heart failure, his wife, Lynne Schwarzenbek-Rayfiel, said.

HOROWITZ--Daniel James, died on June 21, 2011 at his home in Naples, FL. He was 80. The cause was pancreatic cancer. Dan was born May 13, 1931 in Manhattan, NY. His great-grandfather was one of the founders of the Horowitz-Margareten Matzah Company. His sister, the late Naomi Bliven, was a long-time writer for the New Yorker magazine. He graduated from the Bronx High School of Science and received a degree in English from Cornell in 1952. He served in the U.S. Army during the Korean War. Dan had masters' degrees from NYU (Education, Physics) and Virginia Tech (Information Systems). He married Laura Godofsky in 1967. They settled in Alexandria, VA, and had two daughters. Laura founded Editorial Experts, an editorial services firm. She died in 1983. Dan spent 25 years as a physicist in the Night Vision Laboratory at Ft. Belvoir, VA. Dan moved to Naples, FL in 2006. He is survived by his daughters, Ellen (Dr. Steven Goldberg) of Naples, FL, and Natalie (Christopher J. Prokop) of Montclair, NJ; as well as grandchildren Max, Mimi, Roman, and Veronica.

There weren't a lot of blacks in my high school graduation class - two, to be exact - which meant that race was somewhat of an abstraction, happening elsewhere, mostly on a screen or from the grooves of a record. And then I saw Clarence Clemons with Bruce Springsteen. Mind you, this was a stage, only a bit more of projected reality than television. Still, the Big Man and the Boss - opposites in look and style, Southern Baptist black and Jersey Shore white - projected a kind of joy that made it easy to believe that this mess of a country could get along. My friends and I came home from that first concert doing air saxophone riffs.

LEVITT--Gene. Beloved by all who knew him and friend to all who met him, a larger than life man of integrity, humor and generosity. Admired and respected for his deep and abiding contributions to his community and their institutions and his unconditional love for his family and friends. Gene was more a brother than brother-in-law to Harris and Helen, and a loving and devoted uncle to Julie. Our love goes out to Shirley, Marc, Joy, Diane, Sam and all of his grandchildren and extended family. He will be greatly missed. The Barer Family
BRODSKY--Judith. Memories are treasures -- and last forever. With love, Grace and Ruth
DePINNA--Marcia. Mommy, you left this earth 5 years ago, but you are always in my heart. Love you and miss you so very much, your Janie.

PORTLAND, Ore. -- The scene at the Bitter End Pub one recent Saturday was a sports bar's dream: With the Colorado Rapids about to face the hometown Timbers in a professional soccer game across the street at Jeld-Wen Field, hundreds of supporters of both teams were shoulder to shoulder, laughing and toasting their team's success. ''This could not happen in England, even among friendly fans,'' Chris Moyer, a Briton and member of a Rapids fan group, said of the bonhomie between rivals.

DEVLIN--Elizabeth Mary, born April 24, 1981, died peacefully on June 21 surrounded by her family after a two year battle with cancer. Lisi, as she was affectionately known, was the beloved daughter of Eugene and Lisbeth Devlin of Rye, NY. From the moment she was born, Lisi's radiant smile, bright outlook, effervescence, and natural grace affected everyone she met. Lisi spent her early education at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, CT and graduated from Rye High School in Rye, NY in 2000. She attended Fairfield University in Connecticut and after a yearlong absence to recover from AML Leukemia, graduated with a BA in Communications and a minor in Education. She received a Masters of Science in Education from Bank Street Teachers College in NYC with a duel certification in Early Childhood Special and General Education. Lisi was passionate about family, children and teaching. She thrived as an elementary and then pre-school teacher. Her colleagues had the utmost respect for her but, more importantly, her students adored her. She had a natural ability to relate and interact with children having never lost her sense of wonder. She is also survived by her three elder siblings, Jennifer Burke (husband Michael) of Ridgewood, NJ, Gene Devlin (wife Lilly) of Middlebury, VT, and Christie Furman (husband Michael) of Manhattan, NY, her adoring five nephews and three nieces, her 25 aunts and uncles and 32 first cousins. In lieu of flowers, donations in the memory of Elizabeth M. Devlin can be made to Bank Street Family Center for a scholarship fund. Send to Bank Street College, 610 West 112th Street, NY, NY 10025, attn. Carla Scheele. Memorial visiting is Sunday, June 26th at the Graham Funeral Home in Rye, NY from 2 to 6pm. Funeral Mass is on Monday, June 27th at The Church of the Resurrection in Rye, NY at 11:00am.

It was only April, but the Boston Red Sox were in trouble. Despite glowing preseason predictions, they started the season with six consecutive losses, and by April 15 their record was a dismal 2-10. Their vaunted lineup was hitting .224, and the pitching staff was allowing 6.6 runs a game. Alarms sounded throughout New England. In the ensuing hysteria it was learned that no American League team had ever overcome so shaky a start to qualify for the playoffs, let alone make a serious bid at the World Series. Surely such an omen meant the 2011 Red Sox were doomed.

George M. White, the architect who oversaw myriad federal projects on Capitol Hill, including the construction of the Hart Senate Office Building and the restoration of the old Supreme Court and Senate chambers in the United States Capitol itself, died Friday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 90. The cause was complications of Parkinson's disease, his daughter Jocelyn said.

Harry Potter is coming as an e-book. J. K. 3:57 p.m. | Updated While it tries to resolve a dispute with Time Warner Cable over the iPad, the cable channel owner Viacom is suing another cable operator, Cablevision, over the same issue. Viacom said Thursday it was taking the action because its discussions with Cablevision about licensing MTV, Nickelodeon and its other channels for iPad streaming have been ''limited and unproductive.''

They're young. They're in love. They kill people. And soon they're going to sing and dance on Broadway. Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow, those fresh-faced outlaws whose bank-robbing exploits thrilled Depression-era America (and inspired an Arthur Penn movie so violent it might as well have come with its own bib), will be the subject of a musical that will open at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater this fall, press representatives for the show said on Thursday. The Broadway production of ''Bonnie & Clyde,'' which has previously been presented at the La Jolla Playhouse in California and the Asolo Repertory Theatre in Sarasota, Fla., will star Laura Osnes (of the current revival of ''Anything Goes'') as Bonnie, reprising the role she originated in the earlier productions. Jeremy Jordan (''Rock of Ages,'' ''West Side Story'') will also star as Clyde, having played the character at the Asolo Rep. Jeff Calhoun, who provided musical staging for Broadway's ''Grey Gardens,'' will direct.

An article on Sunday about a plan to close Erikson School, a small school for children with severe behavioral problems, misspelled the surname of a special-education representative for the San Francisco Unified School District. He is Sam Janeway, not Jameway.

WEINSTEIN--Yada. March 31, 1928-June 21, 2011 in Fairfax, VA. Predeceased by parents Hattie and Harry Gladstone, husband Howard, brother Aaron and daughter Joy. Beloved mother of Tina Wallace and husband Steve. Adored grandmother of Hilary, Matthew and Josh. Loving aunt of Peter, Jay, Michael and Steven, and adoring sister Doris Berkman and husband Gerald. A friend to many and a smile for all.

LOS ANGELES -- Charlie and Carol Gasko seemed to be just another fading, elderly couple enjoying retirement in a modest apartment building a few blocks from the Pacific in Santa Monica. He told a neighbor he had emphysema and spent his days lying on the couch watching television. Carol would venture out for strolls on the nearby Third Street Promenade, stopping by the Saturday Farmers' Market or feeding a neighborhood stray cat. Often, he tagged along. But they were reclusive and a little odd, neighbors said. Charlie would often wear a baseball cap or fedora that shadowed his face. He would bark at neighbors when Carol lingered too long to speak to them, said one neighbor, who described him as ''a rageaholic''; Carol explained that he was suffering from dementia. In recent months, another neighbor said, a note was taped to their door reading, ''Please do not Knock at Any Time.''

Coming off of a big win over Li Na on Center Court just two days before, Lisicki now faced Doi, a lefty from Japan who had come through the qualifying at Roehampton.

WIMBLEDON, England — It was worth the jet lag and the hassle of two transatlantic journeys for Mardy Fish to be able to spend time with his baby on her second birthday. Her name is Charlie and she’s a dachshund that Fish, who is married to the Beverly Hills lawyer Stacey Gardner, described as “kind of like a child for us.”

Mikhail Youzhny advanced to a Round of 16 match with Roger Federer by convincingly defeating Nicolas Almagro, 4-6, 6-3, 7-6, 6-3, on Saturday at Wimbledon. On a sunny, breezy day on Court 18, they each competed at a high level, but Youzhny was mentally stronger, playing with unwavering concentration, bearing down especially hard on his service games. Remarkably, he was not broken in the last three sets.

WIMBLEDON, England — The Nets’ failure to make the playoffs for a fifth consecutive season was not all bad. It allowed Maria Sharapova to be reunited with her fiancé, Sasha Vujacic, a New Jersey guard, who traveled with her to the French Open and Wimbledon.

Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York had help in securing passage of the bill that will provide for equal treatment of same-sex couples under New York’s marriage law. Public opinion on the issue is shifting rapidly: 58 percent of New Yorkers support same-sex marriage today compared with 37 percent in 2004. Many allies were at work on the cause, from gay rights groups to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to the pop star Lady Gaga, who at a concert in Buffalo urged her fans to lobby the freshman State Senator Mark J. Grisanti, a Republican, to vote for the bill. (Mr. Gristani, initially considered a strong “no” vote, was one of four Republicans to support the measure.)

The days of dominance for the United States women’s national team — when it could count on defeating opponents with sheer athleticism — have passed. The women’s game has evolved, and teams around the world are showing greater skill and tactical sophistication.

Ever since I discovered mulberries growing in a park in Flushing, Queens, on the day of my grandmother’s death two years ago, the delight of finding summer berries has been bittersweet for me. Last week, I was having another difficult day when my fiancé and I took a walk in Central Park to search for the linden trees, which I thought would be in full bloom and would make a lovely tea. But our most recent heat wave had spurred an early flowering, and when we arrived in the area I call “Linden Hill,” the creamy-colored blossoms were already browning with age.

The United States will face Mexico in the Gold Cup final on Saturday night, which should surprise no one: those teams routinely dominate the event. But that does not mean that the tournament has not been full of surprises: Mexico was reduced to a 17-player roster for most of its games by injury and drug suspensions, and still outscored its first three opponents, 14-1.

WEINSTEIN--Yada. March 31, 1928-June 21, 2011 in Fairfax, VA. Predeceased by parents Hattie and Harry Gladstone, husband Howard, brother Aaron and daughter Joy. Beloved mother of Tina Wallace and husband Steve. Adored grandmother of Hilary, Matthew and Josh. Loving aunt of Peter, Jay, Michael and Steven, and adoring sister Doris Berkman and husband Gerald. A friend to many and a smile for all.

ARTS & LEISURE A cover essay this weekend about the online storage of music misstates the name of the Apple service that will scan and recognize music and add Apple's own copies without uploading. It is iTunesMatch, not iMatch.

Digitally savvy academics have been struggling to reconcile new media with traditional scholarly publishing, which is painfully slow and generally locked behind paywalls or unavailable online. One answer has been offered by the Roy Rosenzweig Center for History and New Media at George Mason University, which on Wednesday unveiled PressForward, a new open access platform for online scholarship. ''It's a major new initiative we're launching to change the landscape of scholarly communication,'' said Dan Cohen, a historian and the director of the center. With an $862,000 grant from the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, PressForward will collect everything from blogs to conference papers, reports and other projects created specifically for the Web.

Google confirmed on Friday that the Federal Trade Commission had opened an antitrust investigation into its core search and advertising business. The inquiry has the potential to turn into the biggest showdown between the United States government and a major technology company since the Microsoft antitrust trial that began in the late 1990s.

8 P.M. (HBO) GOING THE DISTANCE (2010) Justin Long and Drew Barrymore, above, play Garrett and Erin, lovers trying to maintain a bicoastal romance -- she's an aspiring newspaper reporter in San Francisco; he's a record label grunt in New York -- amid lowered romantic and professional expectations in this comedy from Nanette Burstein. The film, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, ''acknowledges both the difficulty and the comic potential of the arrangement, and does so with enough insight and charm to make you wonder why frequent-flier love is not a more popular theme in romantic comedies,'' even though the scenario ''sounds kind of sad, even dreary.'' He added: ''Happy solutions to intractable problems are what romantic comedies are supposed to supply, of course, and while 'Going the Distance' hardly breaks the generic mold, it has enough honesty and charm to set it apart from most other recent examples.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Deborah Potter explores the separation of church and state in France and the modern manifestations of the country's secularism, including the prohibition of public displays of religious beliefs and the recent ban on veils worn by some Muslim women. In another segment Lucky Severson looks at the Creation Museum in Kentucky and the plans of its chief executive to build a theme park called the Ark Encounter that would include a full-size Noah's Ark. Tax breaks have been granted to the proposed park to create jobs in a depressed region, but those opposed to them complain that they violate the separation of church and state, and that teaching creationism instead of evolution sends the wrong message about Kentucky.

New York City's Office of Chief Medical Examiner said on Thursday that it was conducting an investigation into the death of a stagehand at the Broadway musical ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.'' Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner's office, said that an autopsy was conducted on the stagehand, a 29-year-old man whose name has not been released, and that it would be ''a couple of weeks'' before the results of further study and testing were available. Ms. Borakove said that toxicology tests would be conducted.

At 9:40 a.m. Thursday, a man stood across from the World Trade Center site covered in paint. With his whitened face, he looked, thought Koos Koning, a Dutch tourist, as though it were Sept. 11 all over again. ''Maybe he came out of the World Trade Center with a white face and ashes.''

BOCOUR--Peter. Painter and designer, died June 23 from leukemia. Born in New York City in 1947, the son of Leonard Bocour, a manufacturer of paint for artists, he grew up in the world of the arts. He attended NYU, Cornell, and Berkeley. His work was exhibited at the Sarah Renschler, RC Fine Arts, Allen, and Algira galleries. His paintings were characterized by brilliant colors and energetic movement. He lived in Montclair, NJ. Beloved husband of Nina Pellegrini Bocour, father to Angelica and Nicola, and grandfather to Oliver, he will also be missed by brothers Charles and Paul Hirsch. The funeral will be at Moriarty Funeral Home, 76 Park St., Montclair, NJ, Sunday, June 26, at 2 p.m. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

MENON--Girija. 1950-2011. Retired Division One Officer of the Administrative and Diplomatic Service of the Government of Malaysia, she passed away from complications arising from cancer in New York on Sunday, June 19. She was a founding member of Educational Welfare and Research Foundation and also worked with artistic organizations in Kuala Lumpur. In 1991, she married Malaysian playwright-director and New York attorney Kannan Menon at the Hindu Temple in Flushing, Queens, New York. She was the Producer of a number of her husband's productions, including, Haze Fever in 1997 (Kuala Lumpur) and At A Plank Bridge in 2003 (New York). In 1997 she completed her LLB from the University of London. Funeral services will be held at the Park Hill Funeral Home, 102-17 101 Avenue, Ozone Park, New York at 11.00am on June 25th. The service will be streamed live on the web. For more information or to leave condolence messages please visit: FranciscoFuneralHome.com

ING Direct USA account holders are reacting to the sale of the online bank about as well as they would if Capital One's famous television barbarians had battered down the doors of their homes. Social media sites, including ING Direct's own Facebook page, and banking blogs have erupted with customer antipathy for the deal, which was announced last week. A sale was required by European regulators as a condition of financial assistance given to ING's Dutch parent bank during the banking crisis. ING Direct, headquartered in Wilmington, Del., offers savings accounts, checking accounts, mortgages and brokerage services to 7.7 million customers.

In a project that will hopefully be completed in less time than it took for Brian Wilson to finish ''Smile,'' an independent production company is preparing a biographical film about Mr. Wilson, the troubled pop music genius and creative force behind the Beach Boys. River Road Entertainment, which has previously produced features like ''The Tree of Life'' and ''Fair Game,'' said that it is developing a film about Mr. Wilson, who with his brothers, Dennis and Carl, and Mike Love and Al Jardine formed the Beach Boys in 1961. That band's groovy hits include ''Surfin' U.S.A.'' and ''Good Vibrations,'' as well as the album-length mini-masterpiece ''Pet Sounds.'' River Road Entertainment said in a statement that its film would ''take an unconventional look at Wilson's unique musical process as well as his struggles with mental illness, and how he managed to persevere as an artist with the love and support of his wife Melinda.'' The company has secured the musician's life rights for the project, and Oren Moverman, the director and co-writer of ''The Messenger,'' will write its screenplay. No title or release date for the film was given, and its producers haven't announced which actor will be lying in bed just like Brian Wilson did.

LEVITT--Gene. Beloved by all who knew him and friend to all who met him, a larger than life man of integrity, humor and generosity. Admired and respected for his deep and abiding contributions to his community and their institutions and his unconditional love for his family and friends. Gene was more a brother than brother-in-law to Harris and Helen, and a loving and devoted uncle to Julie. Our love goes out to Shirley, Marc, Joy, Diane, Sam and all of his grandchildren and extended family. He will be greatly missed. The Barer Family

NEW YORK Because of an editing error, an article on June 15 about new data from the New York State Education Department showing a lack of college preparedness among students misstated the place where only 6 percent of students who graduated in 2010 after four years of high school were deemed ready for college or well-paying careers. It is the city of Rochester, not Rochester County. (There is no Rochester County in New York; Rochester is in Monroe County.)

Cee Lo Green's summer just got a little less busy. Mr. Green, whose song ''---------- You'' helped him earn four Grammy Awards nominations, and win one in February, has been performing as an opening act on Rihanna's tour in between his appearances on ''The Voice,'' the hit NBC talent show. But on Friday Mr. Green dropped out of the tour, citing a busy schedule that includes not only his TV commitment but preparations for a book and a new album.

JOHN HULS, outside the Stonewall Inn in Greenwich Village after the New York Legislature voted to approve same-sex marriage. [A3]

DEVLIN--Elizabeth Mary, born April 24, 1981, died peacefully on June 21 surrounded by her family after a two year battle with cancer. Lisi, as she was affectionately known, was the beloved daughter of Eugene and Lisbeth Devlin of Rye, NY. From the moment she was born, Lisi's radiant smile, bright outlook, effervescence, and natural grace affected everyone she met. Lisi spent her early education at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, CT and graduated from Rye High School in Rye, NY in 2000. She attended Fairfield University in Connecticut and after a yearlong absence to recover from AML Leukemia, graduated with a BA in Communications and a minor in Education. She received a Masters of Science in Education from Bank Street Teachers College in NYC with a duel certification in Early Childhood Special and General Education. Lisi was passionate about family, children and teaching. She thrived as an elementary and then pre-school teacher. Her colleagues had the utmost respect for her but, more importantly, her students adored her. She had a natural ability to relate and interact with children having never lost her sense of wonder. She is also survived by her three elder siblings, Jennifer Burke (husband Michael) of Ridgewood, NJ, Gene Devlin (wife Lilly) of Middlebury, VT, and Christie Furman (husband Michael) of Manhattan, NY, her adoring five nephews and three nieces, her 25 aunts and uncles and 32 first cousins. In lieu of flowers, donations in the memory of Elizabeth M. Devlin can be made to Bank Street Family Center for a scholarship fund. Send to Bank Street College, 610 West 112th Street, NY, NY 10025, attn. Carla Scheele. Memorial visiting is Sunday, June 26th at the Graham Funeral Home in Rye, NY from 2 to 6pm. Funeral Mass is on Monday, June 27th at The Church of the Resurrection in Rye, NY at 11:00am.

An article on June 14 about the increase in New York City elementary and middle school students who must attend summer classes this year to be promoted misstated the level that students must have scored to be required to attend summer school. It is only Level 1, not Levels 1 and 2.

KEEFE--Anna E.,passed away on June 23, 2011. Mother, wife of more than forty years, friend, healer and helper of many, Anna in her larger-than-life way and with her abundance of talents, enabled and assisted countless individuals during her more than thirty years of private practice as a psychotherapist in Manhattan and Scarsdale, NY. She was also a former Executive Director of the Training Institute in New York City. More than a person, Anna was a presence, a life-force, a creative power and a grace in its most spiritual sense. Her skills went beyond psychotherapy. She was also an artist in the kitchen and, with her decorating skills, an artist in every other room of the house as well. But most of all, Anna was an artist in understanding and transforming others. She is survived by her husband, Martin, their daughter, Casey, and her brother, Anthony. Friends may call at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home in Bronxville, (914-337-6770) 2 to 4 and 6 to 9pm, Sunday, June 26. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Monday, June 27 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Jansen Hospice, 69 Main St., Tuckahoe, NY 10707 (914-961-8654).

ROTH--Posie Robins, died on June 8, 2011 from breast cancer. She was born on March 22, 1954 in New York City, the eldest of the late Fay Robins Roth and the late Herbert Roth. She graduated from Forest Hills High School after which she attended Clark University, graduating in 1976, later earning a Master's Degree in Cultural Geography. In 1987 she graduated from The American Center for the Alexander Technique in New York City and embarked on a career as an Alexander teacher. In 1993 she moved to Colorado. She was a uniquely dedicated and loving mother. She is survived by her son Max Green of Chicago, daughter Faye Green of Denver, sister Beth Roth of Connecticut, sister Jinny Isserow of Virginia, Godmother Gorena Brown of North Carolina, and other relatives and close friends. She will be remembered with extraordinary love and admiration, and live forever in our hearts. Funeral service to be held Sunday, June 26 at 10:00am, IJ Morris Funeral Parlor, 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, NY 11550.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Wednesday about Thomas N. Armstrong III, a former director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, referred imprecisely to his tenure as director of the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh. Although he was the director when the museum opened in 1994, he was not the museum's first; Mark Francis was director from 1989 to 1993, when the museum was in the planning stages, and subsequently became its curator.

ROSEN--Ruth K.,90, of West Hartford, CT, formerly of Bethpage, NY and Delray Beach, FL, died June 23, 2011. Widow of Leon Rosen. Daughter of the late Armin and Gizella Klein. Mother of David J. Rosen (Susan) of New York, NY, Mark I. Rosen (Lynn) of Roxbury, CT, and Hanora L. Rosen Berman (Ed) of New York, NY; sister of Samuel Klein (Rosalind) of Florida and the late Herbert Klein; five grandchildren; and six great-grandchildren. Strong, indomitable, devoted to family and friends, successful in her professional life. Funeral will be Sunday, June 26, 2011 at 11:00am at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I., NY. Shiva will be observed on Monday in Bloomfield, CT and New York, NY, and on Tuesday in New York, NY.

FRONT PAGE An article on Friday about the capture of James (Whitey) Bulger, once Boston's most fearsome crime boss, and his companion, Catherine Greig, misstated the location in Santa Monica of the apartment building where theylived and were arrested. It is just off the corner of Third Street and Washington Avenue, not on the corner of Third Street and California Avenue, which is a block south.

ALBANY -- Lawmakers voted late Friday to legalize same-sex marriage, making New York the largest state where gay and lesbian couples will be able to wed and giving the national gay-rights movement new momentum from the state where it was born. The marriage bill, whose fate was uncertain until moments before the vote, was approved 33 to 29 in a packed but hushed Senate chamber. Four members of the Republican majority joined all but one Democrat in the Senate in supporting the measure after an intense and emotional campaign aimed at the handful of lawmakers wrestling with a decision that divided their friends, their constituents and sometimes their own homes.

MAGAZINE An article on Page 36 this weekend about Jon Huntsman, who recently announced he was running for president, misidentifies the recipient of a letter whom Mr. Huntsman praised as having a ''brilliant analysis of world events.'' It was President Bill Clinton, not President Obama. The article also quoted incorrectly from a U.S. News & World Report article in 2009 in which David Plouffe, Mr. Obama's campaign manager in 2008, discussed his feelings about Mr. Huntsman as a potential opponent for Mr. Obama in 2012. Mr. Plouffe did not use the phrase ''a wee bit queasy''; those words were used by the U.S. News & World Report writer to describe how Mr. Plouffe felt.

WASHINGTON -- The House dealt a symbolic blow to President Obama on Friday by resoundingly rejecting a bill to authorize United States military operations in Libya. But the chamber also defeated a measure that would have limited financing to support those efforts. The result, coming after weeks of tension between Congress and the White House over authorization of American military aid for the NATO mission in Libya, was a mixed message to the Obama administration, with Republicans and Democrats forming alliances that splintered customary party lines.

The exhibition galleries at the Smithsonian's Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum will close on July 4 for a two-year renovation and expansion. The project, which starts this fall, is part of a $64 million capital campaign that includes a 60 percent increase in exhibition space, improvements to the National Design Library and an increased endowment. During the renovation of the Carnegie Mansion, scheduled to be completed in 2013, Cooper-Hewitt's exhibitions, events and education programs will be staged at various off-site locations. The show ''Design with the Other 90%: Cities,'' for example, opens Oct. 15 at the United Nations and runs through Jan. 9, 2012. Admission to the museum will be free from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on July 4 to mark the closing of the final exhibition, ''Set in Style: The Jewelry of Van Cleef & Arpels.'' The museum's terrace, garden and shop will remain open this summer without an admission fee. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

YEGELWEL--Bernard H.,age 85, of Teaneck, formerly of Fair Lawn, died Wednesday. Beloved husband of Bunny, devoted father of Eric and Gail Yegelwel, Jodi and Tony Senese and Caren and David Gutwetter. Cherished grandfather of Robin, Sam, Elyse. Ben, Anthony, and Sarah. Bernie was a CPA. Services 12noon, Sunday at Louis Suburban Chapel 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West) Fair Lawn, NJ.

BRADY--Wilfred T.,III, (Ted), 62, of Keyport, New Jersey, passed away, Wednesday, June 22, 2011, at Bayshore Community Hospital, Holmdel. Born in Long Island, he resided in Hazlet before moving to Keyport. He worked in Operations as a VP with Mitusbushi UFJ Trust and Banking Corp, NYC, retiring in August 2010. He served his country in the Navy during Vietnam. Wilfred was predeceased by his parents, Wilfred T. Brady, II and Marie Hammond Brady. He is survived by his loving children, Heather Brady of Keyport and Tara Brady of Hazlet; his dear siblings, Joan Brady of Arizona; John Brady and his wife, Pam of Ohio; Kathleen Hartman and her husband, Charlie of California; Jane Brady of California; and Marianne Conte and her husband, Gabe of Florida; and one cherished grandchild, Brynn Champagne. He will be dearly missed by all who knew and loved him. Family and friends are invited Saturday, June 25, 2011 and Sunday, June 26, 2011, from 2-4 and 7-9pm, Day Funeral Home, 361 Maple Place, Keyport; and Monday, 9am, with a 9:30am service at the funeral home. Interment to follow at Pinelawn Cemetery, Long Island, NY. To offer the family online condolences or for directions to the funeral home, please visit www.dayfuneralhome.com.

LATTIMORE--Martha, of New York City and Lattimore, NC. It is with great sorrow that we, her friends in New York City, mourn the loss of our cherished Martha. We extend our warmest sympathy to her beloved family: her mother, Mary Frances Lattimore; her brothers, John and Tom Lattimore; her nephews, Alex, Edley and Lee Lattimore; and their dearly loved children.

WIMBLEDON, England - The greatest opportunity of Ryan Harrison's professional tennis career was slipping through his fingers, as evidenced by the racket skidding onto the court. For four sets, the 19-year-old Harrison had kept his cool and turned up the heat on David Ferrer, the No. 7 seed from Spain. He went to sleep Thursday night leading Ferrer by two sets to one and trailing, 2-4, in the fourth.

FOX--Lester. It is with great sadness we announce the death of Lester Fox, 77, of New York and Montauk, on June 23, 2011. Lester was the loving husband of Audrey for 55 years. For many years they enjoyed traveling the world together. He was the very proud father of Russell (Andrea), Spencer (Amy) and Caryn (Michael), and proud grandfather of Erik, Matthew, Dorrie, Brandon, Hayley, Connor and Brendan. Lester attended New York University, became a CPA and later received his MBA from New York University. Family was his first love and he drew great satisfaction from his second love, being an esteemed financial professional and providing valued advice to his many clients. He will be deeply missed.

The Brooklyn Museum announced Thursday that it had elected a new chairman, John S. Tamagni, an investment banker who has served on the board for more than 30 years. He will succeed Norman M. Feinberg, who has led the museum's board since 2006. Born and raised in Brooklyn, Mr. Tamagni, is also a trustee of the Orchestra of St. Luke's and an overseer of the Hood Museum of Art at Dartmouth College, where he is an alumnus. He takes over at a time when the museum continues to contend with the lingering effects of the economic downturn; citing a lack of money, it recently canceled plans to mount a New York version of ''Art in the Streets,'' a show of graffiti and street art now under way at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles.

Wouldn't it be nice to have a mortgage where the interest rate begins with the number ''3?'' More borrowers seem to think so, as more of them are opting for adjustable-rate mortgages, whose rates have become even more alluring compared with fixed-rate mortgages.

The first round of the N.B.A. draft on Thursday night had an international flavor, with 10 of the players having been born outside the United States. Even Canada got into the mix, producing two first-rounders. But the story of the night was the resurgence of Eastern Europeans, with six players from that region going in the first round. Recent N.B.A. history has seen a number of stars hailing from Western Europe, like Dirk Nowitzki of Germany, Pau Gasol of Spain and Tony Parker of France, but this year's first-rounders hearkened back to the N.B.A.'s earlier European imports like Drazen Petrovic, Vlade Divac and Arvydas Sabonis.

Everyone knows that having a good credit score qualifies you for lower interest rates on loans and better terms on credit cards. But it can also affect the rates you pay for car insurance - sometimes quite significantly, when the savings are measured over time. The most important factors in setting rates generally are your age, where you live and driving record, says Des Toups, senior managing editor of CarInsurance.com, a rate-quoting Web site. But most insurers also check your credit when quoting a rate, because there's a correlation between your score and the likelihood you will file an insurance claim. The higher the score, the less likely you are to file one.

DONNENFELD--Dr. Alvin M.,died peacefully at home, June 24th, after a long battle with renal disease. He is survived by Eleanor, his wife of 63 years and his children Marc, Gail and Penny, their spouses Cathy and Paul and his grandchildren Beatrix, Alex and Jake. He was an innovative and visionary obstetrician/gynecologist who worked to better conditions for pregnant women and their partners and supported the out-of-hospital birthing movement as medical advisor to the Maternity Center Association on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. His practice was far reaching. He touched the lives of thousands of families and served as an inspiring mentor to countless students. We will miss him. The funeral will take place at "The Riverside" on Sunday, June 26 at 11:45am. Shiva will be observed on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday evenings, starting at 6:30pm at the Donnenfeld Residence, 160 East 84th St., Apt 3D.

Caroline Wozniacki and Dominika Cibulkova, who play for a place in the quarterfinals Monday, met in the third round of the Australian Open. Cibulkova jumped out to an early lead by playing grip-it-and-rip-it tennis, going for winners early and often against the steady Wozniacki. It was impressive for the first few games, but Wozniacki gave Cibulkova one too many balls, and the unforced errors mounted for Cibulkova.

In a PGA Tour playoff duel between former Clemson teammates this season, the gloves were off. Lucas Glover dispatched Jonathan Byrd on the first extra hole in a shootout that thrilled Tigers fans and no doubt led to sweaty palms in the highly lucrative golf glove industry.

Tomas Berdych, last year’s surprise Wimbledon finalist, has regained his winning form on grass after a disappointing clay-court season. At 6-foot-4, Berdych has a big first serve and follows it up with a cleanly hit forehand that is fast, heavy and generated with little fuss. His tremendous power comes from his legs, which may be the strongest in tennis. His game is simple: serve big, keep the backhand deep and in play, and wallop his classic-style forehand.
Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo took the hero’s stroll down Fifth Avenue Sunday, his reception from the Gay Pride masses somewhere between loving and rapturous. And who could argue?

It’s a truism that in Paris suits are not for Suits, which Scorecard knows was exemplified Saturday by Kris Van Assche’s whiteout of superskinny-lapel jackets and dropped-crotch high-waters accessorized with wide-brimmed toppers on the Dior Homme runway. Too bad, then, that Raf Simons had to make it all look literally old hat with his witty display of that creative industry favorite — plaid — in a former bank headquarters. It might just be hip to be square.

Pixar’s “Cars 2” overcame surprisingly negative critical reviews to overperform at the weekend box office, selling an estimated $68 million at North American theaters. That No. 1 finish extends Pixar’s perfect box-office track record — all 12 of its feature films have opened in first place. How sales hold up, however, will be watched carefully. “Cars 2,” directed by John Lasseter, chief creative officer at Pixar, represents an end to the studio’s perfect critical track record; only about 34 percent of reviews were positive, according to RottenTomatoes.com, by far the worst for any Pixar title.The R-rated comedy “Bad Teacher” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was a stronger-than-expected second with about $31 million in ticket sales — a result that cements mega-raunchy films as one of Hollywood’s best performers of the moment. “Green Lantern” (Warner Brothers) fell 65 percent in its second weekend to third place, taking in about $18.4 million for a new total of $89 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. “Super 8” (Paramount Pictures) continued to show strength in its third weekend, selling about $12 million for a new total of $95 million. “Mr. Popper’s Penguins” (20th Century Fox) was fifth with about $10.3 million for a two-week total of $39.4 million.

Just a thought suggested by some economic discussions I’ve followed, including the comments on this blog: many people seem to have a hard time accepting that there are intermediate positions, in particular that you can question free-market, hard-money dogma without being a wild man. To say that some inflation can sometimes be a good thing does not mean advocating hyperinflation; to call for deficit spending in slumps does not mean saying that debt and deficits never matter; and so on.

STRICKMAN--Arthur, passed away June 9, in Rancho Mirage, CA just before his 87th birthday. Previously of Roslyn Heights and Lenox, MA. Pre-deceased by his beloved Rosemary. Father of Ellen Walsh, Wendy Hoffman and Nancy Stein. Grandpa to William Perry, Arthur, Zachary and great-grandpa to Gia. Services were private.

In her Riff column, Heather Havrilesky nailed it. ''Friday Night Lights'' is the awkward, too-big-for-his-age defensive tackle with a heart of gold who can't get the girl; ''Glee'' is the talented, chic nerd who can't help showing off. ''Friday Night Lights'' will be as relevant 10 years from now -- hopefully still in syndication -- as it is today. ''Glee'' will age badly, destined to become a cultural artifact marking an era but unable to transcend it. Like bell-bottoms. KEVIN COOL, Palo Alto, Calif.

Change is in the air for rewards programs linked to debit cards, like those that let users bank airline miles with each purchase. For Chase Continental debit card holders, this will mean no more miles. Last year, when Congress enacted the regulatory financial reform law, an amendment by Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, effectively put many debit-card rewards programs on death row.

A cover essay this weekend about the online storage of music misstates the name of the Apple service that will scan and recognize music and add Apple's own copies without uploading. It is iTunesMatch, not iMatch.

EVANS--Harold M.,90, passed away June 24, 2011, surrounded by his loved ones. He is survived by his beloved wife of 57 years, Anne, daughter, Suzan Hochberg (Mitchell), son, Dr. Richard Evans (Rachel), and his cherished grandchildren Isabelle, Julia, Ross and Jessica. We will forever miss his sense of humor and love of laughter; unique curiosity and life lessons taught. He lived his life with integrity, honesty, and with the highest set of standards and values to pass down to next generations. He was a talented craftsman, jeweler and highly regarded authority of antique jewelry. In 1938, he founded the Jamaica Silversmith, a jewelry manufacturing and restoring company; and was a pioneer in the mail order business, a forerunner to online marketing. He was an avid athlete and sports fan. He enjoyed motorcycling, tennis, horseback riding, baseball, and the occasional game of poker. Above all, it was life's simple pleasures and the love of his family that he most cherished.

ROSENFELD--Lillian, nee Altman, wife of the late Arthur S. Rosenfeld, beloved mother of Linda Pomper and the late Mark Rosenfeld, beloved grandmother of Lauren Orenstein, Robin Ellenberg, Daniel and Ariana Rosenfeld, and great-grandmother of four.

ARMSTRONG--Thomas N. III. In recent years, Tom has been a meaningful part of the Sotheby's community, contributing his broad experience in the art world to many of our endeavors and sharing his enthusiasm with an admiring circle of colleagues. We will miss his wit, and charming presence with the omnipresent bow ties and canvas tote bags, assumed to be filled with a mass of architectural and horticultural temptations. We extend our deep felt sympathies to Bunty, his family and many friends. The Officers and Staff of Sotheby's, New York

JEAN PAUL GAULTIER'S first major retrospective opened this month at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts, to the delight of more than 2,000 fans. ''The Fashion World of Jean Paul Gaultier: From the Sidewalk to the Catwalk,'' which runs until Oct. 2, collects four decades of couture and ready-to-wear pieces by theme (The Boudoir, Urban Jungle) and includes photographs (Ali Stephens by Thierry Le Gouès, left), videos, sound recordings and memorabilia from the designer's childhood. Among the looks on display were sheer tattoo-covered bodysuits, a nude corset with metal cone breasts and a white lace dress with cutouts in the shapes of religious icons. Fashion's enfant terrible was nearly upstaged by the exhibition's talking mannequins, with anthropomorphic faces so expressive that some visitors mistook them for real people. SHIRINE SAAD

The days of dominance for the United States women's national team - when it could count on defeating opponents with sheer athleticism - have passed. The women's game has evolved, and teams around the world are showing greater skill and tactical sophistication. The United States, for the most part, has dealt with these changes admirably, as Coach Pia Sundhage has in the last few years led her players through something of a philosophical transformation.

The In the Region article in some copies last Sunday, about the new preference among developers of low-income housing in Elizabeth, N.J., for building rental units rather than condominiums, misidentified the location of the Stafford Park development. It is in Stafford Township, not Barnegat. The article also misstated the land's previous use. It was a landfill, not the site of a former strip club. Because of an editing error, the article misstated the type of housing units in the development's luxury component. They are rentals, not condos.

ABRAMSON--Robert Joseph, age 89, passed away on June 19, 2011. As a young soldier during WWII, Bob worked as a war correspondent for YANK Magazine, the serviceman's magazine. He took part in the invasion of Normandy and both covered and fought in many of the principal battles in the European theatre of operations, including Monte Cassino and the Battle of the Bulge, for bravery during which he was awarded the Bronze Star. He was present at the liberation of Dachau, and was one of the first American soldiers to enter liberated Paris. After the war Bob co-founded, with his brother Arnold, Universal Publishing and Distributing Co. which launched The Family Handyman magazine and the Nick Carter series of books. An avid golfer, Bob believed there was a market for golf enthusiasts and developed and launched Golf Magazine, one of the earliest successful "special interest" magazines. Following the success of Golf, Bob went on to launch Ski Magazine, which was similarly successful. In 1976, Bob founded RJA & Associates, the first literary agency devoted to the international licensing of periodical rights. The agency continues to exist today, run by his daughter Libby. Bob was a smart, funny and supremely confident man. He was successful in most everything he did, took enormous pleasure in life, and will be missed by all who had the privilege and the joy to know him. Bob leaves behind his loving wife Hilda, his children Libby, Saralynn and Richard, his grandchildren Leslie, Matthew, Nina, Emily, Jonathan and Michael, and his great-grandchildren Jake, Liam, Drew, Ava, Chloe and Madeleine.

WILLENBUCHER--Marguerite "Peg," on June 24, 2011. Loving wife of the late William. Devoted mother of Marguerite "Peggy" and Paul, Robert and Jane. Dear grandmother to Sarah and Joseph. Cherished sister of Nora and the late Mamie, Kathleen, Jim, Patrick and Daniel Rieder. Beloved aunt of Ted, Richard "Dick," Patricia, Marguerite, Annie, George, Tom, Carol, and the James. She will also be missed by many friends, in particular Ann, Stephanie, Sofia, Jak and Liz. Visitation Sunday 2-4pm and Monday 2-4 and 6-8:30pm, "The Riverside", 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Service Tuesday 10:00am, Christ and St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 120 W. 69th Street.

A brief report on June 5 in the Also Out This Week column, about the release of the DVD of the film ''Another Year,'' misspelled the given name of one of its lead actresses. She is Lesley Manville, not Leslie. The report also misstated the actor who portrays Gerri, half of the film's long-married couple. She is Ruth Sheen, not Ms. Manville.

DURBIN--Betty Lehman, died on June 11 peacefully at home in Seattle after long illness, surrounded by loving family. Betty lived in New York until 1966 and never lost her New York accent or attitude. We will dearly miss her wit, honesty, and compassion.

Loved it -- laughed out loud several times while reading. Wished Sullivan would have given his thoughts on the following: childless middle-aged adults visiting the park who routinely shove little kids out of the way to get to a ride; massive people eating roasted turkey legs like wild jackals in the animal kingdom; Lark-scooter-riding people (because of age or obesity) running down aforementioned little children; and best of all, young honeymooners who proudly wear special bridal Mickey and Minnie ears in the Magic Kingdom (bride's ears are white with a modest little veil).

RESORT'S scuba-style, wet-suit-inspired pieces (i.e., Derek Lam's sexy scuba sweater, left) make you want to dive right in. For those with deep pockets, there's no need to wait until November. This front-zippered maillot from Balenciaga by Nicolas Ghesquière leaves you panting for flippers. It's $685 at Balenciaga boutiques, or call (212) 279-4440. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

TOMITA--Iwao. It is with deep sadness that the firm of Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu LLC (hereafter Tohmatsu), the Japanese member firm of Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu Limited, announces the death of Iwao Tomita. He died on June 6, 2011, in Tokyo, surrounded by his family. One of the founding partners of the Japanese public accounting firm Tohmatsu, Mr. Tomita was 86 years old. He was a respected partner of Tohmatsu, and later a senior advisor to Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu International. In a final message to his family and colleagues, he said, "My mission is accomplished." That mission was to establish Tohmatsu as the leading public accounting firm in Japan, not only in size but also in professional standards and quality of service. One of Mr. Tomita's proudest moments was when Deloitte Haskins & Sells merged with Touche Ross in 1990, and the two international firms invited Tohmatsu to join them as an equal to form Deloitte Ross Tohmatsu International, which changed to Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu International in 1990. At the time, J. Michael Cook, chairman and CEO of Deloitte & Touche in the United States, referred to Tohmatsu as the crown jewel of the international organization. "We have had no more global citizen, and no one more committed to our global organization. Tomita deserves significant credit for the global growth of our services for Japanese headquartered companies," said Jim Quigley, global CEO of DTTL until May 31, 2011. Quoted in a history of the Japanese firm published in 1995, Edward Kangas, then chairman of Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu International, said, "Tomita-san has been a man of vision, a man who proposed practical implementation of his vision and a very good friend." Many people are visionaries and strategists, but they can't translate their ideas into action. Tomita-san has an incredible capacity to translate his strategy and vision into action in a powerful way." In 1967, the Deputy Minister of Finance asked Mr. Tomita to organize the first nationwide public accounting firm. It was to be established to accomplish two main objectives: the first, to be capable of reporting to the Securities and Exchange Commission in the United States according to U.S. accounting standards; the second, to establish offices overseas. He allied himself with former Admiral Nobuzo Tohmatsu to found Tohmatsu in 1968. Three years later, Mr. Tohmatsu withdrew from the business due to an incapacitating stroke; Mr. Tomita continued pursuing their original goal of making a truly international accounting firm for Japan. Mr. Tomita later succeeded to the position of chief executive officer. In 1975, Tohmatsu became a member firm of Touche Ross International, and Mr. Tomita was asked to join the international Board of Governors. The alliance meant that, rather than establish separate offices as it had done in New York, Tohmatsu would instead send forth a wave of professionals to be assigned to Touche Ross offices worldwide, coinciding with the rise of the Japanese economy. What began as a firm with a few offices in Japan is today an organization with a workforce of over 6000, including 658 partners, and professionals posted on long-term assignments to more than 40 locations outside Japan where they serve the unique needs of Japanese companies operating overseas. Today, the founders' goal is realized: Tohmatsu is one of the largest and the most international professional services firm in Japan. From the founding of the firm, Mr. Tomita traveled extensively to establish Tohmatsu's presence abroad, beginning in San Francisco and quickly spreading throughout the Americas, Europe and Asia. Until months before his death, Mr. Tomita kept up a heavy travel schedule, averaging 150 days annually outside Japan. In the past decade he increased his efforts in Asia, where he saw the most growth potential. His ability to see and shape the future led him to send a Tohmatsu professional to the People's Republic of China as early as 1979 to start the long process of establishing an office in Beijing. Wherever he traveled, he met with Tohmatsu professionals assigned overseas, to offer advice and encouragement. "Tomita-san's extraordinary vision and courage as a founding partner of our Deloitte Japan Tohmatsu member firm and his global mindshare in his actions over many decades is a lesson for us all in As One behavior long before we termed this vision. We will miss his presence though will reap the benefits of his legacy for many years to come," said Barry Salzberg, global CEO, Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu Limited. Mr. Tomita was preceded in death by Yoko Tajima Tomita, his wife of 54 years. He is survived by three daughters; eight grandchildren; and four great-grandchildren. Funeral services were held June 10 at St. Ignatius Church in Tokyo. A memorial service will take place Tuesday, July 5, 2011, in Tokyo from 11:00am to 1:00pm at the Imperial Hotel "Fuji No Ma."

RIORDAN--George Nickerson, died on May 27, 2011, at home in Pasadena, CA, after a long illness. He was 78. George was born in Patchogue, NY, and raised in Brooklyn, where he graduated from Erasmus Hall. In 1955, he received a B.S. degree from the School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell University. From 1955-57, he served as an officer in the United States Air Force. He then earned an MBA at Harvard Business School in 1960. He started his investment banking career at Lehman Brothers in New York. After joining Blythe, Eastman, Paine, Webber, he moved to Los Angeles, where he became Managing Director of Corporate Finance in 1980. Later, he was also Managing Director of Corporate Finance at Prudential-Bache in Los Angeles. He ended his career as Chairman of the Board of MSC Software Corporation. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Ann Wiggins Riordan; his daughter, Susan Milligan Riordan; his son, Peter George Riordan; his brother, Arthur Whelden Riordan; and four grandchildren. Mr. Riordan and his family spent summers in Quogue, NY, from the early 1960s until 2006. A Memorial Service will be held at the Presbyterian Chapel, Quogue, NY, on July 16, at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, those who wish to may contribute to VNA-Hospice, 3452 E. Foothill Blvd., Pasadena, CA 91107, or The Quogue Historical Society, P.O. Box 1207, Quogue, NY 11959.

LA RIBERA, a neighborhood in downtown Barcelona, is best known as the city's medieval quarter. After the 1992 Olympics, however, dozens of trendy boutiques opened, and today, this barrio, which Barcelonians more often refer to as El Born (after a local market that dates from the 19th century), is as much a destination for shopping as it is for historic sites. Juxtaposing old and new, these spots are housed in centuries-old buildings on the grand Calle Princesa and a number of tucked-away cobblestoned side streets. SHIVANI VORA

MILWAUKEE - Evan Longoria is the oldest of four siblings - the youngest a 16-year-old brother - and he has established high expectations at the start of his major league career. In each of his first three seasons with the Tampa Bay Rays, Longoria has been an All-Star, voted to start at third base the last two years. At 25, he would seem to be a safe bet to make it every summer. Longoria will be in Arizona when the game is played July 12 in Phoenix, but only because he lives in Scottsdale. With a .232 average through Friday, he has little hope of making the team.

ROTHENSTEIN--Edward M.,most recently of Delray Beach, Florida, passed away peacefully on June 24, 2011. He was 85 years old. A kind, generous and vivacious person, Mr. Rothenstein was the son of Albert and Florence Rothenstein of New York City and Woodmere, New York, and the brother of the late Howard Rothenstein of Boca Raton, Florida. Mr. Rothenstein held Bachelor's and Master's degrees from the Ohio State University and served in the United States Navy during World War II. He had a long and successful career in the electronics industry, served for many years in several positions at Temple Beth-El in Cedarhurst, New York, and continued his community and charitable activities after retiring to Florida in the late 1990s. His family, many friends and the communities to which he contributed so much will remember him for his sense of humor, keen intellect and eagerness to be of service to those who would benefit from his help. Mr. Rothenstein is survived by his devoted wife of 61 years, Shirley (nee Block); his daughters Barbara Budasoff and Julie Morgenstern; sons-in-law Daniel Budasoff and Saul Morgenstern; grandchildren Alana Budasoff Kanzer, Peter Morgenstern, Larry Budasoff and Emily Morgenstern; grandson-in-law Adam Kanzer; and his many close friends, all of whom love, and will miss him, dearly. A service will be held at 10:00am on Monday, June 27, 2011 at the Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, New York 10522. (914-693-3330). www.edwardsanddowdle.com In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Valencia Falls Cancer Research Chapter, c/o Pap Corps, 1192 East Newport Center Drive, Deerfield Beach, Florida 33442.

Twenty years ago, I circumnavigated upstate New York with my 10-year-old son, an ex-husband and a neighbor family with two boys in two 20-foot motor boats. It took us 10 days to go 700 miles, never knowing where we would spend the night. We had fabulous adventures of a modest kind, and loved the travel through all the canals and locks. There is a speed limit on the Erie Canal to prevent erosion, and the authorities will impound your boat if you get to the next lock before your time. SALLY GIDDINGS SMITH, East Boothbay, Me.

THE newly opened Ruschmeyer's in Montauk, N.Y., is a 20-room hotel, restaurant and bar that feels like a cross between an old-school camp (it was one, in the 1950s) and a chic hippie commune with tepees on the lawn. Formerly the Second House Tavern, Ruschmeyer's now has white paper ''moons'' hanging from the trees in the Magic Garden, a quiet spot that sits right on Fort Pond. Locals, surfers and families have been ordering the Montauk white clam pizza with chili and green monkfish curry in the restaurant, which is run by the guys behind the Fat Radish on Orchard Street. The attractive staff members (the men are in J. Crew shirts and boat shoes; the women wear Madewell striped shirts and shorts) deliver cocktails like the Gin Dandy, with cucumber and ginger. There's also a buzzy late-night bar. Rooms start at $475 on weekends: (631) 668-2877 or visitruschmeyers.com. JULIE EARLE-LEVINE

The Queens entry last Sunday in the Four Boroughs section of the Residential Sales Around the Region column misidentified the neighborhood where 71-36 Kessel Street is located. It is Forest Hills, not Forest Hills Gardens.

MOSCOW -- The billionaire owner of the New Jersey Nets basketball team, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, was elected leader of a Russian political party on Saturday in the first foray of a big businessman into politics here in nearly a decade. Tall, lithe and an avid basketball player himself, Mr. Prokhorov had been publicity shy for years, mostly confining his appearances outside the boardroom to sports events. Recently, though, he has become a magnet for attention, and is poised to play a significant though still uncertain role in Russian politics.

GENS--Louise Reeder. Louise Reeder Gens, 98, died peacefully June 4, 2011 in Hilton Head Island where she resided the past 18 years. Formerly from New Canaan, Connecticut, she was the widow of the late John Paul Gens, MD, and predeceased by her daughter Gretchen and sister Cathleen. She is survived by her sons John Paul Jr. of Portsmouth, NH, and David of Annapolis, MD, respective wives Mary and Rose, grandchildren Cathy, Eric, Maggie, Christine, Ryan and Jennifer, four great-grandchildren, and her two nieces Carolita and Camilla and cousin John Rohrbach. She was born in the Panama Canal Zone to Dennis and Mini Reeder, and graduated from Mount Holyoke College '33. She was a loving wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. In her very full life, she pursued a wonderful "joie de vivre" which she expressed in many ways by a passion for reading, gardening, tennis, charities, traveling and financial investing. She influenced everyone around her with her great spirit, wisdom, and most of all her kindness. A burial will be held in Darien, Connecticut on July 2nd, 2011, followed by a Memorial Service at the First Congregational Church of Darien at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to the "Cypress Club" for the Memorial Peace Garden which she helped create, at 20 Lady Slipper Lane, HHI, SC, 29926. She will truly be missed by all. Ciao Bella!
KANTER--Beverly Brilliant, predeceased by dear husband Hal. Mother of Drs. Steve, Roy, Merrill (Carolin). Sister of Corinne Brilliant Gitter. Her light will shine on forever.

LAST summer it was all about Silly Bandz, those brightly colored rubber bands in odd shapes that the junior set wore stacked as bracelets. This summer, the jewelry designer Lisa Salzer of Lulu Frost, along with her orthodontist sister, Jennifer, and Jennifer's partner, Dr. Marc Lemchen, have come up with the newest must-have: a bangle that is one part middle-school torture device and all parts fun. Each of the rubber links (available in a myriad of neon and neutral shades) are connected by metal brackets that those of us without overbites never had to endure. But thanks to medical technology, we're all brace-faced now! They're $4.99 each at bracedlets.com. EDWARD BARSAMIAN
To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Hallowed and Imperfect Ballpark,'' June 20: Thank goodness for the perspective of Carlos Pena as he contemplates his good fortune to play baseball at Wrigley Field.

The Economic View column last Sunday, about bipartisan agreement on aspects of health care reform, misstated the status of means-testing -- a financial test for determining eligibility -- as it relates to Medicare. Although proposals might add such testing, it already exists in some parts of the program, in the form of higher premiums for people with certain income levels.

An article on Page 36 this weekend about Jon Huntsman, who recently announced he was running for president, misidentifies the recipient of a letter whom Mr. Huntsman praised as having a ''brilliant analysis of world events.'' It was President Bill Clinton, not President Obama. The article also quoted incorrectly from a U.S. News & World Report article in 2009 in which David Plouffe, Obama's campaign manager in 2008, discussed his feelings about Mr. Huntsman as a potential opponent for Mr. Obama in 2012. Mr. Plouffe did not use the phrase ''a wee bit queasy''; those words were used by the U.S. News & World Report writer to describe how Mr. Plouffe felt.

IT is an American impulse to covet the new and improved -- whether it's a faster computer, a smarter cellphone or a more fuel-efficient car. And in medicine, too, new drugs, devices and procedures have advanced patient care. But the promise of innovation can also prove a trap, a situation now playing out with dire consequences for possibly tens of thousands of people who received artificial hips intended to let them remain active.

Derek Jeter, the Yankee captain, as we are often reminded, emerged from the visitors' dugout about two hours before a game last month at Baltimore's Camden Yards and into late-afternoon sunshine. ''Derek!'' a middle-aged man in a Yankees cap called out from the first row of seats. ''Hey, buddy, how you doin'?'' Jeter said, giving a glance over his shoulder but not breaking stride. He continued on toward home plate, where several Orioles players stepped away from their pregame batting practice to shake his hand.
Manhattan Gramercy Park Area $380,000

FOX--Lester. It is with great sadness we announce the death of Lester Fox, 77, of New York and Montauk, on June 23, 2011. Lester was the loving husband of Audrey for 55 years. For many years they enjoyed traveling the world together. He was the very proud father of Russell (Andrea), Spencer (Amy) and Caryn (Michael), and proud grandfather of Erik, Matthew, Dorrie, Brandon, Hayley, Connor and Brendan. Lester attended New York University, became a CPA and later received his MBA from New York University. Family was his first love and he drew great satisfaction from his second love, being an esteemed financial professional and providing valued advice to his many clients. He will be deeply missed.

MILLER--Robert Peter, 72, who supported the careers of many significant contemporary artists, died from complications arising from a staph infection on June 22nd in Miami, Florida with his children by his side. He had been in poor health for many years and had retired to Florida more than a decade ago to paint for his own pleasure and spend time swimming and collecting. In the early 1960s shortly after earning a MFA degree in painting from Rutgers University, Mr. Miller moved to Manhattan at the urging of Roy Lichtenstein, for whom he had been a teaching assistant, and Lee Krasner, for whom he had been a studio assistant, intending to pursue a career as a painter. During this period he had two exhibitions at Martha Jackson Gallery, however, these were not commercially successful and he became focused on promoting the work of other artists. By 1966 he was a director at Andre Emmerich Gallery working with such artists as his friend David Hockney and eventually became a partner there. In 1977 he and his wife, Sarah Wittenborn Miller, opened the Robert Miller Gallery Inc. at 724 Fifth Avenue. Within a few years the gallery moved to the second floor at 41 East 57th Street. During these years he developed enduring friendships as well as working relationships with Robert Mapplethorpe, Rodrigo Moynihan, Alex Katz, Bruce Weber, Al Held, Lee Krasner, Patti Smith and Milton Resnick. Perhaps his most important contribution to the arts was his support of underrepresented voices in contemporary art, particularly those of female artists and open homosexuals. It is a testament to his dedication that many of these artists have now joined the 20th century canon and that the difficulty of their art within the historic context it was originally presented in has been forgotten. He established an international reputation working directly with some of the most important and influential artists of the last three decades such as Louise Bourgeois, Gilbert and George, Yayoi Kusama, David Hockney, Leon Kossoff, Lee Krasner, Robert Mapplethorpe, Joan Mitchell, Alice Neel, Georgia O'Keeffe, Patti Smith, Andy Warhol, and Tom Wesselmann, and with the estates of Diane Arbus, Eva Hesse and Jean-Michel Basquiat. He was a man of eclectic tastes; he loved to find unusual objects at flea markets as well to collect what he believed to be important art, antiquities and cultural artifacts. Over the years Mr. Miller became increasingly disenchanted with the changing art world and the speculation in art that he thought made it difficult for young artists to maintain their integrity and brought many older artists bitterness. In 1988 he said, One of the things that people equate with art's being of interest is that it so expensive... Perception and possession have so little to do with each other. You cannot possess much of the great art of the world, but you can perceive it, particularly through reading. With all the increased art activity, people are reading less and that opportunity to perceive is slipping away. So what people do is they seize the art, in order to think they have it. Miller painted throughout his life. He showed his work at Martha Jackson Gallery 1965, Nicole Klagsbrun Gallery, 1999, Dorothy Blau Gallery, Miami, 2000, Dorsch Gallery, Miami, 2001 and J.Johnson Gallery, Jacksonville, 2003. Robert Peter Miller was born in New Jersey on April 17, 1939. He is survived by his children, Robert Peter Miller Jr. Sarah Elizabeth Miller, Christopher Richard Miller, and a grandson, Alden Miller Gaussoin all of Manhattan and two brothers, Alfred Peter Miller III and Paul Joseph Miller. A memorial service is being planned for the fall.

Eric Swenson, a founder of Thrasher, a magazine that re-energized the sport of skateboarding and helped propel it from a suburban teenage activity to an international form of recreation and a competitive sport, died on Monday in San Francisco. He was 64. The cause was suicide; he shot himself in front of a police station, the police said.

PELLICANE--Richard, 79, died June 18th in Southampton, NY. He is survived by his partner Ilse Wolff, his sister Mary, four children Mary, Joe, Kate and Lora (Vincent) and three grandchildren Gina, Conner and Lauren. Richard who was known as "Dick", was the youngest of five children; his parents emigrated to the U.S. from Sicily circa 1905. Born and raised in Queens, NY, he served in the U.S. Marine Corps after graduating from Adelphi College. Subsequently he attended Columbia Law School from which he graduated in 1958. Dick went on to have a long and fulfilling career as an attorney. He was a passionate person who read voraciously and loved to write; he enjoyed the beaches of Southampton and the gardens at his home. Dick had a great sense of humor, loyalty and a generosity that touched many. We will all miss him. Services were private. In lieu of flowers, you may honor Dick's memory with a donation to hospice or the charity of your choice.

In advance of the 10th anniversary of 9/11 and the opening of the 9/11 Memorial on Sept. 12, NYC & Company, the official marketing, tourism and partnership organization for New York City, is encouraging tourists to visit, dine, shop and stay in the downtown area. The Get More NYC: Lower Manhattan campaign, which runs until Sept. 6, includes special events and art exhibitions, and highlights weekend promotions at hotels like the Andaz Wall Street and W New York-Downtown. The hotel promotion includes a complimentary Downtown Culture Pass, offering free admission and discounts to attractions like the New York City Police Museum and Museum of American Finance. Other discounts are offered until July 31.

A WHOLE LOT of money was spent on residential real estate in the last week, with deals closing on 10 properties that were listed for over $6 million, four of them for over $10 million, according to Streeteasy.com.The biggest sale was a three-bedroom three-and-a-half-bath condominium at 15 Central Park West that closed for $24.5 mil- lion, according to Streeteasy.com and city property records.And, as is often the case at 15 Central Park West, the sale of the 3,100-square-foot unit, which was last listed for $27 million, reflected a huge profit. It last sold in June 2008 for $11.7 million. It was listed in October 2010 for $25 million, and the asking price rose by $2 million a month later, records show.Big Ticket includes closed deals from the previous week, ending Wednesday.SARAH KERSHAW

At the Open House In addition to inspecting the property, prospective buyers should ask how the auction will work, if proof of income or seriousness is required, if the auction is absolute (meaning the seller will accept any price), and whether there is a buyer's premium. Most auction houses charge a premium of 5 to 10 percent of the total purchase price.

TAKE a mansion for sale on a singular block of Fifth Avenue, designed by a Gilded Age architect whose work defined an aesthetic that forever changed the landscape of the well-to-do corners of New York, throw in a $49 million price tag, and you have a blockbuster listing that is going on the market this weekend. The mansion at 973 Fifth Avenue, with its grand Italian Renaissance Palazzo style and more than 15,000 square feet of living space on seven floors, was built for Henry H. Cook, a banker and railroad tycoon, and completed in 1907, a year before the architect, Stanford White, was shot and killed by the jealous husband of a former lover. It was one of the last buildings White designed, in the swan song of Beaux Arts architecture, before Modernism began to overtake the Renaissance ideal, architectural historians say.
