MANY day trips and overnight stays -- especially to outlying towns and cities in southern Europe where weekend hours for shops and tourist sites can seem almost whimsical -- often do little more than whet one's appetite to return for a proper visit. But, at less than two hours by car from Lisbon, an overnight visit to the storied Portuguese city of Évora and the surrounding area packs a lot into relatively little time. To start, there is the stunning combination of Roman, Gothic and Baroque architecture for which Évora has been designated a Unesco World Heritage Site. But there are many other aspects to the city, which is a bit like its churches -- seemingly staid and whitewashed on the outside until you step inside to discover sumptuous interiors adorned with gleaming gold leaf and thousands of dazzling tiles.

A review on June 12 about two books on Jane Austen misstated the medium of a 1995 adaptation of ''Pride and Prejudice'' in which Colin Firth appeared as Mr. Darcy. It was a television mini-series, not a film. The review also misidentified the director of the mini-series. It was Simon Langton, not Andrew Davies. (Davies was the screenwriter.)
The Look picture feature on Page 45 this weekend, about the Fashionetta Debutante Cotillion in St. Louis, misspells the given name of an attendee. She is LaKeySha Bosley, not LaKeSha.

WELCH--Earlene Ynes Hornbostel Wirsching. Passed away on June 20, 2011, at the age of 59. She was the beloved daughter of Elizabeth Valdez Wirsching and Norbert R. Wirsching and cherished sister of Elizabeth del Alamo and Margaret Still, loving wife of Teed Welch, devoted mother of Theodore TJ Welch, and dear sister-in-law of Constancio del Alamo and Gary Still. Earlene was a beautiful, intelligent, and accomplished woman. She attended the American School in Manila, the Philippines, and graduated from the International School in Hong Kong. She received her Associate's Degree from Tobe-Coburn School for Fashion Careers, her B. A. in Economics from Columbia University School of General Studies, and her M.B.A. from Columbia University. Earlene worked for Nabisco Brands / Planter's Peanuts Division, Kiddie Products/The First Years, and for IBM's Marketing Communications Division. She retired in 1998 to become a full-time Mom. Her family loves her, and will always hold her dear in our hearts. Elizabeth, Norbert, Bunny and Margie

DONNENFELD--Dr. Alvin M.,died peacefully at home, June 24th, after a long battle with renal disease. He is survived by Eleanor, his wife of 63 years and his children Marc, Gail and Penny, their spouses Cathy and Paul and his grandchildren Beatrix, Alex and Jake. He was an innovative and visionary obstetrician/gynecologist who worked to better conditions for pregnant women and their partners and supported the out-of-hospital birthing movement as medical advisor to the Maternity Center Association on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. His practice was far reaching. He touched the lives of thousands of families and served as an inspiring mentor to countless students. We will miss him. The funeral will take place at "The Riverside" on Sunday, June 26 at 11:45am. Shiva will be observed on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday evenings, starting at 6:30pm at the Donnenfeld Residence, 160 East 84th St., Apt 3D.

In his second start for the Pittsburgh Pirates, in August 2008, Jeff Karstens took a perfect game into the eighth inning against Randy Johnson and the Arizona Diamondbacks. As his former Yankees teammates watched on television before their game at Texas, Karstens got two outs before a double ruined his attempt. ''I can still see the pitch Chris Young hit down the line,'' Karstens said last week over the phone from Pittsburgh. ''It was probably my worst slider of the day. But early in that game, I was really lucky because they hit four fly balls that traveled about 1,600 feet.''

ROGEBAN, Libya --Until a few weeks ago, the rebellious towns in the Nafusah Mountains were struggling to survive on dwindling supplies of barley, water and gas during a long siege by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's soldiers. But after an improbable series of military victories over the past three weeks -- with fewer than 100 rebel fighters killed, their military leaders say -- residents of a broad area in this mountain region are celebrating virtual secession from Colonel Qaddafi's Libya. While there have been defeats, and the Grad rockets of Colonel Qaddafi's forces still menace the outskirts of Nalut near the Tunisian border and Yafran to the east, rebels point hopefully to the growing stability of the towns under their control as evidence of how tenuous Colonel Qaddafi's grip may be.

ANNETTE ROGERS: We were in Key West on the second night of a weeklong vegan cruise called Holistic Holiday at Sea. I was tired but also very nervous because my fiancé, a doctor, had to speak about the benefits of the vegan lifestyle, and I had to work on his PowerPoint presentation. I was like: ''It's game time. O.K., here I am, the little blond fiancée. I look like a Barbie doll or a bimbo. And I'm really not. And I've got to pull this thing off, and I've got to be smart, and I've got to be on it.''

Social Lights Additional images atnytimes.com/magazine. To some, the Fashionetta Debutante Cotillion in St. Louis is from a bygone era: a yearlong public-service program that culminates in a black-tie event, at which young women are formally ''introduced'' into local society. The ceremony features white-gloved male escorts and choreographed movements, including a dramatic deep curtsy. (''To me, it represented a new beginning; we were opening up to the world,'' said Miss Fashionetta 2011, LaKeSha Bosley, 18. ''And when we got back up, we were women.'') Fashionetta is also about making plans for college (participants receive scholarships), meeting people and learning skills like runway walking and behavior on formal interviews. ''We did so much practicing,'' Bosley said, ''but it was worth it.''

AT the women's fall shows in March, John Galliano's arrest and dismissal from Dior dominated the week. Now the spring men's shows are under way, and though Mr. Galliano, looking thin and barely audible, was on trial this week, there was virtually no discussion in the front row about him or the racial-insult case. One reason is that the editors and writers who cover men's wear are less familiar with Mr. Galliano than those on the women's side. True, the Galliano brand sells men's clothing (a show by the design team will be presented tonight), but he is best known for his women's fashion at Dior, which transformed a decidedly stodgy French label.

GAMBLE--Diane Elaine, community leader and accomplished business woman, died peacefully at her home on Tuesday, June 14. The cause was cancer. She was 73. At the incipience of the internet boom, Diane had a front row seat, serving as President and CEO of Link Resources, Inc., a market research firm specializing in emerging communications technologies. After Link was acquired by International Data Group, Inc. she served as an executive of various research departments in the Walt Disney Company and American Broadcasting Company. Prior to career in market research, she worked for the then Governor Nelson Rockefeller, both in Westchester County, New York City and Albany. She had a broad interest in her community, ultimately becoming President of the Junior League of Westchester on Hudson and President of the New Castle Historical Society. She was also very active in the formative years of what became the Westchester Symphony Orchestra. She is survived by her husband, Lex and son, Alex and his wife Carol; and 21 nieces, nephews and cousins.

GLINE--Doris Gline (nee Ferber), 92, wife of the late Seymour Philip Gline, died peacefully at home in Manhattan on June 20, 2011. Born June 11, 1919, Doris was a graduate of art and design from the Pratt Institute and a lifetime New Yorker. Doris is survived by her daughters and their husbands, Lauri Gline Lefkowitz of Leonia, NJ (Howard), Mari Gline Plotkin of Short Hills, NJ. (David); and four grandchildren Marc Alan Lefkowitz and Stephanie Carey Lefkowitz, and Adam Jonathan Plotkin and Elizabeth Ann (Plotkin) Keil. World traveler, fan of "good jazz," tremendously modern, always pretty, and fiercely independent, Gramma is well loved and will be terribly missed.

On the corner of State and Camp, I came upon a Google Street View car at a stop sign. The driver was a young, husky guy with mirrored shades, a faint goatee and a phone pressed to the side of his head. The car was painted in bright colors with the Google logo, and jutting upward from the roof was a small tower on which sat a bright red ball that contained a camera. It looked like a giant penis with an eye. I was on my Vespa, and I pulled over. The car crossed State Street and headed up Camp, toward Audubon Park. California plates. I took out my iPhone, turned on the camera and pursued. The adrenaline that coursed through me contained a mixture of surprise, excitement and hostility. Cameras are ubiquitous in any city, especially in New Orleans -- there are the parents of little kids,always snapping away; the tourists framing this house, that tree; and the many movie sets, gargantuan operations set up like medieval encampments. Landlords talk excitedly about renting to ''movie people.''

In the Metropolitan cover story last week, N. R. Kleinfield profiled Carol Einhorn and her family -- her son, Griffin; her friend George Russell, Griffin's biological father, who lives with her part time; and Mr. Russell's partner, David Nimmons, with whom he lives the rest of the week. Following are excerpts from reader comments posted on NYTimes.com: What childish people! This will be the lesson they teach the poor kid: Flake around, build your life around someone eminently unreliable, hold your breath and hope he doesn't run away; ask nothing, expect nothing, give nothing. Accidentally do something serious by having a child, then refuse to commit to the child, and announce that refusal in The New York Times as your child looks on. How terribly sad.

KEEFE--Anna E.,passed away on June 23, 2011. Mother, wife of more than forty years, friend, healer and helper of many, Anna in her larger-than-life way and with her abundance of talents, enabled and assisted countless individuals during her more than thirty years of private practice as a psychotherapist in Manhattan and Scarsdale, NY. She was also a former Executive Director of the Training Institute in New York City. More than a person, Anna was a presence, a life-force, a creative power and a grace in its most spiritual sense. Her skills went beyond psychotherapy. She was also an artist in the kitchen and, with her decorating skills, an artist in every other room of the house as well. But most of all, Anna was an artist in understanding and transforming others. She is survived by her husband, Martin, their daughter, Casey, and her brother, Anthony. Friends may call at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home in Bronxville, (914-337-6770) 2 to 4 and 6 to 9pm, Sunday, June 26. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Monday, June 27 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Jansen Hospice, 69 Main St., Tuckahoe, NY 10707 (914-961-8654).

Also survived by cousins Robert, Susie and Dewey Wigod, Cantor Emily Wigod Pincus and Leon, Dr. Judith and Alex Jacobson. Dear brother-in-law of Innis and Rosemary Shoemaker. Last week, Jack McKeon, 80, was rehired to manage the Florida Marlins. McKeon's managerial career started nearly 40 years ago, making his the second-longest span in baseball history. A look at the five men whose managing careers spanned the most years.

TRIBECA has never really gelled as a fashion destination. But Patron of the New may change all that. Its owner, Al Abayan, who ran the vaunted No. (N)ine for years, is on a constant quest to stimulate jaded palates. With a décor that recalls the interiors of Jean-Michel Frank and a high-low inventory that includes the goth designs of Nicolas Andreas Taralis and Zilla's weird but chic handbags made from sponges, Patron of the New invites shoppers to wander and explore. Plans for dinner parties, art openings and made-to-order floral arrangements are in the works. Mr. Abayan said, ''The shop is really how I live.'' Patron of the New, 151 Franklin Street (Varick Street), (212) 966-7144; patronofthenew.com. NANCY MacDONELL

We might wish politicians and pundits from opposing parties to engage in reasoned debate about the truth, but as we know, this is not the reality of our political discourse. Instead we often encounter bizarre and improbable claims about public figures. Words are misappropriated and meanings twisted. I believe that these tactics are not really about making substantive claims, but rather play the role of silencing. They are, if you will, linguistic strategies for stealing the voices of others. These strategies have always been part of the arsenal of politics. But since they are so widely used today, it is worth examining their underlying mechanisms, to make apparent their special dangers.

Here's a sampling of readers' comments on Robin Pogrebin and Daniel J. Wakin's article about New York City Opera and its financial problems. ''The situation that City Opera now finds itself in cannot be blamed on its attempt to bring adventurous programming to 'the people.' The blame is on New York City's so-called leaders who don't care about opera, or classical music. Germany supports some 78 opera houses that all do what we would call wild productions, where the thought behind the voice is considered more important than luscious high notes. The problem lies with closed-minded audiences and uncaring official leaders.''

FALK--Peter. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of Peter Falk, a great friend to our Taub Institute for Research on Alzheimer's Disease and the Aging Brain. His ongoing generosity was vital in helping our researchers continue their work uncovering the causes of Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and other age-related brain diseases and discovering ways to prevent and cure these diseases. All of us at Columbia extend our condolences to his wife, Shera Danese, his daughters, Jackie and Catherine, and to the rest of his family. Lee Goldman, MD Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Executive Vice President, Columbia University Richard Mayeux, MD, MSc Gertrude H. Sergievsky Professor of Neurology, Psychiatry & Epidemiology Chairman, Department of Neurology Co-Director, Taub Institute Michael L. Shelanski, MD, PhD Delafield Professor and Chairman Department of Pathology and Cell Biology Co-Director, Taub Institute

The board of directors of The Robert Mapplethorpe Foundation mourns the loss of Robert Miller, founder of the Robert Miller Gallery, which represented Robert Mapplethorpe with great distinction during the artist's life time, and The Mapplethorpe Foundation for many years thereafter. Bob Miller and the Gallery helped to develop Mapplethorpe's career into one of significance and international recognition. He was a valuable advisor and friend to the artist as well as to those who remained to manage the artist's legacy. Our thoughts and sympathies are with the Miller family and all those who share this loss. Classical Steve Smith
To the Editor:

EVER since I discovered mulberries growing in a park in Flushing, Queens, on the day of my grandmother's death two years ago, the delight of finding summer berries has been bittersweet for me. Last week, I was having another difficult day when my fiancé and I took a walk in Central Park to search for the linden trees, which I thought would be in full bloom and would make a lovely tea. But our most recent heat wave had spurred an early flowering, and when we arrived in the area I call ''Linden Hill,'' the creamy-colored blossoms were already browning with age. Disappointed, we walked toward the road to look at the juneberry trees. The week before, the berries had been small and whitish-green, but when we arrived, the trees' branches were heavy with thick clusters of pink and reddish-violet fruit, ripe for plucking. A small European starling landed on an upper branch and grabbed a rose-colored berry in its beak.
LAMLE--Betsy. Our heartfelt condolences to Hugh and Alexandra on their sudden loss. Our thoughts and prayers are with you during this difficult time. Stacy and Jonathan Hochberg

My two friends and I don't expect a Nobel Prize. We don't expect to have a bridge or a building named after us. None of the great scientists think in those terms while pursuing their breakthroughs; they think only of the good their research might do for humanity. That's what we were thinking about as we sat in assorted public places on an 80-degree evening taking turns wearing a pair of purple earmuffs and a ridiculous knit cap made to look like a kitten's head. At least, I'm pretty sure that's what we were thinking. It was actually somewhat difficult to concentrate because of the racket the bagpipers and tuba players were making.

An article last Sunday about wrongful convictions in Illinois misstated the name of a group that, along with the Better Government Association, conducted a study analyzing the economic and social costs of 85 wrongful convictions. It is the Center on Wrongful Convictions, not the Center for Wrongful Convictions.
Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the Core Club, a private club in New York, misstated the year the Union Club, another such organization, was founded. It was 1836, not 1863.

EBELING-KONING--Blanche T. van Berckel PhD, of Greenbelt, MD passed away on May 25, 2011 while recovering from surgery. Born in The Netherlands on January 20, 1928 she spent her adult life in the USA working in the academic world as a rare books librarian at the libraries of Harvard, University of Maryland, Catholic University, Brown and the Smithsonian Archives. She is predeceased in 1987 by her husband, Jacob J. Ebeling-Koning. Surviving her are her step-children, Natasha EK Sigmund of Brooklyn, NY, Derek Ebeling-Koning of Allison Park, PA, Gwen EK Waddington of Shelter Island, NY and their families. In the Netherlands, she is survived by her sisters, Ann Blijdenstein, Marthe Ankersmit, and sister-in-law Mary van Berckel, plus ten nieces and nephews. Her magnum opus, the translation of van Baerle's "The History of Brazil under the Governorship of Count Johan Maurits of Nassau, 16361644" will be published this fall. A brief memorial service was held in D.C. Correspondence can be addressed to: Derek Ebeling-Koning, 3266 Wagner Rd., Allison Park, PA 15101.

The Stanley Feingold Luncheon Group meets every other month - an argumentative gathering of City College graduates and the provocative political science professor who taught them a half-century ago. The meetings are usually held in the sky-view conference rooms of prestigious law firms, where some of Mr. Feingold's former students now toil.

Capturing Glasgow's industrial heritage and its geographic link to the sea, the new Riverside Museum ( glasgowlife.org.uk/pages/default.aspx), designed by Zaha Hadid, has just opened. Though Ms. Hadid lives in London, this museum devoted to transportation and travel is her first major commission to open in Britain. The £74 million ($119,524,000) project fronts a bend in the River Clyde, historically the central waterway for Glasgow's shipbuilding industry. Its V-shaped design features a ridged roof pattern that resembles waves on the water, when seen from above. These pleats create sharply peaked windows on either end of the building that overlook the river.

Social Lights Additional images atnytimes.com/magazine. To some, the Fashionetta Debutante Cotillion in St. Louis is from a bygone era: a yearlong public-service program that culminates in a black-tie event, at which young women are formally ''introduced'' into local society. The ceremony features white-gloved male escorts and choreographed movements, including a dramatic deep curtsy. (''To me, it represented a new beginning; we were opening up to the world,'' said Miss Fashionetta 2011, LaKeSha Bosley, 18. ''And when we got back up, we were women.'') Fashionetta is also about making plans for college (participants receive scholarships), meeting people and learning skills like runway walking and behavior on formal interviews. ''We did so much practicing,'' Bosley said, ''but it was worth it.''

ARMSTRONG--Thomas N.,III of Manhattan and Fishers Island, NY, died on June 20, 2011. He is survived by his wife Bunty, his four children, Thomas N. Armstrong IV, Whitney B. Armstrong, Eliot A. Foote and Amory A. Spizzirri; his sister Susan A Watts and seven grandchildren. Tom was the director emeritus of the Whitney Museum of American Art, Chairman of the Garden Conservancy in Cold Spring, NY and a trustee of the New York School of Interior Design in Manhattan. A memorial service is planned for Wednesday, June 29th at 11:00am in Manhattan at Saint Bartholomew's Church, 325 Park Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Garden Conservancy, PO Box 219, Cold Spring, NY 10516.

Only in the City of Light is the question “Men in skirts or men in suits?” an endlessly fruitful topic of discussion. On the final day of the Paris men’s-wear shows, Scorecard knows that at the iconic belle époque watering hole Maxim’s, Thom Browne’s biannual surreally performative undermining of heteronormativity melted a bit under scrutiny. Meanwhile over on the stock exchange, Lanvin’s poetic designers Alber Elbaz and Lucas Ossendrijver told their boys to man up — in a Byronic hero kind of way.

It’s no surprise that trenches are a mainstay of the fall collections, but seeing them at the resort shows reminds us that they’re a fashion staple. This resort season, Bibhu Mohapatra and Mulberry showed classic khaki, while Lanvin and Nina Ricci favored glamour over utility, casting their versions of the iconic topper in neutral silks. At the prefall collections designers like Marni, Céline and Emilio Pucci reinvented the staple with patent leather, shorter hems and tweed. These not-so-basic basics are worth the investment.

When Jon Caramanica made his first trip to Eau Claire, Wisc., to interview Justin Vernon for a profile in the magazine, the second Bon Iver record wasn’t even mastered. (You don’t want to put all your energy into the Peter Frampton profile to coincide with the release of “I’m in You.” Not that the first Bon Iver record, “For Emma, Forever Ago,” is exactly analogous to “Frampton Comes Alive!” But you get the picture.)

Maria Sharapova dominates matches with her big first serve and her fearless return. She excels in the first two shots of each point, putting enormous pressure on her opponent with her unbridled aggression. On Monday she gave Shuai Peng a lesson in power tennis on grass, winning, 6-4, 6-2, to advance to the Wimbledon quarterfinals.

In today’s Science Times, Jane E. Brody, personal health columnist, writes about vertebral fractures, the common compressions in the bones of the spinal column that can lead to chronic back pain, loss of height and hunched posture.

In an article in Monday’s Times, I write about various strategies that European cities are using to cut down on private car use and inner-city driving. In Zurich, a multipronged approach has left residents less likely to own a car and less likely to use one if they do.

It was Friday, June 24. In Albany, the State Senate was voting on a bill to legalize same-sex marriage. In New York City, the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, was anxiously awaiting the decision in her Lower Manhattan office, a cellphone glued to her right ear and her longtime partner, Kim Catullo, on the line.

Trust Dolce & Gabbana to come up with a cat’s meow of a compact. Its new Animalier Bronzer, designed by the makeup artist Pat McGrath in the house’s signature leopard print, is almost too chic to brush away. The limited-edition bronzer ($50 at saks.com) offers spot-on smoldering shades that are surprisingly versatile. Dust a bit below the cheekbones and along the jaw for a fresh, sun-kissed glow, or play with the lighter, more neutral browns to emphasize the brow line. You can even create a smoky eye using the mahogany and umber tones. We’re purring already.

Jets wide receiver Braylon Edwards’s driving record is far from pristine. He has been pulled over for speeding at least seven times since 2002 and was arrested for a D.W.I. in Manhattan last September after he blew a .16 breathalyzer.

Starting in the fall of 2012, travelers to Amsterdam will have to make do with fewer artistic masterpieces, as the Van Gogh Museum closes for a six-month refurbishment.

On a low-rated Sunday night of network television, CBS’s line-up of “60 Minutes” and reruns delivered the most viewers in prime time, while NBC’s second season premiere of “The Marriage Ref” struggled, garnering just 4.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. “60 Minutes” attracted the night’s largest audience with 7 million viewers at 7 p.m.; after that CBS broadcast repeats of “Hawaii Five-0” (4.9 million), “Undercover Boss” (4.8 million) and “CSI: Miami” (5.2 million) until 11 p.m. NBC ranked second for the night despite the modest showing for “The Marriage Ref” at 10. NBC broadcast an encore of last week’s “America’s Got Talent” and it averaged 5.4 million viewers an hour from 8 to 10. ABC was third over all with repeats of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” (3.9 million), “Castle” (4.2 million), and “Body of Proof” (4 million). Fox ranked a distant fourth with reruns of its regular Sunday night comedies.

American Ballet Theater plans to take up residence at City Center from Nov. 8 through Nov. 13 to present a combination of new work and revivals. The opening-night gala will kick off with a new ballet choreographed by Demis Volpi, a member of the Stuttgart Ballet. Twyla Tharp’s “In the Upper Room” and Martha Clarke’s “Garden of Villandry” will also be performed that evening. Among the works audience members will get a chance to see later in the week are revivals of Merce Cunningham’s “Duets,” with music by John Cage; Paul Taylor’s “Black Tuesday,” set to Depression-era music; and Ms. Tharp’s “Sinatra Suite,” which includes music sung by Frank Sinatra and costumes by Oscar de la Renta.

New York may be a concrete jungle, but the bright lights of Broadway have inspired Alicia Keys to produce Lydia R. Diamond‘s play “Stick Fly” for the Lyceum Theater at the end of the year. The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston said it would pay an unspecified amount to the heir of an art dealer who was killed at Auschwitz and will keep a 17th-century Dutch painting in its collection that was once owned by the dealer and likely seized by the Nazis. The Boston Globe reported that after a lengthy investigation into the work, an oil portrait by the Dutch painter Eglon van der Neer, the museum determined that it had belonged to Walter Westfeld, who had run a German gallery shut down by the Nazis in 1936 and who was sent to Auschwitz in 1943. The museum, which purchased the painting in 1941, posted an image of it online in 2000 amid concerns about its provenance; in 2004 it was contacted by Fred Westfield, a nephew of the art dealer. Mr. Westfield, a retired economics professor in Tennessee, learned about the painting from a Google search. The Globe said that the museum had in recent years returned other works stolen during World War II. It also fought a legal battle to keep the Oskar Kokoschka painting “Two Nudes (Lovers)”; a federal appeals court ruled last year that it was the rightful owner of this work.

Whether you’re interested in Philip Roth’s critical exegesis of “A Visit From the Goon Squad,” his contrarian take on “Freedom” or just curious to know what he thinks of “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” his answer is likely to be the same: He probably hasn’t read them because he is no longer reading fiction at all. In an interview with The Financial Times, Mr. Roth, the ornery author more than two dozen novels (the FT credits him with 53 books) including “Portnoy’s Complaint,” “The Human Stain” and “Nemesis,” said that other people’s literary inventions are no longer part of his diet. “I’ve stopped reading fiction,” he said. “I don’t read it at all. I read other things: history, biography. I don’t have the same interest in fiction that I once did.” Asked why he came to this position, Mr. Roth said: “I don’t know. I wised up.”

The road to Mitzpe Ramon, a dusty town halfway across Israel’s Negev Desert, is well paved and lonely. Heading south from Tel Aviv, you’ll pass by (and hopefully not drive into) some camels, zip past an ancient Nabatean fortress, spot an Israeli military base or two and even a disconcertingly large prison. All this is set against a rocky, khaki-drenched landscape that seems to close in on itself as you near the town; then, in a strikingly silent swoop, it opens up in the form of Makhtesh Ramon, the biggest erosion crater on the planet. And on its rim, in a crafty juxtaposition of luxury and nothingness, you have the new resort Beresheet.

RAWLINGS--Eleanor Hasbrouck, 101 years, of Stamford, CT, died on June 22. Descended from Abraham Hasbrouck (1650-1717), a patentee of historic New Paltz, NY. Artist, master of American Decorative Arts, decoupage and bonsai, author and poet, she taught at the Spence School, 1931-1933, and Buckley Country Day School, 1933-1938. Her husband J. Donald Rawlings, predeceased her. She leaves daughters Jane Odenweller and Sarah Skidmore, four grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A memorial service will take place at St. Paul's church, Riverside, CT, Wednesday, June 29, 10:30am. Memorial gifts may be sent to Historic Huguenot Street, in New Paltz.

SCHULMAN--Paul, age 81 of Brooklyn, died peacefully Saturday, June 25, 2011 at home in Belle Harbor. Beloved husband and soul mate of Myra Cohen; loving father of Jan (Art), Lisa (Steve), and Sara (Eliot); adoring grandfather of Michael, Natalie, Adam Cohen, Daniel and Joel Hein. Admired and respected for his creativity, persistence, and many accomplishments personally and professionally, he will be remembered with extraordinary love and live forever in our hearts. Funeral 11:30am, Tuesday, June 28th at Parkside Memorial, Flatbush Av, Brooklyn.

CITRON--Mark B.,61 of Montclair, New Jersey, died peacefully Sunday morning, after a courageous battle with brain cancer. A consummate fighter, Mark was immensely driven and goal-oriented, qualities he applied to all he did in life. Responsible for the approval of numerous cutting-edge medical devices, Mark devoted his life and career to advocating for the improved health of others. A graduate of UMass Amhert and Wagner College, Mark spent over 30 years working in the medical device industry, at the FDA, Johnson & Johnson, Bristol Myers Squibb, Genzyme, Biomimetics, and most recently TYRX. Throughout the decades, Mark developed both state of the art products as well as life-long friendships. A stickler for detail, Mark was known lovingly at home as the 'Inspector General' and employed his considerable investigatory skills for matters both big and small. A man with a grand sense of humor, he was a lover of movies, music, and pinball he approached life with an endless enthusiasm, hence he had no need for a bucket list. He is survived by his beloved wife of 30 years, Barbara Friedman, his cherished children, Rachel and Andrew, his devoted brothers Richard (Karen) and Jim (Nancy), and his adored mother-in-law Dorothy Lang to whom he never failed to wish Good Shabbas. Funeral at Temple Ner Tamid, Bloomfield, NJ on Tuesday, June 28th, at 11am.

ROTHENSTEIN--Edward M.,most recently of Delray Beach, Florida, passed away peacefully on June 24, 2011. He was 85 years old. A kind, generous and vivacious person, Mr. Rothenstein was the son of Albert and Florence Rothenstein of New York City and Woodmere, New York, and the brother of the late Howard Rothenstein of Boca Raton, Florida. Mr. Rothenstein held Bachelor's and Master's degrees from the Ohio State University and served in the United States Navy during World War II. He had a long and successful career in the electronics industry, served for many years in several positions at Temple Beth-El in Cedarhurst, New York, and continued his community and charitable activities after retiring to Florida in the late 1990s. His family, many friends and the communities to which he contributed so much will remember him for his sense of humor, keen intellect and eagerness to be of service to those who would benefit from his help. Mr. Rothenstein is survived by his devoted wife of 61 years, Shirley (nee Block); his daughters Barbara Budasoff and Julie Morgenstern; sons-in-law Daniel Budasoff and Saul Morgenstern; grandchildren Alana Budasoff Kanzer, Peter Morgenstern, Larry Budasoff and Emily Morgenstern; grandson-in-law Adam Kanzer; and his many close friends, all of whom love, and will miss him, dearly. A service will be held at 10:00am on Monday, June 27, 2011 at the Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, New York 10522. (914-693-3330). www.edwardsanddowdle.com In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Valencia Falls Cancer Research Chapter, c/o Pap Corps, 1192 East Newport Center Drive, Deerfield Beach, Florida 33442.

MAIDUGURI, Nigeria (Reuters) -- People suspected of being members of a radical Islamist sect threw bombs at a drinking spot in Nigeria's northeastern town of Maiduguri on Sunday, killing about 25 people, witnesses and military officials said. The attackers, who the military said were suspected of being members of the Boko Haram sect, threw three sets of explosives from the back of motorbikes and appeared to be aiming at police officers, witnesses said.

She is remembered with love for her independent spirit and resilience. Services Tuesday 11:30am at The Riverside 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

While the Tea Party movement has led the charge for cutting the national debt, its supporters have often struggled to explain how, exactly, they would do so. Now some are out to change that, joining a Tea Party debt commission that plans to hold hearings over the summer, in the hopes of delivering recommendations to lawmakers by January.

BRADY--Wilfred T.,III, (Ted), 62, of Keyport, New Jersey, passed away, Wednesday, June 22, 2011, at Bayshore Community Hospital, Holmdel. Born in Long Island, he resided in Hazlet before moving to Keyport. He worked in Operations as a VP with Mitusbushi UFJ Trust and Banking Corp, NYC, retiring in August 2010. He served his country in the Navy during Vietnam. Wilfred was predeceased by his parents, Wilfred T. Brady, II and Marie Hammond Brady. He is survived by his loving children, Heather Brady of Keyport and Tara Brady of Hazlet; his dear siblings, Joan Brady of Arizona; John Brady and his wife, Pam of Ohio; Kathleen Hartman and her husband, Charlie of California; Jane Brady of California; and Marianne Conte and her husband, Gabe of Florida; and one cherished grandchild, Brynn Champagne. He will be dearly missed by all who knew and loved him. Family and friends are invited Saturday, June 25, 2011 and Sunday, June 26, 2011, from 2-4 and 7-9pm, Day Funeral Home, 361 Maple Place, Keyport; and Monday, 9am, with a 9:30am service at the funeral home. Interment to follow at Pinelawn Cemetery, Long Island, NY. To offer the family online condolences or for directions to the funeral home, please visit www.dayfuneralhome.com.

Sports fans drifting toward summer after the Dallas Mavericks took the N.B.A. title, and after the N.H.L. Stanley Cup series, which went to a dramatic seventh-game finish and a win for Boston after 39 years, stumbled on a new name at the U.S. Open Golf Championship: Rory McIlroy, above. The 22-year-old golfer from Northern Ireland broke eight Open records on his way to winning his first major championship. Golf fans and those just learning about McIlroy turned to Wikipedia, the golfer's own site, and WTOC11, which is the CBS affiliate in Savannah, Ga. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Politico, an accelerant to the news cycle like wind is to brushfire, is taking on the one realm of political news that it has not yet sped up: book publishing. The all-things-politics Web site is teaming up with Random House to publish four e-books about the 2012 presidential campaign, the first of which is scheduled to go on sale sometime before Christmas. Each will be in the 20,000- to 30,000-word range and written by Mike Allen, right, Politico's chief White House correspondent, and Evan Thomas, a longtime political reporter who has written for Time and Newsweek.

The president of the cable channel AMC said he didn't regret the cliffhanger ending of ''The Killing'' a week ago but admitted there was a lesson to be learned. ''We underestimated the passion'' viewers have for closure within a season, Charlie Collier told Entertainment Weekly on Friday. ''If I could do anything differently, it would be to manage expectations.'' Many fans of ''The Killing'' (with Mireille Enos, above), which is about an investigation into the death of a teenage girl in Seattle, were left fuming when the first season ended on June 19 without an explanation for the crime. The anger was noticeable on social media Web sites, prompting Mr. Collier's acknowledgment. ''The audience has an important voice, we heard them and don't take them for granted,'' he said. Mr. Collier said he stood by the show's executive producer, Veena Sud, who told The Hollywood Reporter last week that the investigation would be resolved in Season 2. Ms. Sud recounted a conversation on one Web site that had a viewer declaring, ''I'll never ever come back for season two.'' She said, ''On the same thread three more people popped up and said: 'I haven't watched this show yet, but now I will because you guys are so emotional about it, it's gotta be something to watch.' So that's a great thing.''

Hewlett-Packard researchers are hard at work on a fully flexible display screen that they say can have all sorts of consumer and retail uses. Imagine candy bar wrappers, or screens as wallpaper, all made out of a flexible material that can change images in an instant. Compared with today's screens, which are made with glass and can easily break, these new displays could bring down the cost of consumer electronics and make gadgets more robust and bendable. The displays could also end up replacing hundreds of products that are currently made with paper and plastics.

MINNEAPOLIS -- Andrew Breitbart wasn't supposed to be sitting here in a television studio makeup chair. But when he heard that Anthony Weiner was about to announce his resignation, he dropped everything. Mr. Breitbart, the conservative author and blogger who first published Mr. Weiner's suggestive self-portraits, had ditched his book-signing in central Illinois and hopped on a flight earlier than planned to the Twin Cities, where he was booked as a marquee attraction at RightOnline, a conservative bloggers conference.

KREIDMANN--Kenneth Lloyd, age 66, of Mt. Kisco, NY died June 25 , 2011, after a lengthy illness. Born in New York City, the only son of Arthur M. Kreidmann and Leona F. (Benjamin), nephew of Robert Benjamin (deceased). Attended Columbia Grammar School, class of '62, Princeton University class of '66 and Columbia Law School class of 69. Survived by his aunt, Betty Benjamin, cousins John and Richard Benjamin and longtime friend, Anne Davies. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Ken's memory can be made to the charity of your choice.

SOICHER--Harvey, 77, on June 25, 2011. Beloved husband of Linda, brother of Larry, father of Lisa (Greg), Barry (Heather), Laura (Greg) and Caryn (John). Grandfather of nine. Services today at 1pm Gutterman's INC 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, NY.

How do you help brick-and-mortar stores sell books? Throw in an e-book. That is the idea of one publisher, Algonquin, which began a promotion in 300 Barnes & Noble stores this month that gives a discounted e-book to customers who buy an Algonquin trade paperback. The publisher has planned a similar effort for October, giving customers who buy a hardcover copy of ''When She Woke,'' by Hillary Jordan, the digital version of the book free.

BAGHDAD -- Two American soldiers were killed Sunday in Iraq, the military command said, making June the worst month in combat-related fatalities for United States forces in Iraq in more than two years. The casualties also reflected the dangers ahead as the United States prepares to withdraw all its troops from Iraq by the end of the year. The June total of so-called hostile-related deaths of American soldiers is now 11, the most since May 2009, when 12 were killed, according to icasualties.org, an online database that tracks the deaths of foreign forces in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars.
EDELMAN--Morton H. With us always in work, poetry, humor, and love. Diana and Alex

Pixar's ''Cars 2'' overcame surprisingly negative critical reviews to overperform at the weekend box office, selling an estimated $68 million at North American theaters. That No. 1 finish extends Pixar's perfect box-office track record - all 12 of its feature films have opened in first place. How sales hold up, however, will be watched carefully. ''Cars 2,'' directed by John Lasseter, chief creative officer at Pixar, represents an end to the studio's perfect critical track record; only about 34 percent of reviews were positive, according to RottenTomatoes.com, by far the worst for any Pixar title. The R-rated comedy ''Bad Teacher'' (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was a stronger-than-expected second with about $31 million in ticket sales - a result that cements mega-raunchy films as one of Hollywood's best performers of the moment. ''Green Lantern'' (Warner Brothers) fell 65 percent in its second weekend to third place, taking in about $18.4 million for a new total of $89 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. ''Super 8'' (Paramount Pictures) continued to show strength in its third weekend, selling about $12 million for a new total of $95 million. ''Mr. Popper's Penguins'' (20th Century Fox) was fifth with about $10.3 million for a two-week total of $39.4 million. Over all, ticket sales for the weekend stood at $176 million, an increase of 7 percent over the same weekend last year. Ticket sales for the year are down about 8 percent.

Dozens of new restrictions passed by states this year have chipped away at the right to abortion by requiring women to view ultrasounds, imposing waiting periods or cutting funds for clinics. But a new kind of law has gone beyond such restrictions, striking at the foundation of the abortion rules set out by the Supreme Court over the last four decades. These laws, passed in six states in little more than a year, ban abortions at the 20th week after conception, based on the theory that the fetus can feel pain at that point -- a notion disputed by mainstream medical organizations in the United States and Britain. Opponents of abortion say they expect that discussion of fetal pain -- even in the face of scientific criticism -- will alter public perception of abortion, and they have made support for the new laws a litmus test for Republicans seeking the presidency.

On Monday, Hearst Magazines is to begin an elaborate advertising campaign, aimed at advertisers and readers, to burnish its brand image rather than promote individual magazines like Esquire or Good Housekeeping. The campaign, with the ''Unbound'' theme, comes after significant business developments like the $892 million acquisition of 100 publications from Lagardere, the $325 million purchase of the digital marketing agency iCrossing and the joint venture with Scripps Network Interactive to introduce Food Network Magazine. ''We're unleashing our brand DNA,'' said Michael Clinton, president for marketing and publishing director at Hearst Magazines.

KNOLL--Monica. The founder and Executive Director of CANCER101, died on June 20, 2011. She is mourned by her family, friends and the Board of Directors of CANCER101. Monica was born on February 11, 1964. She was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2000 and ovarian cancer in 2006. While being treated for breast cancer, Monica created the CANCER101 Planner designed to empower cancer patients and their caregivers to fight the disease from the moment of diagnosis. The CANCER101 Planner is now used by thousands of patients in over 300 cancer centers across the country. Through her tireless work, Monica will have a lasting impact on the medical community and grateful patients everywhere. A memorial service will be held on July 19, 2011 at 4pm at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations are welcomed on CANCER101.org or mailed to CANCER101, 304 Park Avenue South, 11th Floor, New York, NY 10010.

CZITROM--Louis, 90, passed away on June 25, 2011. A loving husband, father, and grandfather, survived by his three sons, Ralph, Daniel, and Michael; granddaughters Nina, Betty, and Molly; step grandchildren, Sarah, Melissa, and Matthew D'Amico; and daughters-in-law Karen Marcus and Meryl Fingrutd. He was pre-deceased by his beloved wife of 42 years Betty (Barsky) Czitrom, his companion later in life Rose Rappaport, and Gerald Hayes, Michael's partner. A child of Hungarian Jewish immigrants, Lou grew up fatherless and poor in the Yorkville neighborhood during the Great Depression. He committed himself to a life of political activism around the struggles for socialism, peace, racial equality, and gender equity. He volunteered for the US Army after Pearl Harbor and served four years as a corporal in the Medical Corps in North Africa, Sicily, and Italy. For twenty-five years he was a proud member of Steamfitters Local 638, and later the Communications Workers of America. In lieu of flowers the family asks that donations in Lou's name be made to the Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives (www.alba-valb.org).

Breakfast NY, an interactive advertising agency based in Brooklyn, is trying to get past the Web. Michael Lipton, one of the founders of the company, said marketing campaigns needed to be more creative than a simple site or would-be viral video to cut through the noise of everything else online.

There were the usual iconic faces of Yogi Berra and Whitey Ford, Reggie Jackson and Goose Gossage at Old-Timers' Day on Sunday at Yankee Stadium. But the loudest recognition during the introductions at the 65th annual meeting of former Yankees was saved for Joe Torre and Bernie Williams, each making his Old-Timers' Day debut. ''I certainly did feel differently when I put it on today, knowing I hadn't done it in a long time,'' said Torre, in a Yankees uniform for the first time since the 2007 postseason.

ALBANY -- After a string of defeats in recent years from California to Maine, the movement to legalize same-sex marriage is hoping its unexpected victory in New York will revive efforts to legalize gay weddings around the nation. But the movement's success here could prove difficult to replicate. Twenty-nine states have constitutional bans on same-sex marriage, while 12 others have laws against it. And many of those states where support for same-sex marriage is high have already acted on the issue.

Here are some rather startling facts, but ones that explain a lot about why buying electronics can be anxiety-producing. Last year, on average, six new laptop models and one new TV model came out each day; a new camera came out every other day. This information was relayed to me by Oren Etzioni, director of the University of Washington's Turing Center and the brains behind Farecast, the site that predicts changes in air fares. Farecast was sold to Microsoft, which uses it in the Bing search engine.

LEXINGTON, Ky. - Henry Clay became speaker in 1811 on his first day in the House of Representatives. It took Nancy Pelosi and John A. Boehner 20 years apiece. ''Slow learner,'' Mr. Boehner said with a chuckle, seated alongside Ms. Pelosi and former Speaker J. Dennis Hastert on Friday night at a tribute to Clay, their legendary predecessor. He called Clay a role model, ''the first real speaker of the House that had some power.''

KUMMEL--Eugene H. of Manhattan and Edgartown, MA died on June 25, 2011 at age 88. Cherished husband of Barbara, his wife of 56 years, proud father of Charles, Andrew and William, dear father-in-law of Shawna, loving brother of Bertram and adoring uncle, grand-uncle and great-grand-uncle of 21. Admired and respected for his love of family, friends and colleagues, he will be greatly missed. Family will be at home Tuesday from 5 to 7pm. Services will be on Wednesday, June 29th at 10 am at Temple Emanu-El of New York City.

WATNICKI--Marie, born Leah Ackerman in Michow, Poland May 26, 1919, passed away June 10, 2011, in Coconut Creek, Florida. Survivor of the Holocaust, she came to New York in 1950, and became a successful businesswoman, vital member of the community, an extraordinary wife, mother, and beloved grandmother. She shone in life, creativity and accomplishments. She is survived by her daughter, Ellen W. Echeverria, another daughter, son-in-law, three grandchildren including Alia Varsano, and four great-grandchildren.

GAMBLE--Diane Elaine, community leader and accomplished business woman, died peacefully at her home on Tuesday, June 14. The cause was cancer. She was 73. At the incipience of the internet boom, Diane had a front row seat, serving as President and CEO of Link Resources, Inc., a market research firm specializing in emerging communications technologies. After Link was acquired by International Data Group, Inc. she served as an executive of various research departments in the Walt Disney Company and American Broadcasting Company. Prior to career in market research, she worked for the then Governor Nelson Rockefeller, both in Westchester County, New York City and Albany. She had a broad interest in her community, ultimately becoming President of the Junior League of Westchester on Hudson and President of the New Castle Historical Society. She was also very active in the formative years of what became the Westchester Symphony Orchestra. She is survived by her husband, Lex and son, Alex and his wife Carol; and 21 nieces, nephews and cousins.

(Showtime) THE TWILIGHT SAGA: ECLIPSE (2010) Kristen Stewart, center, reprises her role as Bella Swan, who must choose between her love for the vampire Edward (Robert Pattinson, right) and her friendship with the werewolf Jacob (Taylor Lautner, left) while being pursued by a vengeful bloodsucker, Victoria (Bryce Dallas Howard). ''If there is a bit more humor on display here -- some of it evidence that an element of self-conscious self-mockery is sneaking into the franchise -- there is also more violence, and, true to the film's title, a deeper intimation of darkness,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this third installment in the film series based on the books by Stephenie Meyer. ''What there isn't, as usual, is much in the way of good acting, with the decisive and impressive exception of Ms. Stewart, who can carry a close-up about as well as anyone in movies today.'' The film leads in to the season premieres of ''Weeds,'' at 10, which finds Nancy Botwin (Mary-Louise Parker) in New York City after having spent three years in federal prison for murder, and ''The Big C,'' at 10:30, in which Cathy Jamison (Laura Linney) continues her battle against Stage 4 melanoma with a new oncologist (Alan Alda) and a new friend (Hugh Dancy). 8 P.M. (ABC) THE BACHELORETTE The notorious Bentley shows up in Hong Kong with a request to speak to Ashley. But does he hope to sweep her off her feet? Or is he simply there to play more mind games? In ''Extreme Makeover: Weight Loss Edition,'' at 10, Chris Powell helps LaRhonda, 24, a former marching band queen who now weighs 433 pounds, overcome the childhood trauma that led her to become seriously obese.

In a PGA Tour playoff duel between former Clemson teammates this season, the gloves were off. In response to Friday’s column about the Jaipur Limb, an inexpensive, locally-made artificial leg that has helped millions of impoverished people in poor countries to regain their dignity and livelihood, Laurie C. from Marina,Calif., (5), a reader who uses a wheelchair, made an important point:  “It can be scary to know that you live in a body that is so dependent on inanimate equipment that if you don’t have that equipment, you basically fall off the radar of life itself,” she wrote. “You disappear from society, people avoid you, you become ‘a burden’ … all for the lack of a piece of equipment.”   This is a very persuasive argument for why a low-cost wide-scale product like the Jaipur Limb is necessary.

The designer Mihara’s favorite song, Pink Floyd’s existential meditation “Wish You Were Here,” provided the source material for his elegaic Miharayasuhiro collection for spring/summer 2012. Choosing to forgo a runway show in place of a showroom presentation, he donated the saved funds to charities benefiting those affected by the tsunami in Japan. He applied flocked letters from the title of the song onto layers of jersey vests, shirts and jackets, letting the message continue to reveal itself. Paired with fleece shorts constructed from various necklines of T-shirts, the outfit was a moving, romantic take on the athletic wear we’ve seen this season.

On draft night, the Dallas Mavericks traded away a late first-round pick for the opportunity to add veteran Rudy Fernandez to their championship core. For a team on Dallas’s timeline, the immediacy of such a move makes sense; there’s an allure in a proven N.B.A. rotation player over an untested prospect, even if some of the prospects available (Texas’ Jordan Hamilton, who was once viewed as a talent worthy of the late lottery, chief among them) have intriguing long-term potential.

The Smithsonian Institution has indefinitely postponed its plans to mount an exhibition of Chinese artifacts salvaged from a shipwreck because of opposition from archeologists who say the objects were collected by a commercial treasure hunter in a manner that violated professional standards. The exhibition, “Shipwrecked: Tang Treasures and Monsoon Winds,” was tentatively scheduled for next spring at the Freer Gallery of Art and Arthur M. Sackler Gallery, the Smithsonian’s Asian art museums. A museum spokeswoman, Deborah Galyan, said that the earliest the museum might mount a “Shipwrecked” exhibit now would be 2013, a delay that she said would give the museums’ director, Julian Raby, who also curated the exhibition, time to address some of the archeologists’ concerns. The exhibition was conceived by the government of Singapore, which bought the artifacts for $32 million from the company that salvaged them from a wreck off the coast of Indonesia. It is currently on view at the ArtScience museum at the Marina Bay Sands resort and casino in Singapore. The salvage company has said it mined the artifacts quickly to avoid looting.

In the ongoing debate over raising the debt ceiling, one option has not had much prominence: whether the Obama administration could ignore it altogether, and just spend the money it owes anyway. Would that be legal?

The Los Angeles Times reports of an online fraud that relies on fabricated mock-ups of Edmunds.com Web pages to ensnare used-car shoppers. The scam promises shoppers a purchase-protection plan via Edmunds.com, the automotive information Web site, through which funds would be transferred into an escrow account to secure a vehicle purchase. The general counsel for Edmunds said that the company had received calls from multiple victims. Read more »

Andy Rubin, a vice president for engineering at Google who leads the company’s Google Android platform, said in a Twitter message Tuesday that the company was now activating over 500,000 Android devices each day.

If you had the number three in your office pool of how many new Broadway plays would be announced on Tuesday, prepare to collect your winnings. Adding to today’s embarrassment of Rialto riches, the producers Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel said that they will bring a production of David Henry Hwang’s comedy “Chinglish” to Broadway in the fall, after its run at the Goodman Theater in Chicago ends in July.

City Room was thrilled to receive a news release from the Department of Parks and Recreation on Tuesday afternoon announcing that all 54 outdoor city pools will open to the public on Wednesday. Our excitement, however, turned to something else entirely when we read that “former NY Yankee Lee Mazzilli” would be on hand for opening day at a pool in the Bronx.

Athens is in trouble. The boutiques on the posh shopping streets of Kolonaki are empty. Constitution Square is a landfill of protest placards. And the normally cheery summer afternoon ritual — an iced Nescafé paired with half a pack of cigarettes — has become an exercise in existential brooding. “It makes me so sad,” Stefania Flenga, an executive for the boutique hotel chain Yes! Hotels, said while surveying the slow simmer of civil unrest on view in front of the Greek parliament. She was no doubt thinking about how all these disturbances are bad for the tourism industry, which accounts for almost 18 percent of the Greek economy. “They’re shooting themselves in the foot,” she said of the picketers.

For enthusiasts of obscure midcentury car design, the star of the movie “Cars 2″ may be the villainous Professor Z, based on the Zündapp Janus of 1957 and 1958. The stubby vehicle, built by a traditional motorcycle maker, appears to have two front ends; it’s the automotive equivalent of Dr. Dolittle’s Pushmi-Pullyu.

The conventional wisdom is that Wall Street has turned its back on President Obama. But DealBook examines whether financial leaders are simply hedging their bets.

ABC’s reality competition “The Bachelorette” posted its best ratings in three weeks on Monday, delivering the night’s largest audience with eight million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The solid ratings helped ABC extended its winning streak to 16 weeks as the top-rated network on Monday night. NBC ranked second as “Law & Order: LA” finished in a tie with ABC’s “Extreme Makeover: Weight Loss Edition” at 10 p.m., each attracting 6.4 million viewers. Earlier, NBC’s rerun of “America’s Got Talent,” at 8 p.m., garnered 5.8 million viewers and “Law & Order: Criminal Intent” drew 4.8 million at 9, less than the five million viewers who watched a new episode of Fox’s “MasterChef” in the same time slot. For the night, however, Fox lagged behind CBS, which placed third with reruns of its sitcom line-up followed by a “Hawaii Five-0” repeat at 10 p.m. (5.8 million).

When my column about technology and children was published on Sunday, the Supreme Court had not yet ruled on California’s ban on the sale of violent video games to children under the age of 18. Yesterday as expected, the Supreme Court struck down the ban. It was a 7 to 2 decision, but that suggests greater agreement than there really was, as Adam Liptak maps out. What’s most interesting about the fissures on the court is the different thinking among the justices about the impact of technology on children, and the implications for other important clashes over teenagers’ free-speech rights that are percolating in the lower courts.

The Brazilian singer-songwriter Caetano Veloso has agreed to step into an unfamiliar role, that of “guest director” helping to pick and present the films for the 38th Telluride Film Festival, which will be held over the Labor Day weekend. A confessed cinephile, Mr. Veloso has composed soundtracks for movies, performed in his friend Pedro Almodóvar’s “Talk to Her,” written essays about his love for Italian neo-realist films and even recorded a CD tribute to Federico Fellini and Giulietta Masina.

Adam Posen gave a talk yesterday (pdf) about British monetary policy that drives home a point I’ve been meaning to make; namely, that what’s happening in Britain on the monetary front right now is very much a teachable moment for monetary policy more generally. The Bank of England faces the same kind conflict between what it should be doing and what it’s under pressure to do that faces the Fed, but in starker form. And if the BoE holds its ground, we should soon have a clear demonstration that one side is right and the other is wrong.

He made angry men of Lee J. Cobb and E. G. Marshall, got Peter Finch mad as hell and had Al Pacino screaming “Attica” at the top of his lungs, and next month Sidney Lumet, the director of “12 Angry Men,” “Network,” “Dog Day Afternoon” and many more seminal works of cinema, will be the subject of a tribute by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. The society said that the retrospective, called “Prince of the City: Remembering Sidney Lumet,” will run from July 19 through 25 and will feature screenings of 16 films by that director, who died in April. Movies including “Serpico,” “The Verdict” and “The Wiz” will be shown at the Walter Reade Theater in Manhattan. The retrospective will also feature a Q-and-A with Walter Bernstein, the screenwriter of “Fail Safe,” after a showing of that film on July 20; the actor Treat Williams and the N.Y.P.D. detective Robert Leuci will appear after a screening of “Prince of the City” on July 24; and, of course, Lumet’s film “Q&A” will be followed by a Q-and-A with Luis Guzman, Paul Calderon and Judge Edwin Torres, the author of the novel from which the film was adapted.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

“To all whom it may concern: Be it known that I, Harry C. Bunnell, a citizen of the United States, residing at Westport, in the county of Essex and the State of New York, have invented a new and useful Improvement in Chairs. … ” So begins patent number 794,777, dated July 18, 1905, in reference to what we commonly refer to as the Adirondack Chair. With its signature slanted back and wide armrests, the recognizable profile of this outdoor recliner has become a trademark of summer in America. Despite the patent filed over a hundred years ago, though, Harry Bunnell, a carpenter and shop owner, was not actually the one who created the chair’s design.

The Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum may be closing its galleries starting Monday for a two-year renovation, but it is hardly going quiet. In addition to a previously announced show to take place at the United Nations this fall, the museum will host an exhibition of contemporary graphic design next summer on Governors Island. The exhibition, “Graphic Design: Now in Production,” is co-organized with the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, where it will run from Oct. 22 to Jan. 22. It is to open on Governors Island, in Building 110, on June 2, 2012, and run through Sept. 30. The previously announced show at the United Nations, “Design With the Other 90%: Cities,” the second of a series on how design can address critical global issues, opens Oct. 15 and runs through Jan. 9. Admission to both exhibitions will be free.

The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston said it would pay an unspecified amount to the heir of an art dealer who was killed at Auschwitz and will keep a 17th-century Dutch painting in its collection that was once owned by the dealer and likely seized by the Nazis. The Boston Globe reported that after a lengthy investigation into the work, an oil portrait by the Dutch painter Eglon van der Neer, the museum determined that it had belonged to Walter Westfeld, who had run a German gallery shut down by the Nazis in 1936 and who was sent to Auschwitz in 1943. The museum, which purchased the painting in 1941, posted an image of it online in 2000 amid concerns about its provenance; in 2004 it was contacted by Fred Westfield, a nephew of the art dealer. Mr. Westfield, a retired economics professor in Tennessee, learned about the painting from a Google search. The Globe said that the museum had in recent years returned other works stolen during World War II. It also fought a legal battle to keep the Oskar Kokoschka painting ''Two Nudes (Lovers)''; a federal appeals court ruled last year that it was the rightful owner of this work. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

ACCUSED OF COLLUSION Two former executives of Marsh & McLennan who are suing the insurance broker contend in an amended complaint that Marsh & McLennan colluded with Eliot Spitzer, left, when he was New York attorney general to avert a criminal prosecution of the firm. In October 2004, Mr. Spitzer's office accused Marsh & McLennan of rigging bids for contracts and steering business in exchange for incentive payments. The two men -- William Gilman and Edward McNenney -- argue that as result of the company's assistance, Mr. Spitzer received the bragging rights that come with a big settlement. SUSANNE CRAIG

In the arena of international geopolitics, the United States' relationship with North Korea preserves the chill of the Cold War. On the soccer field, feelings are not much warmer, but at least in the setting of the Women's World Cup, the teams and players meet on common ground, if for only 90 minutes. On Tuesday, the United States begins play in the Women's World Cup against North Korea in Dresden, Germany. It is the fourth consecutive World Cup in which the teams have been drawn into the same first-round group. It is an odd twist of fate spread over 12 years, a streak that began for the United States with a 3-0 victory in 1999 and continued with another 3-0 win in 2003 (when both tournaments were played in the United States), and then a 2-2 draw in 2007 in China.

KUMMEL--Eugene H. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System mourn the loss of advertising legend Eugene Kummel, a long-time member of Lenox Hill Hospital's Board of Trustees. For more than 25 years, Mr. Kummel worked tirelessly on behalf of the hospital, lending his expertise to numerous committees, including its auxiliary. In 1999, he received the United Hospital Fund's Distinguished Trustee Award for his contributions to healthcare. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Barbara, an active member of the auxiliary; sons Charles, Andrew and William; daughter-in-law Shawna; bro- ther Bertram and the other members of his family. Michael J. Dowling, President & CEO, North Shore-LIJ Health System; Richard D. Goldstein, Chairman, North Shore- LIJ Health System; William O. Hiltz, Chairman, Executive Committee, Lenox Hill Hospital

NYMAN--Lawrence (Larry). A good man has died. A wise man has died. A courageous man has died. Lawrence (Larry) Nyman succumbed at age 85 on June 27, 2011 after a lengthy bout with prostate cancer, just shy of his 24th wedding anniversary. Larry was a generous friend and colleague, a most loving husband, father, and grandfather. A professor of psychology at City College of New York for 39 years, Dr. Nyman specialized in family therapy and maintained a clinical practice. Deeply interested in the roots of human behavior and in the processes of psychological and institutional change, he recorded the illustrious history of the City College Psychology Department based on interviews with notable past scholars including Gardner Murphy and Kenneth Clark, and in 1989 organized the fiftieth anniversary celebration of the Department's establishment. As part of his exploration of past accomplishments of previous faculty members, Nyman recently published an article on the life and work of Kenneth Clark, whose studies of African American children played a key role in the 1954 United States Supreme Court Brown v Board of Education decision that outlawed segregation in American public schools. To encourage continuing scholarly investigation of family process at CCNY, he established the Lawrence and Danielle Nyman award for the best yearly student project in this vital area of study.Larry was a WWII vet (a proud 1st lieutenant) and an avid athlete. He played football for Rutgers University, and received a number of tennis trophies, including one from Theix, France, given for good sportsmanship after a tough three-hour match with a man three decades younger. Larry was endowed with a multiplicity of talents. He was an astute reader of people and devoted to helping others. He was a repairer of cars, including those of his friends; a creative cook, a fixit man, a proficient gardener, an early environmentalist who taught many to garden without pesticides and to start compost heaps (he gave away many cuttings, some to strangers passing by). Larry is survived by his wife Danielle, two daughters, Tamar and Reba, a stepson Dov, and four grandchildren. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Society for the Protection of Nature in Israel, 28 Arrandale Ave, Great Neck, NY 11024-1804. If you visit Israel, we invite you to see the Nyman Pond in the Jerusalem Bird Observatory.

FRANKENBERG--Alvin, age 87, died on June 25, 2011. He was born in the Bronx, NY on December 30, 1923. Devoted and loving husband of Audrey Sandler Frankenberg, dearest father of Bruce Frankenberg and the late Susan Silverman, and caring brother of Richard Frankenberg. Alvin enlisted in the Marine Corps and served during World War II. A graduate of City College and the New York Law School, he was an Attorney at Law in private practice in New York and Councilman at Large during the Lindsay Administration. Alvin was a long-standing member of the Liberal Party. He was Deputy Commissioner of the Motor Vehicle Department of New York State. He served as Counsel to the New York State Speaker of the Assembly, and most recently as a City Marshall. Alvin had many interests and a great zest for life. He will be missed by many. You may honor Alvin's memory with a contribution to National Hillel at 800 18th St. NW, Washington, DC 20001 or any charity of your choice.

An article in some copies on Saturday about reaction to the New York State Legislature's approval of a measure to legalize same-sex marriage referred imprecisely to the uprising at the Stonewall Inn in Greenwich Village in 1969. While the uprising is generally seen as the beginning of the modern gay rights movement, national gay rights organizations had existed for decades before that.

9 P.M. (13) THE CHILD CASES When abuse is suspected in a child's death, experts are called to testify. But what happens when that testimony is considered flawed, as it was in the case of Ernie Lopez, above, who was sentenced to 60 years in prison after an infant in his care died? In this joint investigation with ProPublica and NPR, the ''Frontline'' correspondent A. C. Thompson examines more than 20 cases in which people were imprisoned based on medical evidence centered on abuse, assault and ''shaken baby syndrome'' that was later found to be unreliable. In other segments Martin Smith investigates for-profit colleges that aggressively recruit veterans from Iraq and Afghanistan. And Atul Gawande reports on Dr. Jeffrey Brenner and his team in Camden, N.J., who seek out the community's sickest and most expensive-to-treat patients in a practice called hotspotting, which is thought to reduce sharply the city's overall medical costs. In ''My Perestroika,'' presented by ''POV'' at 10 on Channel 13, and at 11 on Channel 49, Robin Hessman looks at the last generation of Soviet youth through the stories of five classmates. They go from living sheltered childhoods to experiencing the reforms enacted by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the chaos of the Soviet Union's dissolution to searching for their places in contemporary Moscow. 5:40 P.M. (Starz) SOLITARY MAN (2009) Michael Douglas (right, with Susan Sarandon) plays Ben Kalmen, a businessman trying to rebuild his life after cheating in his bookkeeping and on his wife (Ms. Sarandon), disappointing his daughter (Jenna Fischer) and ending up divorced and shackled by legal troubles. Now his most recent companion (Mary-Louise Parker) may want him dead. Danny DeVito plays the old college friend who takes pity on Ben; Jesse Eisenberg is the student who warily accepts him as a mentor. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said: ''The filmmakers' only misstep is to supply, early and late, a too-neat explanation for the slow-motion train wreck that Ben's life has become. But it is easy enough to ignore this lapse in the face of such unassumingly intelligent screenwriting and so much understated, brilliant acting.'' Especially that of Mr. Douglas, Mr. Scott added: ''After 'Wall Street' and 'Wonder Boys,' he could have played Ben Kalmen in his sleep, but instead he is fully alive, as engaged with the complexities of actorly portraiture as he has ever been. Ben, for all his manifold flaws, is never dishonest -- his mistake is to place a higher value on candor than he does on decency -- and Mr. Douglas never hits a false note. It may not be easy to like this solitary man. It may be impossible. But by the end of this trim and satisfying movie, you know him.''

GORDON--Kenny, on your 39th Birthday. Not a day goes by for us without memories bringing smiles to our faces or tears to our eyes. You are missed every minute of every day. Our aching hearts are always filled with love for you. Mom, Dad, Jonny, Catherine, Kenya & Chloe

Humans are a much bigger problem than wolves for a caribou herd in the oil sands area of Alberta, Canada, scientists reported last week in Frontiers in Ecology. Studies of scat of moose, caribou and wolves in the area showed that caribou accounted for only 10 percent of the animals consumed by wolves. Eighty percent of the wolves' diet was deer, with moose making up the remainder. Wolves' preference for deer, the researchers conclude, draws them away from the areas where caribou thrive.

Lowry Memorial Fund at New Jersey Health Foundation. 908-731-6595 www.foundationofumdnj.org

Engrossing storytelling is certainly among the pleasures the theater can provide. But how much story is too much story onstage, where time constraints make it harder to maintain a balance between narrative, character development and the exploration of theme? The question arose for me last week when I headed to San Francisco to review the new stage adaptation of Armistead Maupin's ''Tales of the City'' at the American Conservatory Theater. Having recently reread the novels, I was looking forward to getting reacquainted with the spirited gang whose romantic exploits Mr. Maupin chronicled with such warmth and humor in the books: the Cleveland refugee Mary Ann Singleton, her ever-on-the-prowl gay pal Michael ''Mouse'' Tolliver, their earth-mother landlady Anna Madrigal and the many other characters orbiting 28 Barbary Lane, Mrs. Madrigal's Russian Hill home. The musical's authors, Jeff Whitty (''Avenue Q'') and the songwriting team from the band Scissor Sisters, Jake Shears and John Garden, obviously have great affection for the material. In fact their affection for Mr. Maupin's books - and the ample cast of characters they contain - may have posed problems when it came time to shape the material into a single evening of musical theater.
For a group of Chinese students spending this summer working in New York City, learning English was challenging enough. But learning Brooklynese? - that's Chinese for ''Fuhgeddaboudit.''

ROTHSTEIN--Dr. Morton H.,passed away on June 27, 2011; he was 83 and a resident of Massapequa. Devoted husband of Selma; loving father to Stephen, Robin, Mark, and Scott, and grandfather to Greg, Danielle, Allison, Jaclyn, Lauren, and David. Dr. Rothstein was an osteopathic surgeon who co-founded Massapequa General Hospital in Seaford, NY. Admired and respected for his integrity and dedication, he will be remembered always by those who knew and loved him.
