It was the NJ Transit Police Department, not the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey Police Department.

CLARK--Nathan. Although his life spanned almost a century, his wit and charm, intelligence and curiosity were undiminished. It was a privilege to have known Nathan, and his memory will live on in our hearts. Buchbinder & Warren

Brent Glass, the director of the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History, who oversaw a two-year renovation that answered some of the criticisms of the museum, will retire effective July 10. An acting director is to be appointed in July, and Mr. Glass will continue as an adviser to the Smithsonian through the end of the year. Mr. Glass, 64, arrived in 2002, shortly after a commission appointed by the Smithsonian's Board of Regents submitted a stinging report on the museum in which it noted a lack of ''aesthetic appeal, organizational coherence and the perception of substantive balance.'' He oversaw an $85 million renovation that created a new, light-filled atrium and reorganized the museum's layout; he also introduced new exhibitions, including ''The Price of Freedom,'' a narrative of the nation's wars.
Most people looking at the water tanks atop many older Manhattan buildings might see an iconic vestige of old New York. Glen Whitney sees a math equation.

HOLMES--Eve (Evelyn) Hatch, of New York City, Cedarhurst, New York and Palm Beach, Florida died at New York Hospital on June 24, 2011 following brief illness. Adored wife of the late E. Williams Homes. Loving stepmother of E. Williams Holmes, Jr., Peter B. Holmes and Jay H. Holmes. Eve was the daughter of novelist and screenwriter Eric Hatch and Sylvia Whiton-Stuart Hatch and cherished granddaughter of Frederick H. Hatch and May Daly Hatch. She had a long and distinguished career in the world of fashion and was for many years fashion editor of Town & Country magazine. Eve was an active member of the Lawrence Beach Club, Rockaway Hunt Club and the Colonial Dames of America. To her galaxy of dear friends worldwide, Eve was especially loved for her loyalty, razor-sharp mind and rollicking wit. She will be missed. Funeral service and burial: Trinity-St. John's Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, New York, Wednesday, June 29, at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to the charity of your choice will be appreciated.

CZITROM--Louis, 90, passed away on June 25, 2011. A loving husband, father, and grandfather, survived by his three sons, Ralph, Daniel, and Michael; granddaughters Nina, Betty, and Molly; step grandchildren, Sarah, Melissa, and Matthew D'Amico; and daughters-in-law Karen Marcus and Meryl Fingrutd. He was pre-deceased by his beloved wife of 42 years Betty (Barsky) Czitrom, his companion later in life Rose Rappaport, and Gerald Hayes, Michael's partner. A child of Hungarian Jewish immigrants, Lou grew up fatherless and poor in the Yorkville neighborhood during the Great Depression. He committed himself to a life of political activism around the struggles for socialism, peace, racial equality, and gender equity. He volunteered for the US Army after Pearl Harbor and served four years as a corporal in the Medical Corps in North Africa, Sicily, and Italy. For twenty-five years he was a proud member of Steamfitters Local 638, and later the Communications Workers of America. In lieu of flowers the family asks that donations in Lou's name be made to the Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives (www.alba-valb.org).

HEALY--Jack. Internationally renowned Textile Converter and 20 year CFO of Metro Fabrics in New York, died on June 24th after a brave battle with cancer. Jack is survived by his wife of 47 years, Anita, their three children, Craig, David and Danielle and four grandchildren. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9pm, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Funeral Mass Sacred Heart Church, Dobbs Ferry, NY, Thursday at 9:30am. www.edwardsanddowdle.com

Hoda Abou-Jamra still remembers the meeting when potential investors for her private equity fund thought she was the secretary. ''I would ask a question, and they would answer to the man next to me. I would answer their question, and they would look at him,'' she said, laughing. ''I didn't let it bother me. I just stood up straighter and talked louder.''

New York's $66 billion budget, which the City Council is set to approve on Tuesday, averted the laying off of thousands of teachers that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had said would be necessary. But the plan does not spare the schools from cuts. The schools chancellor, Dennis M. Walcott, told principals on Monday that individual school budgets would decline by an average of 2.4 percent, forcing tough choices about what -- or whom -- they can do without.

An article on the Personal Tech pages on Thursday about useful features common to a variety of phones using the Android operating system misstated a limitation for users of a rival, the iPhone from Apple. Unlocked iPhones that can be used on GSM networks, including T-Mobile's, are available from Apple retail stores and the Apple online store; buyers are not limited to service from AT&T and Verizon.

Admired and respected for his love of family, friends and colleagues, he will be greatly missed. Family will be at home Tuesday from 5 to 7pm. Services will be on Wednesday, June 29th at 10 am at Temple Emanu-El of New York City.

An obituary on Monday about the actress Alice Playten misspelled the given name of her brother, who survives her. He is Stephen Plotkin, not Steven. The obituary also misidentified her place of birth. It was Manhattan, not Brooklyn.

Don't sleep with mean people. That's a lesson some of us learn painfully, if at all, in regard to our personal happiness. That there could be a cosmic evolutionary angle to this thought had never occurred to me until I heard Baba Brinkman, a rap artist and Chaucer scholar, say it the other night. Think of it as the ultimate example of thinking globally and acting very, very locally. We are all in the process of recreating our species in our most intimate acts:

Barbra Streisand has had a long association with Marilyn and Alan Bergman, the songwriters and lyricists who wrote or co-wrote some of her biggest hits, like ''The Way We Were,'' ''You Don't Bring Me Flowers'' and the songs from her 1983 movie ''Yentl.'' For her next album, ''What Matters Most,'' Ms. Streisand will be singing 10 songs by the Bergmans that she has not already recorded, like ''Nice 'n' Easy'' (sung by Frank Sinatra in 1960) and ''The Windmills of Your Mind,'' from the film ''The Thomas Crown Affair,'' which Ms. Streisand sang at a charity dinner before the Grammy Awards in February.

LAWRENCE--Walter, passed away on June 24, 2011. He was predeceased by his wife Llewellyn. He is survived by two children, Carol and Tony, a daughter-in-law, five grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, and numerous in-laws, relatives, and friends. Service Wednesday, June 29th, 11am, Nazarene Congregational Church, Brooklyn.

The United Nations Security Council on Monday unanimously approved a resolution authorizing the deployment of 4,200 Ethiopian troops to Sudan's disputed Abyei region, a move diplomats said was aimed at defusing tensions in the run-up to the southern third of the country declaring independence on July 9. The resolution, which was drafted by the United States and authorizes the deployment of the troops for a six-month period, comes a week after north and south Sudan signed a deal in Addis Ababa to demilitarize Abyei and allow Ethiopian peacekeepers to monitor the situation.

(Benjamin), nephew of Robert Benjamin (deceased). Attended Columbia Grammar School, class of '62, Princeton University class of '66 and Columbia Law School class of 69. President Obama's $35,800-a-plate fund-raising dinner was the talk of Wall Street last week. Held at Daniel, the Michelin three-star restaurant of Daniel Boulud on the Upper East Side, the event was seen as a test of the president's popularity among the deep-pocketed financiers he has often vilified but has long relied on to finance his campaign. The tables were filled with moneymen like Marc Lasry, the billionaire founder of the hedge fund Avenue Capital; Robert Wolf, the chief executive of UBS Group Americas; and Mark T. Gallogly, a co-founder of Centerbridge Partners.

SUMMER is here, the airplanes are full, fares are rising, service is falling and flight delays are increasing. Can we also expect to see more planes stranded for long hours on the tarmac, as we did in the summers of 2008 and 2009? The Transportation Department insists not. In the spring of 2010, responding to many well-publicized accounts of planes being stranded on tarmacs for four, six and even 10 hours, the department issued a rule that carries severe fines for airlines that keep passengers on idled planes for more than three hours without a very good excuse. After the rule went into effect, the problem seemed to nearly disappear.

An obituary on Saturday about Peter Falk, the star of the television series ''Columbo,'' misstated part of the name under which that series and others were originally shown on NBC. It was ''NBC Mystery Movie,'' not ''NBC Mystery Theater.''
CLARK--Nathan, of Street, Somerset, UK and New York City, July 17, 1916 to June 23, 2011. Shoemaker. Contact email: Julie.Willbourn@Clarks.com

NATIONAL An article on Monday about laws passed in the last year in six states to ban abortion after 20 weeks of pregnancy misspelled the surname of the president of the Center for Reproductive Rights. It is Nancy Northup, not Northrup.

One day during medical school, my classmates and I learned that one of the most well-liked doctors-in-training in the hospital had had a seizure while leading morning work rounds. The sight of him writhing had caused the other doctors and nurses on the ward to panic. Some stood mute, frozen with fear. An intern, believing that the seizure arose from low blood sugar levels, took his half-eaten jelly doughnut and held it against the mouth of his seizing colleague. Others yelled to the ward secretary to ''call a code,'' and continued to do so even after another dozen doctors and nurses had already arrived on the floor.
FREUND--Lucas Samuel. "The wound is the place where the Light enters you" Love, Mommy and Charlotte

FOREIGN An article on Sunday about Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the billionaire owner of the New Jersey Nets basketball team who was elected to lead the Right Cause political party in Russia, misspelled the surname of a former leader of the Soviet Union in a quotation about Russian politics by Konstantin Remchukov, editor of the Nezavisimaya newspaper. He is Nikita Khrushchev, not Kruschev.

Margaret Tyzack, a stalwart British actress who won myriad awards for her stage performances, including a Tony, but who was best known in the United States for her roles in the public television series ''The Forsyte Saga'' and ''I, Claudius,'' died on Saturday in London. She was 79. Her death was announced by her agent, Pippa Markham, who did not specify a cause.

American Ballet Theater plans to take up residence at City Center from Nov. 8 through Nov. 13 to present a combination of new work and revivals. The opening-night gala will kick off with a new ballet choreographed by Demis Volpi, a member of the Stuttgart Ballet. Twyla Tharp's ''In the Upper Room'' and Martha Clarke's ''Garden of Villandry'' will also be performed that evening. Among the works audience members will get a chance to see later in the week are revivals of Merce Cunningham's ''Duets,'' with music by John Cage; Paul Taylor's ''Black Tuesday,'' set to Depression-era music; and Ms. Tharp's ''Sinatra Suite,'' which includes music sung by Frank Sinatra and costumes by Oscar de la Renta. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SEIDMAN--Martha, on June 26, 2011 at age 90. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Loving mother of Larry (Ilene) and Ben. Adored grandmother of Sarah and Josh. Lover of books and knowledge, and a student of Yiddish. Librarian at Washington Irving High School. Funeral service will be held 11am, Wednesday, June 29, 2011 at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 353 Second Ave, (between 20th and 21st streets). Interment to follow at Mount Moriah Cemetery. Contributions in her memory can be made to: Workman's Circle Bookstore.

An article on Monday about the obstacles that the movement to legalize same-sex marriage faces beyond New York State misstated the success of efforts to defeat same-sex marriage proposals at the ballot box. In 2006 Arizona voters defeated a measure that would have banned a broad range of same-sex partnerships -- including marriage. (In 2008 they approved a narrower measure banning same-sex marriage only.) It is not the case that no state referendum or initiative to outlaw same-sex marriage has been defeated.

McMILLIN--Peter Sheehan, on June 26, 2011, of Garden City. Beloved son of John and Ellen. Dear brother of Andrew. Also survived by loving aunts, uncles and cousins. In his short life he touched many with his fun loving spirit, wit and charm. His life greatly enriched his family and friends. Visiting Tuesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, 10:30am at St. Josephs R.C. Church, Garden City. Interment to follow at Locust Valley Cemetery.

Sandy Pope acknowledges straightaway that she faces an uphill battle -- she is the first woman to run for the presidency of the very macho Teamsters union, and she is running against a three-term incumbent, James P. Hoffa, who has the most famous last name in American labor. But Ms. Pope, president of the Teamsters Local 805 in Queens since 2005, insists that she can pull off an upset. She argues that the rank and file are tired of Mr. Hoffa and fed up with contracts packed with concessions.

New York may be a concrete jungle, but the bright lights of Broadway have inspired Alicia Keys to produce Lydia R. Diamond's play ''Stick Fly'' for the Lyceum Theater at the end of the year. Press representatives for the show said on Monday that Ms. Keys, the ''Empire State of Mind'' songstress, will present the play, which she is producing with Reuben Cannon and Nelle Nugent, and which will be directed by Kenny Leon, the director of last year's Tony Award-winning revival of ''Fences.'' This incarnation of ''Stick Fly,'' which chronicles the interactions and revelations within a well-to-do black family at its home in Martha's Vineyard, will mark the Broadway debut for Ms. Diamond, a widely produced playwright whose other works include ''Voyeurs de Venus,'' ''The Gift Horse'' and ''The Bluest Eye,'' an adaptation of the Toni Morrison novel.

DONNENFELD--Alvin, M.D. He is acclaimed for his vision as an obstetrical collaborator with pioneering nurse-midwives who in 1975 opened the first demonstration free-standing birth center in the country on Carnegie Hill in the Upper East Side of New York City. The success of that initial effort, also replicated in the Southwest Bronx, resulted in over 200 such midwifery sponsored centers operating today with state licensure, national standards and formal accreditation available. One such center, opened in 2000 in a disadvantaged African American community of our nation's capital, has succeeded in reducing preterm birth, low birth weight infants and cesarean section, while simultaneously improving family cohesiveness and reducing the costs of care. It was Dr. Donnenfeld's early support for those childbearing families demanding the personalized care for which he was known, a homelike setting and low intervention, that provided significant support to the general acceptance of the midwifery model. He was undeterred by the reluctance of most colleagues to acknowledge his insights as to the potential and now demonstrated national benefits. Our hearts go out to his wife, Eleanor and his family. Ruth Watson Lubic, CNM, Ed.D, Founder Developing Families Center, 801 17th St. NE Washington, DC. 202-398-2007

COHEN--Dinah, daughter of the late Henry Cohen and the late Maye Cohen, passed away on June 25, 2011. Ms. Cohen was 87 years old. For over 30 years Ms. Cohen was an employee of Polo Ralph Lauren. In addition, she was an avid animal lover and supported many animal charities. A Memorial Service will take place on Tuesday at 6pm at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the ASPCA.

Whether you're interested in Philip Roth's critical exegesis of ''A Visit From the Goon Squad,'' his contrarian take on ''Freedom'' or just curious to know what he thinks of ''The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,'' his answer is likely to be the same: He probably hasn't read them because he is no longer reading fiction at all. In an interview with The Financial Times, Mr. Roth, the ornery author more than two dozen novels (the FT credits him with 53 books) including ''Portnoy's Complaint,'' ''The Human Stain'' and ''Nemesis,'' said that other people's literary inventions are no longer part of his diet. ''I've stopped reading fiction,'' he said. ''I don't read it at all. I read other things: history, biography. I don't have the same interest in fiction that I once did.'' Asked why he came to this position, Mr. Roth said: ''I don't know. I wised up.'' The Financial Times said Mr. Roth was not expected to be in London on Tuesday when he will be celebrated as the winner of the Man Booker International Prize, a literary award honoring his lifetime achievements. Carmen Callil, a former judge for that prize, probably wishes that she had the same discretion to read or not read other people's books. When Mr. Roth was named the winner she quit the panel in protest, saying, ''I don't rate him as a writer at all.''

FRONT PAGE Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Congressional votes on United States military involvement in Libya misstated the outcome if the Senate passed a resolution proposed by Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona. Such a vote would express only the Senate's support for the Libya mission. The resolution would require approval by the House as well for full Congressional authorization of United States military involvement.

About midday on June 30, 1861, the Sumter, a recently refitted Confederate ship helmed by Capt. Raphael Semmes, slipped over the bar at Pass à l’Outre, the easternmost channel of the Mississippi River south of New Orleans; after a dramatic four-hour chase by the Brooklyn, a Union sloop-of-war, it was on the loose in the Caribbean. The Sumter was just one ship, helmed by an obscure former United States Navy officer — but over the next six months it would have a devastating impact on Union commercial shipping.

The Knicks extended a qualifying offer to forward Derrick Brown on Wednesday, making him a restricted free agent. The designation means that the Knicks will have the right to match any offer Brown receives, assuming the rules do not change substantially in the N.B.A.’s next labor deal.

Call it a new twist for an old business — Microsoft is rolling out a mode of advertising that will enable Xbox Kinect users to use game-style voice and motion controls to interact with ads. This month, the Supreme Court ruled that police, when questioning a child suspected of committing a crime, must take the suspect’s age into account and may have to provide Miranda warnings in circumstances that would not require the warnings to be given to an adult suspect.  The vote was 5 to 4, and the author of the majority opinion was Justice Sonia Sotomayor. The premise that children are different from adults and may feel coercive pressure when an adult would not, she said, was simply one of “commonsense reality.”

DETROIT — Sandy Alderson was so taken by the combination of events that produced two grand slams in the span of seven at-bats Tuesday night — after the Mets had gone almost two years without one — that he provided an eloquent analysis worthy of the event.

A bill that would move New Jersey’s presidential primary election to June, instead of February, awaits Gov. Chris Christie’s signature. The delay has two benefits: both political parties said they would penalize most states that hold nominating contests before March 2012, and by having the presidential primary on the same day as the races for all the other offices in the state, New Jersey could save as much as $12 million, according to one estimate.

There is a ripple of unease among many scientists who study the warming of the planet these days. Some have faced harassment, legal challenges and even death threats related to their research, the American Association for the Advancement of Science reports.

The performance artist Xavier Cha thrives on the unknown. Her process is largely improvisational and embraces the random variables many artists work hard to avoid. For “Holiday Cruise!,” her solo show at Taxter and Spengemann Gallery back in 2006, Cha enlisted about a hundred performers to interact with her as she played three different characters. One of the characters was dressed in a bodysuit completely covered with cornrows (and elicited numerous requests to dance). Another character simply lay in and among oversized fruits and vegetables in a massive Horn of Plenty. The third character, Polyhedra, was still as a statue.

If there was any doubt that resort is now a fully fledged season — and not just a smattering of pretty frocks and bikinis to fill the months between fall and spring — Massimiliano Giornetti, may have settled it, presenting his collection for Ferragamo last night to much fanfare at the former Doris Duke mansion on the Upper East Side. A fleet of nautical-inspired looks, evening gowns in a range of blue hues and this crisp, cotton scarf print top and skirt, harked back to the label’s heyday in the 1930s and spoke to Giornetti’s ambition to complement the “stylish lifestyle of a well-traveled heiress.”

Lanvin’s spring/summer 2012 collection finale in the rotunda of the historic Bourse de Commerce was an unexpectedly moving experience, with a parade of models neutrally and rather simply attired (for Lanvin standards), ascending a staircase from below and walking in a giant circle, melding into one continuous rotating mass until each model in succession retreated back downstairs. Maybe it was the stirring music. Maybe it was the simplicity of a stronger, more utilitarian look that seemed straight out of Claire Denis’s meditation on the military, “Beau Travail.” The gauzy gray mix of a layered double-breasted jacket worn with an airy duster and semisheer trousers tucked into combat boots was heroically beautiful.

The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday designated a 600-building swath of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, as a historic district. The district, bound by Bergen Street and Eastern Parkway to the north and south, and Nostrand and Brooklyn Avenues to the west and east, adjoins the existing Crown Heights North Historic District, which includes 472 buildings and was designated in 2007.

John Byrne and David LaChapelle used to be a couple. The romance didn’t last, but the two have continued their relationship through art. Mr. Byrne, a choreographer and former dancer for Paul Taylor, worked on “Rize,” Mr. LaChapelle’s 2005 documentary about krumping, as well as “Elton John: The Red Piano.” Now Mr. LaChapelle has produced Mr. Byrne’s first full-length work of dance, “Transcending Form,” with Fred Torres, at Theater 80 every Wednesday through Aug. 24. In addition, Mr. Byrne has created a structured improvisation piece at Lever House, home to an exhibit of Mr. LaChapelle’s work, “From Darkness To Light.” Pedestrians can happen across this performance every Wednesday from 1 to 2 p.m. We talked to Mr. Byrne and Mr. LaChapelle about their new works, their collaboration and the melding of dance and art. The final round of NBC’s singing competition “The Voice” garnered its best ratings in four weeks on Tuesday as the four remaining contestants battled it out to be the last singer standing. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two-hour episode delivered the night’s largest audience, 12.5 million viewers, building on NBC’s ratings at 8 p.m. for “America’s Got Talent” (12 million). No other network came close on the night. CBS placed second with reruns of “NCIS” (8.2 million) and “NCIS: Los Angeles” (8 million) at 8 and 9. ABC was third, drawing its best ratings at 8 for “Wipeout” (5.5 million) and solid results at 9 for “101 Ways to Leave a Game Show” (5.3 million). At 10, ABC’s “Combat Hospital” (4.6 million) lagged just behind CBS’s repeat of “The Good Wife” (4.8 million). Fox finished in fourth as “MasterChef” attracted 4.2 million viewers at 8 while back-to-back reruns of “Raising Hope” averaged 2.2 million viewers at 9 p.m.

MySpace, the troubled Web site that was bought by the News Corporation six years ago for $580 million, was sold on Wednesday to the advertising targeting firm Specific Media for roughly $35 million, The New York Times reports. The News Corporation, which is controlled by Rupert Murdoch, had been trying to get rid of the unprofitable site since last winter. Read more »

Had one of Andy Warhol’s more entrepreneurial visions come to fruition, the storefront at the northeast corner of 74th and Madison, today a vintage watch dealer, would be the site of the world’s first Andy-Mat, an international chain of fast-food restaurants for people who prefer to eat alone. “I want to start a chain of restaurants for other people like me called Andy-Mats,” Warhol said. “The restaurant for the lonely person. You get your food and then take your tray into a booth and watch television.” According to architectural drawings, customers would have placed their orders with the kitchen directly, through a system of pneumatic tubes. The food, prepared off-site and frozen, would have been delivered to the franchise and then reheated. The project fell through in 1977, but not before $40,000 in rent had been paid, $1 million in capital had been secured, and Maxine de la McKendry, a society hostess and onetime food columnist for Vogue, had prepared the menu: milk over ice, anyone?

The final designs for the Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center, a major hub for the arts planned for Athens, were unveiled on Wednesday. The center, designed by Renzo Piano, includes a 42-acre park, the headquarters for the National Library of Greece and a 1,400-seat opera house for the Greek National Opera. Budgeted at more than $800 million, the project is to be financed by the Stavros Niarchos Foundation. Construction, to begin later this year, is to be completed in 2015.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- Several heavily armed attackers stormed one of the capital's fortified premier hotels on Tuesday night, and sporadic shooting and at least two loud explosions were heard as Afghan security forces battled insurgents for hours afterward. Coming within a week of President Obama's announcement of troop withdrawals from Afghanistan, the attack underscored the still precarious nature of security, even in the capital, as the transfer of responsibility to Afghan forces is about to begin in several areas of the country, including Kabul.

SCHIOWITZ--Stanley, D.O.,died at the age of 88 on Monday, June 27th, 2011. Devoted husband of the late Lillian Schiowitz for 59 wonderful years, he is survived by his children Josh Schiowitz, Ellen and Keith Ellis, and his granddaughter Justine. An Osteopathic physician, Dr. Schiowitz graduated from the Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine in October of 1944 at the age of 22. Over the next 35 years he worked as a Family Physician, incorporating Osteopathic manipulative medicine into his practice in his native Brooklyn. During the course of his career in Brooklyn, he held various positions in professional organizations, including serving as President of the New York State Osteopathic Medical Society. In 1966, he and several colleagues created Interboro General Hospital of which he became the Director of Medical Education from 1971 to 1977. One of the founders of the New York College of Osteopathic Medicine and first chair of the Department of Osteopathic Manipulative Medicine, Dr. Schiowitz became Dean of the school in 1992. He added duties as the Dean of the School of Allied Health and Life Science in 1995 for which he created degree programs in a variety of medical, allied fields. He is also the author of several articles as well as one of the editors of An Osteopathic Approach to Diagnosis and Treatment, a textbook in use at various Osteopathic medical colleges. He has received numerous awards, including the highest award given by the American Osteopathic Association, the Distinguished Service Certificate. After retiring in 2002, he remained active in the field by traveling around the country teaching Master classes to younger physician-colleagues already practicing the art and science of Osteopathic manipulative medicine. Stanley touched many lives. We have lost a healer, mentor, educator, wise counselor, friend, father, and grandfather. He spent his life as a humanitarian, helping others while never asking for help himself, and always going just one step more. In honor of his late wife Lillian he helped fund a lecture series concerning Jewish Women, knowing these events were just the kind of evenings Lillian would have happily attended. Memorial Service will take place on Wednesday, June 29th, 1pm, at Riverside-Nassau at 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck 11021. Donations can be made to Temple Israel for the Lillian Schiowitz Fund, (108 Old Mill Rd, Great Neck, NY 11023) or to a charity of your choice.

The man at the center of the fight is a New York billionaire who runs the energy business from offices on the top floor of the General Motors Building on Fifth Avenue overlooking Central Park.

Call them nature's Pop Rocks. Szechuan buttons are little yellow flower buds that produce a strong, tingling and numbing effect on the tongue, like Sichuan peppercorns, hence the name. Acmella oleracea, sometimes called the toothache plant for its anesthetic effect, which takes about 10 minutes to wear off, is the source. Tiny dulce buttons from a South American plant tickle another part of the mouth; they are said to be 1,000 times as sweet as cane sugar. Both are intriguing and fun to use to garnish ice cream and drinks. Szechuan buttons are $44 for 30; dulce buttons, $54 for 50, and a mix of both is $59 for 80, all including shipping; marxfoods.com. Refrigerated, they keep 10 days and can be frozen.

SMITH--Walter V.,age 67, a long time Stamford resident passed away on Tuesday June 28th after a brief illness. Walter was born in Long Island City, New York on February 21, 1944. He was the son of the late Walter V. and Lillian V. Smith. He is survived by his devoted wife of 44 years, Judith; his beloved children Jessica Smith, Stephanie Smith Geier and her husband Alex, Jason Smith and his wife Lyn, and Colleen Smith. He also leaves behind four adored grandchildren; Eleanor, Margaret, Colin and Keira. He is also survived by his sister; Judith Brennan her husband Sean and his loving uncle and aunt Jack and Kathleen Geiger as well as many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his brother, Jonathan W. Smith. Walter was a tax attorney who had a long and distinguished career with Altria Corporation where he was the Vice President of Corporate Taxes. He was a member of St. Leo's Parish and was an active volunteer in the community. Upon retirement, Walter explored his sense of adventure through traveling, becoming a licensed pilot and also joining the United States Auxiliary Coast Guard where he achieved the status of Flotilla Staff Officer and Vessel Examiner. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Friday, July 1, 2011 at St. Leo Parish, 24 Roxbury Road in Stamford at 10am. Interment will follow at Our Lady Queen of Peace Cemetery, Stamford. Relatives and friends may call at Leo P. Gallagher & Sons Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford on Thursday, June 30, 2011 from 4 to 8pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to AmeriCares, ATTN: Andrea Vakos 88 Hamilton Avenue, Stamford, CT 06902.

MONAGHAN--Terry. We mourn the passing of Terry Monaghan, the co-founder of London's Jiving Lindy Hoppers, who played a major role in the world-wide revival of Swing. He was 67 years old. An indefatigable researcher and relentless interviewer, Terry was the world's foremost authority on Harlem's Savoy Ballroom, the home of happy feet and the home of the Lindy Hop. If there is a great ballroom in the sky, he joins Al and Frankie, Whitey and Leon, and the other great Lindy Hoppers from the Savoy. We will miss him and always remember him. Larry Schulz and Sandra Cameron

The Brazilian singer-songwriter Caetano Veloso has agreed to step into an unfamiliar role, that of ''guest director'' helping to pick and present the films for the 38th Telluride Film Festival, which will be held over the Labor Day weekend. A confessed cinephile, Mr. Veloso has composed soundtracks for movies, performed in his friend Pedro Almodovar's ''Talk to Her,'' written essays about his love for Italian neo-realist films and even recorded a CD tribute to Federico Fellini and Giulietta Masina. Past guest directors at the festival have included writers like Salman Rushdie and Don DeLillo, the composers Stephen Sondheim and Laurie Anderson and the film directors Bertrand Tavernier and Peter Bogdanovich. Mr. Veloso, who is 68 and in the 1960s was a founder of the influential cultural movement known as Tropicalismo, was suggested for the post by the theater director Peter Sellars, himself a former guest director.

If you had the number three in your office pool of how many new Broadway plays would be announced on Tuesday, prepare to collect your winnings. Adding to today's embarrassment of Rialto riches, the producers Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel said that they will bring a production of David Henry Hwang's comedy ''Chinglish'' to Broadway in the fall, after its run at the Goodman Theater in Chicago ends in July. The plot chronicles the translational and trans-national tensions that develop when the owner of an American sign company travels to China in hopes of stirring up business there. Reviewing ''Chinglish'' for The Chicago Tribune, Chris Jones called it a ''shrewd, timely and razor-sharp comedy'' and said it was Mr. Hwang's best work since ''M. Butterfly''; in The Chicago Sun-Times, Mary Houlihan described it as a ''complex roundelay of words and misunderstandings'' that ''evolves into a one-joke comedy milked to the last drop.''
International PROTESTS IN GREECE

BUSINESS DAY An article on Monday about the conservative author and blogger Andrew Breitbart described incorrectly the reaction of an N.A.A.C.P. audience to a remark by Shirley Sherrod, a black Agriculture Department official. In a short video clip of the speech, which Mr. Breitbart released as evidence that Ms. Sherrod acknowledged not helping a white farmer, some audience members nodded and murmured in apparent approval; they did not applaud, although Mr. Breitbart stated that they did. (The full video showed that Ms. Sherrod's speech was about overcoming racial prejudice, and that she did go to great lengths to help the white farmer.)

9 P.M. (Style) CLEAN HOUSE: MESSIEST HOME IN THE COUNTRY 5 Lillian, a dysfunctional mother living in squalor, above, on the outskirts of Richmond, Va., and her daughters receive a life makeover, above right, from Vicki Gunvalson of ''The Real Housewives of Orange County'' in this two-hour special. Among the family's challenges are moldy bathrooms in disrepair and a kitchen overrun with critters. Then there's the emotional debris. Lillian has been estranged from her husband for nearly two decades, but she still irons his shirts, and he pays the bills. She also hasn't worked in 22 years and can't explain how she spends her time -- except to say that she doesn't clean. The clutter fills 83 garbage bags and 468 boxes, creating the inventory for an 80,000-square-foot yard sale. Proceeds are to benefit the Wounded Warrior Project, which helps severely injured troops as they return to civilian life. 8 P.M. (NBC) THE VOICE The winner of $100,000 and a recording contract is revealed.

He made angry men of Lee J. Cobb and E. G. Marshall, got Peter Finchmad as hell and had Al Pacinoscreaming ''Attica'' at the top of his lungs, and next month Sidney Lumet, the director of ''12 Angry Men,'' ''Network,'' ''Dog Day Afternoon'' and many more seminal works of cinema, will be the subject of a tribute by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. The society said that the retrospective, called ''Prince of the City: Remembering Sidney Lumet,'' will run from July 19 through 25 and will feature screenings of 16 films by that director, who died in April. Movies including ''Serpico,'' ''The Verdict'' and ''The Wiz'' will be shown at the Walter Reade Theater in Manhattan. The retrospective will also feature a Q-and-A with Walter Bernstein, the screenwriter of ''Fail Safe,'' after a showing of that film on July 20; the actor Treat Williams and the N.Y.P.D. detective Robert Leuci will appear after a screening of ''Prince of the City'' on July 24; and, of course, Lumet's film ''Q&A'' will be followed by a Q-and-A with Luis Guzman, Paul Calderon and Judge Edwin Torres, the author of the novel from which the film was adapted. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

CAIRO (AP) -- Security forces firing tear gas clashed with about 5,000 rock-throwing protesters in central Cairo late Tuesday in the latest unrest to rattle Egypt, witnesses and medical officials said. Clouds of tear gas engulfed Tahrir Square. Many demonstrators are relatives of the more than 850 people killed during the revolution this year. The families are frustrated with what they view as the slow prosecution of those responsible for the deaths.

INTERNATIONAL An article on Thursday about the political reaction to President Obama's speech on withdrawing American troops from Afghanistan misstated the military service records of candidates who have announced they are running for president in 2012. Representative Ron Paul, Republican of Texas, served in the United States Air Force as a flight surgeon. It is not the case that neither Mr. Obama nor any current presidential candidates has served in the military.

Now that ''Born Yesterday'' has ended its Broadway run, it looks like its star Nina Arianda will be returning to her routine of attending auditions and occasionally subjugating the men who run them. Which is to say, she will reprise her breakthrough role in David Ives's play ''Venus in Fur,'' in a new Broadway production that Manhattan Theater Club will bring to the Samuel J. Friedman Theater in the fall, press representatives for the show said on Tuesday. Ms. Arianda won rave reviews last year for the play's original Off Broadway production at Classic Stage Company, in which she portrayed Vanda, an actress who is willing to go to extreme lengths and then some to land a role in the play-within-the-play, adapted from Leopold von Sacher-Masoch's erotic novel ''Venus in Fur.''

DONNENFELD--Alvin, M.D. He is acclaimed for his vision as an obstetrical collaborator with pioneering nurse-midwives who in 1975 opened the first demonstration free-standing birth center in the country on Carnegie Hill in the Upper East Side of New York City. The success of that initial effort, also replicated in the Southwest Bronx, resulted in over 200 such midwifery sponsored centers operating today with state licensure, national standards and formal accreditation available. One such center, opened in 2000 in a disadvantaged African American community of our nation's capital, has succeeded in reducing preterm birth, low birth weight infants and cesarean section, while simultaneously improving family cohesiveness and reducing the costs of care. It was Dr. Donnenfeld's early support for those childbearing families demanding the personalized care for which he was known, a homelike setting and low intervention, that provided significant support to the general acceptance of the midwifery model. He was undeterred by the reluctance of most colleagues to acknowledge his insights as to the potential and now demonstrated national benefits. Our hearts go out to his wife, Eleanor and his family. Ruth Watson Lubic, CNM, Ed.D, Founder Developing Families Center, 801 17th St. NE Washington, DC. 202-398-2007

Pinkies up, wiseguys. Sullivan St. Tea & Spice Company has moved into the former home of Vincent Gigante's Triangle Social Club in Greenwich Village. Mark Greenberg, the owner, said he wanted to offer more products than he could at Grounded, his organic coffee and tea cafe in the West Village. There is now plenty of room for about 70 teas, most of them organic, and about 80 spices. There is a rare, spinach-green shade-grown gyokoru tea from Japan, and potted herbs, succulents and even Venus' flytrap plants. Sullivan St. Tea & Spice Company, 208 Sullivan Street (Bleecker Street), (212) 387-8702. Teas, herbs and spices are sold by the ounce, 70 cents to $9. Potted herbs are $3.50.

Mark J. Gerard, a veterinarian who cared for champion racehorses like Kelso and Secretariat but who perpetrated one of the most notorious racetrack frauds of the postwar era, died June 21 in Miami. He was 76. The cause was complications of a stroke, his sister, Joyce Aimee Titchnell, said.

SEGAL--Edith Levy, died peacefully at home on Tuesday, June 28, shortly before her 95th birthday. Beloved wife of Martin E.; mother of Susan Rai and Paul Segal; mother-in-law of Kanti Rai and Christine Flynn; grandmother of Samantha and Joshua Rai, Emma Segal, and Sarah Flynn; grandmother-in-law of Jay Zaslow; great-grandmother of Ella and Mira Zaslow; and sister of Jacqueline Levy and the late William Levy. A 1936 graduate of Hunter College, for 74 years she stood behind and beside her husband while he built a business and then became a founder and leader of arts institutions. She served as a volunteer for nearly half a century, first at her children's school, then as an evaluator of books for the Child Study Association, and finally--well into her eighties--as a teacher of public school children who did not speak English. She taught three generations how to be a loving, and effective, child, spouse, parent, and grandmother; a responsible member of the community; and a good person. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, June 30 at 10:30am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. Interment will be private. The family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Friday, July 1 from 10:00am to 1:00pm; Tuesday, July 5 from 4:00 to 7:00pm; and Wednesday, July 6 from 4:00 to 7:00pm. In lieu of flowers you may contribute to WQXR (WQXR c/o New York Public Radio, PO Box 1550, New York, NY 10116-1550), which brought her so much pleasure throughout her life and so much comfort in her final months.

LOS ANGELES -- When he took over as governor this year, Jerry Brown set his ambitions high. He wanted to break the partisan gridlock that had handicapped the Legislature for years. With the state facing a staggering deficit, Mr. Brown said over and over that he refused to close the gap with the same sort of smoke-and-mirrors budget tricks that the state had relied on for years. But now, months after he assumed the state's highest office (for the second time), Mr. Brown finds himself crashing against the same wall of frustration, unable to get support from the Republican opposition. While the $131 billion budget agreement between Mr. Brown and the Democrats who control the Legislature, which relies heavily on optimistic revenue predictions, is by many measures an improvement from the recent past, it falls far short of what Mr. Brown hoped for as recently as last week. That budget passed the legislature late Tuesday night.

FELDMAN--Dr. Stephen, M.D. Our dearest Steve fought lung cancer for over four years. His life was filled with love, honor and dignity. He will live in our hearts forever. Dr. Glen and Diane Mogan and children.

In the interest of letting nothing go to waste, White Cow Dairy in East Otto, N.Y., near Buffalo, has introduced what it calls yogurt tonics, made from the cloudy liquid whey on top of yogurt that is usually either poured off or stirred in. Patrick Lango, the owner, said he wanted to find a use for whey, which he blends with whole milk yogurt to make drinks, which are said to be rich in probiotic enzymes and come in various flavors. The sunflower-yellow turmeric is delicious with Indian food. The lime tonic, and the Big Star, with star anise, sumac and honey, are winners, and the lemonade and berry flavors are nicely tart. White Cow Dairy Tonics are $3.99 for 11 ounces at Murray's Cheese stores, 254 Bleecker Street (Cornelia Street) and at Grand Central Market, Lexington Avenue and 43rd Street.

SONENBERG--Martin, M.D.,Ph.D., 90, was a world renowned physician and researcher who made significant contributions to the treatments of thyroid cancer and growth disorders. He was Chief of Endocrinology at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and Professor of Medicine and Biochemistry at Cornell University Medical College. Dr. Sonenberg won numerous awards throughout his career and served as Chair of the National Institutes of Health Endocrine Study Section. He also served as a medical officer in the U.S. Navy. He is survived by his wife, Dellie, daughters Santha (John Ogulnik) and Andrea, and grandchildren, Josh and Rebecca Jurbala. A celebration of Dr. Sonenberg's life and his tremendous contributions will take place on Friday July 1, 2011, at 1:00pm at The Cornell Club, 6 East 44th Street, New York, NY 10017, with a reception to follow.

PARIS -- Christine Lagarde on Tuesday became the first woman to be appointed to the helm of the International Monetary Fund, taking on one of the most powerful positions in global finance as a worsening crisis in Greece threatens the euro currency union and rattles financial markets worldwide. Her victory was sealed when the U.S. Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, said the United States would endorse her over the Mexican central bank governor Agustín Carstens -- her only competitor for the job.

An article on Tuesday about Sandy Pope, a female candidate for president of the Teamsters union, misstated a provision of a Teamster contract with YRC Worldwide that was criticized by Ms. Pope. It granted some equity in YRC to union members, not to the union itself. (It would be a violation of labor law for the company to grant stock to the union.)

OBITUARIES An obituary on Saturday about the comic-book artist Gene Colan misstated the name of the woman to whom he was previously married. She was Sallee Greenberg, not Cynthia Sanders. The obituary also omitted two surviving children from Mr. Colan's marriage to Ms. Greenberg, Valerie Waldman and Jill Kubicki, and two grandchildren.

KUMMEL--Eugene H. of Manhattan and Edgartown, MA died on June 25, 2011 at age 88. Cherished husband of Barbara, his wife of 56 years, proud father of Charles, Andrew and William, dear father-in-law of Shawna, loving brother of Bertram and adoring uncle, grand-uncle and great-grand-uncle of 21. Admired and respected for his love of family, friends and colleagues, he will be greatly missed. Services are today at 10am at Temple Emanu-El of New York City.

BROWNJohn, 68, died on June 27 after an extended illness. Beloved by his family--his wife, Susan Feagin, his daughter and son-in-law Jennifer and Ryan McDonald, his daughter and son-in-law Julie and Matt Hinkle, and grandchildren Kaylie, Shae, and Seth--John led a remarkable life. He contributed immeasurably to our nation's cultural vibrancy as a fundraiser and fundraising consultant on behalf of hundreds of universities and nonprofits, including Harvard, where he created the planned giving program, and more recently the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. His consultancy, John Brown Limited, mentored a generation of planned giving specialists and other fundraising professionals based on principles of fostering donor ownership and respect. The family is planning a public memorial service for later this year. John, your wisdom, laughter, and love of life will stay with us always.

STEINER--Dr. Charles. Renowned physician Dr. Charles Steiner of South Orange, NJ died on Monday. A native of Newark, he served the communities of Essex County for over 60 years. Earlier this year he was awarded Physician of the Year by the New Jersey Association of Osteopathic Physicians and Surgeons. He was married to the late Dr. Gloria Steiner for 66 years. An avid tennis player, he played in senior tournaments until age 91. He began as a general practitioner, delivering babies, doing surgery and making house calls day and night. Later he specialized in physical medicine, curing bad backs and joint ailments. He discovered a technique for relieving joint and muscular pain and saved scores of people from the need for surgery. Throughout his life he was involved with numerous community and professional organizations. In the 1950's he helped found the Morton Street Boys Club in Newark and much later became the Founding Chairman of the Sister Rose Thering Fund, which supports Jewish-Christian Studies at Seton Hall University. A founder of West Essex General Hospital, Livingston, NJ he was for many years its Chief of Staff. Dr. Steiner was the Founding Chairman and Professor of the Department Of Osteopathic Sciences of the NJ School of Osteopathic Medicine at UMDNJ. He is survived by his son Charles Steiner, Jr. and Charles' wife Leona Strassberg Steiner, his daughter Susan Sher and Susan's husband Neil Cohen, his daughter Jeanne Steiner and Jeanne's husband Will Rosenblatt, as well as his beloved grandchildren Graham Moore, Evan Moore, Hannah Rosenblatt and Jesse Rosenblatt. The funeral will take place 10:30am Wednesday, June 29 at B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills. Donations in his name may be made to The Sister Rose Thering Scholarship Fund at Seton Hall University.

MILLER--Robert. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the passing of their distinguished colleague. For more than 30 years the Robert Miller Gallery, under his and his wife's direction, has exhibited the work of a wide ranging group of artists whose work he championed. Since his retirement a decade ago the gallery has been led by his wife, Betsy, to whom we send our sympathy and condolences, as well as to his children, Robert Jr., Christopher and Mary Elizabeth. Lucy Mitchell-Innes, Pres.

City Room was thrilled to receive a news release from the Department of Parks and Recreation on Tuesday afternoon announcing that all 54 outdoor city pools would open to the public on Wednesday. Our excitement, however, turned to something else entirely when we read that ''former NY Yankee Lee Mazzilli'' would be on hand for opening day at a pool in the Bronx. Former what?
7:36 p.m. | Updated LinkedIn's stock is a long way from its first-day pop, when it traded above $100 a share. But its underwriters are feeling pretty optimistic about the Internet company.

THE ARTS A report on Monday in the Arts, Briefly column, about controversy surrounding the season finale of ''The Killing'' on AMC, misstated the media outlet for which the show's executive producer, Veena Sud, spoke in defense of her cliffhanger ending. It was the public radio show ''The Business,'' whose host is Kim Masters -- not The Hollywood Reporter, for which Ms. Masters also works.

PORGES--George Wolfgang, 74, a resident of Dallas, Texas, died in New York City on June 25, 2011, from complications of esophageal cancer. Born in Vienna, he had emigrated from Austria with his parents and brother shortly after the Anschluss, in May of 1938. His mother was a talented artist; his father was a practicing gynecologist-obstetrician. He grew up in Queens, attended Forest Hills High School, and was a graduate of Duke University. He worked for most of his adult life for Caltex Petroleum Company, beginning in 1960 and retiring in 1998. On his first expatriate assignment in Holland he met his wife Nicole (nee Margaine). Their life became an international voyage. His career moved from product engineering as a lubricant specialist, then into sales, oil trading, and finally various senior management positions with the company around the world. Early in his career he was part of the team in Korea that led to the establishment of the Caltex/LG joint venture Refining/Petrochemical company. Over the years George held a number of positions in the joint venture company ending up as General Manager of Caltex' Korean Operations. Today this company is arguably the most successful, long-lived joint venture company in Korea. He continued his involvement with Korea after retirement maintaining his membership in the US Korean Society and staying in contact with many of his Korean business associates. Interspersed with foreign assignments in Tokyo, Seoul, and Singapore were years of living in Dallas, New York City and summers in Connecticut. He and his friends from Caltex took many vacations sampling the world's best golf and ski resorts. George was charming and gregarious, liked and respected by all who knew him. Following a protracted illness, his wife Nicole predeceased him by less than three months. He is survived by his brother Robert and wife Felicia, his nephew John and wife Alexandra, their sons Dylan and David, and his niece Vicki and husband Joe Eisner, and their children Erin and Jesse, all in New York. Contributions may be made in George's memory to the NYU Langone Medical Center at 550 First Ave., New York City or to Duke University. A memorial gathering is planned in Dallas.

JENSEN--Mark William. Only 28 years old...you said goodbye to me on Gay Pride Day, June 29, 1986. Your loving and beautiful memory has been with me for 25 years. Growing up in Omaha, NE and educated in Kansas, you lived Over The Rainbow in New York. Thank you for giving me my courage and a heart. Yours always with love, Steven

We have every reason to believe that deep down, Alan Rickman is a decent, warm-hearted individual, if his affectionate farewell letter to the ''Harry Potter'' movies is any indication. But after playing the sinister Severus Snape in the final installment of that boy-wizard franchise this summer, Mr. Rickman will next be portraying another in his long line of memorable creeps in ''Seminar,'' a new play by Theresa Rebeck that will open on Broadway in the fall. ''Seminar,'' a dark comedy, casts Mr. Rickman as Leonard, a legendary author who provides private instruction to four promising young writers. But, as a news release for the production says ominously, ''as Leonard deems some students more promising than others, tensions arise. Sex is used as a weapon, alliances are made and broken, and it's not just the wordplay that turns vicious.''

VIDEO A. O. Scott looks at Alexander Mackendrick's 1957 film ''Sweet Smell of Success,'' starring Burt Lancaster as a powerful gossip columnist and Tony Curtis as an ambitious press agent. www.nytimes.com/video

The Smithsonian Institution has indefinitely postponed its plans to mount an exhibition of Chinese artifacts salvaged from a shipwreck because of opposition from archeologists who say the objects were collected by a commercial treasure hunter in a manner that violated professional standards. The exhibition, ''Shipwrecked: Tang Treasures and Monsoon Winds,'' was tentatively scheduled for next spring at the Freer Gallery of Art and Arthur M. Sackler Gallery, the Smithsonian's Asian art museums. A museum spokeswoman, Deborah Galyan, said that the earliest the museum might mount a ''Shipwrecked'' exhibit now would be 2013, a delay that she said would give the museums' director, Julian Raby, who also curated the exhibition, time to address some of the archeologists' concerns. The exhibition was conceived by the government of Singapore, which bought the artifacts for $32 million from the company that salvaged them from a wreck off the coast of Indonesia. It is currently on view at the ArtScience museum at the Marina Bay Sands resort and casino in Singapore. The salvage company has said it mined the artifacts quickly to avoid looting. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
A report on the Food Stuff page last Wednesday misidentified the maker of Hop Drops beer candy. He is Bob Bero, not Steve Casselman, who is selling it.

THE UNITED STATES scored twice in the second half to open its World Cup with a 2-0 victory over a young North Korean team. The North Koreans threatened in the first half, but American halftime adjustments paid off as North Korea tired. Lauren Cheney and Rachel Buehler scored for the United States. SWEDEN labored to a 1-0 win in 90-degree heat over the long shot Colombia. Jessica Landstrom scored Sweden's goal in the 57th minute after missing several chances.

RICHMAN--Jacqueline Corman, died peacefully on May 28, 2011 after a long illness. Today would have been her 82nd birthday. She and her husband, Lenny, enjoyed over 56 years of marriage before he predeceased her. She was an administrative assistant in the Long Beach Public Schools, served on the Board of Long Beach Reach, was a member of the Nassau County Commission on Human Rights, and was a contributor and supporter of many charities. She was a delegate for Senator Edward Kennedy at the 1980 Democratic National Convention, and previously held leadership positions in the campaigns of Congressman Allard K. Lowenstein. In her later years, she found a talent for writing, contributing a regular column to a local newspaper in Delray Beach, FL, and filling dozens of journals with stories. She adored and was loved in return and will be greatly missed by her family, her sons Michael P. Richman and Laurence B. Richman, Michael's wife Liz Fried Richman and their children, her grandsons Joseph and Peter Richman, her brother Avery Corman and her sister-in-law Judy Corman, who predeceased her, and their children, her nephews Matthew and Nicholas Corman, her cousins Alan and Iris Jacobs, and her nephew and niece Mark and Janet Baumgarten. Her wit and contagious exuberance for life and her essential goodness will also be greatly missed by her many devoted friends. Contributions in her memory may be made to God's Love We Deliver, www.GLWD.com.

SEGAL--Edith. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and extend condolences to her family, particularly her husband Martin E. Segal. Together they have shown their deep dedication to the culture of this city and have been generous benefactors of the Graduate Center and the cause of higher education. We and all New York will miss her incomparable spirit and kindness. William P. Kelly, President Frances Degen Horowitz, President Emerita CUNY Graduate Center
TALBOT--Donald E. Always. Roslyn and James

Dennis M. Walcott spoke about his own experience in Queens public schools. He described skydiving on his 50th birthday. And he told graduates all over New York City, those fin- ishing fifth, eighth or 12th grade or getting a G.E.D., that he hoped one of them would take his job someday. Mr. Walcott, who became schools chancellor in April, has spoken at 14 commencement ceremonies this month (a 15th was planned for Belmont Preparatory High School in the Bronx on Wednesday), far more than his predecessors (Joel I. Klein ad- dressed four in each of the past two years). On Tuesday, Mr. Walcott spoke at the com- mencement of his alma mater, Francis Lewis High School. More at nytimes.com/nyregion.JESSICA BELL, JESSICA CAMPBELL, CHRISTINA DIAZ AND RACHEL OHM Urban Assembly School for Applied Math and Science (South Bronx)June 25, 11 a.m.

An article last Wednesday about pisco, a South America grape spirit, attributed incorrectly the conclusion that pisco was the fastest-growing spirit in the country from 2009 to 2010. It was based on data from several sources; it was not a finding of the Distilled Spirits Council of the United States.

SEGAL--Edith. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts are profoundly saddened by the passing of Edith Segal, a beloved member of the Lincoln Center family and devoted wife of Chairman Emeritus Martin E. Segal for 74 years. With her warm spirit and welcoming smile, Edith stood at Marty's side for events ranging from practically every major gala at Lincoln Center to the annual Martin E. Segal Awards in generous support of young artists. Our heartfelt sympathies to her husband Martin, their son Paul and daughter-in-law Christine Flynn, their daughter Susan and son-in-law Dr. Kanti Rai, their grand and great grandchildren, and the entire Segal family. She will be deeply missed by all of us. Katherine Farley, Chair Reynold Levy, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

Updated, 4:10 p.m. | He sat. He rapped. He handed police officers his demo tape. For nearly two hours on Tuesday morning, a man held court atop the traffic-light apparatus on 44th Street and Seventh Avenue, attracting a camera-wielding crowd and closing down three blocks of traffic in the middle of Times Square.

HOLMES--Eve (Evelyn) Hatch, of New York City, Cedarhurst, New York and Palm Beach, Florida died at New York Hospital on June 24, 2011 following brief illness. Adored wife of the late E. Williams Homes. Loving stepmother of E. Williams Holmes, Jr., Peter B. Holmes and Jay H. Holmes. Eve was the daughter of novelist and screenwriter Eric Hatch and Sylvia Whiton-Stuart Hatch and cherished granddaughter of Frederick H. Hatch and May Daly Hatch. She had a long and distinguished career in the world of fashion and was for many years fashion editor of Town & Country magazine. Eve was an active member of the Lawrence Beach Club, Rockaway Hunt Club and the Colonial Dames of America. To her galaxy of dear friends worldwide, Eve was especially loved for her loyalty, razor-sharp mind and rollicking wit. She will be missed. Funeral service and burial: Trinity-St. John's Church, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, New York, Wednesday, June 29, at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to the charity of your choice will be appreciated.

NEW YORK An article on Tuesday about the cuts to schools in New York City's $66 billion budget misstated the formula by which federal money, known as Title I funds, has been granted to schools serving poor children For this school year and the previous one, it has gone to schools where 40 percent of students qualified for free or reduced-price lunch, not where 60 percent of students qualified for free lunch or 40 percent qualified for lunch at a reduced price.

KARP--Rose, on June 28, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Herman J. Karp. Devoted mother of Dr. Marvin Karp and Richard Reed. Cherished grandmother of Stacey Karp and Courtney Karp and great-grandmother of Stella Rose LeClair. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service: Thursday, June 30, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street.
In June 2011, Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, delivered his first floor speech from the floor of the U.S. Senate.
A family fleeing Tripoli arrived at the Libyan western mountains on Thursday and Libyans walked past destroyed buildings in Misurata.

NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. — Ever since Arnold Palmer clicked the clasp on his first Rolex wristwatch in 1967, the timepiece has been the go-to brand in well-healed golf circles. Now it faces competition from an old rival that has become the new face of one of the four major championships and the Ryder Cup matches.

FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — How long, on average, does it take you to suss out that there is something fishy going on in a crossword? Let’s say we’re talking about rebuses, which is actually quite convenient because today’s grid happens to have a rebus element in it. It’s not quite like other rebuses, though, and it’s kind of clever. If you are still wondering how to enter multiple letters in a grid, please read Martin Herbach’s wonderful instructional write-up here.

The Borders Group said on Thursday evening that it had picked the Najafi Companies, a private equity firm that owns the Book-of-the-Month Club, as the lead bidder in a forthcoming court-supervised auction for the bankrupt bookseller.

Steen B. Iversen tests mobile phones for the Danish telecommunications firm TDC. Before landing his job two and a half years ago, Iversen, 50, who has been diagnosed with Asperger’s Syndrome, spent more than 12 years looking for work. “It’s always been somewhat traumatizing,” he said. “I have had jobs, but I always got fired. People would laugh about me behind my back and laugh at me to my face. Those problems have more or less been a problem for me from childhood.”

WIMBLEDON, England — In 2008, James Cerretani’s father, Chip, strongly suggested it was time for him to retire from tennis and put his Brown University degree to use. Three years later, Cerretani’s sister Chrissy, a former college player at Clemson, is on the verge of quitting her job in Boston to travel with him on tour, he said — and with their father’s blessing.

Last summer, I wrote about a brewing court battle in Colorado. At issue was the question of whether the state could reduce the annual cost-of-living adjustments for the pensions of state workers who were already retired.

Californians will have to start paying sales tax on their purchases from Amazon.com starting Friday after Gov. Jerry Brown signed legislation earlier this week requiring online retailers to collect the tax.
In a commercial for Febreze, people were asked to take part in a scent experiment.
Despite what appeared to be clear photographic evidence published earlier this month on a Chinese government Web site, China has admitted that, in fact, its officials cannot levitate.

PHILADELPHIA — President Obama, speaking at a fund-raiser here on Thursday, did not roll out the aggressively partisan rhetoric he used at a news conference Wednesday to describe Republicans’ approach to budget negotiations.

Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner is weighing whether to step down after a deal is reached on the federal deficit, reports Mark Landler of The New York Times, citing two officials familiar with his thinking. "If Mr. Geithner does exit later this year, he would be the last member of Mr. Obama's economic brain trust to leave the administration after two-and-a-half years of turmoil," Mr. Landler writes. Raj Rajaratnam will enjoy another two months of freedom.

New York State Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s energy plans for the state are crystallizing. Through administrative moves, he has indicated that he sees the need to responsibly exploit the state’s enormous gas resource while moving toward ending nuclear power generation near New York City and its suburbs.

France and Germany filled the first two slots in the quarterfinals. France routed Canada, 4-0, becoming the first team to score more than two goals in a game so far. Germany eliminated a hard-working Nigeria team, which was unlucky to lose both its games by 1-0 against strong opposition.

Medicare confirmed on Thursday that it would pay for Provenge, the prostate cancer drug whose $93,000 price had set off debate about the cost of cancer treatments.

ALLENTOWN, Penn. — Standing before the locked gate of a steel plant that President Obama had once visited to promote his economic stimulus plan, Mitt Romney pointed out weeds and boarded-up windows on Friday and called the president’s handling of the economy a failure.

The comedian Stephen Colbert’s successful campaign to form a super PAC got plenty of attention on Thursday, but the Federal Election Commission‘s granting of Mr. Colbert’s request might not have been its most significant action of the day.

Forty thousand fireworks. Now that’s bound to make some noise. There are New Yorkers who will love every decibel on the Fourth of July, when Macy’s puts on its “biggest fireworks display in America.” Other New Yorkers — well, they’d much rather see the rockets’ red glare than hear the bursting in air. Certainly all city dwellers are used to noise, but there are those who hear a symphony in the cacophony and those who seek out New York’s many pockets of peace and quiet. Here, two views. Which do you prefer, the cacophony of New York or the quiet?

Everyone savors those “only in New York” moments: watching the Nathan’s hot-dog-eating contest in Coney Island or spotting a movie star in a restaurant in Manhattan. But another, equal pleasure is often overlooked: the “I can’t believe I’m still in New York” moment.

Atrios is annoyed at David Wessel, and rightly so. I’d summarize Wessel’s column a bit differently: it’s roughly “Some people thought from the beginning that the stimulus should have been much bigger. Hahaha! Also, it turns out that the stimulus was too small, so we need some more.”

It was a voyeuristic thrill watching the performance artist and Internet video sensation Kalup Linzy prance around the Boom Boom Room at the Standard Hotel, singing his heart out about his typically provocative subject matter. Clad in a green bathrobe (that had been cut into a dangerously short minidress) and a blond wig, Linzy sauntered barefoot before a relatively stodgy crowd of art-world types, who seemed to clutch their Champagne flutes in confusion. Hosted by Creative Time, the party celebrated the second installment of StandART, the hotel’s video art channel, which this time around includes works by Linzy, Terence Koh, Slater Bradley and Allison Schulnik, among others.

Blame Canada — or at least Air Canada. My simple trip home from Toronto turned into an 8-hour ordeal. And today I not only had to get tomorrow’s column done, I had to discuss a (very good) paper on the financing of frozen chicken exports. Honest.

Concerned, perhaps, that the contrails of atmospheric exhaust were not reaching prospective patrons as far away as the Avenue of the Americas intersection, the operators of the Subway restaurant at 31 West 43rd Street planted their flag firmly on the avenue itself.

The opera house of Brussels has appointed the Frenchman Ludovic Morlot as its chief conductor, an assignment being heralded halfway around the world, in Seattle. Mr. Morlot is the incoming music director of the Seattle Symphony, and will be taking on a second major job with his new position in Belgium starting next year at the Monnaie / De Munt opera house. The orchestra’s executive director, Simon Woods, said the appointment “demonstrates the growing international profile” of the Seattle music director.
The Fox News Channel’s temporary replacement for Glenn Beck will be a talk show featuring a rotating panel of opinionated people.

In a vote of 94-to-0, the Senate confirmed Gen. David H. Petraeus’s nomination to serve as director of the Central Intelligence Agency on Thursday. General Petraeus, the architect of counter-insurgency strategies in Iraq and Afghanistan, will succeed Leon E. Panetta, who is in turn taking over for Robert M. Gates at the Pentagon.

Anthony Vaccarello has a new accolade to add to his list of accomplishments. The 31-year-old Belgian designer has been named this year’s winner of the ANDAM Fashion Award, the French equivalent of the Council of Fashion Designers of America prize. He follows in the footsteps of past winners who include Giles Deacon, Gareth Pugh, Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren of Viktor & Rolf, and Martin Margiela.

Stephen Colbert, the satirical host of Comedy Central’s “Colbert Report,” got permission on Thursday to form a political action committee and promote it on his show.
Marc Andreessen, the founder of the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, announced yet another addition on Thursday.

The increasingly bitter dispute that erupted early in April when the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced it was eliminating 31 categories from the Grammy Awards notched up yet another step on Thursday when a New York law firm announced plans to sue the academy on behalf of musicians who play Latin jazz, one of the categories that is being dropped.

A rather peculiar building has appeared next to a canal in Hackney Wick, London. Just outside the future Olympics site, and shoehorned beneath the underpass of the A12 highway, “Folly for a Flyover” is the work of Assemble, a young collective of designers, artists and architects. The red brick structure — with a roof that peaks out between the eastbound and westbound lanes of highway above — was constructed by volunteers from reclaimed and donated materials. On the weekends the Folly houses a cafe, workshops and performances. Adventurous visitors can rent handmade rowboats from a small dock on the canal. In the evenings, from Friday to Sunday, there is a bar and an adjacent auditorium space underneath the highway, which hosts a series of screenings curated by the Barbican Art Gallery as part of its current exhibition “Watch Me Move: The Animation Show.”

The latest story in the ongoing International Herald Tribune series “The Female Factor,” which  looks at the global role of women, addresses a question we discussed on Motherlode this week — what does the life/work balance equation look like around the world? It is also thematically related to the Motherlode conversation Thursday  morning about whether Gen X women in the United States and Britain are choosing work over motherhood.
Kim Cattrall (“Sex and the City”) will reprise her role in “Private Lives” when Noël Coward’s comedy opens on Broadway this fall after a run in London last year.

The producers of the new Off Broadway musical “The Magdalene” met with representatives of the New York office of the Anti-Defamation League on Wednesday after receiving an e-mail the day before saying that the production contains anti-Semitic elements. The show, inspired by the Gnostic Gospels, offers an alternate version of the traditional story of Mary Magdalene. In the musical the title character, played by Lindsie Van Winkle, is not a prostitute and has a romantic relationship with Jesus, or Yeshua (Shad Olsen), causing infighting among his circle of disciples and further invoking the ire of the Roman government. The story ends as it usually does, with the Jesus character crucified.

When I walked into Other Music last weekend, the song “Dark Allies” by a two-person Brooklyn band called Light Asylum was playing. I have hardly stopped listening to it since. A Pitchfork review earlier this year praises singer Shannon Funchess for managing to “route her sinewy vocal through the cold-blooded seething of Ian Curtis, the deadpan drawl of Grace Jones and the full-tilt intensity of Henry Rollins circa ‘Damaged.'” I would add Peter Murphy. If you walk through the streets of New York with this on your iPod, every passing pedestrian looks like a lunatic just barely keeping it together — more than usual, I mean. On the band’s MySpace page, the genre is described as “Gospel/Gothic/Melodramatic Popular Song.” My new favorite genre.

Sam Calagione, the founder and president of Dogfish Head Craft Brewery, clearly enjoys adventurous brewing. But less exotic crafting has its appeal, too, as Kevin Burg and Jamie Beck’s “cinemagraphs” — photographs with movement on a loop — make clear. “My favorite days at Dogfish are the ones in which we are brewing a beer for the first time,” Mr. Calagione writes from Rehoboth Beach, Del. Instead of only describing the process or using “plain ol’ photos,” he invited the cinemagraphers, who are also his friends, to document a day of making strawberry beer: “Their amazing cinemagraphs have a mystical effect of bringing the viewer into the moment.”

Staying in shape on your summer vacation just got a little easier: Fairmont Hotels & Resorts is rolling out a free bike loan program at more than 55 of its properties worldwide. It has teamed with BMW Group to provide up to eight cruise bikes, along with helmets and locks, at participating hotels. Locations in North America already have the cycles (Le Manoir Richelieu in Quebec is shown at right); other properties will have them by mid-July. Concierges can help plan bike itineraries: visitors to the Fairmont Le Montreux Palace on Lake Geneva in Switzerland, for example, can cycle around the lake and surrounding countryside.

Lovers of folk art have just a week left to visit the American Folk Art Museum at its home on West 53rd Street before it closes its doors there for good. Struggling under a heavy load of debt, the museum recently sold the building to the Museum of Modern Art. On Thursday it said its last day in the building would be July 8. The museum will remain in operation in its much smaller branch at 2 Lincoln Square, where it currently has a show of quilts from the collection. MoMA has not yet said what it plans to do with the building, which was designed by the architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien and opened in 2001. A spokeswoman for the folk art museum, Susan Flamm, said the museum would have 90 days to vacate the building after the sale closes, which she said would happen in mid-July.

When it comes to motion pictures, Charlie Chaplin is the man, no? Well, an all-but-forgotten short film featuring footage of the comic star failed to sell at a London auction, defying expectations that it might fetch a six-figure sum, Reuters reported. The reserve price on the film at Wednesday’s sale was £100,000 ($160,000) at Bonhams auctioneers, but apparently that was too high. “Charlie Chaplin in ‘Zepped,’ ” is believed to be a propaganda film made in Britain during World War I. A collector discovered the seven-minute short inside an old film reel tin and bought it in 2009 for £3.20 (about $5) on the online auction site eBay. The film shows Chaplin taking on a German Zeppelin aircraft and features some of the earliest animation in film history. Chaplin probably never knew of the movie’s existence, said the film critic and Chaplin biographer David Robinson, according to Reuters. Mr. Robinson said an anonymous filmmaker had put together outtakes from three earlier Chaplin pictures — “His New Profession” (1914), “A Jitney Elopement” (1915) and “The Tramp” (1915) — and included sequences of stop-motion animation and other effects. Chaplin was not involved in the production of “Zepped,” but famously satirized Adolf Hitler in the 1940 movie “The Great Dictator.”

Maria Sharapova advanced to the Wimbledon final with a straight-sets victory over Sabine Lisicki. If you’ve been noticing more and more women sporting longer, impossibly perfect locks, it’s not your imagination. Hair extensions are practically de rigueur. The newest are Platinum Seamless Hair Extensions, which are tiny, sticky strips applied to the hair in under two hours (not the seven or eight that other methods require), and are said to be less damaging to hair and more natural looking. Stylists say these last up to three months, which is just as well. Platinum can cost $2,500 — no small chunk of change. At Ricardo Rojas, one of the few salons offering Platinum, that fee includes color match, installation, cut and styling. I tried them out last week and Rojas, whose clients include Eva Longoria and Bar Rafaeli, told it to me straight: “You don’t need these.” But now that I have them, I know why women become addicted. My hair attracted a bizarre amount of attention, so much that I decided it deserved its own diary.
