An obituary on Monday about the art dealer Robert Miller misstated his marital status at the time of his death. He was divorced from Betsy Wittenborn Miller, the current owner and president of the Robert Miller Gallery in Manhattan; she is no longer his wife and therefore should not have been listed among his survivors.

An article last Thursday about an American World War II veteran who received a replacement for the Patek Philippe watch that he had during the war but later lost in a burglary misidentified a German prisoner-of-war camp where he had been held. It was Stalag VII A, not Stalag Luft VII A.

POLKA DOTS, a fashion perennial, attracted a new round of attention when Marc Jacobs, who played around with circles for spring, went hog-wild on his fall runway with polka-dot pillbox hats and hosiery, and everything in between. Dots continued to pop up -- at Stella McCartney, Gucci and Lanvin. Celebrities ahead of the curve have already selected their spotted favorites from the fall collections. Beyoncé, out and about in Paris, wore a two-tone green-and-burgundy look from Mr. Jacobs's collection; Kate Winslet, for her ''Mildred Pierce'' premiere, chose a black Stella McCartney with one sheer polka-dot sleeve; and in London this month, the model Natalia Vodianova (above right) wore a laser-cut leather one-shoulder dress from the British designer David Koma. You can be ahead of the pack with a prefall look like this oversize circle-print dress from Acne or the sleeveless shift with an adorable bow from Sonia by Sonia Rykiel, both in stores now.

CHACE--Malcolm G.,Providence, RI. Malcolm Greene Chace, a leading businessman and philanthropist who enthusiastically embraced family, friends and community, died on Thursday, June 23, 2011 at Mass General hospital surrounded by his family. He was 76. Malcolm G. Chace Kim was born in Providence, RI on October 26, 1934, the son of the late Malcolm G. Chace, Jr. and Beatrice (Happy) Oenslager Chace. Providence was his home for the majority of his life. He married Elizabeth Zopfi Saltonstall on February 8, 1975, in Providence. Kim attended The Gordon School, Providence, RI and graduated from The Brooks School, North Andover, MA (1952) and Yale University, New Haven, CT (1956). The grounding to Mr. Chace's long and successful career in business and as a private investor began at Chase Manhattan Bank in New York City. He returned to Providence in 1967 to participate in the family businesses. In 1996 he founded Bank RI where he remained as Chairman of the Board. In 1992 Kim succeeded his father on the board of Berkshire Hathaway, which he served on until 2007. One of Mr. Chace's proudest moments in support of the arts in Providence was the 2009 opening of The Rhode Island School of Design Chace Center, which he jointly endowed with his two sisters, Jane Chace Carroll and Eliot Chace Nolen. In recognition of his dedication to Rhode Island education, he received honorary degrees from Brown University, Bryant University and Johnson and Wales University While known for his philanthropy, Kim is remembered by his family and friends for his support, love, prodigious intellect, voracious reading and rapier-like wit. His greatest legacy, however, is a large and loving family. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Zopfi Chace; sisters Jane Chace Carroll and Eliot Chace Nolen both of Manhattan; daughter, Elizabeth (John) Sundell of Nantucket, MA; son, Malcolm (Erin) Chace Jr. of Providence, RI; daughter, Barbara (Tony) Ulehla of Wilton, CT; step-daughter, Joanna Saltonstall (Larry Farwell); step-son, William (Katherine) Saltonstall of Hingham, MA; step-son, Thomas (Stephanie) Saltonstall; step-daughter, Julia (Bradford) Haley; and, 15 grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held on Thursday, July 14th, at 11am in Grace Church, Westminster St., Providence. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Chace Fund, 121 South Main Street, 4th Floor, Providence, RI 02903 from which funds will be distributed to community organizations with which Mr. Chace was deeply involved.
ROTHMAN--Deborah. 7/27/40- 6/30/07 Love always, Gary and David

FRONT PAGE An article on May 28 about a pledge by the Group of 8 wealthiest industrialized nations to send billions of dollars in aid to Egypt and Tunisia misstated the size of both the Egyptian and Tunisian economies. Egypt's is about $231 billion, according to the International Monetary Fund 2011 estimate, not $500 billion; Tunisia's is about $47 billion, according to the I.M.F. estimate, not $100 billion. This correction was delayed because an e-mail pointing out the error went astray at The Times.

G IVEN the kaleidoscopic signature print on the cap of its faceted pebble-shape bottle, and its soft green contents, we might buy the latest Emilio Pucci perfume even if it didn't smell so fine. Fortunately, it has a breezy summery scent to back the beautiful packaging. The newest of the Vivara series (the original was introduced in 1966), the fragrance is a blend of mint leaves and bergamot, sweetened by neroli bigarade and Turkish rose, with a base of cedar wood and Tonka bean. Inspired by the lush greenery of Vivara, an island near Capri, it's summer in a bottle. Or two. Emilio Pucci Vivara Variazioni Verde 072, $59 for 1.7 ounces at sephora.com.

General Electric extended its global Olympic sponsorship on Wednesday through 2020, matching the decision three weeks ago by NBC Universal to acquire the rights to the four Olympics from 2014 to 2020 for $4.38 billion. G.E., which sold majority control of NBC Universal to Comcast, has sponsored the Olympics since 2008. It added an estimated $200 million sweetener to the $2 billion it paid for NBC to carry the 2008, '10 and '12 Games.

BLACK--Bradford Reynolds, 24, beloved son of Steven and Deborah Black passed away June 23, 2011. He attended Brunswick School and Greenwich High School before completing his degree in Washington state. Bradford was bright, clever and witty, always jumping into every endeavor with passion and enthusiasm. He used his creative skills in many ways. He loved drawing, creating cartoons and was particularly adept at innovative computer programming. With his contagious smile, he never failed to make those around him laugh. In the last year he had rediscovered his lifelong passion for food and was pursuing a diploma at Le Cordon Bleu College of Culinary Arts in Los Angeles. He was so proud of his creations, frequently emailing photos of his dishes to his family and friends. In addition to his parents, he is survived by his sister Heather, his brother Taylor, his paternal and maternal grandparents and many aunts, uncles and cousins who all loved him dearly. A memorial service will be held on Friday, July 8 at 11:00am at Christ Church, Greenwich, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made in Bradford's name to the charity of your choice.
A listing on Wednesday in the Transactions column, about a recent lease at 118 Baxter Street in Manhattan, misstated the rent per square foot. It is $39, not $2,280, which is the monthly rent.

With or without new rules, the derivatives industry is gearing up for big changes. Three years ago, the complex securities wreaked havoc on Wall Street, prompting Congress to overhaul the long-unregulated market. The Dodd-Frank financial regulatory law requires companies to trade credit-default swaps and many other derivatives contracts through regulated exchanges or on a new invention known as swap execution facilities, or S.E.F.'s.

SEGAL--Edith Levy, died peacefully at home on Tuesday, June 28, shortly before her 95th birthday. Beloved wife of Martin E.; mother of Susan Rai and Paul Segal; mother-in-law of Kanti Rai and Christine Flynn; grandmother of Samantha and Joshua Rai, Emma Segal, and Sarah Flynn; grandmother-in-law of Jay Zaslow; great-grandmother of Ella and Mira Zaslow; and sister of Jacqueline Levy and the late William Levy. A 1936 graduate of Hunter College, for 74 years she stood behind and beside her husband while he built a business and then became a founder and leader of arts institutions. She served as a volunteer for nearly half a century, first at her children's school, then as an evaluator of books for the Child Study Association, and finally--well into her eighties--as a teacher of public school children who did not speak English. She taught three generations how to be a loving, and effective, child, spouse, parent, and grandmother; a responsible member of the community; and a good person. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, June 30 at 10:30am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. Interment will be private. The family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Friday, July 1 from 10:00am to 1:00pm; Tuesday, July 5 from 4:00 to 7:00pm; and Wednesday, July 6 from 4:00 to 7:00pm. In lieu of flowers you may contribute to WQXR (WQXR c/o New York Public Radio, PO Box 1550, New York, NY 10116-1550), which brought her so much pleasure throughout her life and so much comfort in her final months.

A few years ago I took a trip to Europe and carried along my brand new iPhone for a bit of sightseeing. With international roaming charges so high, I reduced my e-mail and Web browsing to a mere trickle, thinking I'd save a bit of money. Little did I know that downloading maps would push my expenses over the edge, resulting in a nearly $1,000 bill. ''Never again,'' I swore beneath the Eiffel Tower, ''will mapping cost me so much.'' Enter OffMaps 2, a new version of OffMaps for the iPhone and iPad. OffMaps allows you to download an entire city's map at once and store those maps right on your cellphone or tablet. Your phone can access map data offline, as opposed to using the iPhone's built-in Maps app, which requires data roaming and can cost you an arm and a leg.

BECKER--Dr. Norwin H.,1923--2011, Pathologist. The Staff and Alumni Association of Montefiore Medical Center was deeply saddened to hear that our dear colleague. Dr. Norwin H. Becker, a pathologist at Montefiore Medical Center and Professor at Albert Einstein College of Medicine for nearly half a century, died on May 30 at his home in New City, New York. Dr. Becker was the renowned leader of anatomical pathology at Montefiore's Moses Division from 1973 to 1999. He was widely published in peer-reviewed journals and textbooks, with 62 publications focused on surgical pathology, histochemistry, electron microscopy, and hematopathology. He was a loyal and dedicated member of the Association and in 2004 we honored him as Physician Honoree at our Annual Dinner Dance & Awards Night. Our sincere condolences are expressed to his family members. We will miss him and his infectious sense of humor which always managed to lift our spirits. The Executive Committee of the Staff & Alumni Association Montefiore Medical Center, the University Hospital for the Albert Einstein College of Medicine

The economy is clearly weaker than expected, and housing prices are falling throughout the land, eroding bank asset values. Yet regulators are on their heels in Washington as bankers and their lobbyists push back against the postcrisis regulations, even publicly condemning the new rules.

It's been a springboard for Brooklyn nostalgia, a debate about urban design and the politics of eminent domain and, depending on your perspective or basketball affiliation, a community uniter or divider. Now Atlantic Yards, the development that will bring the New Jersey Nets to downtown Brooklyn, will also be a cultural center. The Barclays Center, the 18,000-seat arena at the heart of the project, will host performances by artists selected by the Brooklyn Academy of Music in a programming alliance between the two neighboring institutions, their directors said. The collaboration will include three or four shows a year and allow the academy to bring to Brooklyn work that would not fit into its theaters -- the largest of which has 2,000 seats -- with costs underwritten by the arena.

Two new singers take over the Billboard album chart this week with modest sales. The R&B singer Jill Scott hits No. 1 for the first time with her fourth studio album, ''The Light of the Sun'' (Warner Brothers), which sold 135,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. And Bon Iver, the group led by the singer-songwriter Justin Vernon, bowed at No. 2 with its self-titled second album; released by the independent label Jagjaguwar, the album sold 104,000 copies, Bon Iver's highest chart position and best sales week.

There will be no free concerts in the parks for the New York Philharmonic this summer. But Alan Gilbert, the orchestra's music director, has given his word that situation will change in 2012. ''I am making a personal promise that these beloved free concerts will return next summer and continue for many years to come,'' he wrote in a letter sent via e-mail to The New York Times on Wednesday, following the publication of a critic's notebook lamenting the orchestra's decision to suspend the series, which began in 1965. According to Zarin Mehta, the Philharmonic's president and chief executive, the popular annual parks tour was dropped this year to make way for other projects. These include a memorial concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Sept. 10 to commemorate the tenth anniversary of the terrorist attacks. On that day, Mr. Gilbert is scheduled to conduct Mahler's ''Resurrection'' Symphony, which will be broadcast live on radio and rebroadcast on television the next night by PBS.

CHONGQING, China -- The kindergarten musical climaxed in a whirlwind of violence: A teacher playing a Japanese soldier sliced down a peasant girl with a curved sword, just as two tykes in Red Army outfits took aim at him with plastic pistols. Dozens of girls in cerise silk outfits broke into song and dance in the schoolyard, and a teacher at the microphone delivered the lesson: ''If you don't put up your defenses, you'll lose your life.''

Updated, 2:51 p.m. | Four former New York City school custodial workers were arrested on Wednesday on charges they stole roughly $500,000 from the city through a pair of parallel schemes that included holding jobs they never performed, and doing maintenance work on private properties on the public dime. A fifth employee was still being sought, officials said. In a statement, the United States Attorney for the Southern District, Preet Bharara, said that the men ''lined their pockets with hundreds of thousands of dollars that were supposed to be used to keep New York City public schools clean and safe for students.''

Randy Falco, the chief operating officer of Univision Communications, was promoted on Wednesday to be the president and chief executive of the fast-growing Spanish language media company. Mr. Falco was the unanimous choice of the Univision board of directors, according to its executive chairman, Haim Saban. The company had been conducting a search for a new chief executive since March, when Joe Uva exited.

NATIONAL An article on Wednesday about Gov. Jerry Brown's goals for California's budget misstated the official who said he would withhold legislators' pay until a new budget was passed. It was the state controller, John Chiang -- not the state treasurer, Bill Lockyer.

The final designs for the Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center, a major hub for the arts planned for Athens, were unveiled on Wednesday. The center, designed by Renzo Piano, includes a 42-acre park, the headquarters for the National Library of Greece and a 1,400-seat opera house for the Greek National Opera. Budgeted at more than $800 million, the project is to be financed by the Stavros Niarchos Foundation. Construction, to begin later this year, is to be completed in 2015. The center's design is inspired by the Acropolis, with the park rising gradually to a summit where a ''reading room'' with glass walls will provide views of the city and the Aegean Sea. Under the reading room, the main library is to house more than two million books, and the opera house will mount a variety of concerts, ballets and musicals. The center's operations are to be run and paid for by the Greek government, raising obvious questions about center's future, given the current debt crisis. Andreas C. Dracopoulos, a co-president of the foundation's board of directors, wrote in an e-mail that the project is ''a good example of a public-private partnership where the State has made available the land, our Foundation has taken the full financial responsibility to build and deliver the project, and then upon delivery it will be wholly transferable to the State so that the people and society at large can enjoy it.'' Of the risk posed by the government's financial troubles, he said only that the group is ''closely working with all related parties to make sure that all operational and organizational issues are taken into account so that our finished product can be one of efficiency, viability and sustainability.''

ALBU--Eugene, M.D.,an exceptional man, died on June 26, 2011 at the age of 85. Cherished husband of Paula, his wife of 62 years, proud father of Peter and father-in-law of Jeanine; loving grandfather of Myra and Monica. After a successful surgical career in Romania, Dr. Albu joined the attending staff at the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center where he continued to practice surgery for another 22 years. He was Assistant Professor of Surgery at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Diplomate of the American Board of Surgery, Fellow of the American College of Surgeons and member of many prestigious American and European Surgical Associations. A revamped version of George Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess,'' starring Audra McDonald, Norm Lewis and David Alan Grier, will go to Broadway soon after it completes its run, previously announced, at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass. Producers announced on Wednesday that the show -- which plays down its roots as an opera and features a reworked book by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Suzan-Lori Parks and new arrangements by Diedre Murray -- will open at the Richard Rodgers Theater on Jan. 12, with previews beginning on Dec. 17.

American Ballet Theater and the School of Dance at the University of North Carolina School of the Arts in Winston-Salem are embarking on a five-year partnership that will teach ABT's National Training Curriculum throughout three divisions at the school: preparatory, high school and collegiate. The partnership will be announced officially on Thursday by Rachel S. Moore, Ballet Theater's executive director, and John Mauceri, chancellor of the school of the arts. The partnership will begin at the start of the fall 2011 term. Its plans also call for making the U.N.C.S.A. campus a second home for Ballet Theater's Manhattan-based Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School, a pre-professional ballet training program for students ages 11 to 18.

CARRAS--W. Gabriel. Cherished father, grandfather and husband passed away peacefully at home on June 28. An army veteran, he spent more than 50 years in service to his beloved NYU as a professor and a dean. He shared his love of political science, history and teaching with his coworkers and students. A devoted father, he always put his sons' interests first and helped guide them and other family members and friends toward meaningful lives. Family to receive friends on Tuesday, July 5 from 2-4 and 7-9 at Arlington Funeral Home, 83-15 Parsons Blvd. Jamaica; service Wednesday, July 6 at 9:30. Donations in his name may be made to North Shore Animal League.

8:14 p.m. | Updated MySpace, the long-suffering Web site that the News Corporation bought six years ago for $580 million, was sold Wednesday to the advertising network Specific Media for roughly $35 million. The News Corporation, which is controlled by Rupert Murdoch, had been trying since last winter to rid itself of the unprofitable unit, which was a casualty of changing tastes and may be a cautionary tale for social companies like Zynga and LinkedIn that are currently enjoying sky-high valuations.

Over the last half-century, Barbie has come in about as many guises and get-ups as Inspector Clouseau: cheerleader, supermodel, ski queen, doctor, astronaut, lawyer. Last year, Mattel, the doll's maker, released ''Mad Men'' versions, giving Barbie a pile of fire-red hair and a fetching office-girl dress in her Joan Holloway incarnation. Now, high art is taking a turn at a makeover. Three Barbies have just been released, inspired by great paintings, Tablet Magazine reported. One takes a crack at Mona Lisa -- a long overdue role for Barbie -- though the doll itself, with heavy eyeliner and a shower of curls, looks more like a model in an ad for a Renaissance fair. Another doll is inspired by Van Gogh's ''Starry Night,'' a painting that does not happen to feature a woman, so the Barbie is simply a blonde with a ''Starry Night''-print strapless gown.Undoubtedly the strangest of the three is the Barbie based on Gustav Klimt's ''Portrait of Adele Bloch I,'' the Viennese Secessionist masterpiece that Ronald Lauder bought for what some reported to be $135 million in 2006, one of the highest prices ever paid for an artwork. The Barbie, with a winged hairdo and a dress that gets the dazzling Byzantine mosaic pattern from the painting almost right -- minus Klimt's gold-leaf -- goes for $34.95.

Dannijo crystal and oxidized silver-plate earrings, $172 at shopbop.com.

The Knicks extended a qualifying offer to forward Derrick Brown on Wednesday, making him a restricted free agent. The designation means that the Knicks will have the right to match any offer Brown receives, assuming the rules do not change substantially in the N.B.A.'s next labor deal. Free agency normally begins July 1, but the N.B.A. is expected to impose a lockout that will place all player transactions on hold indefinitely. It is unclear what effect the owners' push for a new salary-cap system might have on free-agency rules.

Bernadette Peters, Jan Maxwell, Danny Burstein and Ron Raines are set to reprise their starring roles in the Kennedy Center production of ''Follies'' when it opens Sept. 12 at the Marquis Theater on Broadway for a limited engagement, the show's producers said on Wednesday. The Tony-award winning musical, with a book by James Goldman and a score by Stephen Sondheim, is directed by Eric Schaeffer and will feature musical direction by James Moore and choreography by Warren Carlyle.

SCIENCE TIMES Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about threats to caribou in the oil sands area of Alberta, Canada, misstated the attribution for a prediction that herds east of the Athabasca River will die out within 30 years if development trends continue. It was made by researchers at the University of Alberta in a study published last year, not by Samuel K. Wasser of the University of Washington and his colleagues, whose recent report assessing the effects of human presence on caribou was the basis of the article. The article also described incorrectly the grazing pattern observed by Dr. Wasser and his colleagues. Though the caribou graze in flat wetlands, as the article noted, they do not eat lichen there.

Beloved husband of Deborah Shaffer and father of Maya Bogdanow, brother of William Bogdanow (who pre-deceased him), Barbara Lavi and Michael Bogdanow, and many loving nieces, nephews, cousins, step-siblings, in-laws and friends. Larry's love of his family and friends, and of life itself, touched so many, as did the many warm, creative and beautiful restaurants and other spaces he designed in New York and elsewhere. May his memory be a blessing. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Laskey Fund, Washington University Box 1079, One Brookings Drive, St. Louis, MO 63130. Services to be held Friday, July 1st at 1pm in Columbia University's Faculty House.

Investment professionals have a new pitch: The sky could soon be falling. While Greece took a step back from the brink on Wednesday, the possibility of a default remains a fear. Q. I am running out of space on my iPad and can no longer get updates to apps. I killed off some apps. I killed photos. How do I kill music on the iPad without losing it on my PC and iPhone when I sync iTunes? A. Instead of automatically synchronizing all the music in the iTunes library to every device, you can be more selective about what goes on each iOS gadget. You can set the iPad to copy only certain playlists (or no music at all) to the iPad while leaving your current settings for the iPhone intact.

When you are shopping for a camera memory card, faster is better, right? Not necessarily. The fastest cards are so fast that few cameras can use their full capacity, so you end up overpaying for performance you can't use.

Commander James Alden was by all accounts a resourceful and clever naval officer, talents he put to use in June 1861 as he and his ship helped establish the sprawling Union blockade against Confederate ports. Aboard his now-oddly named steamer, the South Carolina, he dropped munitions to federal troops at Fort Pickens, near Pensacola, Fla., then sailed west to join the Gulf Blockading Squadron off Louisiana. On July 2 the ship suddenly appeared off Galveston, one of the busiest ports in the South and a boom town riding a wave of cotton exports to Europe. Riding the low Gulf breakers, the South Carolina, brought to Texas President Lincoln’s Anaconda strategy: strangling the South by sea.

In her reply to my column, the author of “Unnatural Selection” also disputes my suggestion that her book’s tone of moral outrage depends on an (implicit) sympathy for aborted female fetuses as well as a concern for the societal impact of sex-selective abortion. “I make very clear in my book that the victim is women,” Hvistendahl writes — “women who in the 1960s and 1970s were used as pawns in a Western drive to reduce birth rates in Asia, women who later aborted female fetuses against the backdrop of patriarchy, and women who, now that they are scarce, find themselves at greater risk of being trafficked, kidnapped, or sold by their parents to men desperate to find wives. Sex-selective abortion is wrong because women should account for half of the human population, and in parts of the world they now account for far less. That alone justifies moral outrage.”

I discovered Dan Savage, the subject of my cover story this weekend, in 2004, when I became editor of the alternative weekly paper in New Haven. I did not know much about alt weeklies, and to get ideas I looked around for some of the best. Somebody said I had to check out The Stranger, the bigger of Seattle’s two alt weeklies. So I e-mailed the editor, who was this Dan Savage guy. I figured that couldn’t be his real name; it was probably some alt weekly stunt. But “Dan Savage” sent me a bunch of issues, and the paper was brilliant: smart, good-looking, edgy. Inside, the editor wrote a really good sex column called Savage Love, and I asked my publisher if we could drop our syndicated sex column and replace it with Savage Love. “Can’t,” he said. “Too dirty. People would object.” That was about all I knew of Dan Savage for the next couple years, although occasionally I would see links to Savage’s work on Andrew Sullivan’s blog.

For CBS, an all-repeat lineup eked out a first-place finish for the network in the ratings on Thursday as “CSI” and “The Mentalist” delivered the night’s largest audiences in prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 7.8 million viewers tuned in for a rerun of “The Mentalist” at 10 p.m.. while “CSI” attracted 6.8 million at 9. “Wipeout” on ABC led the 8 p.m. hour with 6.5 million viewers, outperforming CBS’s combination of “The Big Bang Theory” (6.6 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (4.9 million). ABC earned a second-place finish, drawing 6.1 million at 9 p.m. for “Expedition Impossible” and 5.4 million at 10 for a new installment of “Rookie Blue.” Fox was third, averaging 5 million for “So You Think You Can Dance” at 8 p.m. followed by a rerun of “Glee” (2.9 million) at 9. NBC trailed in fourth with sitcom repeats and a new episode of “Love Bites” (1.8 million) at 10.

Dressing for a holiday often revolves around a slew of clichés that make us look (and feel) cheesy– orange and black, anyone? — as opposed to smartly festive. It certainly doesn’t have to. This fourth of July, opt for the unexpected in some coolly patriotic looks like Lanvin’s lamé shorts rather than classic denim, and pair them with bright, playful Superga sneakers. In the evening, go for relaxed Americana by mixing a Sonia by Sonia Rykiel T-shirt with a ladylike Donna Karan silk skirt. For a patriotic décolletage, wear this red lace bra from Deborah Marquit with a sexy sheer Equipment top. The black and white stripes (as opposed to boring blue and red) are as chic as a Mount Vernon fireworks display.

Wealthy families have long realized that their children need to learn about money, Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week. They will often send their children to retreats like the one run by Citi Private Bank, which focuses on investing, running businesses and giving money to charity.

Harlem Stage, the multidisciplinary performing arts center supporting artists of color that has made a huge name for itself while managing to weather the recent economic storms, announced on Friday its fall 2011 season of new dance, film, theater and music. Among the highlights are “Visible,” a new work by choreographers Nora Chipaumire and Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, which will have its world premiere Oct. 10-15 at the Harlem Stage Gatehouse. Two new editions of the WeDaPeoplesCabaret will jump-start the Uptown Nights series in September. Carl Hancock Rux is the curator on Sept. 17, with a program featuring Nona Hendryx, the political monologist Reno and the author and producer Nelson George. The Grammy-nominated trumpeter Christian Scott will offer two nights with his quintet on Oct. 28 and Oct. 29. The D.J. Rich Medina will transform the Harlem Stage Gatehouse into a space to celebrate the life of Fela Anikulapo Kuti on Nov. 19 with music, dance and conversation. On Nov. 10, as part of its Harlem Stride – Community Concert series in partnership with the Weill Music Institute of Carnegie Hall, the Grammy nominee Miguel Zenon leads his quintet in a program featuring music by great songwriters from Puerto Rico. Tickets are free. Ticket prices for most Harlem Stage performances are $20 or less; some are free and generally don’t go higher than $45.

A few years ago, just as the recession hit, the Chambre Syndicale, the French fashion authority, decided to separate the June men’s shows and the haute couture by a week. The two groups of shows had followed each other, as they still do in January. A week of free time in Europe is no longer regarded by publications with the joie de vivre of the past, so I usually split the time between work and pleasure. At the moment I’m in a village in Burgundy, staying at La Source des Fées, a vineyard owned by Thierry Nouvel and Philippe Greffet. The place is as lovely as it is laid back, with delicious dinners, and each night brings new guests — Dutch, Swedes, French. It’s the beginning of the European summer.

A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the closing of an elementary school, the same-sex marriage law in New York and a disappearing artist at ground zero.

DealBook’s Susanne Craig speaks to a Reuters Breakingviews editor, Rob Cox, and a columnist, Antony Currie, about cutbacks in staff and compensation on Wall Street. How does the current round of layoffs and austerity in the financial industry compare with the “Armageddon” at the height of the financial crisis?
July 1, 2011 - DealBook's Susanne Craig speaks to Reuters Breakingviews about why financial institutions are laying off staff and cutting expenses.

Lincoln Center’s Mostly Mozart Festival announced it is adding to New York’s menu of free concerts with a performance on July 30 at Avery Fisher Hall. The hourlong concert will feature the overture to “The Marriage of Figaro;” Mozart’s Symphony No. 36, the “Linz;” and Stravinsky’s Symphony in C, performed by the Festival Orchestra and the music director, Louis Langrée. Lincoln Center did not immediately release information on how to obtain the tickets, but said word would be posted on mostlymozart.org

“Legion Lost,” a tale of the Legion of Super-Heroes, a group of champions from 1,000 years in the future, lands at No. 2 on the hardcover list this week. The group, published by DC Comics, has had a bit of a confounding history. The Legion was created in 1958. They were time travelers from the future who had traveled to the past to meet their heroic inspiration: Superboy. Cut to 1985 when DC published Crisis on Infinite Earths, a limited series intended to streamline the decades of convoluted continuity of its heroes. It was decided that Superman never had costumed adventures as a youth, so the reason for the Legion’s founding had to be reconsidered. A lot of stories were crafted to give them a new reason for forming – until it was decided, 20 years later when DC published Infinite Crisis – that Superman did have a career as Superboy so the Legion could be inspired by him.

On July 1, 1898, United States forces, including Teddy Roosevelt’s Rough Riders, defeated greatly outnumbered Spanish forces at San Juan Hill and Kettle Hill near the Spanish stronghold of Santiago de Cuba. The victory allowed the United States to begin a siege of Santiago de Cuba, which led to Spanish surrender and the end of the Spanish-American War.
The economist Justin Wolfers wrote a provocative post last month arguing that children are “inferior goods.”

I developed this recipe about five years into my stint as the Minimalist. By that point I had already exhausted (or thought I had; I was wrong) most of the obvious candidates for the column– five-ingredient pasta dishes, simple marinated meats, 10-minute green salads — and was forced to research and invent recipes that were less conventional but no more complicated. This salad is one of my favorite results of that challenge, and I still make it regularly. It turns out watermelon and tomato make spectacular plate fellows, and they’re even better with a few assertive accompaniments.

The Plaza Hotel in New York City will revive its Tricycle Garage, which will be good news for “Eloise” fans — especially those lucky enough to stay at the renovated landmark hotel. Beginning on July 1, the Plaza will offer children’s bike rentals – including Radio Flyer tricycles, bicycles and scooters – for hotel guests and a few lucky New Yorkers.

Without risking a citation, owners of certain hybrids as of Friday can no longer occupy the high-occupancy-vehicle lanes on California’s freeways absent the requisite number of passengers. Drivers of the Toyota Prius, Honda Insight and Honda Civic Hybrid gained access to the lanes under a 2004 legislative action, but were excluded from a new sticker system expected to go into effect on Jan. 1, 2012, that would prioritize next-generation clean-air vehicles like the Nissan Leaf. Super-ultra low-emissions vehicles (SULEV) like the the Honda Civic GX, which runs on natural gas, and the purely electric Tesla Roadster are allowed to remain in the lanes until 2015. Read more »

The Aug. 2 debt ceiling deadline is holding firm. The Treasury Department said Friday morning that its latest estimates still show that’s the date the government will exhaust its ability to pay all of its bills, unless Congress agrees to raise the total amount that the United States can borrow.

Free tastes of wine from Italy’s Veneto region will be served on Friday from 2 to 4 p.m. at Enoteca Di Palo, 200 Grand Street (Mott Street), in Little Italy. From 6 to 8 p.m., sparkling wines from the region will be available at I Tre Merli, 463 West Broadway (Prince Street), in SoHo.

As you depart for whichever backyard, or beach, or local park, or airport marks the start of your Independence Day weekend, an update on Malaysia Airlines’ announcement that infants will not be allowed up front when the airline introduces its new Airbus A380 aircraft next year. The airline already has such a ban on its 747-400 fleet.

For those infected with jungle fever (see Prada’s chic monkey and banana frocks for spring), the good news is you can follow the trend into fall. The Marc by Marc Jacobs collection, in stores this month, features panthers and antelopes on everything from drop pants to jacquard blazers. The prints are the handiwork of Michael Roberts, who, when he’s not working for Vanity Fair as style editor at large, is illustrating childen’s pop-up books about the jungle. This clutch, for example, with its sleek appliqué ($328), is entirely fierce. Go to marcjacobs.com. For the scarf, $178, go to nordstrom.com.

We found ourselves in a dilemma for this week’s issue: four different cover treatments and many different opinions about which one was the most aesthetically pleasing. First we did an internal poll in the art department. The rules were simple, vote on your favorite cover by putting a small wooden chip (broken coffee stirrer) into the matching cup. Only problem was, we had a tie and we needed more votes. So we opened up the judging to the entire staff and 37 staff members from every department voted.

James de Givenchy intended to give his daughter, Stella, a 1940s candy-striped bracelet that he bought online. When the piece arrived, de Givenchy, a jeweler, was so taken with the quality of the plastic that he took it into in his workshop for further study, leaving it next to a pile of faceted lapis. The commingling was purely serendipitous. “I thought it would be so much fun,” de Givenchy said of the costume bauble-turned-fine jewelry. A very American transformation, don’t you think? $10,000. Go to taffin.com or call (212) 421-6222 for an appointment.

The Australian skin care brand Aesop — Greek for “storyteller”— is a cult favorite among the type of discerning consumers who prefer their jeans dark, their espresso straight up and their bathrooms uncluttered. And like the Aesop products, the Aesop boutiques make innovative use of unusual ingredients, so there’s no sense of shopping at a chain when you pop in to pick up your Parsley Seed Anti-Oxidant Facial Serum (which, incidentally, is brilliant for maintaining a glowing complexion through the depths of sticky East Coast summers). Case in point: the first of Aesop’s four planned New York shops, which opens in the Graybar Passage in Grand Central Terminal next week, will be built primarily from recycled 19th-century newspapers. Locations on Elizabeth Street and University Place will follow by the end of the summer, and a flagship on Bleecker Street will open in December. The Moment recently caught up with the Aesop founder, Dennis Paphitis, to talk about architecture, why art inspires him and what he thinks about all-natural skin care claims.

Apple’s iPhoto program, which comes free on most new Macs, can automatically pull in pictures from a connected digital camera, but you can also easily save images attached to Mail messages too. When you open a message in the Mac OS X Mail program and see photos that you’d like to add to the iPhoto library, click and hold the cursor down on the small blue Save button in the message header. At the bottom of the drop-down menu that appears, select the “Save to iPhoto” option to save all pictures into the iPhoto program.

Novak Djokovic advanced to his first Wimbledon final with a hugely entertaining win over Jo Wilfried Tsonga, winning in four sets, 7-6, 6-2, 6-7, 6-3. The match featured several thrilling all-court points, with each man making acrobatic gets on passing shots. In the end, Djokovic’s solid returning and relentless ground game wore down Tsonga’s aggressive shot-making.

8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: SINGING COWBOYS Turner Classic Movies celebrates the tuneful heroes of the Wild West -- the cowpokes like Gene Autry and Roy Rogers (above) who could ride, shoot and slug it out with the best of them before sliding out of the saddle, grabbing a guitar and serenading listeners with ballads like ''Tumbling Tumbleweeds'' and ''Happy Trails.'' Not every tough guy was up to the job. John Wayne once said, according to TCM, that the most embarrassing moment of his career took place during the filming of ''Riders of Destiny'' (1933) when executives at Monogram Pictures insisted he sit by a tree, move his lips and pretend to sing while a hidden warbler named Bill Bradbury did the actual crooning. This 26-movie tribute, shown on Fridays in July, kicks off with three classics starring Rogers; his wife, Dale Evans; and Rogers's golden palomino, Trigger: ''Cowboy and the Senorita'' (1944), about outlaws who conceal a gold mine's true value from the man who inherited it; ''Don't Fence Me In'' (1945), about a female reporter who travels west to dig up the truth about a long-dead bandit, at 9:30; and ''My Pal Trigger'' (1946), at 10:45, in which a cowboy fights to clear his name after he is accused of shooting a friend's horse. 8 P.M. (NBC) FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS Coach Taylor (Kyle Chandler) faces extensive budget cuts to his East Dillon football program, while Tami (Connie Britton) is given the opportunity of a lifetime in Pennsylvania. Meanwhile the Lions prepare for the state championship.

An analysis article on April 12 about the first-round playoff series of the National Hockey League erroneously attributed a distinction to the New York Rangers' coach, John Tortorella, who was suspended for a playoff game two years ago after he squirted water on a Capitals fan. He was not the first N.H.L. coach suspended in the playoffs; in 1988, the New Jersey Devils' coach, Jim Schoenfeld, was suspended for a game in a playoff series against the Boston Bruins after he confronted a referee and told him to ''have another doughnut.'' The correction was delayed because an internal e-mail was misdirected at The Times.

KRUGMAN--Dorothy C.,88, passed away peacefully, with her family by her side, on June 30, 2011 in Stamford, CT. Born in New Bedford, MA., Dorothy spent most her childhood in the Bronx and received a BS in Psychology CCNY in 1942, having been one of the first women liberal arts students at the Uptown Campus. She received an M.S.Ed. from Teachers College and worked during the war as a mental health counselor in various locations in Texas and Florida, where her husband was stationed. After the war she resumed her studies and earned a Ph.D. in psychology from Columbia University. She spent the next 50 years teaching and helping others in the field of child psychology, and working with foster children, foster parents, and staff at all of the major adoption agencies in the New York City area. Involved in dancing and the arts since her high school years, Dorothy became involved with and was eventually a board member for the New Dance Group Studio in Manhattan and the Joyce Trisler Danscompany. She took class at the Studio for many years, and went on pointe for the first time at the age of 48. Moving from Manhattan to Stamford in the 1970s, she became an active supporter of the Connecticut Ballet, acting as board member, donor, costumer, and all-around assistant for her great friend and company director Brett Raphael. Her work with the company continued until the day she died. The company gave her great joy, and its current growth and success are the culmination of three decades of devoted labor. In 1942, Dorothy married her college sweetheart, Herb Krugman, and she spent the next 69 years with him in a marriage based on deep love, mutual respect, and support for each other and their own individual endeavors. She is survived by her loving familyher husband, her son Ed, daughter-in-law Ethel Klein, daughter Laura, and son-in-law Rick Culley. She will also be greatly missed by her four grandsons, Aaron Krugman and Paul, Luke, and Alex Culley. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday, July 3, at 11:30, at The Riverside, Amsterdam and 76th. There will be a memorial performance on a date to be announced at the Connecticut Ballet studio, 20 Acosta St. in Stamford. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Connecticut Ballet.

So much about the jazz bassist Ben Williams and his working band, Sound Effect, pushes a contemporary currency. There's the matter-of-fact way they engage with pop, and especially funk. There's the evident commitment to a group sound. There's the look: stylish but not dandyish, trying not to care too much. And finally there's the rhetoric. Mr. Williams has said repeatedly that with his debut release, just out on Concord, he wanted to reflect the sound of today; he titled the album ''State of Art.'' All of which is fine -- and a little puzzling, once you really deal with the music. On Wednesday night at Harlem Stage Gatehouse, in an engaging and admirably poised performance, Mr. Williams and crew kept evoking the flavor of a distinct moment in jazz and pop: the mid-1990s, when most of them were still in grade school.

ALBU--Eugene, M.D.,an exceptional man, died on June 26, 2011 at the age of 85. Cherished husband of Paula, his wife of 62 years, proud father of Peter and father-in-law of Jeanine; loving grandfather of Myra and Monica. After a successful surgical career in Romania, Dr. Albu joined the attending staff at the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center where he continued to practice surgery for another 22 years. He was Assistant Professor of Surgery at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Diplomate of the American Board of Surgery, Fellow of the American College of Surgeons and member of many prestigious American and European Surgical Associations. A memorial gathering of family and friends will be held on Sunday, July 3rd 2011, 3pm at the Louis Suburban Chapel in Fair Lawn, NJ.

Four months into the NATO air campaign, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is still in power, protected by loyalists and mercenaries. Americans are weary of war, and patience in Europe is also wearing thin. But NATO must not give up. If Colonel Qaddafi is allowed to have his way, thousands more Libyans will die. The credibility of NATO and this country would also be severely damaged. Colonel Qaddafi, who has a long history of sponsoring international terrorism, is not one to let bygones be bygones.

CALEV--Benjamin B. (Ben), of Scottsdale, AZ, formerly of Islip and Glen Cove, NY, passed away peacefully on June 25th after a long illness. Born in Manhattan, New York, Ben worked in his father's Army/Navy store and developed an interest in photography. After distinguished service as a B-17 Radio Operator with the US Army Air Corps during WWII, Ben along with his brother Joe went on to found Calev Photolabs, Inc. Under Ben's leadership, the company would be a driving force in the wholesale photofinishing industry, and took pride in being New York City's first Kodacolor Lab. Having been a member of The Buck Rogers Group and President of the Photo Marketing Association International (PMAI) from 1983 - 1984, Ben helped to shape many of the photographic and marketing concepts taken for granted today. Ben is survived by his wife of over 60 years, Bea, son Andrew (Carol), grandchildren Ben (Erin) and Rebecca, great-grandchildren Emily and Anna, and sister Sylvia Gany of Tampa, Florida. In remembrance, donations may be made to the Parkinson's Foundation.

KONIGSBERG--Sidney S. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express profound sorrow at the loss of Sidney S. Konigsberg of San Rafael, California, a Technion Guardian and devoted and generous leader. Following a visit to the Technion in 1995, he joined the ATS North Pacific Region as president and then chair. A true gentleman, he was a member of the national Board of Directors and honorary life member of the Technion International Board of Governors. Mr. Konigberg and his wife Vivian were devoted to encouraging the careers of Technion students, funding the Joanne Konigsberg Chair in Life Sciences, the Konigsberg Career Development Chair, and the Sidney and Vivian Konigsberg Fund for Exceptionally Gifted Students. He was honored with a Technion Honorary Fellowship in 1997 and an Honorary Doctorate in 2002. Mr. Konigsberg was an award-winning engineer for 60 years and builder of successful companies. We extend condolences to his nieces and nephews. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology. Joel Rothman, President Joan Seidel, Chairman Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

8:31 p.m. | Updated LONDON - The Lloyds Banking Group said on Thursday that it planned to eliminate 15,000 jobs by the end of 2014 and scale back its overseas operations as part of a reorganization aimed at allowing the British government to sell its stake in the company.

Lovers of folk art have just a week left to visit the American Folk Art Museum at its home on West 53rd Street before it closes its doors there for good. Struggling under a heavy load of debt, the museum recently sold the building to the Museum of Modern Art. On Thursday it said its last day in the building would be July 8. The museum will remain in operation in its much smaller branch at 2 Lincoln Square, where it currently has a show of quilts from the collection. MoMA has not yet said what it plans to do with the building, which was designed by the architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien and opened in 2001. A spokeswoman for the folk art museum, Susan Flamm, said the museum would have 90 days to vacate the building after the sale closes, which she said would happen in mid-July. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The ethical judgments of the Supreme Court justices became an important issue in the just completed term. The court cannot maintain its legitimacy as guardian of the rule of law when justices behave like politicians. Yet, in several instances, justices acted in ways that weakened the court's reputation for being independent and impartial. Justices Antonin Scalia and Samuel Alito Jr., for example, appeared at political events. That kind of activity makes it less likely that the court's decisions will be accepted as nonpartisan judgments. Part of the problem is that the justices are not bound by an ethics code. At the very least, the court should make itself subject to the code of conduct that applies to the rest of the federal judiciary.

The increasingly bitter dispute that first erupted early in April when the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced it was eliminating 31 categories from the Grammy Awards notched up yet another step on Thursday when a New York law firm announced plans to sue the Academy on behalf of musicians who play Latin jazz, one of the categories that is being dropped. At a news conference in Manhattan, the drummer Bobby Sanabria, one of the Latin jazz musicians who has been most vocal in criticizing the Academy's action and in leading efforts to restore all 31 categories, also called for a national boycott against CBS, which broadcasts the Grammy Awards program each February. Speaking in both English and Spanish, he urged viewers to refrain from watching programs on the network and to write letters of protest to corporations sponsoring shows on CBS.

RIVERHEAD, N.Y. -- After all the shooting was done, and the bodies of four victims were splayed across the floor of Haven Drugs, the door to the pharmacy opened once more. Melinda Brady entered into view of one of the store's surveillance cameras, and one that was equipped with a microphone caught her reaction, the Suffolk County district attorney, Thomas J. Spota, said in a news conference on Thursday.

The memory of the New York poet Jack Agüeros is capricious nowadays. He remembers the lyrics of certain Puerto Rican folk songs and the name of his petite, growling dog: Nikki. He does not remember collecting the old radios, locks and cast-iron pieces that once decorated his Manhattan apartment on West 14th Street. Mr. Agüeros, 76, a community advocate who directed El Museo del Barrio for almost a decade starting in the mid-1970s, has also forgotten that he is the author of four books and several plays. He wrote sonnets and satiric psalms about immigration, poverty and social inequality. He also compiled and translated the complete poems of the renowned Puerto Rican writer Julia de Burgos.

A brass quintet from New York City Opera's orchestra played tunes from ''Carmen,'' ''Aida'' and ''La Boheme'' on the sidewalk in front of Lincoln Center Plaza on Thursday. A sanitation truck driver honked in solidarity. Protesters held signs denouncing the company's leader and demanding that he not move City Opera from the cultural complex. Under crystalline skies and surrounded by balmy breezes, the musical demonstration by several dozen choristers and musicians, many in concert black, was a time-tested means of labor protest for orchestra players. The artists were adding their voices to the calls of many others in the music world, including Julius Rudel, the company's former general director and principal conductor, to keep City Opera at Lincoln Center.

WASHINGTON -- Republicans and Democrats on the House oversight committee this week intensified their efforts to shape the narrative surrounding Operation Fast and Furious, the border-security strategy that allowed guns to be shipped illegally into Mexico in an effort to track them to drug cartels. Democrats, who held an unofficial hearing on Thursday on the now-defunct operation of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, have focused on what they see as a lapse in American laws involving firearms purchases. Republicans, led by Representative Darrell E. Issa, the chairman of the oversight committee, are pushing to blame high-ranking officials in the Obama administration for the operation.

Robert Morris, a cryptographer who helped develop the Unix computer operating system, which controls an increasing number of the world's computers and touches almost every aspect of modern life, died on Sunday in Lebanon, N.H. He was 78. The cause was complications of dementia, his wife, Anne Farlow Morris, said.

WASHINGTON -- The White House believes it must strike a budget deal with Congress by July 22 to avoid a risk of defaulting on the national debt, Democratic officials briefed on the negotiations said Thursday, as Senate leaders canceled a recess next week to try to break the deadlock with Republicans. The July 22 date looms large, the officials said, because it will take lawmakers at least a week to draft a bill and get it through two houses before Aug. 2. That is the day when, officials say, the government will reach its debt ceiling and no longer be able to borrow what it needs to keep operating and repay existing debt.

HIRING SPREE Marc Andreessen, a founder of the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, announced yet another addition on Thursday. Less than 24 hours after its appointment of Lawrence H. Summers to the role of special adviser, the firm is adding Jeff Jordan, left, the executive chairman of OpenTable, as general partner. With the arrival of Mr. Jordan, Andreessen Horowitz is now a team of five general partners, led by Mr. Andreessen and the firm's co-founder, Ben Horowitz. EVELYN M. RUSLI

MANHATTAN can be too much with us. It can seem like a 23-square-mile rugby pitch, where on any given day nearly three million people are shoving elbows, blowing cigarette smoke, jabbering on cellphones or to themselves, all ready to rumble over the slightest slight. Not long ago a well-educated woman slapped another well-educated woman in a confrontation over a package of vegan pad Thai in the frozen-food section of Trader Joe's. To which inhabitants of Manhattan might say: ''Yeah? So what?'' But the never-ending scrum, the divine experiment designed to explore the limits of humankind's patience, could not function as miraculously as it does without its pressure-release valves. This island of asphalt and steel has oases of solitude, catch-your-breath places that have neither the seedy sensibility of a Midtown peep-show booth nor the sobering sadness of the waiting room at the medical examiner's office.

Effectively ending a two-year dispute, Brandeis University announced on Thursday that it had settled a lawsuit brought by supporters of the university's Rose Art Museum who went to court to prevent Brandeis from exploring a sale of the museum's art works in order to shore up the university's finances. In January 2009, during the depths of the economic recession, Brandeis's trustees voted to ''transition'' the museum -- founded in 1961 and one of the most important collections in the New England, with works by de Kooning, Warhol, Lichtenstein and others -- into a teaching center and gallery, and to conduct ''an orderly sale or other disposition'' of its works to raise money. Later that year Brandeis backed away from the decision, saying that no works would be sold in the immediate future and that the building would remain open as an art study center, but not as a public museum. Still, the action prompted widespread criticism, and four of the museum's benefactors, Jonathan Lee, Meryl Rose, Lois Foster and Gerald Fineberg, sued to stop any art sales. The Massachusetts attorney general's office also began an investigation of the propriety of the Brandeis plan.

Officials said Thursday that the Las Conchas Fire, burning near the Los Alamos National Laboratory, has spread to 92,000 acres and could soon become the largest in the state's history. The blaze was on pace to surpass the Dry Lakes Fire, which charred 94,580 acres of the Gila National Forest in 2003. Doug Tucker, fire chief for Los Alamos County, and Charles McMillan, the national laboratory's director, said the facility was not at risk.

He had such confidence in his serve that he thought the odds of coming back and holding serve were still in his favor, even if faced with three straight break points. As Union soldiers went off to war, the national figure most often urging them on in political cartoons and political stump speeches wasn’t Uncle Sam, but Columbia. Forgotten today even as her name adorns universities, rivers and cities across the country, Columbia was America’s response to Britannia, a secular goddess who personified the national spirit. Both Britannia and Columbia were patterned after other goddess figures: Britannia copied Minerva’s helmet, for example, and both symbols frequently identified themselves with the Goddess of Liberty by displaying or wearing the “liberty cap.”

LAByrinth Theater Company has a steady home for its newly announced 2011-12 season. The company, which has historically found space all over New York, most recently at the Public Theater, has taken up residence in the newly rechristened Bank Street Theater for the foreseeable future, a spokesman said on Thursday. The 90-seat theater, at 155 Bank Street, is a Greenwich Village landmark formerly known as the Cherry Pit. The Cherry Lane Theater announced last July that for cost-cutting reasons it would not renew its lease on the Cherry Pit when it ended last December. At the same time, the Cherry Lane announced that it would not produce any plays on its main stage for a year beginning in September, and possibly longer, to cope with a deficit.

BAAN NONG TUN, THAILAND -- Smiling farmers knee deep in emerald rice paddies and shirtless children riding on the backs of mud-caked water buffalo -- these are the romantic images of the Thai countryside. There is one problem with it, says Udom Thapsuri, a farmer here and a local sage. It does not exist anymore. ''No one walks to their farm with a big bamboo hat on. That's over,'' said Mr. Udom, 63, sitting next to his pickup truck.

Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota, will report raising $4.2 million for his presidential campaign during the fund-raising period that ended on Thursday, his campaign announced Friday afternoon. But the campaign would not release a breakdown showing how much of that money is earmarked for a general election campaign. Since general election money raised now will not be available to Mr. Pawlenty until and unless he wins the Republican nomination, it remained unclear on Friday just how much cash the candidate actually has to spend in the Republican primary.People close to Mr. Pawlenty's campaign had suggested early in the week that he would report under $5 million raised. The campaign did not release any figures Friday indicating how much Mr. Pawlenty spent in the period, but it suggested that his cash on hand was comparable to that of past Republican candidates who won early primaries and caucuses.''Governor Pawlenty will report that his campaign has raised about $4.2 million and begins the third quarter with more available cash-on-hand than the Republicans who won the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary had in July 2007,'' said Alex Conant, a Pawlenty spokesman, in a statement.For the record: By the end of June 2007, Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor who went on to win the Iowa caucus the following year, had a total of $436,190 in cash on hand, according to the Federal Election Commission. At the same point in the race, Senator John McCain, who won the New Hampshire primary in 2008 and later the Republican nomination, had a total of $1,439,781.68 in cash on hand after subtracting its debt.

A Danish manufacturer of a drug used in executions announced Friday that it would no longer sell to prisons that perform lethal injections. Ulf Wiinberg, the chief executive of Lundbeck Inc., said the company ''adamantly opposes the distressing misuse of our product in capital punishment.'' The drug, sodium pentobarbital, a barbiturate, has become a substitute drug for many states in light of shortages of a similar drug, sodium thiopental. ''We can't make guarantees'' that prisons will not circumvent the sales controls, he said, but ''we are confident that our new distribution program will play a substantial role in restricting prisons' access'' to the drug. Maya Foa, an investigator with the anti-death-penalty group Reprieve, said the move shows that ''any company manufacturing execution drugs and refusing to take such steps will therefore be directly complicit in executions.''

Most people buy life insurance to protect against the risks of dying too soon. Now, there are new products offering the same protection if you live too long. It's known as longevity insurance, and there's clearly a huge market for it: Life expectancies are on the rise, cushy pensions are on the decline, and most people don't have enough savings to carry them through two decades or more of retirement. This is not lost on insurance companies, which would like you to think about the product as a pension of sorts -- albeit one that you have to buy with your own money.

When it comes to motion pictures, Charlie Chaplin is the man, no? Well, an all-but-forgotten short film featuring footage of the comic star failed to sell at a London auction, defying expectations that it might fetch a six-figure sum, Reuters reported. The reserve price on the film at Wednesday's sale was 100,000 ($160,000) at Bonhams auctioneers, but apparently that was too high. ''Charlie Chaplin in 'Zepped,' '' is believed to be a propaganda film made in Britain during World War I. A collector discovered the seven-minute short inside an old film reel tin and bought it in 2009 for 3.20 (about $5) on the online auction site eBay. The film shows Chaplin taking on a German Zeppelin aircraft and features some of the earliest animation in film history. Chaplin probably never knew of the movie's existence, said the film critic and Chaplin biographer David Robinson, according to Reuters. Mr. Robinson said an anonymous filmmaker had put together outtakes from three earlier Chaplin pictures -- ''His New Profession'' (1914), ''A Jitney Elopement'' (1915) and ''The Tramp'' (1915) -- and included sequences of stop-motion animation and other effects. Chaplin was not involved in the production of ''Zepped,'' but famously satirized Adolf Hitler in the 1940 movie ''The Great Dictator.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Providence Equity Partners agreed on Friday to buy Blackboard Inc., a maker of college coursework software, for $1.64 billion in cash, in the private equity firm's latest foray into the education market. Under the terms of the deal, Providence will pay $45 a share, a 3.7 percent premium to Blackboard's closing price on Thursday. It is 21 percent higher than Blackboard's stock price on April 18, the day before the company announced it was considering a sale.

8:31 p.m. | Updated Nortel Networks, the defunct Canadian telecommunications equipment maker, says it has agreed to sell more than 6,000 patent assets to an alliance made up of Apple, Microsoft and other technology giants for $4.5 billion in cash.

BLUESTONE--Norman. Passed away June 30th, 2011 at age 84. Norman is survived by his beloved wife Joan, brothers Harold and Eli, sisters-in-law Gilda and Emma, and an extended family of nephews, nieces, grand-nephews and grand-nieces. Norman was the senior partner in The Bluestone Organization, a prominent developer and builder in the New York City area. Norman will be missed by all who knew him and were touched by his special presence. Funeral services will be held at Sinai Chapel 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY, on Sunday at 10:15am.

The media jackals have been all over Representative Michele Bachmann for misstatements, zany ideas and alterations to history as she kicked off her presidential run in Waterloo, Iowa, home to serial killer John Wayne Gacy - not the actor John Wayne, as she said in her evocation of dreamy small-town life. From her contention that eliminating the minimum wage would mean full employment to her assertion that ''almost all'' people in the ''gay lifestyle'' have been abused, these things can be explained. Bachmann has a worldview that requires constant reshaping in the face of real life. However, if God is writing the script for her campaign, as she says, He needs a fact-checker.

An article on Friday in some editions about the murder indictment against David S. Laffer, who is charged with killing four people at a pharmacy on Long Island last month, misidentified a person who District Attorney Thomas J. Spota of Suffolk County said was seen on a surveillance camera entering the store after the killings. It was James Manzella Jr., the fiancé of one of the victims, Jaime Taccetta; it was not Melinda Brady. The article also misstated Ms. Brady's relationship with Mr. Laffer. She is his wife, not his fiancée.

SAGULLO--Candido Makalindong, M.D. Didong of Candelaria, Quezon and Scarsdale, NY passed on June 28, 2011. A beautiful death for a beautiful person. . . Didong passed away very silently in his sleep, sparing his loved ones from pain and suffering. For a life of gentleness, kindness, and closeness to the Lord, he was rewarded with a peaceful death. He lived a full life serving his patients well, helping relatives and friends who needed help, traveling the world, and showering his family with unending love and affection. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Lorceli Quintos Sagullo, daughter Dimple Anne, sister Sr. Francisca delas Llagas, nephews, nieces, grandnephews and grandnieces. Visiting Thursday, July 7 and Friday, July 8, 2-4 and 7-9pm. Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home. Mass of the Resurrection Saturday, July 9, 9:30am, Our Lady of Fatima Church, Scarsdale, NY. The family requests the readers to pray for his eternal rest. Contributions to the St. Clare Monastery in Sariaya, Quezon, Philippines in memory of Didong shall be appreciated, in lieu of flowers. EdwardsandDowdle.com

Todd Conover (Sally), Kathy Bogart and Elizabeth Schneider-Cohen (Peter). Stepmother to Carol Lidz (Howard) and Stephanie Schurak (Ira). Grandmother of Kirsten, Alison, Jason, Andrew, Maxwell and Jonathan. Step-grandmother to Tiffany, Scott, Marshall and Chelsey. Great-grandmother to Nicholas, Cassidy, Mackenzie, and the late Grant Kinnear, Scott and Logan. Step-great-grandmother to Bailey. Polly was a great beauty inside and out. She was quietly strong and generous with her time, heart and hearth. She touched many lives and will be missed by all. Funeral services were held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. (81st St.) July 1st at 11:30am.

An article on Thursday about President Obama's effort to persuade Republicans that they must accept higher taxes as part of any plan to reduce the federal deficit misstated the relative length of time, under a Democratic proposal, that owners of corporate jets would have to write off the aircrafts' cost. It is more years, not fewer.

Fulfilling the wishes of local political leaders, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Friday that a special election to fill the seat of former Representative Anthony D. Weiner would be held on Sept. 13. The special election means that party leaders will select the candidates to represent the Ninth Congressional District, which covers parts of Queens and Brooklyn. Some good-government advocates had hoped that there would be open primaries to allow for more candidates, even though they conceded that there was no legal consensus as to whether such primaries could be held to fill a Congressional seat.

Stan Lee, the comic book creator, has announced a joint venture with a Hong Kong investment company for a new superhero franchise aimed at Chinese and foreign audiences, The Associated Press reports. Mr. Lee's POW! Entertainment said in a statement issued on its Web site this week that the new company, Magic Storm Entertainment, will announce its first film project later this summer. ''I have been eagerly awaiting this great opportunity - a chance to combine the best of American superhero epics with the best of Chinese and Asian classical filmmaking for a motion picture that would be excitedly received worldwide,'' Mr. Lee said in the statement.

Pretty much everyone agrees it's a good idea for home buyers to put some of their own money down when borrowing to buy a house. Having a stake in the property, the thinking goes, encourages homeowners to keep making payments on the mortgage. But how much of a down payment is reasonable? Ten percent? Twenty? Five?

The Aug. 2 debt ceiling deadline is holding firm. The Treasury Department said Friday morning that its latest estimates still show that's the date the government will exhaust its ability to pay all of its bills, unless Congress agrees to raise the total amount that the United States can borrow. ''Secretary Geithner urges Congress to avoid the catastrophic economic and market consequences of a default crisis by raising the statutory debt limit in a timely manner,'' the department said in a statement issued in the name of Mary Miller, the assistant secretary for financial markets.

An article on Page 7 this weekend about a documentary about Nim Chimpsky, a chimpanzee who was raised as a boy, misstates the given name of the woman who wrote the book ''Nim Chimpsky, the Chimp Who Would Be Human.'' She is Elizabeth Hess, not Stephanie.

The team behind the Broadway revival of ''On a Clear Day You Can See Forever,'' starring Harry Connick Jr., has announced an opening date and stage: Dec. 11 at the St. James Theater. With music by Burton Lane and lyrics by Alan Jay Lerner, the new production of this classic musical will feature a new book by Peter Parnell (''QED''), based on the original book by Mr. Lerner. The Tony Award-winning Michael Mayer (''Spring Awakening'') will direct the show. Mr. Connick, the singer, actor and bandleader, will play Dr. Mark Bruckner, a psychiatrist pining for his dead wife. When Dr. Bruckner takes on the case of David Gamble, a florist's assistant, he discovers that Gamble might have had a former life as Melinda Wells, a 1940s jazz singer with whom the psychiatrist falls in love. Additional casting for those roles has yet to be announced.

Is there enough food? How do we get it to people? What is its quality? These common questions all concern supply; people spend a lifetime addressing them, and if you closely examine any one, you're ensnared in a complex web. Yet we don't spend enough time discussing what happens to food once it's in the home. Or what doesn't happen. Which is cooking. And that part is pretty simple.

Just a few months ago, the people behind ''Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides'' were shivering in their timbers. Would their $250 million movie win back fans, the ones who were fed up with bloated running times and bewildering plots? Or would the audience respond with a great big yo ho hum? Suffice it to say, the Disney series is fixed. Directed by Rob Marshall and produced by Jerry Bruckheimer, ''Stranger Tides'' on Saturday is expected to break the $1 billion mark at the global box office, powered by enormous results overseas. Only seven other films have achieved that feat (in unadjusted dollars).By joining the $1 billion club, Mr. Marshall vanquishes any doubts about his bankability following commercial duds like ''Nine'' and ''Memoirs of a Geisha.'' The windfall also reverses Mr. Bruckheimer's cold streak following the wince-inducing ''Sorcerer's Apprentice'' and ''Confessions of a Shopaholic.'' Rich Ross, Disney's newish movie chairman, also gets a feather for his tricorn, proving that he can at the very least turn up the sizzle on continuing film franchises.

Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival announced it is adding to New York's menu of free concerts with a performance on July 30 at Avery Fisher Hall. The hourlong concert will feature the overture to ''The Marriage of Figaro;'' Mozart's Symphony No. 36, the ''Linz;'' and Stravinsky's Symphony in C, performed by the Festival Orchestra and the music director, Louis Langree. Lincoln Center did not immediately release information on how to obtain the tickets, but said word would be posted on mostlymozart.org This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

(Starz) BURLESQUE (2010) Christina Aguilera plays Ali, an Iowan refugee for whom the big time means doing the bump and grind in a Los Angeles club, and Cher, above, is Tess, the aging proprietress of the kind of hole in the wall where dreams turn into realities, in what Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called a ''backstage tease-o-rama about life in and out of corsets and garters.'' She added: '' 'Burlesque' nods, though more rightly wags its derrière, in the direction of new burlesque, but it's strictly old school -- at times, really old school -- with a story line that had already gathered dust by the time the choreographer Busby Berkeley pointed his camera up the collective skirt of the chorus in the 1933 musical '42nd Street.' '' And though Ms. Aguilera proves to be ''a serviceable screen presence who has a voice and an occasional song (Etta James's 'Tough Lover') big enough to keep her from sliding off screen,'' the movie ''quickly proves achingly dull.'' 7:30 P.M. COHEN--Elias A. Although 59 years have passed since our beloved founder, Elias A. Cohen, passed away on July 2, 1952, he is still remembered with love and reverence by the thousands of deserving boys and girls who were privileged to come to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp for a few fun filled weeks each summer since July 1st, 1919. In the spirit of Noblesse Oblige his devoted family, his many loyal friends and a grateful Alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquillity Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that Tranquillity is now celebrating its 93rd year. Tranquillity Camp, Inc.Earlton, NY Richard Lawrence, President

I’ve always liked John Philip Sousa’s “The Stars and Stripes Forever.” I first became aware of the song in Popeye cartoons from the 1930s and ’40s. It consistently accompanied his post-spinach trouncing of his rival, Bluto. The music gave Popeye strength, better posture, moral certainty and an aura of the American military’s invincibility. Battleships firing cannons even appeared in his muscles. I guess that’s what a good march does: it makes you stronger on your way to battle. This performance is excerpted from a 1906 Edison recording featuring Sousa’s band.

When the Confederacy opened fire on Fort Sumter in April 1861, Abraham Lincoln responded within hours, ordering a naval blockade of Southern ports and calling for 75,000 volunteers to “maintain the honor, the integrity, and the existence of our National Union.” But in a 19th-century precursor to President Obama’s decision to act alone against Libya, Lincoln made no effort to win immediate Congressional approval — much less appropriations to pay for his orders. The reason seemed simple enough: Congress was out of session and out of town.

ALBERT--Eugene, long-time resident of Croton-on-Hudson, died on June 25 after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. Gene was born on June 28, 1924 in the Bronx and graduated from Croton Harmon High School in 1942. During WWII he served as a navigator in the Army Air Corps and after the war received a BS in Sociology from Columbia University. He spent his early career in insurance and real estate sales and later started his own appraisal business, the Albert Appraisal Company. Throughout a career of more than 50 years Gene set the standard for excellence in real estate appraising. At the age of 63 he received a law degree from Pace University and thence began his second successful career. Gene is survived by his wife Ingrid, his three children Anthony, Joe, and Jeannie, his brother Richard, his first wife Vera, and three grandchildren. We love and miss you. A private memorial service is being arranged by the family. Please consider making a contribution in the name of Eugene Albert to the American Parkinson Disease Association, www.apdaparkinson.org.

LONOFF--Richard, of Northbrook, IL, died peacefully after a brief illness, June 27, 2011, at age 90. Born October 18, 1920 in New York City, he graduated from Brooklyn College, served in the air force during World War II, attended Columbia Teachers College and then worked in the New York City Public School System until retirement in 1978. He did yeoman service as principal of PS 20 in the South Bronx from 1961 to 1971. Devoted husband of 61 years to Evelyn, he is survived by his sister Rita and sons Jon and Marc (Alice) and grandchildren Julie and David. Service and interment will be private. Services by N.H. Scott & Hanekamp Funeral Home 847-998-1020.
