The golden age of polo in the 1920s and '30s was recalled last month on Governors Island. The 14,000 spectators carried on the tradition of dressing up. For men: Bermuda shorts, shirts, jackets and ties. For women: dresses long and short, hats a must. Jeans were scarce. Unlike the crowd at summer matches in the Hamptons, everyone here watched the action and the star player, Nacho Figueras.

NORSA--Luigia (Gigi), died on June 20, 2011. She was born in Milan, Italy in 1921 and moved with her family to Schenectady, NY in 1938. Gigi made Manhattan her home and practiced Psychiatry and Neurology. After retiring from medicine, she volunteered at the Malloch Rare Book Room and continued to write about art and neurology. Gigi is survived by her sister, Bruna, her brother-in-law, Angelo, her nieces, Adriana and Paola and by Adriana's children, Jonah and Leo. She leaves behind a circle of friends, colleagues and family who will remember her wit, fierce independence and her love of animals. A special thanks to her friends, the doormen and superintendent at her building, the caregivers and social workers and all the other people who helped her live the last years of her life with independence and dignity. A memorial is planned for early August. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Vassar College, Class of 1943 Scholarship Fund, Box 14, 124 Raymond Ave, Poughkeepsie, NY 12604.
WASHINGTON THE Piper PA-31 Navajo took off into the sultry Miami morning and streaked southward toward the Caribbean. High over Haiti, the cameras inside began to snap.
To the Sports Editor: Re ''Away From Main Stages, a Victorious Serena Williams Sees Inequality,'' June 24: If Serena Williams wants equality, tell her to play five sets.

MILLER--Alan Michael, MD, JD, a nationally-recognized endocrinologist, has died at his home in Los Angeles with his family by his side, after a long battle with Hodgkin's Lymphoma. Dr. Miller was born in New York City. His father, Irving, owned a manufacturing company and his mother, Leona, was an educator at Hofstra University. He graduated from Pennsylvania, received his MD at Albany Medical College, interned at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Manhattan, and did residency in endocrinology at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He spent a brief period as a USAF Doctor at Andrews AFB. In 1977, he joined Riverside Medical Clinic and in 1991, Kaiser Permanente, where he retired from practicing medicine in 2009. In 2004, he earned a JD from Concord University School of Law. He is survived by wife, Barbara Rosenfeld, children Lauren (John), Geoffrey (Kerrith), Andrew, Joshua, and Benjamin, grandchildren Ross and Grant, brother David, sister-in-law Joni, niece Jill, nephew Marc, former wives Dr. Sally Freitas and Meryl Miller-Talbert.
Film Jeannette Catsoulis

BONOMO--Victor, on June 29, 2011. Beloved father and father-in-law of Richard and Marla, Roger and Kathleen, and Ruth. Adored grandfather of Alexandra, Jordan, David, Elizabeth and Hannah. Memorial service to be announced.

Dupont Circle is one of Washington's premier destinations for foodies and revelers. Now activists have a place at the table as a new museum sheds light on China's labor camp system. The Laogai Museum (1734 20th Street NW; 202-408-8300; laogaimuseum.org) is the only museum in the United States to focus on China's labor camp system. The museum opened in April with support from the Yahoo! Human Rights Fund; it features interactive exhibits and special events like speeches and home-cooked Chinese meals.

Starting this fall, travelers to Amsterdam will have to make do with fewer artistic masterpieces, as the Van Gogh Museum (vangoghmuseum.nl) closes for a six-month refurbishment. Two of the city's other major museums, the Rijksmuseum and the Stedelijk Museum, are already partly closed for renovations. Like them, the Van Gogh Museum will be displaying some of its best-known pieces elsewhere: starting in October, 75 paintings and a selection of works on paper will be shown at the nearby Hermitage Amsterdam (hermitage.nl).

FOR those infected with jungle fever (see Prada's chic monkey and banana frocks for spring), the good news is you can follow the trend into fall. The Marc by Marc Jacobs collection, in stores this month, features panthers and antelopes on everything from drop pants to jacquard blazers. The prints are the handiwork of Michael Roberts, who, when not working for Vanity Fair as style editor at large, is illustrating children's pop-up books about the jungle. This clutch, for example, with its sleek appliqué, is entirely fierce. It's $328 at Marcjacobs.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

THE Royal Shakespeare Company doesn't travel light. In mid-June a convoy of 46 shipping containers began to arrive at the Park Avenue Armory, having made the journey by truck and boat from Stratford-Upon-Avon to the Upper East Side of Manhattan. One container was filled with flat-packed hoop skirts and World War I uniforms. Another held a life-size model of a wild boar and a 12-foot bear suit with glowing eyes. A third stored 20 wigs, 15 mustaches and several cans of litchis to serve as Gloucester's savaged eyeballs in ''King Lear.'' But that was just for starters.

TWO apartments closing for $20.5 mil- lion, a condominium in the Time War- ner Center and a co-op at 640 Park Avenue, tied for the highest sale of the week, according to Streeteasy.com and city property records.The 17-room Park Avenue co-op, with four bedrooms and six bathrooms, was bought by Alexander H. Tisch, a grandson of Laurence A. Tisch, a founder of the Loews Corporation, and his wife, Bara. It was first listed by Brown Harris Stevens for $26 million in September 2009, when such luxury properties were barely moving. It was taken off the market for a year, relisted and the price was reduced in January to $24.5 million, according to Streeteasy.At the Time Warner Center, Alfred R. Kahn, who retired as the chairman of 4Kids Entertainment in January, and his wife, Pat- sy, sold their five-bedroom condo for $13.10 million less than the original asking price of $33.6 million. It was first listed in January 2010 with Brown Harris Stevens; the last asking price was $24.95 million.Big Ticket includes closed deals from the previous week, ending Wednesday.SARAH KERSHAW

MAY--Richard Jr. 93, died July 1st in Nyack, NY. He was a leader in local, national and international Urban Planning. He is survived by his wife, Joan Martinson May, children Peter May, of Rio de Janeiro and Julie May of Brooklyn and grandchildren, Rasheed, Maya and Joao. A celebration of his life will be held in July.

Her résumé reads like a Who's Who of the greatest classical characters: Juliet, Cleopatra, Lady Macbeth, Medea, Phaedra ... and Richard III. Yes, Seana McKenna, 54, and a 20-year veteran of the Stratford Shakespeare Festival is treading new ground this season. ''I had always been interested in exploring a male Shakespearean character's mind just to see if it was any different,'' Ms. McKenna said by telephone from her Ontario home. Now she regularly dons a wig of long, bedraggled locks and a shoulder hump, walking with a limp to impersonate Shakespeare's ''lump of foul deformity,'' one of his most unapologetically evil characters. ''I don't wear much makeup, but I'm allowing my face to reflect the nasty thoughts inside,'' she said. ''I don't think women do that because it will create those frown lines.''

GLICK--Mae, March 7, 1914-June 29, 2011. Daughter of Gussie and Max Weitzman, sister of Sol and Lillian, deceased, Dorothy Brickel living in New Jersey. Mae was married to Murray for 50 years. She is loved and cherished by her children, Bobby married to Lois, Joyce married to Max and grandchildren, Danielle, Jackie, Dara married to David, Jessica married to Geoff and great-grandchildren, Madison, Claudia and Stevie. Donations in memory of Mae Glick, Sutter Visiting Nurses Hospice Foundation, 1625 Van Ness Ave., 4th Floor, San Francisco, CA 94109

NOWHERE does Beijing feel more ancient than in its alleyways, or hutongs, where the bell chimes of passing bikes keep pedestrians on their toes amid single-story, slate-gray dwellings. These days, there's no better place to get lost in Beijing's back streets than the Yonghegong area, a maze of alleys branching out from the 17th-century Lama, or Yonghe, Temple, a popular tourist spot and one of the city's best-known places of worship. Over the past year, combined cafe-boutiques and restaurants with stone courtyards have opened along the streets around the lamasery. In a city full of high-rise malls, these new spots set themselves apart simply by keeping things quaint: the bars are tiny, pet cats laze about in the cafes, and one fashion designer hands out free brownies on the weekend. COLLEEN KINDER

ACCORDING to numerous reports, the Obama administration has advanced a federal fuel efficiency fleet average standard of 56.2 m.p.g. for 2025. But while an official number from the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is not expected until September, the reported standard has prompted intense jockeying among automakers and environmental groups and has again put a focus on California. In 2009, the state tabled its clean-car mandates to adopt a fleet-average standard set by the federal government for 2012-16. That standard called for a gradual strengthening of Corporate Average Fuel Economy, known as CAFE, that would culminate in a 35.5 m.p.g. fleet-wide requirement in 2016.

BOWING to pressure from team owners; race circuit managers; and Bernie Ecclestone, the series chief, the governing body of Formula One announced Wednesday that it would shelve a plan to require more fuel-efficient 4-cylinder engines on all of its racecars in 2013. Under a compromise reached last week between team owners and the Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile, racecars would be equipped with 6-cylinder engines for 2014 and beyond.

(13, 49) POIROT XI: HALLOWE'EN PARTY David Suchet, below, continues his stint as the dapper Belgian supersleuth Hercule Poirot in the last of three new mysteries based on the novels by Agatha Christie and presented by ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' In this installment a universally disliked girl, Joyce Reynolds (Macy Nyman), boasts at a Halloween party of having seen a murder -- and ends up dead in an apple-bobbing mishap. Another guest, the mystery writer Ariadne Oliver (Zoë Wanamaker), summons her old friend Poirot to the scene, where, with the help of the spiteful village crone, Mrs. Goodbody (Paola Dionisotti), he must figure out how a long-ago stabbing, a Russian au pair (Vera Filatova) and a forgery are connected before another corpse surfaces. 9 A.M. Here's a sampling of readers' comments on Jon Pareles's essay about changes in how music collections can be stored and retrieved online. ''I'm astonished. Everyone is mad keen to put stuff they paid for in a place where they keep paying for it and may potentially lose all access to it (at least to the point where they have to buy it again) so that they don't have to lug around some trivial amount of actual physical material. This isn't like putting your bike in winter storage. This is like handing your kids to somebody for safekeeping with the prospect that the somebody may someday try to ransom them back to you. Or even give them to somebody else.''

A news analysis article on June 26 about the pervasive reach of petroleum into everyday life misstated a substance used in the 18th and 19th centuries to make cosmetics. It was spermaceti, a waxy solid obtained from the oil of cetaceans and from the heads of sperm whales; it was not whale sperm.

The cover article on June 19 about a married couple returning to Provence 40 years after their honeymoon there misstated the circumstances of the car crash in which Albert Camus died in 1960. Camus was not driving the car ''home'' to Provence from Paris. He was in the front passenger seat, and the car was traveling to Paris. The article also misstated the title of the current owner of the cottage in Opio where the newlyweds had lived for a year. He is Earl Spencer, brother of the late Princess Diana; not the Earl of Spencer. A listing with the article, for Bistrot Découverte in St. Rémy de Provence, misidentified the town in which Vincent van Gogh spent his final days. It was Auvers-sur-Oise, not St.-Rémy.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Transcendent Thud,'' June 23: I was part of an elite hammer throwing group, and we frequently discussed the split between techniques: Americans are more about strength and big, bulky muscles, and Eastern Europeans are more about perfecting their finesse. There are also subtle differences in the winds and turns of Americans and Eastern Europeans.

NOT too long after watching the New York State Senate pass the marriage-equality bill on television, Bill White turned to his longtime partner, Bryan Eure, and asked, ''Want to have a wedding?'' His answer: ''Yes, but -- -- ''
Dance Claudia La Rocco

During most of the 1990s the actress Patricia Richardson was supermom Jill Taylor on the sitcom ''Home Improvement.'' Her forthcoming gig playing the quintessential cougar and not-so-nice mom Mrs. Robinson in ''The Graduate,'' at the Cape Playhouse on Cape Cod, is a wholly different job, of course, but then Ms. Richardson is a different actor today. ''I've had so many horrible things happen in my life since I did 'Home Improvement' that it's worried me about doing comedy because, how do I say this, I'm a much darker person than I was,'' she said from her home in Los Angeles, a few days before heading to the East Coast. ''I've lost my mother, I've lost my father. I just lost my brother-in-law in January. There's been a lot of grief and loss.'' Nowadays, she said, bleaker comedy suits her just fine.

ANDREA WEBER had been thinking about leaving the Merce Cunningham Dance Company. It was 2008, she had been dancing with the troupe for four years, and her mind was slowly wrapping itself around the idea of what life after Cunningham might look like for her. And then she and her colleagues were informed of the organization's intention to dissolve the troupe at the end of a goodbye tour that would follow Cunningham's death (which came in 2009). For Ms. Weber this radical decision changed everything.

PORGES--Lucie, died June, 17th. Our incredible, vibrant, curious courageous Lucie. She was a fashion designer, artist, teacher, wife of 60 years to cartoonist Paul Peter Porges, sister to Elfi, mother of Claudia and Vivette, mother-in-law to Jean Philippe and Paul, grandmother of Kitt, Evan, Katalina, Ella, and Max. We are so proud of her remarkable life, born in Vienna, Austria in 1926, forced by war to leave her homeland, met her future husband in Geneva 1945. They created a new life in New York, where she designed beautiful clothes with Pauline Trigere for 43 years. After her retirement she went on to teach the popular class "Fashion Atelier" at Parsons for 14 years and continued designing on her own while loving her life, family, friends, and traveling. A memorial will be held in August.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article on residential auctions in New York City misidentified a condominium in East Harlem that was auctioned by Paramount USA Realty on June 19. It is the Alto, not the Winfield. (Paramount USA auctioned units at both buildings on June 19.)

An opinion article on June 26 about the path the Obama administration should take in withdrawing from Afghanistan incorrectly described the end of Richard M. Nixon's presidency. He resigned; he was not impeached.

SWEDEN once again struggled to score but secured its second straight 1-0 victory on Saturday, beating NORTH KOREA in Augsburg, Germany. Midfielder Lisa Dahlkvist scored in the 64th minute. The UNITED STATES followed with a 3-0 win against COLOMBIA in Sinsheim, sending both the Americans and the Swedes to the quarterfinals. It could have been worse for the Colombians: the Americans missed at least a half-dozen other good scoring chances, and had a 27-12 advantage in shots. In a game with plenty of near misses, Lisa Dahlkvist of Sweden, left, provided the only highlight against North Korea. Linda Forsberg crossed into the middle and Therese Sjogran fed the ball to the unmarked Dahlkvist for a simple finish from close range.

Do you have a minute for gay rights? How about Planned Parenthood? A.S.P.C.A.? Save the clock tower? It's that season again. Of the many hallmarks of summer in New York City perhaps the most unsung are the sidewalk volunteers. See them stationed there in their neon T-shirts, facing each other at either end of the block, requesting your personal information and your money. The world is their foosball table, and you are their teeny-tiny ball. These binder-brandishers aren't just handing out paper; they're doling out guilt. And that we already have on us as we round the corner.

Like them, the Van Gogh Museum will be displaying some of its best-known pieces elsewhere: starting in October, 75 paintings and a selection of works on paper will be shown at the nearby Hermitage Amsterdam (hermitage.nl).

Interview by Jessica Bruder Sister Mary Kate, 18: We pray the rosary at the same time every day at the Dominican Sisters of Mary, Mother of the Eucharist -- always after lunch. You're basically repeating the words that Archangel Gabriel said to Our Lady. These are the most important words in history, so to say them over and over again doesn't make them in the least bit old.

When the playwright Michael Weller heard that Karen Allen wanted to direct his 1970 play, ''Moonchildren,'' at the Berkshire Theater Festival this summer, he was wary. ''I thought, 'Oh, she's an actress, she'll just want to work with the actors.' But the first thing she said was, 'I want to talk to you about the order of the scenes,' '' Mr. Weller recalled. ''She was just dramaturgically so astute.'' Ms. Allen, perhaps forever to be known as Marion Ravenwood, the love interest of Indiana Jones in ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' is directing professionally for the first time, though she said she has been ready for a while. ''There's always been a part of me that was very much interested in working as a director, but you end up sort of feeling like you can't straddle both,'' she said.

PORTLAND, Ore., boasts more craft breweries than any other city in the world. Probably the smallest of them, Captured by Porches, is a mom-and-pop operation in a one-of-a-kind location: a truck on wheels that takes advantage of the city's loose alcohol laws and roving spirit of culinary adventure. Between four and eight craft ales are served from three circulating trucks. Its flagship beer is made from local hops and smoothly toes the line between sweet and pleasantly bitter. ''We just can't make enough beer,'' said Brian White, a brewer and occasional bartender on wheels. Hence the operation's recent expansion from a nanobrewery (roughly two kegs at a time) to a proper microbrewery. Passing by its Alberta Street location, a curious local stopped to ask, ''Is there really a brewing company inside a bus?'' Go to capturedbyporches.com. JORDAN MICHELMAN

In an important prosecutorial-misconduct case this term, the Supreme Court's conservative majority threw out a $14 million jury award for a New Orleans man who was impris- oned for 18 years, including 14 on death row, for a robbery and a murder he did not commit. One month before John Thomp- son's scheduled execution, a private investigator discovered that prosecutors had hidden evidence that exonerated him. After his release, Mr. Thompson won a civil lawsuit against the Orleans Parish district attorney's office, which had been led by Harry F. Connick, for its gross indifference to the incompetence of the prosecutors who violated his consti- tutional rights.

WHEN FASHION MEETS FISHING, THE FEATHERS FLY In a collision of cutting-edge chic and a hobby that requires drab waders, fly fishing shops are suddenly inundated with women looking to get in on the latest trend: colorful feathers that are bonded or clipped into hair. (Published June 28)
BAY RIDGE BROWNSTONE $1,299,000

Amar'e Stoudemire signed with the Knicks as a free agent last summer after eight seasons with the Phoenix Suns. He led the Knicks to their first winning record (42-40) in 10 years and their first playoff berth in seven. Stoudemire, 29, was limited by a pulled muscle in his back during the first-round series against Boston, and the Knicks were swept. He was in Manhattan for a promotion before the N.B.A. imposed a lockout last week.Q.What has been the best part about being a Knick?A.The fans. When we are winning, the fans are incredible. When we're losing, they can grow impatient. Winning a championship takes patience, and the fans here in New York are not willing to wait - and neither am I.Q.How can the Knicks improve themselves in the off-season?A.I think defense is where it all starts. We need an interior presence to help us on the floor. I don't have any one particular player in mind, but I know he's out there. Q.As a former member of the Suns, where do you prefer living, in the East or West?A.The East Coast is more entertaining. You have so many great cities here, like Miami, New York and Philadelphia, that have so much to offer culturally. These are intriguing cities to me. They're fun to visit and explore.Q.What were your thoughts on the N.B.A. finals?A.I thought the games were great, very exciting. Every game could have gone either way, depending on how the ball bounced.Q.Did Miami prove that having three talented go-to guys - LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh - can actually disrupt team chemistry?A.It's hard to have three guys averaging 25 points a game. I think the Celtics do a great job with their Big Three because they believe in the pass, and that's something we're going to stress next season, believing in each other. I don't know if Miami had enough time to figure that out this season.Q.The Celtics' nucleus of Kevin Garnett, Paul Pierce and Ray Allen is aging. Have they missed their window of opportunity to win another championship?A.I think there's still a window of opportunity for them to win it all again, but it won't be easy because there are so many teams in the East, like the Knicks and the Chicago Bulls, who will keep getting better each season.Q.Are you worried about the possibility of an N.B.A. lockout?A.It's something I dread. I don't want a lockout, I want to play. I want to have a training camp to get me and my teammates in shape for the coming season. We need to negotiate and find a common denominator.Q.Tell us something no one knows about you.A.I enjoy eating Gummi Bears.Q.What are you doing in the off-season?A.A lot of traveling, a lot of resting and a lot of rehabbing my back. I never had a back injury before. It definitely hindered my style of play against Boston. I'm rehabbing my back in the gym almost every day by lifting weights. It's still a little sore, but it's getting better.

WAGNER--Edward, passed away peacefully on July 1, 2011. Beloved by his family and his devoted wife and best friend Ruth, his loving children Peter and Cindy, Marcy and Doug, and his adoring grandsons Adam, Harrison, Josh and Danny. Services at "Sinai Chapels". For information Call: 718-445-0300.

Touring Vermont Before Settling Down My wife and I are planning to move this August from N.Y.C. to Burlington, Vt., where I will be attending medical school. We are looking to travel in the area (by car, preferably) for a week or so before settling into Burlington. We like to hike and do outdoor activities, but also enjoy a day on the beach. Would you have any recommendations of where we can spend a few days in or around Vermont? Obviously, as a medical student about to incur some hefty debt, a vacation on the cheap would be most welcome!
An article last Sunday about Nadia G and the ''Bitchin' Kitchen'' show on the Cooking Channel misspelled the surname of the host of another personality-driven food show. She is Paula Deen, not Dean.

Ken Olin will be 57 soon, but these days he is sounding like an exuberant young actor as he prepares for his role in ''F2M,'' a play written by his wife, Patricia Wettig. ''It's the most fantastic thing to get in touch with,'' he said before a recent rehearsal. ''It's getting in touch with how it all began for me when I was 22 years old, and I came to New York, and I just wanted to be in the theater.''

Until a few years ago, the manager of the All-Star team chose all of the pitchers and reserves for his league. The responsibilities are different now, and as much as the managers might prepare, they make only 16 selections: seven by the American League manager, nine by the National League manager. ''I can't put anything together until the fans tell me who they've got, and the players tell me who they've got,'' said Texas Rangers Manager Ron Washington, who will guide the A.L. team in Phoenix on July 12. ''Then I'll get a chance to see what's the need.''

The cover article on June 26 about the future of the electric car described incorrectly the batteries for the Chevrolet Volt and the Nissan Leaf. The Volt has a 16-kilowatt-hour battery, not a 16-kilowatt. The Leaf has a 24-kilowatt-hour battery pack, not a 24-kilowatt. The article also referred incorrectly to the engine that won the race in automotive innovation a century ago. It was the gasoline-powered combustion engine, not a combustible engine. A chart with the continuation of the article, comparing four car models, misstated the electricity-only range of the Toyota Prius. It is one mile, not 13. (A plug-in version, which is to go on sale next year, will have a 13-mile electric-only range.) The chart also referred imprecisely to the charging time of the Nissan Leaf. It is 8 hours with a 240-volt charger, and 21 hours with a 120-volt charger. Finally, the chart omitted the eligibility of two of the models for a tax credit; like the Chevrolet Volt, the Tesla Roadster and the Nissan Leaf are eligible for a $7,500 federal tax credit.

As the article stated, the mansion was completed in 1907, which was a year after Mr. White's death, not a year before his death.

An article on Page 7 this weekend about a documentary about Nim Chimpsky, a chimpanzee who was raised as a boy, misstates the given name of the woman who wrote the book ''Nim Chimpsky, the Chimp Who Would Be Human.'' She is Elizabeth Hess, not Stephanie.

The last thing a team wants in the late innings of a game is base runners. With that in mind, a look at the middle relievers most likely to strike out the opposition. If strikeouts are the best indicator for future success, these pitchers could become closers. Statistics through Friday's games.

The article on Page 22 this weekend about marital infidelity misidentifies a disease contracted from prostitutes that men in the 18th century could write or talk freely about. It is syphilis, not smallpox.

TREIBER--William, of Massapequa Park, died on June 22nd after 87 joyful years. Cherished son of the late Louis and Mae Treiber; adored brother of the late Eleanor Mendelsohn; beloved husband of 46 years to Rita (who predeceased him in 2002), beloved father of Malka Drucker and her partner Gay Block, Pamela Treiber Opper and her husband, Gary, the late Gale and Paul Wilkow, and Linda Landsman and her husband, Michael; proud grandfather of Ivan, Max, Chaya, Hailey, Andrew, Seth, and Gregg; and amazed great grandfather of eight. He will be missed by all who had the privilege of knowing this kind man who loved almost everyone he met.

JAMES de GIVENCHY intended to give his daughter, Stella, a 1940s candy-striped bracelet that he bought online. When the piece arrived, Mr. de Givenchy, a jeweler, was so taken with the quality of the plastic that he took it into in his workshop for further study, leaving it next to a pile of faceted lapis. The commingling was purely serendipitous. ''I thought it would be so much fun,'' Mr. de Givenchy said of the costume bauble turned fine jewelry. A very American transformation, don't you think? It's $10,000. Go to taffin.com or call (212) 421-6222 for an appointment. STEPHANIE LA CAVA

A HANDGUN is the murderer's firearm of choice, according to the F.B.I. But for the fashion-wise femme fatale for whom plugging a victim full of holes is too, like, messy, why not twist him around your finger instead? To aid and abet such mortal seductions, the Dutch jewelry designer Ted Noten (tednoten.com) has made a series of compacts in the shape of a pistol, each dedicated to a different cosmetic giant. The customized guns are produced on a 3-D printer, then retrofitted with 18-karat gold details and loaded with all the ammo one needs to win the battle of the sexes: lip gloss in the muzzle, pills (including Viagra) in the loading chamber, 50 grams of 24-karat gold in the gun's clip and a 4-gigabyte thumb drive. The black Chanel gun will set a girl back $17,000, so she might want to persuade a fiancé that this beats blood diamonds as a way to say, ''Until death do us part.'' LYNN PHILLIPS

HOLDING banks accountable for all those disastrous mortgages has been remarkably difficult. But last week, a big bank agreed to pay a price: Bank of America announced that it would part with $8.5 billion to settle claims that its Countrywide Financial unit had packaged garbage loans into investments that were said to be safe. That is good news for investors, as these things go. But another, lesser-known case now winding its way through the courts may help others recover losses from lenders who dealt in risky mortgages and claimed that they had no duty to their customers.

BLACK--Bradford Reynolds, 24, beloved son of Steven and Deborah Black passed away June 23, 2011. He attended Brunswick School and Greenwich High School before completing his degree in Washington state. Bradford was bright, clever and witty, always jumping into every endeavor with passion and enthusiasm. He used his creative skills in many ways. He loved drawing, creating cartoons and was particularly adept at innovative computer programming. With his contagious smile, he never failed to make those around him laugh. In the last year he had rediscovered his lifelong passion for food and was pursuing a diploma at Le Cordon Bleu College of Culinary Arts in Los Angeles. He was so proud of his creations, frequently emailing photos of his dishes to his family and friends. In addition to his parents, he is survived by his sister Heather, his brother Taylor, his paternal and maternal grandparents and many aunts, uncles and cousins who all loved him dearly. A memorial service will be held on Friday, July 8 at 11:00am at Christ Church, Greenwich, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made in Bradford's name to the charity of your choice.

But also, thanks to the site's ''dress me'' tab, you can get a lesson in how to put together last year's clothes, or those from the year before. You can't go wrong with this summer ensemble: an Alice by Temperley maxidress ($158), a bikini by Matthew Williamson ($96.25), Alexander McQueen gladiators ($375) and a Pucci silk scarf ($100.80). Go to theoutnet.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

ROSAMILIA--Thomas A. A remarkable spirited man transitioned on June 24, 2011 at the age of 50. Loving and beloved life partner for a blessed 21 years to Frank S. Cassata, Thomas was a talented, creative man dedicated to bringing beautiful design to the world. Every day he witnessed beauty, joy, love, and limitless potential in everything and everyone. Thomas touched many lives with his handsomeness, wit, spirituality, humor, kindness and love. He will be missed, but his bright energy will remain in the hearts of many. In addition to his partner, Frank, he is survived by his mother, Theresa Rosamilia, his father, Fred Rosamilia, sister, Karen Fleming, sister-in-law, Donna Cassata, brother-in-laws, Thomas Fleming and Robert Mazziotta; as well as three nieces and four nephews to whom he was an inspiration and guide. There will be a celebration of his life, Saturday, July 16th, 2011, between 11am1pm at Peter Norton Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway at 95th St, New York, NY 10025. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Thomas' memory to: Unity of New York/ Manifesting Miracles, 119 West 23rd St, Suite 600, New York, NY 10011. unityofnewyork.com (212)560-0756. Follow your Bliss Thomas, we love you!

The Gray Matter column on June 26 about how scientists correct errors misstated the number of submissions received by The Journal of Personality and Social Psychology that reported failed replications of an earlier study, which had claimed that people's minds could be influenced by events in the future. The journal received only one, not all three.

GEOGHEGAN--Barrett H.,82, of Long Beach, IN and Punta Gorda, FL, passed away June 20, 2011. He was born May 25, 1929, in New York City to Veronica (Hughes) Geoghegan and A. V. B. Geoghegan. Barry played a role in what many consider to be The Golden Age of Television, beginning his career in 1956 in the Executive Training Program at ABC, where he went on to become Director of Sales at WABC-TV. In 1971, he was named an Executive Officer of LIN Broadcasting Corp. and served as President and General Manager of WAND-TV in Decatur, IL until his retirement in 1988. He was both President of the Illinois Broadcasters Association and a Director of the Museum of Communications in Chicago. A graduate of the University of Missouri School of Journalism and a U.S. Navy Veteran of the Korean Conflict, he was a jazz enthusiast who enjoyed deep-sea fishing in the Florida waters, but his passion was always Television. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Joan (Kruckel) Geoghegan and three children Barrett V. Geoghegan, Christine (Ian Edwards) Geoghegan, and Elizabeth E. Geoghegan, and three grandchildren Nicholas Geoghegan, An and Wren Edwards. His son Geoffrey Geoghegan preceded him in death.

IT was named for a European breed of bunny, whose wisdom was singled out in the Bible (''The conies are but a feeble folk, yet make they their houses in the rocks''). That is about as close as Coney Island has gotten to anything holy since it was converted from a barren spit of beach into a rollicking resort nearly two centuries ago. For four decades, the photographer Harvey Stein has returned again and again -- 400 times, by his count -- to chronicle Coney's metamorphosis. Thanks to landfill, it is no longer an island (it is now a peninsula) at the bottom of Brooklyn. Yet it remains a place apart -- a sanctuary from the more serious city where people come to connect with their sybaritic selves on nearly three miles of beach and a boardwalk secured with more than 15 million screws.

Strauss-Kahn dominated the Twitter feeds of New Yorkers on Friday, a day after the news broke that the rape case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn appeared to be on the brink of falling apart. Every development in the case was tweeted and retweeted - Mr. Strauss-Kahn (known as #DSK on Twitter) was in the courtroom, he had been released on his own recognizance, the district attorney was about to speak. As the week began, the legalization of same-sex marriage bill, which passed two days before the city's Gay Pride Parade was held last Sunday, continued to dominate local Twitter feeds - with #equalityforall, #nycpride and Governor Andrew Cuomo. After all, what's a major legislative victory without a little gloating?

Doctoroff, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

Benjamin P. Feldman, a retired real estate investor with the time and the money to chase his enthusiasms, was rummaging through a bin at a flea market in Chelsea last winter when he came across a weathered leather change purse with words engraved in gilt: ''Compliments of Sol Goldberg's Cafe, 71 Canal Street, Tel. 2111 Orchard.'' There was something about the antique purse and its desperate gambit to lure customers that spoke to him.

CARRAS--W. Gabriel. The NYU Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development mourns the loss of Professor Emeritus W. Gabriel Carras, teacher, mentor, friend, dean, and beloved member of the NYU family. In a 54-year career at NYU, Gabe touched the lives of everyone he met. He was scholarly, warm, and a passionate champion of the people and ideals of the university he loved so much. We will miss him. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Grace, and his family.

A few years ago, just as the recession hit, the Chambre Syndicale, the French fashion authority, decided to separate the June men's shows and the haute couture by a week. The two groups of shows had followed each other, as they still do in January. A week of free time in Europe is no longer regarded by publications with the joie de vivre of the past, so I usually split the time between work and pleasure. At the moment I'm in a village in Burgundy, staying at La Source des Fees, a vineyard owned by Thierry Nouvel and Philippe Greffet. The place is as lovely as it is laid back, with delicious dinners, and each night brings new guests - Dutch, Swedes, French. It's the beginning of the European summer. Maybe because of the distance from the men's shows, it's easier to see what they lacked. The other day I wrote about the sensuality in the collections of Givenchy and Comme des Garcons. But I think in general what's missing from the Paris and Milan spring shows is a sense of fun. I had a chat with Carla Sozzani, the Milan retailer, after Lanvin, and she pointed out that the creative spirit that drove designers in the past was in part entrepreneurial; it meant as much to them to design exciting stuff as it did to be their own bosses. But while there are many young designers who still have that mind-set, the field is dominated by big brands. And they want results, Ms. Sozzani said.

Staying in shape on your summer vacation just got a little easier: Fairmont Hotels & Resorts (fairmont.com) is rolling out a free bike loan program at more than 55 of its properties worldwide. It has teamed with BMW Group to provide up to eight cruise bikes, along with helmets and locks, at participating hotels. Locations in North America already have the cycles (Le Manoir Richelieu in Quebec is shown above); other properties will have them by mid-July. Concierges can help plan bike itineraries: visitors to the Fairmont Le Montreux Palace on Lake Geneva in Switzerland, for example, can cycle around the lake and surrounding countryside. Fairmont isn't the only chain to lend guests bikes at no charge. Element, a Starwood brand that began in 2008, has them at its nine properties in the United States. The Park Hyatt has biking programs at various locations, including Chicago and Toronto. And Nantucket Island Resorts in Massachusetts has cruiser bikes available to guests at some of its properties. SHIVANI VORA

GOLDSTEIN--Eda, of Easthampton, died on June 21. Survived by her devoted partner, Patricia Petrocelli, her mother, brother, niece, and nephew. A psychotherapist, author, and NYU professor emeritus, she is recognized as the authority on the application of psychoanalytic theory to clinical social work. A memorial in her honor will take place in the fall and a scholarship has been established in her name at the NYU Silver School of Social Work.

DiPAOLA--Andrew J. Former New York State Supreme Court Justice Andrew J. DiPaola of Glen Cove and Amagansett, NY passed away on June 17, 2011 at the age of 86. Born of Italian immigrants in Astoria, NY, Judge DiPaola spent most of his career as a devoted public servant. He enlisted in the US Naval Air Force, trained as a pilot and served in the Pacific Theater of Operation from 1942 to 1946. He retained a love of flying throughout his life. Educated at Columbia University, Queens College, and St. Johns University School of Law, Judge DiPaola practiced law in Astoria until his judicial election. Prior to becoming a Supreme Court Justice, he served three terms as Mayor and Supervisor of the City of Glen Cove, beginning in 1967. He was particularly proud of his efforts to develop the Glen Cove Senior Citizen Housing complex and Glen Cove public golf course. In 1972, he was elected to the bench and was designated Associate Justice of the Appellate Term, beginning a 28 year career in the New York State Supreme Court. He was later named Presiding Justice of the Appellate term, where his energetic drive and willingness to face tough issues continued until his retirement at the age of 76. He took great joy in the company of his grandchildren who will remember their Poppy for his unfailing support and unique sense of humor. Judge DiPaola is survived by his wife of 65 years, Helen; two children, Andrew, Jr and Anne Nielsten (Gerald); grandchildren, Alysia, Emily, Meghan, and Matthew; and sister, Mary Santulli. Contributions in Judge DiPaola's memory may be made to the North Shore LIJ Health Foundation, 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021 or the Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons, PO Box 901, Wainscott, NY 11975.

WOLPO--Elliott L.,82, of Colchester, CT, and Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Died peacefully on July 1, 2011. Beloved husband of Laura for 51 years. Devoted father of Stephen (Janice) and Marc. Adored grandfather of Ryan, Max and Evie. Cherished friend to many. A Korean War Veteran, avid golfer and fine bridge player. He will be sorely missed. In the Metropolitan cover story last week, David Gonzalez chronicled the closing of St. Martin of Tours, the Roman Catholic elementary school he had attended in the Bronx. Following are excerpts from reader comments posted on NYTimes.com. Readers also responded to Neil Genzlinger's City Critic column about noisy New York and the Make Music festival. Comments on his article are drawn from e-mails sent to metropolitan@nytimes.com. This makes me so unspeakably sad. I too am a product of NYC's Catholic schools, as was my brother. My primary school closed down several years ago, and my brother's alma mater closes down this year. I firmly believe I would not have received as good an education in the local public schools available to me. The city's working-class and middle-class children are the ones who really lose out. We are losing something precious. I just hope it is not lost completely.Lucy

IF you could script your life, how would it play out? Make movies, win an Academy Award, own an enormous apartment on Central Park West and then, in your declining years, marry someone half your age? On a recent afternoon, Celeste Holm, 94, sat in her vast living room overlooking Sheep Meadow, holding hands with her husband, Frank Basile, 48, assessing how things had worked out for her.

A report on June 19 about the marriage of Lauren Eve Rabinowitz and Cantor Daniel Adam Singer misspelled the surname of the bride's mother. She is Beth L. Gottlieb, not Gottieb.

PIGOTT--J. Robert (August 7, 1924 June 25, 2011) Bob Pigott was laid to rest on June 30, 2011 at Cypress Hills Cemetery at the age of 86. He is mourned by his wife of 56 years, Simone. He is also survived his loving children, Patricia Pigott Strauss and James Robert Pigott, Jr. and, grandchildren, James M. and Julia F. Pigott, son-in-law, Wayne Strauss, and daughter-in-law, Cynthia Moekle Pigott. A passionate supporter of liberal causes, he had been actively involved in several local and national political organizations, including the John F. Kennedy Democratic Club and Americans for Democratic Action. He once served as President of the local school board. Bob retired from the New York State Department of Housing and Community Renewal, where he had been active in the Organization of Management Confidential Employees. He served in the Army Air Corps in World War II and was a particularly loyal alumnus of Hamilton College. He was a great lover of history, literature, theater, film and the New York Mets. Condolences may be sent to his former home address or to bobpigott@aol.com.

Because of an editing error, an article in Week in Review on June 19 on the political mood in Libya misstated the surname of the president of the World Chess Federation, against whom Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi recently played in Tripoli. He is Kirsan N. Ilyumzhinov, not Ilyinov. The article also misidentified a game being played in a souk where Libyans openly expressed eagerness for change. It was backgammon, not baccarat.

ENGLISH--Harold Timothy, of New York City died peacefully on May 28, 2011. He was born in Calgary, Alberta, Canada on December 22, 1958. He received his AB from Princeton University and his MBA from The Wharton School of The University of Pennsylvania. He worked in management consulting with Booz Allen Hamilton and information technology systems with Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan. He is survived by his father Henry W. English of Branford, Connecticut and brother J. Benjamin English of Richmond, Virginia and preceded in death by his mother Theresa Ryan English. The family will hold a private memorial service. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to The American Diabetes Association.

In an important prosecutorial-misconduct case this term, the Supreme Court's conservative majority threw out a $14 million jury award for a New Orleans man who was impris- oned for 18 years, including 14 on death row, for a robbery and a murder he did not commit. One month before John Thomp- son's scheduled execution, a private investigator discovered that prosecutors had hidden evidence that exonerated him. After his release, Mr. Thompson won a civil lawsuit against the Orleans Parish district attorney's office, which had been led by Harry F. Connick, for its gross indifference to the incompetence of the prosecutors who violated his consti- tutional rights.

The Pop entry on June 19 in the Week Ahead column, about a show featuring the band Dinosaur Jr., misidentified the replacement for Keith Morris as lead singer in the hardcore punk band Black Flag. It was Ron Reyes, not Henry Rollins. (Mr. Rollins joined the band later.)

Brent Barrett declined to say the title of the first song he sings in ''Silence! The Musical,'' a parody of the creepy 1991 film ''The Silence of the Lambs.'' ''I can't tell you the name of it because it's not printable in the newspaper,'' he said. (He was correct.) Mr. Barrett, 54, a dashing leading-man type, has been in and out of the Broadway production of ''Chicago'' as Billy Flynn and has played many other roles in New York, in regional theaters and internationally, from Fred Graham in ''Kiss Me, Kate'' in London to the title character in ''The Phantom of the Opera'' in Las Vegas. He has sung at Carnegie Hall and recorded albums. This summer, though, he's taking a detour to play the cannibalistic Dr. Hannibal Lecter on a small East Village stage.

The 36 Hours column on June 19, about Newport, R.I., misidentified the students at the Naval War College, who are among the patrons at the Pour Judgement, which offers an impressive beer list. Most are naval officers; none are cadets.

SEGAL--Edith Levy, died peacefully at home on Tuesday, June 28, shortly before her 95th birthday. Beloved wife of Martin E.; mother of Susan Rai and Paul Segal; mother-in-law of Kanti Rai and Christine Flynn; grandmother of Samantha and Joshua Rai, Emma Segal, and Sarah Flynn; grandmother-in-law of Jay Zaslow; great-grandmother of Ella and Mira Zaslow; and sister of Jacqueline Levy and the late William Levy. A 1936 graduate of Hunter College, for 74 years she stood behind and beside her husband while he built a business and then became a founder and leader of arts institutions. She served as a volunteer for nearly half a century, first at her children's school, then as an evaluator of books for the Child Study Association, and finally--well into her eighties--as a teacher of public school children who did not speak English. She taught three generations how to be a loving, and effective, child, spouse, parent, and grandmother; a responsible member of the community; and a good person. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, June 30 at 10:30am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. Interment will be private. The family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Friday, July 1 from 10:00am to 1:00pm; Tuesday, July 5 from 4:00 to 7:00pm; and Wednesday, July 6 from 4:00 to 7:00pm. In lieu of flowers you may contribute to WQXR (WQXR c/o New York Public Radio, PO Box 1550, New York, NY 10116-1550), which brought her so much pleasure throughout her life and so much comfort in her final months.

Massage is a common alternative treatment for chronic low back pain, but most recent studies have found little evidence that it works. A group of researchers designed a study to see if they could find a difference between back pain sufferers who got massage and those who did not.

Our blog today falls on the Fourth of July, a day for celebration and fireworks. To match the summer mood, we have some light number fare, cooked up by my friend Aziz Inan, who is an absolute whiz when it comes to finding numerical coincidences related to dates. Dr. Inan, an electrical engineering professor at the University of Portland, has appeared in this column before with coincidences related to Palindrome Day, Chopin’s birthday, Dr. Martin Luther King Day and Bill Gates’s birthday. As usual he has a set of wonderful connections with today’s date.

Bouchra Jarrar is one of the few ready-to-wear designers to present a collection on the haute couture calendar. The Balenciaga-alum is beloved for the gamine simplicity of her silhouettes, the refinement of her hand (Jarrar’s clothes look as good inside as out), and her cool way with a slit. This collection she showed at the Odeon on Monday did not disappoint: 17 minimal looks cut from men’s suiting wools, tie silks and tuxedo satins. Here, her take on a smoking with an asymmetric collar and a slinky slash down the back.

Last week I took a trip to Silicon Valley, zigzagging around to meet with start-ups, venture capitalists and the big technology companies that inhabit the area. My goal with these meetings was to get a glimpse of new themes and services consumers could soon expect to see. Although everyone I met with was hard at work on exciting new products, I can't really tell you about them. Why? Because there was another, more subtle theme coursing through the Valley that I hadn't expected to see: extreme secrecy.

(Starz) PRINCE OF PERSIA: THE SANDS OF TIME (2010) The producer Jerry Bruckheimer helps transform a video game into a swords-sandals-and-sorcery spectacular starring Jake Gyllenhaal as the warrior of the title, an adopted son of an ancient king. Gemma Arterton is the pouty princess who joins forces with him to safeguard a supernatural dagger; Alfred Molina plays a wisecracking sheik; and Ben Kingsley is the king's suspicious brother. ''For the most part this is perfectly painless mush,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''If nothing else, it's entertaining to think about how this mash-up of ancient Persian heroics and headline news might sit with the Iranian powers that be. In March 2009 a spokesman for the Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, demanded an apology from Hollywood for 'insults and accusations against the Iranian nation' over the last 30 years. Clearly they had no idea they were about to be Bruckheimer-ed.''

The Yankees are so rich with starting pitching options that on Sunday they sent Ivan Nova, who had lost once in his last nine starts, to the minor leagues. No other options made much sense for the Yankees, who demoted him to Class AAA Scranton/ Wilkes-Barre as a prelude to welcoming back Phil Hughes to their rotation after his three-month stay on the disabled list. Hughes will probably pitch Wednesday night in Cleveland in what would be his first start since April 14. ''I'm real excited to get back,'' said Hughes, who had a 13.94 earned run average in three starts. ''I guess they felt after my last outing that I'm ready, and I'm looking forward to it.'' Hughes's recovery from right shoulder inflammation, a condition that sapped his velocity and fatigued his arm, gave the Yankees a surplus of starting pitchers: six players for five spots. As much as Manager Joe Girardi insisted that the Yankees were considering a six-man rotation, it hardly seemed plausible that they would have their ace, C. C. Sabathia, pitch less often. The Yankees are planning to ride Freddy Garcia and Bartolo Colon, their surprising veterans, for as long as possible. That made Nova, who is 8-4 with a 4.12 earned run average, the logical choice to go, because he has minor league options remaining. He will slide into the Class AAA rotation, becoming the Yankees' first option for a call-up in the event of an injury to a starter. The move was not announced until after the clubhouse had closed to reporters before the Yankees' 3-2 loss to the Mets in 10 innings, but when addressing potential solutions to the logjam Sunday morning, Girardi said he did not think it was possible to make a wrong decision. ''It's just a tough decision,'' he said. The right-hander Lance Pendleton took Nova's place on the major league roster, but he might be just a placeholder for Hughes. With A. J. Burnett starting Monday against Cleveland and Sabathia scheduled to work Tuesday, the earliest Hughes could start would be Wednesday. Hughes arrived at Citi Field on Sunday with a suitcase, not knowing whether he would be shipped out for another minor league start Monday or accompany his teammates on their flight. Hughes said he was ready to pitch in the majors after his start for Class AA Trenton on Wednesday, when he struck out eight and his fastball reached 92 miles per hour toward the end of his sixand- a-third-inning outing, and that he would tell the Yankees so, if asked. Clearly, they agreed.

KNOPF--Armand, age 91, passed away peacefully on July 2nd at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. Beloved husband of Bea and the late Marilyn. Precious and adored father of Sandra, Barbara, Jimmy, Donald, David, Bill, Emmy, Ann, Billy and Ellen. Cherished grandfather of Eric, Kenny, Julie, Stephanie and Madeleine. Great-grandfather of seven. An extraordinarily handsome gentleman, he will be remembered for his kindness, generosity and soft spoken words of wisdom. Funeral services at Guttermans in Woodbury, NY, Wednesday 1pm. Expressions of sympathy in his memory may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County. Rest in peace our sweet hero.

SKOPJE, Macedonia -- In the view of many here, the neighbors have been bullying this little Balkan country for a long time. Bulgarians see the people of Macedonia as Bulgarians with accents. Serbia used to consider it Southern Serbia and refuses to recognize its church. Greece accuses the country of nothing less than stealing its name, history and national symbols.

ABRAMOWITZ--Jack, in Forest Hills, NY on July 1, 2011 at the age of 92. Dearly beloved father of Alan (Ann) and Shelley (Kenneth), grandfather of Seth, Jeremy, Diana and Katie. Also survived by two sisters-in-law, Dorothy Abramowitz and Zelda Abramowitz and their families. Pre-deceased by two much loved and missed brothers, Louis and Murray, and his wife, Isabel, with whom he shared 57 happy years. Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1918, Jack was a graduate of Thomas Jefferson High School, Iowa State Teachers College (BA) and Columbia University (PhD). A World War II veteran, he rose from private to second lieutenant, serving as a Army medical corpsman in North Africa, Palestine, Sicily and Italy. A strong and tireless advocate of civil rights and racial equality, Jack wrote his PhD dissertation in the newly developing field of black history. He was a teacher for more than 40 years in New York City and Long Island, serving as Chairman of the Social Studies Department at Syosset High School and Director of Secondary Social Studies in Farmingdale. While teaching, Jack began to develop special educational materials designed for students with learning difficulties. These materials became a series of pioneering textbooks he wrote for the Follett Publishing Company. The history books Jack wrote and texts in other subject areas that he edited were enormously successful and he became one of the nation's leading authorities on directed reading, a technique that teaches students with educational deficiencies reading skills and subject content simultaneously. Some of his textbooks still are in use. Jack's expertise was recognized when he was invited to teach teachers at the University of London, Hofstra University and Nova University in Florida. Jack continued to revise his books and work with teachers during his retirement. He also maintained a website that offered educational materials at no charge to teachers. His mind was sharp and active until his 90s, He was deeply proud and moved to vote for Barack Obama in 2008. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, July 5 with burial at Beth Moses Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY. In lieu flowers and in remembrance, the family asks that donations be made to one of three organizations Jack supported: the American Civil Liberties Union, Doctors Without Borders or the Democratic Party.

GEOGHEGAN--Barrett H.,82, of Long Beach, IN and Punta Gorda, FL, passed away June 20, 2011. He was born May 25, 1929, in New York City to Veronica (Hughes) Geoghegan and A. V. B. Geoghegan. Barry played a role in what many consider to be The Golden Age of Television, beginning his career in 1956 in the Executive Training Program at ABC, where he went on to become Director of Sales at WABC-TV. In 1971, he was named an Executive Officer of LIN Broadcasting Corp. and served as President and General Manager of WAND-TV in Decatur, IL until his retirement in 1988. He was both President of the Illinois Broadcasters Association and a Director of the Museum of Communications in Chicago. A graduate of the University of Missouri School of Journalism and a U.S. Navy Veteran of the Korean Conflict, he was a jazz enthusiast who enjoyed deep-sea fishing in the Florida waters, but his passion was always Television. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Joan (Kruckel) Geoghegan and three children Barrett V. Geoghegan, Christine (Ian Edwards) Geoghegan, and Elizabeth E. Geoghegan, and three grandchildren Nicholas Geoghegan, An and Wren Edwards. His son Geoffrey Geoghegan preceded him in death.

Have you ever stood quietly in a stall at the driving range and listened? There is thrashing, grunting and foot stomping. Scattered between the thumps and thwacks will be soft, beseeching whispers. Someone will, of course, be talking business on the cellphone. Someone else will be asking for advice, or giving it. Someone will be shouting the most tortured lamentations and swearing off golf forever.
SIEGEL--Sidney H. Beloved husband of Marsha. Adored father of Don Siegel, Monica Siegel, Naomi Duval and Mindy Ohringer and a loving grandfather. Services, Tuesday 12 noon at Gutterman's, Woodbury.

The events in ''Star Wars,'' the opening credits reveal, happened ''a long time ago in a galaxy far, far away.'' But did similar events happen before? That is the question posed by ''Star Wars and History,'' a book planned for 2013 by the publisher John Wiley & Sons. In an e-mail posted in June, Nancy Reagin, a history professor at Pace University, and Janice Liedl, an associate professor of history at Laurentian University in Ontario, asked their peers to submit essays that explore the parallels between world history and Star Wars history.

FISCHLER--Barbara. Dearest Barbara, Knowing you as I have for almost thirty years, I know where you would be right now if you could, and I suspect somehow you are with Jonathan even now, loving him and protecting him as you always have. Those of us, who knew you well, know that this terrible, tragic ending doesn't fit the life you've led. It cannot, and it will not define you. We will always remember you as an especially loyal, loving, sensible, and courageous woman, wife, and mother. Be at peace, my wonderful friend. I'll always love you. Carol

JOPLIN, Mo. -- For the last few nights, brief shimmers of fireworks have sparkled in the dark skies over Joplin, heralding the approach of another national birthday. But the monstrous tornado that mowed through here six weeks ago forced the city to change its Fourth of July plans. That's right; plans were changed. Monday's celebration of the Fourth in the partially destroyed city of Joplin will be bigger and louder and better than ever, and will end with an extended display of glittery starbursts designed to brighten the faces of all looking skyward.

This year's top-selling books -- on paper, not hand-held screens -- have included some serious titles, like ''The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks'' and ''Decision Points,'' as well as celebrity autobiographical turns by Tina Fey and Steven Tyler. Publishers are ready with lighter summer reading, so people can settle down with a favored protagonist. Rizzoli and Isles are featured in their ninth mystery, ''The Silent Girl'' by Tess Gerritsen, which comes out this week, along with ''Betrayal of Trust'' by J. A. Jance, the 20th book in the J. P. Beaumont series. SHELLY FREIERMAN

I noticed his wavy hair, his feline eyes and his lips, which moved slightly as he read. But the first thing I noticed was his book: Philip Roth's ''Portnoy's Complaint,'' one of my favorites, was cradled in his palm. Between Delancey Street and Bryant Park on the uptown F train, I fell for him hard. It wasn't the first time I'd flirted my way into a Saturday night date with a simple phrase: ''I love that book.'' I had one good pickup line, and e-readers ruined it. I can no longer hit on a handsome man on a long commute by asking about his book -- because I can't see it. Gone are the days when, sitting on a train delayed in the station, I could imagine exactly where in the New York Public Library we would first kiss -- in the stacks between Mailer and Malamud or Foer and Franzen? E-books may be saving literature, but my dating life has suffered.

LIFF--Cheryl, of Boynton Beach, FL and Rockville Centre, NY, on July 1, 2011. Beloved wife of Steven Liff. Devoted mother of Allison Liff and Bradley Liff and very special aunt of Sean Roemig. She is survived by her brothers Wayne Carlton and Ian Carlton, and her sister Wendy Harris, as well as numerous nieces and nephews, all of whom adored her. She was loved by all who knew her and will be deeply missed by her family and friends. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday July 5 at noon at Gutterman's, 175 N. Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, NY.

An article Friday about the Congressional investigation into ''Operation Fast and Furious,'' a border-security strategy of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, misstated the circumstances under which the bureau's acting director, Kenneth E. Melson, has agreed to talk to Congress about the operation. He has said he will talk with Congressional investigators; it is not clear if he will testify at a Congressional hearing. The article also misidentified the committee before which Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. testified in May that he had learned about the operation only weeks earlier. It was the House Judiciary Committee, not the Senate Judiciary Committee.

EMERSON--Beatrice, on July 1, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Blanchard. Devoted mother of Dr. Ronald and Dr. Stephen Emerson. Adored grandmother of Lauren, Sarah, Blake and Abby. Dear sister of Franklin Gould. Services were held.

When Daniel Snyder, the owner of the Washington Redskins, filed a defamation lawsuit against the Washington City Paper in February, readers rushed to show their support - and the newspaper gave them an outlet. The City Paper set up a fund for reader donations meant to offset the litigation fees, collecting 600 donations totaling $28,000 in the first three weeks. But since the initial influx, the fund has received only 190 donations totaling just over $3,000. With donations slowing to a trickle even as the lawsuit drags on, the paper is left with a fund that matters more for what it has come to represent: tangible evidence of reader loyalty at a time when many newspapers are fighting steep readership declines. Though the fund has not sustained the flood of contributions, its ability to continue to attract donations at all demonstrates what Michael Schaffer, the newspaper's editor, called the ''sense of real, fierce ownership'' that City Paper's readers share.
The International House of Prayer, a Christian ministry founded by Mike Bickle, has rapidly blossomed into a movement.
Ms. Massey, born into a prominent acting family, played roles ranging from lonely spinsters to Margaret Thatcher.

Iowa’s ag-gag law failed to pass before summer recess last week: a good thing. The ridiculous proposition, which died along with similar ones in Minnesota, Florida and New York, would have made it illegal to videotape or photograph in the agricultural facilities that house almost all of our chickens and pigs.

Derek Jeter’s quest for 3,000 hits will be the subject of a one-hour documentary produced by Major League Baseball Productions in collaboration with HBO. It will be shown a few weeks after he reaches the landmark.

According to academic research, the likelihood of Mexicans coming to the United States has fallen to a historic low. Members of the Orozco family talk about their decisions to make the journey or not.

Instead, according to Mr. Frank, the league lost $340 million that year and has lost money every year during the current collective bargaining agreement.

In recent years, there has been a dramatic rise in the diagnosis of autism spectrum disorders (A.S.D.). The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that 730,000 people in the U.S. under age 21 have an A.S.D. It’s much harder to estimate the number of adults on the autism spectrum because only in recent decades has the condition been regularly diagnosed.

Five players — none of them forwards — have scored goals for the United States national team through two games at the Women’s World Cup in Germany. None were as spectacular as the 25-yard frozen rope that exploded off Heather O’Reilly’s right foot in a 3-0 win against Colombia on Saturday.

He said that the discomfort, just above his elbow, had subsided since Sunday, but that the head trainer, Gene Monahan, recommended he rest for at least another day.

For Givenchy haute couture, Riccardo Tisci presented ten stunning floor-length dresses of intricately seamed sheer tulle decorated with lace, pailettes, beads or fringe. The inspirations for the collection were clouds, angels and birds of paradise, the latter reduced to a splattering of pearls on white tulle. Making all this fragile romance signature Tisci were the industrial sporty zippers connecting sleeves to bodices and snaking boldly up backs. Here, a nude dress encrusted exclusively with hand-cut nude tulle pailettes.

Superbly romantic and resolutely urban, Karl Lagerfeld’s collection for Chanel haute couture was a celebration of nightfall and all its aesthetic offshoots: the shimmer of streetlights on cobblestones; the deep blues and purples that bow to black; the silent army of shadows. To make this clear he built a neon-lit model of the Place Vendome in the Grand Palais with Coco herself atop the obelisk. The clothes were sensational and womanly: jutting peplums, ankle grazing dresses and coats, gloves and boots to elongate every silhouette. Here, on Stella Tennant, a draped and tucked dress in black silk taffeta with a spine of crystal buttons.

Every Saturday, an empty lot on Williamsburg’s East River waterfront is transformed into Smorgasburg (a mash-up of smorgasbord and Williamsburg), an open-air food festival with more than 90 stands, over 50 of which sell stuff that’s ready to eat: chilled soups, grilled meats, Vietnamese salads, fresh juices, cold-brew coffee, ice cream in clever flavors, sesame noodles with a pedigree. In this week’s $25 and Under column, I call Smorgasburg “a fitting playground for a food-crazy generation that photographs what it eats.”

“I came here with AmeriCorps after the storm and never really left.” That’s the story of T. Cole Newton, a post-Katrina New Orleans transplant and the owner of 12 Mile Limit, a new bar in the Mid-City neighborhood that doubles as Newton’s own private cocktail laboratory. “This place has been a bar for 90 years,” he says, “and after the storm it was under two feet of water.” The people who used to own the place, he added, “threw a lot of wild parties here.” Cocktails are the specialty now, immensely creative drinks that celebrate the bartending history of New Orleans while embracing a new influx of ideas and characters. “Everyone becomes a New Orleanian, if you give them long enough,” Newton says. “Miss your flight, you’ll be here five years”.

Pat Neely, along with his brothers, opened his first barbecue restaurant in Memphis in 1988. Their chainlet in Tennessee has expanded since then, involving Pat’s wife, Gina. The couple became Food Network stars three years ago, so now they are poised to make a grand entrance in New York.

When I wrote about shaken baby syndrome last winter for the magazine, a Canadian pathologist named Evan Matshes was working on intriguing new research that hadn’t yet been published. Matshes’s paper is just out, in Academic Forensic Pathology, the journal of the National Association of Medical Examiners. It opens a new avenue of inquiry for this difficult and fraught diagnosis.

The folks who run the Pitchfork Music Festival — the influential three-day summer showcase of indie music in Chicago — have announced plans to stage a fall festival in Paris, headlined by the folk-rock group Bon Iver. The European festival is the latest milestone in Pitchfork’s remarkable rise as a force in the world of indie rock. Not only has this summer festival, now in its sixth year, become a must-go event for people interested in indie music, but the Web site of the same name has become one of the most prominent brands in online music journalism, widely seen as having the influence to pluck bands from obscurity and jump-start their careers.

Kenneth L. Lay, the former chief executive of Enron, died of a heart attack five years ago today. The stunning news came a month after a Houston jury convicted him of securities fraud and three months before his scheduled sentencing.

When Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, releases his campaign fund-raising filings this month, he is expected to report somewhere south of $20 million in contributions for the second quarter of the year — more than any of his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination, but somewhat less than might be expected for the candidate who has built the most robust fund-raising operation in the G.O.P. field.

I’m as over Anthony Weiner as any of the rest of you, but as I was catching up on The Nation this weekend, I saw JoAnn Wypijewski’s byline on an article about him and felt compelled to read it. JoAnn is one of my favorite journalists. She wrote a nice story for this magazine in 2004 about the disenchantment of black voters with the Democratic Party, but the one that I am most indebted to her for is the riveting account of Nushawn Williams, a young man who infected at least 13 women with H.I.V., which she wrote for Harper’s Magazine in 1998. (Not available free online, sorry. Worth buying a subscription to the magazine, trust me.). This is one of the finest magazine stories I’ve ever read, in part because it so beautifully and sensitively evokes the desperate straits of Jamestown, N.Y., my father’s hometown. Even without that personal connection, you’ll find it a deeply satisfying reading experience.

The Big Three will be reunited at the 2012 Masters, Augusta National Golf Club announced Tuesday. Gary Player will make his debut as an honorary starter next year at Augusta, joining Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus on the first tee to fire the opening shots in the popular Thursday ceremony that is the official opening of the tournament.

The Givenchy couture collection on Tuesday consisted of just 10 outfits, all in white or off-white, with minimal touches of gold, and each far from the everyday, as you expect of couture. The mostly long dresses or delicate tops and boleros were made in fragile tulle and lace embroidered with clusters of tiny knots, caviar beads and feathers. Some styles were bareback. Evening bags covered in superlong silk fringe and mounted on hidden stands made at least a few Americans say: “Oh, sweet. It’s Cousin Itt.”

With kimonos and geishas for inspiration, Giorgio Armani presented a beautiful collection for Privé today, one of his finest since launching the haute couture line 6 years ago. Black velvet trouser suits lined and outlined in Japanese floral silks were a perfect mash up of his/hers and east/west, and yet linear, untricksy, and exquisite. The evening dresses were columnar, often obi’d, and with a hint of plissé or a jacquard petticoat dusting the floor. Here, a big night stunner with sequined bodice, velvet skirt (cut narrow as trousers) and hints of vivid floral silk.

Giorgio Armani called his fall haute couture collection an homage to Japan. The designer who helped liberate women from boring executive wear and floppy bow ties confined his homage to traditional Japanese costumes and feminine floral patterns. There was no Goth Lolita moment or anything you might associate with Tokyo street fashion of the last 20 years. He stuck to a silhouette seemingly drawn from the kimono and obi (translated as stiff black patent leather bodices), and one or two models were slowed to a mincing gait. The prints and embroideries were lavish, but as Armani collections go, it was an island unto itself.

Canadians hoping to get their hands on news parody will soon need to look no further than Toronto. The Toronto Star, Canada’s largest newspaper, has teamed up with the Onion to distribute the satirical publication and its sister publication, the A.V. Club, beginning in the fall. With the agreement, Toronto will become the 14th city – and the first outside the United States – where the Onion is distributed.

The timeless Jack Purcell sneaker gets another update, this time in the hands of the über-cool retailer Aloha Rag. Launching today as part of Aloha Rag’s 20th anniversary, the Aloha Rag for Converse Jack Purcell Zip shoe remains true to Converse’s classic look but is given a bit of edginess. Featuring a calf-leather interior, embroidered skull-and-hearts logo, and zip tongue, the sneaker exudes the owner Tatsugo Yoda’s aesthetic, which combines punk style with nods to luxury. Only 150 pairs will be made available at Aloha Rag stores in New York and Honolulu and on its Web site.

10 P.M. (13); 11 P.M. (49) SWEETGRASS In 2001 Lawrence Allestad realized that not only was he the last of the traditional sheepherders in the American West, but he was also about to make his last drive into the Absaroka-Beartooth Wilderness north of Yellowstone in Montana, where his Norwegian-American family had fattened their herd on sweet summer grass for generations under a public grazing permit. In this ''POV'' presentation, Ilisa Barbash and Lucien Castaing-Taylor follow Mr. Allestad, his family and their hired hands as they drive 3,000 sheep, above, some 250 miles round trip through untamed country, encountering bad weather, grizzly bears and wolves and enduring the foolish ways of their charges. The documentary also chronicles the day-to-day rhythm of a century-old tradition coming to an end. Though much of the footage was shot that first summer, Ms. Barbash and Mr. Castaing-Taylor, anthropologists associated with Harvard University, ended up filming and working with the Allestads for several more years. The ranch and most of the sheep were sold in 2006. 9 P.M. (Fox) MASTERCHEF The 13 contestants must recreate the signature dish of Whitney Miller, who won the competition's first season.

ABU DHABI -- Abu Dhabi is talking caviar on a scale that would make czars blush. The emirate, already home to the world's first gold-bar automatic teller machine and a Christmas tree so chock-full of bling it earned a place in the Guinness Book of World Records, has now said it will be host to the world's largest indoor caviar farm. At full production, expected in 2015, the factory will churn out 35 tons of the prized fish eggs -- more than a quarter of current global production.

And the events in New York also have national repercussions: because several Democratic-dominated states have already legalized same-sex marriage, gay-rights advocates increasingly need Republican support if they are to change local laws elsewhere in the country.'' KETTEL--Edward J. Our family remembers how fortunate we were to have Edward J. Kettel as a husband, father and grandfather. Ed was born in Manhattan to Harold and Evelyn Kettel. He died peacefully at his home in Vero Beach on July 5, 2010. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II and was wounded in the Battle of the Bulge". He received a BA at St. Francis College and his Masters Degree at Columbia University. He and Janet Johnson were married in 1952. Ed worked as risk manager for several oil and chemical companies assessing their insurance needs. He served as Chairman of the Board for "Oil Insurance, Ltd." Hamilton, Bermuda. He retired from Chevron Corporation, San Francisco in 1998, as Assistant Treasurer. Ed is survived by his loving wife, devoted daughter, Dorothy Kneski, proud son, David Kettel, admiring granddaughters, Katherine Biancaniello and Patricia Kneski and precious great grandchildren Nick and Allie. Ed was known in business and in life for his integrity, generosity and marvelous sense of humor. Please remember Ed with a smile, a tear and a good deed for another.

Not long ago, the receptionist on the hospital floor where I work went on a family leave. Calm and with a wisecracking wit that she attributes to her New Jersey roots, she had worked at the hospital for years and knew better than anyone how to make things happen in the system. What doctors and nurses missed most when she was gone, though, was her ability to soothe emotional family members, intuit medical emergencies on the phone and cut off rude doctors -- then tirelessly repeat that good work dozens of times over the course of a day.

A Canadian zinc mining company and a Canadian nonprofit devoted to getting vitamins and minerals to children in poor countries recently joined forces to create a new partnership, the Zinc Alliance for Child Health. Zinc, the metal used to line the bars of traditional Paris bistros, is a mineral crucial in trace amounts to children's growth, brain development and immune system functions. It is found in red meat, beans and peanuts, but many malnourished children eat almost nothing but cornmeal, cassava or other starches.

INTERNATIONAL The Amsterdam Journal article on June 27 about a bill before the Dutch Parliament that would eliminate an exemption for Muslim and Jewish butchers from a law requiring animals to be stunned before they are slaughtered misstated the comments of Aaron S. Gross, a professor of religious studies at the University of San Diego. Dr. Gross said that some Jewish communities practice stunning after the ritual throat cutting required for kosher slaughter. He did not say that many liberal Jewish communities regularly practice stunning before slaughter. (Jewish authorities have generally required that animals be conscious when they are slaughtered.) The article also misstated the age of Marianne Thieme, the head of the animal rights party in the Netherlands that proposed the bill. She is 39, not 49.
