We dance, of course, for joy. But ballet, with its built-in dichotomy of gender roles (women alone rise on point, men alone may do the partnering), has a romantic tension that can seem poignant, even tragic. The full-length ''Swan Lake'' alternates between scenes of celebration (Acts I and III) and romantic tragedy (Acts II and IV), and its classicism can express the tragic dimension in ways that are the very stuff that ballet is made of and yet are singular to this ballet. It's not just romantic and noble, it's fateful and laden with doom. And the storm Tchaikovsky composed in Act IV becomes as cosmic as the one in Shakespeare's ''King Lear.'' Thanks to the movie ''Black Swan,'' the full-length ''Swan Lake'' is more in demand than ever. New York ballet companies have been cashing in: American Ballet Theater's annual week of ''Swan Lake'' at the Metropolitan Opera House just ended, and this year New York City Ballet arranged, first, one batch of ''Swan Lakes'' near the end of its winter season and has programmed another to start its fall season.

FISCHLER--Barbara Schwartz. We are heartbroken at the untimely death of our treasured friend Barbara. We have shared a life time of over 55 years knowing and loving her. There was not a kinder, more caring person on this earth. We will miss her terribly. Peggy and Andy Kahn Judy and Bob Snyder

REIS--Myron L. (Mike). Mike passed away on June 26th. He is survived by his wife Jane (nee Hines), his sister Edith Prostkoff, niece Barbara, nephews Melvin and Arthur, nine great and great-great-nieces and nephews as well as many dear and loving cousins and friends. Mike was a man of integrity, sensitivity and keen intelligence. As a member of the greatest generation, he gave up his Yeshiva College military deferment and joined the Army in 1944; he served in France and Germany. Although Mike did not pursue the rabbinate, he did use his natural gifts to become a master teacher whose career spanned more than 50 years. He was popular among his students from the enthusiastic teenagers at Seward Park High School to the equally enthusiastic fellow seniors at the UFT's Si Beagle Learning Center where, as his last hurrah, he taught "The Bible as Literature". There was a key to Mike's popularity. He cared about the other person. He was an attentive and empathic listener who tried to give the other person something: a laugh; a feeling of being appreciated; an idea to spark intellectual curiosity and untapped creativity. He was a joy to be with. Awhile ago Mike said that he wanted those who had known him to be able to say, "He was a most congenial gentleman."

FISCHLER--Barbara. Those of us, who knew you well, know that this terrible, tragic ending doesn't fit the life you've led. It cannot, and it will not define you. We will always remember you as an especially loyal, loving, sensible, and courageous woman, wife, and mother. Be at peace, my wonderful friend. I'll always love you. Carol

NEWMAN--Frederick Delano. The All Stars Project Board of Directors and staff are deeply saddened by the passing of the All Stars' extraordinary and much loved co-founder, Fred Newman, Ph.D. He was 76. Dr. Newman was born in the South Bronx, grew up in the shadow of the old Yankee Stadium (becoming a lifelong Yankees fan), and served in the U.S. Army in Korea. Upon his return he completed his undergraduate studies at City College and went on to earn his Ph.D. in analytic philosophy and foundations of mathematics from Stanford University in 1962, where he was mentored by the renowned analytic philosopher Donald Davidson. All who knew him will remember him as a fierce champion for giving the best, most sophisticated, most far-reaching tools of postmodern philosophy to ordinary people. He taught at several colleges and universities in the 1960s before dedicating himself to community organizing and the creation of numerous independent education, health, mental health, cultural and political projects in New York and nationally. Dr. Newman was a practicing therapist for more than 30 years and was the founder of a new humanistic psychology known as Social Therapy. The author of numerous books and articles on postmodern, Vygotskian, and performatory psychology, he and his colleagues worked to develop and popularize their breakthrough discoveries about human development. He co-founded the All Stars Project with Lenora Fulani, Ph.D. in 1981 to bring this new science of development to the lives of inner-city young people. He was the chief designer of the All Stars Project's performance-based development approach, which has transformed the lives of hundreds of thousands of poor, Black and Latino youth across the country and is providing a new theoretical and practical framework for eliminating poverty and underdevelopment. Dr. Newman was artistic director and playwright-in-residence of the All Stars' Castillo Theatre from 1989 until 2005. Often a lightning rod for controversy, Fred Newman was a relentless champion for a new style of progressivism. He was also a pioneer in the development of independent politics in the United States, starting in the 1970s, and had a major hand in the creation of the Independence Party of New York, playing a key role in the party's endorsement of Mayor Michael Bloomberg in 2001, 2005, and 2009. Despite serious illness, Dr. Newman was unflagging in his work. He will be deeply missed by the Board of Directors, staff, volunteers and countless young people and their families in our poor communities whose lives he and his work have touched. We extend our deepest condolences to Dr. Newman's life partners Gabrielle L. Kurlander, who so ably serves as the All Stars President and CEO, and Jacqueline S. Salit, and to his children Elizabeth and Donald and granddaughter, Jane. As we mourn the passing of our founder and friend Fred Newman, his legacy of radical humanism, his commitment to community, to development and to creating ensemble performances live on through the work of the All Stars Project.

When I was researching the history of the American soda fountain for my story this week, all roads led to Gregory Cohen, probably the country’s leading expert on the institution. Mr. Cohen, 43, grew up in Midwood in Brooklyn, frequenting Chodosh’s corner store and soda fountain (long closed, it was a fount of egg creams and memories that now has its own Facebook page. If you grew up drinking ginger yips, he knows that you are probably from Georgia, and on top of that he will mix you one at his soda fountain, Lofty Pursuits, in Tallahassee, Fla. (It’s a combination of ginger syrup, soda water, and vanilla ice cream.) His masterwork is a complete taxonomy of soda fountain drinks, compiled from a lifetime of interviews and research in antique manuals like “Ice Cream at the Soda Fountain,” a two-volume set published by the United States Department of Commerce soon after Prohibition went into effect. To learn the precise difference between a milkshake and a malted, an ice cream soda and a French soda, an ade and a fizz, follow the “flow chart.”

Why does exercise make us happy and calm? Almost everyone agrees that it generally does, a conclusion supported by research. A survey by Norwegian researchers published this month, for instance, found that those who engaged in any exercise, even a small amount, reported improved mental health compared with Norwegians who, despite the tempting nearness of mountains and fjords, never got out and exercised. A separate study, presented last month at the annual meeting of the American College of Sports Medicine, showed that six weeks of bicycle riding or weight training eased symptoms in women who’d received a diagnosis of anxiety disorder. The weight training was especially effective at reducing feelings of irritability, perhaps (and this is my own interpretation) because the women felt capable now of pounding whomever or whatever was irritating them.

STAVROU--Christopher, died peacefully at age 97 on June 26th in New York City, surrounded by his loving family. He was a linguist, lexicographer, and professor of Romance languages, ultimately at Upsala College. He managed the Park Lane Theater in Palisades Park, NJ for 3 decades, leaving to earn an MA at Columbia ('58) and a PhD at the University of Pennsylvania ('65). His wife, Virginia, nee Kapsimalis, died in 1980. He is survived by three children, Helen (married to Thomas F. Grannell), Christopher C. (Joanne Walsh), Alexandra (Christopher Wilson), and grandchildren Nikolaos, Timotheos, Alexander, Panagiotes, and Fiona. Friends may call from 2pm with service at 6:30pm, Sunday, July 10, at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave., New York City. Contributions may be sent to the Columbia University GSAS Annual Fund.

FRONT PAGE An article on April 12 about efforts by the Choctaw and Chickasaw tribes in southeastern Oklahoma to gain recognition as joint owners of local water supplies referred imprecisely to the location of Choctaw reservations in the United States. While the Choctaw in Oklahoma have no reservation, there are Choctaw reservations in Mississippi and Alabama; it is not the case that the Choctaw no longer have reservations. This correction was delayed when an email sent internally was overlooked at The Times.

Five players - none of them forwards - have scored goals for the United States national team through two games at the Women's World Cup in Germany. None were as spectacular as the 25-yard frozen rope that exploded off Heather O'Reilly's right foot in a 3-0 win against Colombia on Saturday. ''It was just pure instinct; those are the kind of shots you hit in training and everyone stands around and cheers as they sail high,'' O'Reilly said in a telephone interview from Wolfsburg, where the American team was preparing for Wednesday's final group match against Sweden. It will determine the winner of Group C.

Visiting Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-10pm.

HURWITZ--Milton, 91, considered the world's authority on super premium ice cream, passed away in Napa, CA. Part of the team that created Haagen Dazs in 1959, Mr. Hurwitz was responsible for flavor formulation including specification and sourcing of ingredients and for the design and engineering of all manufacturing facilities. As Senior Vice-President of Operations of Pillsbury Companies, Haagen-Dazs Division, he was responsible for all production, quality control, product formulations, ingredient sourcing and ingredient quality. He oversaw all manufacturing operations, including design and construction of new facilities, and modifications of existing facilities in North America, Europe and Asia. Following his career with Haagen-Dazs, he consulted globally including the creation of the Natuur ice cream line in Korea. He is survived by sons Alan and Eliot, and grandchildren Lake, Grace and Joy.

BANTA--Roger, 81. Died peacefully in Chicago on July 3rd after a long illness surrounded by family and friends. Survived by Florence, who he loved at first sight and for the next 61 years, daughters Barbara and Beverly, and five grandchildren. He will be missed by Glenn, Chester, Rod, Sebastian and all who admired his dignity, decency, courage and strength. A memorial service will be held on September 17, 2011 at the Church of the Holy Family, 200 Hayes Road, Chapel Hill, NC, 27517 at 1:00pm. The family requests expressions of sympathy be donated to Holy Family's memorial fund.

How do you satirize a man whose life has already turned into a perpetual comedy skit? That's for Comedy Central to figure out: on Tuesday that cable channel announced that Charlie Sheen, who has been an ex-star of ''Two and a Half Men'' for so long now that we can't remember why he's still famous, will be the subject-cum-victim of the next installment of its popular series of televised roasts. The ''Comedy Central Roast of Charlie Sheen,'' where celebrity guests and comedians will say to Mr. Sheen the things that they've already been saying behind his back and run catch phrases like ''tiger blood'' and ''winning!'' into the ground, will be filmed in Los Angeles on Sept. 10 and broadcast on Sept. 19, the channel said on Tuesday. Mr. Sheen, who follows in the footsteps of immortal roastees like Donald Trump, David Hasselhoff and Flavor Flav, said in a statement: ''You could say I've been providing kindling for this roast for a while. It's time to light it up. It's going to be epic.'' Comedy Central has already settled on a Twitter hashtag -- #SheenRoast -- for the event, but no celebrity roasters were immediately announced; we'll assume the ''Two and a Half Men'' co-creator Chuck Lorre won't be making a trip to the dais.

Visitors to the Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Canada who were hoping to catch Brian Bedford playing Oronte in ''The Misanthrope'' this summer will be disappointed. The actor, who has performed at the festival since the mid-1970s, has dropped out because of unspecified medical reasons, according a spokeswoman for the festival. Mr. Bedford, who was nominated for a Tony award this season for his portrayal of Lady Bracknell in ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' -- which came to Broadway after a production at Stratford in 2009 -- requires ''immediate medical attention,'' Des McAnuff, the artistic director said in a statement, although ''it is expected that he will make a full recovery.''

AGUA NEGRA, Mexico -- The extraordinary Mexican migration that delivered millions of illegal immigrants to the United States over the past 30 years has sputtered to a trickle, and research points to a surprising cause: unheralded changes in Mexico that have made staying home more attractive. A growing body of evidence suggests that a mix of developments -- expanding economic and educational opportunities, rising border crime and shrinking families -- are suppressing illegal traffic as much as economic slowdowns or immigrant crackdowns in the United States.

The seemingly routine occurrence of Willie Nelson's being found in possession of marijuana has stoked a small conflagration in a Texas county where a judge says she will not permit what she sees as the lenient punishment of this singer by an overly deferential prosecutor. Judge Becky Dean-Walker of Hudspeth County said on Tuesday morning that she would not accept a mailed-in plea agreement for Mr. Nelson that stemmed from a 2010 drug arrest there and that she believed that the county attorney, Kit Bramblett, was giving the singer preferential treatment because he is famous.

ZALAZNICK--Abner Jay. Age 86. On Independence Day, of heart disease and following a courageous struggle of several years against Alzheimer's disease. Abbey was a successful entrepreneur in a series of businesses spanning a 60-year career in women's clothing manufacturing and, later, securities brokerage and banking. He was deeply beloved by his family, friends, customers, partners, and staff for his warmth, empathy, enthusiasm, optimism, and love of life. Abbey was proud of his roots in Washington Heights, where his father and mother owned a candy store; of his service in the U.S. Navy during World War II; of his graduation from New York University, where he was a member of Alpha Epsilon Pi's Alpha Chapter. Abbey's deepest and most essential connections were to his family. He is survived by his wife and best friend of 59 years, Gloria (nee Kastan); his children Robert Zalaznick, Barbara (BZ) Schwartz, and Lauren Zalaznick; his sons-in-law Michael Schwartz and Phelim Dolan; and his daughter-in-law Kathy Miller; and by his grandchildren Alex, Caleb, Ada, Sally, Lucy, and Dale. Abbey is also survived by his sister, Annette Weinreb; and by his brother, Sheldon Zalaznick. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday, July 6 at 12:45pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at West 76th Street, New York City.

Iowa's ag-gag law failed to pass before summer recess last week: a good thing. The ridiculous proposition, which died along with similar ones in Minnesota, Florida and New York, would have made it illegal to videotape or photograph in the agricultural facilities that house almost all of our chickens and pigs. Sadly, a lack of idiocy is not the same thing as a presence of wisdom, and the demise of ag-gag won't give us a clearer view of food production. We need more visibility, not less. But when I visited Iowa in May, I appealed to producers of eggs, chickens, pork and even cooking oil to let me visit their facilities. In general, I was ignored, politely refused or told something like ''it's a bad week.'' (I made standing offers to return at any time; no one has taken me up on that.)

MILBURN--Frank. The Board, Musicians, and Staff of the New York Philharmonic mourn the passing, on July 2, 2011, of our former colleague, whose positions with the Philharmonic ranged from Director of Press to Music Administrator. Known for his encyclopedic knowledge, he was a trusted advisor to Leonard Bernstein, Pierre Boulez, and Zubin Mehta and a calming presence and devoted friend of the Orchestra for 32 years.

For years, Energy Transfer Equity refused to issue new stock, so firmly convinced in that plan that it even walked away from potential deals in the past. But the Williams Companies' $39-a-share rival bid for Southern Union forced the company to step up. And so on Tuesday, Energy Transfer announced a new $40-a-share bid that includes both cash and equity that is both higher and simpler.

FUND-RAISING LightSquared, the telecommunications venture backed by Harbinger Capital Partners, the hedge fund run by Philip Falcone, left, said on Tuesday that it had raised $265 million in new money to help build out its network, the latest step toward the start-up's ambition to be a wholesale provider of 4G wireless service. The company recently signed a roughly $15 billion deal with Sprint to share the cost of a network expansion, a move that would allow LightSquared to piggyback on the company's infrastructure while defraying the cost both would incur to revamp or create a new network alone. At midnight on Thursday, the N.B.A. locked out its players in what could be the start of a long labor dispute. Some observers, like ESPN's Michael Wilbon, believe the entire 2011-12 season could be threatened. Such a move would not be without precedent: the N.H.L. canceled its 2004-5 season. But the N.B.A.'s current financial condition is different than the N.H.L.'s in one important respect. Whereas there was almost no doubt that the N.H.L. was in fact losing money in advance of its lockout -- player salaries had mushroomed by more than 400 percent from 1994 to 2004, according to independent estimates -- the N.B.A.'s claims of financial hardship should be viewed more skeptically.

Sting has thrown his support behind striking oil workers in Kazakhstan, abruptly canceling his concert that was scheduled for July 4 in the capital, Astana, after he learned of a government crackdown on the strikers. ''Hunger strikes, imprisoned workers and tens of thousands on strike represents a virtual picket line which I have no intention of crossing,'' Sting, the 59-year-old British rocker, said in an online statement. Several thousand workers who work for a subsidiary of the state oil company went on strike May 26, complaining that their salaries had been cut and their lawyer imprisoned. The strike is only one conflict in a wave of labor unrest racking western Kazakhstan, crimping oil production in the former Soviet republic and angering the government of President Nursultan Nazarbayev, who rarely tolerates dissent.

With the quarterfinalists in Groups A and B all but mathematically settled, Tuesday's games were about pride and playoff seeding. 9 P.M. (Bio) CLIENT 9: THE RISE AND FALL OF ELIOT SPITZER (2010) Alex Gibney chronicles the prostitution scandal that forced Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York, above, to resign on March 12, 2008 -- a stumble, Mr. Spitzer tells the camera, that was caused by hubris. ''After being exposed, Mr. Spitzer told an aide, 'Welcome to a Greek tragedy,' '' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''More like a depressing lesson in power politics, though that's probably not what Mr. Gibney was shooting for. While its full title suggests that 'Client 9' is about the highs and lows in one powerful man's life, the movie is more rightly an anatomy of political gamesmanship at a high level.'' It is also the fruit of a cross-media partnership with Peter Elkind, the author of ''Rough Justice: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer,'' she said, noting that both the film and the book draw on some of the conspiracy theories that circulated after Mr. Spitzer's fall from grace. ''Those swayed by the argument in 'Client 9' that some of the rich and powerful whom Mr. Spitzer crusaded against might have exploited his stupidity should find all this enthralling,'' Ms. Dargis wrote. ''Others might just remember the hubris.'' 8 P.M. (Encore) FIELD OF DREAMS (1989) Kevin Costner plays Ray Kinsella, an Iowa farmer who builds a baseball diamond in his cornfield, where some ghostly men in old-time white uniforms show up to play. (Above, in a scene from the film, Mr. Costner, far left, Amy Madigan, Gaby Hoffmann and Dwier Brown.) One is Shoeless Joe Jackson, the greatest player on the Chicago White Sox team that threw the 1919 World Series. ''The short route that has led to this point in 'Field of Dreams' goes to the heart of a work so smartly written, so beautifully filmed, so perfectly acted, that it does the almost impossible trick of turning sentimentality into true emotion,'' Caryn James wrote in The New York Times. Ray Liotta makes Shoeless Joe ''ethereal and real at once, a relic of an earlier age much more than a ghost from the past,'' she added. And ''Mr. Costner does not make one false move.''

One of the more distressing euphemisms of soccer is ''the good result,'' a win, but more often a tie on the road. A point is a point, whether it be a 3-3 or 0-0 game. In Major League Soccer, where two coaches have already lost their jobs this season and making the playoffs is crucial, caution is accepted as the best strategy, especially on the road. With the M.L.S. season not yet at the midway point -- its all-star game against Manchester United coming on July 27 -- the 18 teams have combined for 20 scoreless draws, already a league record. The tally ticked over once more late Monday night when the Los Angeles Galaxy and the Seattle Sounders played the latest barren 90 minutes.

LOS ANGELES - Terry Collins was looking through a collection of statistical analyses on Tuesday, checking over certain matchups that his team would be facing over the next several games, when it hit him. Collins figured that the Mets are about to face seven All-Star pitchers in a row, starting with Clayton Kershaw of the Dodgers, who is 8-4 with a 3.23 earned run average, on Thursday. Afterward the Mets head north to San Francisco, where they will face Ryan Vogelsong of the Giants, who is 6-1 with a 6-1, 2.13 E.R.A.; Tim Lincecum, a two-time Cy Young Award winner; and Matt Cain, an All-Star in 2009, to close out the first half of the season.

After the cancellation of a new opera written by Lee Hall, the Tony Award-winning book writer and lyricist of ''Billy Elliot: The Musical,'' its author says that discrimination against gays led to the collapse of the project, while a school whose students would have taken part in the opera said it had withdrawn because of concerns about strong language. BBC News reported that Opera North, a British company based in Leeds, said it was canceling its production of ''Beached,'' a new work by Mr. Hall. The opera, which was to open later this month, tells of a single father's struggles to relax on a trip to the beach, and would have involved about 300 school children from the nearby Bay Primary School.

Devoted father of Charles of Woodcliff Lake, and dear brother of Marie Gouldsbury of Lakeland, FL. A World War II Army Veteran, he worked for The Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of NY, Inc., for over 45 years, retiring as Senior Vice-President and Corporate Secretary. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Friday 10am at St. Anthony's R.C. Church in Northvale, with interment to follow at Rockland Cemetery, Sparkill, NY. Visiting hours are Wednesday 7-9pm and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Anthony R. Pizzi Funeral Home, 120 Paris Ave., Northvale, NJ, 07647 (201-767-3050).
SCHWARTZ--Ann. Shelter Rock Tennis Club mourns her loss and extends sympathy to her family.

LONDON -- ''In my life, why do I give valuable time to people who don't care if I live or die?'' That's the refrain of ''Heaven Knows I'm Miserable Now,'' the 1984 Smiths song. Last month, in the middle of a run of Britten's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' at the English National Opera here, the countertenor Iestyn Davies wrote in a Twitter post that singing along with the song was ''the perfect warm-up for the role of Oberon.'' Reading the post at the time, it seemed unlikely that ''Dream'' -- a fairy tale, right? -- could have much in common with art rock of the 1980s.

Tiger Woods announced Tuesday on his Web site that he would not play in the British Open next week at Royal St. George's in Sandwich, England. Woods, 35, who will miss his second straight major championship because of injuries to his left leg, said he was following the advice of his doctors. ''As I stated at the AT&T National, I am only going to come back when I'm 100 percent ready,'' Woods said. ''I do not want to risk further injury. That's different for me, but I'm being smarter this time. I'm very disappointed and want to express my regrets to the British Open fans.''

Netflix said Tuesday that it would begin offering its streaming movie and TV service in Central America, South America and the Caribbean later this year, marking a major expansion of the company's geographic footprint. To date, Netflix has been available only in the United States and Canada. Investors have been looking for insight into the company's international growth plans.

Any observer walking around ground zero is surrounded by signs of progress: 1 World Trade Center has slowly but surely reached the 70th floor, its frame partly wrapped in glass; 4 World Trade Center stretches about 30 stories above its base; and the World Trade Center memorial looks ready to meet its Sept. 11 opening deadline. But about 20 feet below street level, similar progress is much harder to discern.

Private equity has broken venture capital's heart, and V.C. is not taking it well. The romance ended when Silver Lake, the private equity firm, agreed to sell Skype to Microsoft. Silver Lake is estimated to be pocketing more than $4 billion from the sale.

INTERNATIONAL An article on June 25 about a United Nations war crimes tribunal's conviction and sentencing of a former Rwandan government minister for her role in Rwanda's 1994 genocide misstated the number of women suspects in other United Nations-backed courts dealing with war crimes in Cambodia and Sierra Leone. It is one, not none. (She is Ieng Thirith, a former minister of social affairs under the Khmer Rouge regime, who has since gone on trial in the Cambodia court for her role in the genocide committed while the regime was in power from 1975 to 1979.)

Members of Albert Fritsch's family descended on Grand Central Terminal on Friday to visit a family heirloom (and 45-pound tchotchke) that is now the three-dimensional centerpiece of the exhibition ''The Once and Future Pennsylvania Station.'' What's that you say? Why is their heirloom-tchotchke-lawn ornament on display at the New York Transit Museum Gallery Annex?

With the quarterfinalists in Groups A and B all but mathematically settled, Tuesday's games were about pride and playoff seeding. England, which had not quite clinched a playoff spot, made sure of one with its best game of the tournament, a 2-0 victory over Japan, which had been impressive in previous rounds. New Zealand scored two late goals to earn its first point in three Women's World Cup appearances in a 2-2 tie with Mexico, but both teams are out.

It was the singular combination of Kleenex, peanut butter, a shower cap and earplugs that let Jane Scott thrive in her chosen field for nearly 40 years. Ms. Scott, who long before her retirement in 2002 was widely described as the world's oldest rock critic, never went to a concert without these essentials. Peanut butter gave her strength for a long night ahead. The shower cap, for rain-swept outdoor events, let her keep her preternaturally blond pageboy dry.

We often hear the phrase “the party of Lincoln” ascribed to the Republican Party. The image conjures a political movement dedicated to the abolition or restriction of slavery and to saving the Union. A less well-known feature of the party’s early years was its grounding in the evangelical Christianity of the Second Great Awakening.

Libyan rebels in the western Nafusah Mountains consolidated their gains in the village of Qawalish on Wednesday, but a rebel commander said that a rout of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces in Tripoli was highly unlikely.

No problem there, in the view of the court: for children who want to simulate brutal homicide, it’s protected free speech.

You might remember the car-dealer refrain, “Buy a car, get a check,” or those once-ubiquitous friends and family discounts. In the Pacific Northwest, General Motors is putting another twist on the incentive game, offering a year of free car insurance.

The private equity giant Carlyle Group is in talks to acquire Energy Capital Partners, a buyout shop focused on investments in power plants and gas pipelines, according to two people briefed on the talks.

The successful battle for gay marriage legislation in New York State involved the debut of an intriguing new way to apply social media to social change: Friendfactor.  While the precise role it played in the law’s passage is unclear, Friendfactor offered  a new model for online organizing that could become very useful in similar rights campaigns.

Three young girls zipped across the crowded dance floor, dresses fluttering, as a new D.J. took the stage. Nearby, two intricately coiffed hipsters in tight black cut-offs dipped their feet in a pool and waited to play table tennis.

Matt Mead of Wyoming to take the state’s wolves off the endangered species list and out from under federal protection. Wyoming has long agitated to have the wolves delisted so that hunting could be broadened under state regulations.

On Wednesday, Facebook introduceded two new features to its chat system. One allows people to chat in groups of three or more, rather than just two. The other, powered by a deal with Skype, adds video chat to the social network’s existing text chat system.

On Wednesday, as the sylphs of the front row prepared for Valentino Garavani and Natalia Vodianova’s climactic White Fairy Tale Love Ball, couture fashion week sang its swan song. Scorecard knows the day’s four acts offered more than the usual metaphor for the dichotomy of human desires through the formalized tensions of dance — but in the final reckoning, Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pier Paolo Piccioli’s ethereal creations at Valentino might just have edged Jean Paul Gaultier’s cygnes noirs out.

Via Philip Lane, a paper from the BIS (pdf) analyzing in detail four famous alleged cases of expansionary austerity. The bottom line: none of them show what they were supposed to show. Instead, all they show is that if you have austerity policies at the same time that other big expansionary things are happening, the economy may actually expand.

Bold stripes and prints may be all the rage right now (think Marni, Jil Sander, Prada), but Marimekko has been doing them for years — 60 to be exact, when the designer Armi Ratia and her husband, Viljo, took over a small Finnish textile company, Printex, and reinvented it with a graphic sensibility and an optimistic, almost utopian, outlook, not just as a global lifestyle brand but as a way of life. Jackie Kennedy wore a red Marimekko dress on the cover of Sports Illustrated in 1960; the Marimekko unisex Even Stripe T-shirt was a fixture on the rock and jazz festival circuit in the ’70s. Today, there is no shortage of new Marimekko material around thanks to collaborations with the likes of Crate and Barrel and Converse; and a free-standing Marimekko shop is scheduled to open in the Flatiron district in the fall. But true believers should get their clicker fingers in shape for July 13, when a trove of vintage Marimekko goes on sale on 1stdibs in conjunction with Katy Kane Vintage and Couture Clothing. The perfect, plain shirtdresses, matching jacket and shorts ensembles in unfussy floral prints and breezy striped shifts all came from a single owner, a Westchester-area homemaker, with very progressive taste. When she found a style she liked, she bought it in multiples. That orange and blue awning stripe shirt a little too bold for your taste? It’s also available in ivory and blue. What is more, many of the pieces were never worn and are still wrapped in tissue paper — and are as fresh and new as the day they were designed.

On the prowl recently for an Art Deco ring, I found myself at Erie Basin, a shop in Red Hook, Brooklyn, that sells surprisingly affordable antique jewelry. Their Deco diamonds were nice — they looked like they were mined from the top of the Chrysler Building — but what really grabbed me was a very old, and very peculiar, signet ring in rose gold. In this morning’s paper, there was just another reason why it’s tough not to like hockey players. A new paper from the IMF (pdf) puts another nail in the coffin of the doctrine of expansionary austerity. It basically shows that results purporting to show economic expansion following spending cuts and/or tax increases were based on a statistical illusion: an expanding economy can often lead to rising revenue and/or falling spending (e.g. because safety-net spending falls or because the government cuts back in an attempt to cool off inflationary pressures). And as a result, what the Alesina-Ardagna results capture is muddle by reverse causation.

I started TerraCycle almost a decade ago with a goal of making a profit by eliminating waste, and today our company offers free collection programs for more than 45 waste streams in the United States, along with similar programs in 15 other countries. The stylist Andrew Richardson is a prime example of what the British really mean when they use the word “smart” — having that rare ability to weather the most indecent (or mundane) of circumstances with a show of dignity and class. As the editor in chief of Richardson magazine, a slow labor counting only five issues in 15 years, Richardson has parlayed his interests in post-punk glamour, Helmut Newton’s heroic erotica and transgressive comic books like Frigidaire into a range of professional experience, including a role in Madonna’s 1992 elegy to moral hang-ups, the “Sex” book, to become an agent provocateur of the most polished kind.

It’s been more than a year and a half since Artie Lange, the ragged and randy comedian and sometime sidekick to Howard Stern, was last heard live on the radio, a streak that came to an end on Wednesday night. According to a live blog of the program posted by Punchline magazine, discussion of the sad circumstances that kept Mr. Lange off the airwaves was not abundant, though Mr. Lange said he’s been getting sober at a rehabilitation facility in West Palm Beach, Fla., and Mr. DiPaolo introduced him to the show by joking, “You might have seen him on ‘Intervention.'”

TWOMBLY--Cy. The passing of Cy Twombly is a loss not just for art, but for humanity. Cy was a truly great man, as well as a great painter, sculptor, draftsman and photographer. The power of his art lay not just in its extraordinary and haunting beauty, but in its ability to connect us to those archetypal forces which have driven mankind since classical times and before. Cy Twombly was a man of profound culture, able to draw at will on the poetry of every age, and on the world's literature and its history. His art was intimate, personal, touchingly humble, and true to himself. At the same time it was deeply humanist, grandly ambitious and always heroic. His passing is the end of an era. I extend my deepest sympathy to Cy's family and close friends. Larry Gagosian

How's Bernard L. Madoff doing in prison? Not so badly, despite his simmering moral anguish, he told Benjamin Weiser in an interview in the Times on Wednesday. He's working out and, for the first time in his life, devouring books, from junk novels to biographies. ''Now, I literally read two books a week,'' he said. ''I'm reading all the James Michener novels.'' The first observation to make about Mr. Madoff's situation is this: I know people who might envy his relative luxury. They'd be tempted to be tossed in jail, too, if it gave them more time to read. The second observation: James Michener? A few of Michener's early novels have sparks in them, but the whole lot? That's a bland, squirming torture fit for, well, a Bernard L. Madoff. It's a tenth circle of hell.

An article on June 27 about efforts to reduce traffic in European cities, using information from a transportation researcher, misstated the number of parking spaces for cars at Sihl City, a new shopping mall in Zurich, relative to the number at Atlantic Mall in Brooklyn. Sihl City has 850 spaces and Atlantic Mall has 625; Sihl City does not have half as many as Atlantic Mall. The article also misspelled, in some copies, the name of one of the busiest squares in Zurich where cars are banned on some blocks. It is Löwenplatz, not Lovenplatz.

Mitt Romney's presidential campaign reported on Wednesday that it had raised $18.25 million in the second quarter of this year, more than four times what his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination have raised. The totals for Mr. Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, far outpaced those of the former Minnesota governor, Tim Pawlenty, who reported raising $4.2 million in the quarter; Jon M. Huntsman Jr., the former governor of Utah who reported taking in $4.1 million, a substantial amount of which came from his own fortune; and Representative Ron Paul of Texas, who reported he had raised about $4 million.

For several administrations at least, the White House has declined to send letters of condolence to families of troops who committed suicide, even if those suicides occurred in combat zones. The policy was based on concerns within military circles that recognizing such deaths would encourage more suicides. But it infuriated many of those families, who felt they should have received the same kinds of letters sent to families of every service member killed in action.

VERSATILITY is the key to the line of fitness wear just introduced by threeASFOUR. The collection from this arty New York design threesome -- Adi Gil, Angela Donhauser and Gabriel Asfour -- consists of Lycra bodysuits with mesh cutout swirls, bandeaus and bikini bottoms with peekaboo mesh inserts and tricot leggings, also with mesh inserts, and all well suited for everyday wear. The pieces, in black, maroon, gray and kelly green, easily sub as sexy underpinnings and are intended for multipurpose use. Ms. Gil said she wears the Yin & Yang bodysuit shown here to the studio, to yoga and to the beach. ''People know us as avant-garde designers, which we love, but people want to look good and be comfortable for all of these activities,'' she said. ThreeASFOUR Lycra bodysuit, $222 at planetofstyle.com.

Some of the best featureless phones come from Nokia, including this $114 quad-band Nokia 2700. It's woefully lacking in bells and whistles, but all you have to do is land at your destination and buy a SIM card (or use one of MaxRoam's SIM packages for international travel) and you're ready to go. In 2007 Clark Little took up photography to save money on some seashore artwork his wife wanted. That has turned into a career as an award-winning photographer who was recently honored with the Oceans Photography Award from the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History in Washington, D.C. While not everyone has daily access to the crystal-clear Hawaiian waters where Mr. Little makes his art, he has tips to help anyone who wants to capture aquatic images-even if only at the local pool.

Q.I installed Internet Explorer 9 and now Flash videos won't play. Is there a way to fix this? A.Several issues may prevent the Adobe Flash Player plug-in from loading properly and playing videos and other content in Internet Explorer 9. Microsoft suggests making sure Flash did not get turned off accidentally; click the Tools button in Internet Explorer and choose Manage Add-ons. In the Show menu, select ''All add-ons'' and check that Adobe Flash is enabled.

Representative James P. Moran, a Virginia Democrat who is concerned about the propagation of ethnic museums on the National Mall in Washington, sees a possible antidote: a National Museum of the American People, dedicated, in the words of a resolution Mr. Moran plans to introduce in the House, to celebrating all immigrants, ''from the very first to the most recent.'' It ''may be idealistic,'' Mr. Moran said in a telephone interview, ''but I do think there's merit in the idea of showing all the American people how all the various threads of ethnicities and races and religions came together.'' He said he hoped that such a museum would reduce the pressure to create museums for different ethnic groups, like the National Museum of African American History and Culture, expected to open in 2015, and the proposed National Museum of the American Latino.

TWOMBLY--Cy. The Trustees and the Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with deep sorrow the passing of Cy Twombly. A dear friend of the Museum and an erudite and incomparable artist, Twombly created an utterly personal form of expression that defied categorization. He embraced everything from ancient mythology and epic poetry to the keenly observed forces of nature. Twombly was first shown at the Whitney in the 1967 painting annual and has subsequently been included in more than forty other exhibitions at the Museum. His mid-career retrospective, Cy Twombly: Paintings and Drawings 1954-1977 was organized by the Whitney in 1979. More recently he was the subject of the 2005 exhibition Cy Twombly: Fifty Years of Works on Paper at the Museum. The Whitney is proud to hold a number of his works in our permanent collection, some of which were generous gifts of the artist. He has left an irrepressible and inimitable mark on the history of American art and his indefatigable spirit will be sorely missed. We extend our condolences to his son Cyrus Alessandro Twombly, his two grandchildren, his longtime companion, Nicola Del Roscio, and to his many dear friends. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director Donna DeSalvo, Chief Curator and Deputy Director for Programs

LONDON -- Mitt Romney told reporters outside a lavish town house in the heart of the upscale Mayfair neighborhood on Wednesday evening that he was ''meeting a few friends'' while in London. The invitation from his campaign to attend an evening reception, on a street where a house was listed recently for $26 million, was more candid: ''Suggested contribution to Romney for President: $2,500 per person.'' The event's co-chairmen and co-chairwomen included the hedge fund billionaire Louis Bacon, the New York Jets owner Woody Johnson and two dozen others, mostly drawn from London's still-booming financial sector. The perfectly coiffed guests were deposited by a series of sleek limousines.

Remember the card game Uno? Now, Uno remembers you. To celebrate the 40th anniversary of the game, Mattel developed Uno Roboto, an interactive, computerized version that records the names of the players and their house rule.

Mozart's ''Così Fan Tutte'' at John Jay College. Verdi's ''Traviata'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. A Telemann opera at the Museo del Barrio. The outlines of New York City Opera's 2011-12 season emerged on Wednesday, gleaned from two sources at the company, after City Opera said it would make a formal announcement on Tuesday at the Guggenheim Museum.

Some three months after the authorities captured the so-called Holiday Bandit and charged him with robbing nine banks, the police said another prolific bank robber was on the loose in the city. On Wednesday, the Police Department said that investigators believed 15 different bank robberies and attempted robberies - 14 in Brooklyn and one in Queens - were likely the work of a single man. The robberies, mostly of Chase branches, occurred in two clusters - one from December to February, and another beginning mid-June. All the robberies were ''note jobs,'' meaning that the robber handed over a demand note but never brandished a weapon, the police said.

London SIX years ago today, on July 7, 2005, Islamist suicide bombers attacked London's transit system. They blew up three subway trains and a bus, killing 52 people and leaving a nation groping for answers.

Thinking Cap is about research, mostly in progress, that is outside the scholarly box. ''The Zoot Suit: The Enigmatic Career of an Extreme Style'' (University of Pennsylvania Press) by Kathy Peiss, a history professor at the University of Pennsylvania.

CHELL--Sam, on July 3, 2011 of Guttenberg, NJ. Husband of the late Rosalynd. Survived by a son, nieces and nephews. Services: Sunday, 11:30am at New Montefiore Cemetery.

The DealBook column on Tuesday, about new legislation affecting patents for business methods, omitted one aspect of the background of F. Scott Kieff, a professor at George Washington University Law School, who was quoted criticizing the bill. Mr. Kieff serves as a consultant to DataTreasury, a company whose patents could be affected by the bill and has been fighting it.

TWOMBLY--Cy. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague, who this past May had been awarded the Academy's Gold Medal for Painting. For half a century he challenged the art world's sense of itself by creating work original in conception and haunting in effect. His paintings both reflected and helped shape the American imagination.

TWOMBLY--Cy. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of Cy Twombly, and pay tribute to his indispensable place in the art of our time. Uniquely, Twombly marshalled his love of antiquity and the classical world to create an art of breathtaking modernity. He was a man of immense erudition, boundless curiosity, and unfailing kindness. MoMA was honored to present a retrospective exhibition of his work organized by Kirk Varnedoe in 1994. Twombly worked thoughtfully and generously with us this past year to enrich our holdings of his paintings and sculptures. We will deeply miss this great artist and extend our condolences to his son Alessandro and his family and to his dear friend and scholar of his work Nicola del Roscio. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

Though the producers of ''The Office'' may still wish they had Warren E. Buffett's stock portfolio, they have ultimately been won over by the business acumen (and possibly the alluring stare) of James Spader, naming him on Wednesday to a top position in the fictional hierarchy of that NBC workplace sitcom. Mr. Spader, a star of films like ''Secretary'' and ''Sex, Lies and Videotape,'' and a three-time Emmy Award-winner for ''The Practice'' and ''Boston Legal,'' was one of several guest stars on the May 19 season finale of ''The Office.'' In that episode, which also featured Jim Carrey, Will Arnett, Ricky Gervais and Mr. Buffett, the Berkshire Hathaway chief executive, Mr. Spader appeared as Robert California, an oddly charismatic executive vying to replace Michael Scott as the regional manager of Dunder Mifflin. (Steve Carell, who played the Michael Scott character, triggered this round of musical chairs when he departed ''The Office'' in April.)

Q.Is there any way to see a list of specific items billed to an iTunes Store account, no matter which computer they were bought on?A.The Account Information page for each iTunes Store account keeps a sales record. To get there quickly, open iTunes and click on the iTunes Store link on the left side of the window. On the right side of the Store window click the Account link, type in your name and password, and click the Account Info button. On the Account Information page, click the Purchase History button to see a list of all the songs, apps, videos and other items purchased from the iTunes Store. The list can be helpful if you suspect you may have unauthorized purchases (from sneaky family members or otherwise) on your credit-card bill. You can also use the Report a Problem button on the page to file a complaint about a file that isn't working properly.
KNOPF--Armand. A lifetime of partnership and friendship. We will always miss you. Sleep in peace. From, Claudia Buckner & Family

The Global Update report on Tuesday, about a program to get vitamins and minerals to children in poor countries, using information from Teck Resources, misstated the amount the company is donating toward zinc supplements for Senegalese children. It is $5.2 million, not $6.2 million.

WHO was Good King Henry? I first encountered the label in the Fedco Seeds catalog, as a common name for a plant in the genus Chenopodium. It's an edible perennial with shoots like asparagus and leaves like spinach. But before Good King Henry was a salad green, he was, ostensibly, something nobler: European royalty.

No bigger than a standard sheet of paper, Picasso's ''Tete de Femme (Head of a Woman)'' is hardly one of his largest works, but that apparently made it all the easier for a thief to steal it from a gallery in San Francisco on Tuesday. The San Francisco Chronicle reported that the work, a 1965 pencil drawing measuring 10 5/8 inches by 8 1/4 inches, was taken from the Weinstein Gallery in the city's Union Square neighborhood; the robbery was reported to the police at 11:41 a.m. and the work was being offered by the gallery for more than $200,000. The police told The Chronicle that witnesses described the thief as a white man, 6 feet tall and 30 to 35 years old, dressed in a dark jacket and dark pants, wearing dark glasses and loafers with no socks. He was said to have left in a waiting taxi cab after taking the drawing. Rowland Weinstein, the gallery's president who returned from a European honeymoon on Tuesday, told The Chronicle that while the stolen Picasso may be difficult for a thief to sell, he remained concerned for its safety. ''My greatest fear,'' he said, ''is that, with all this attention on it, the person will realize it's unsellable and will dispose of it in a less-than-proper manner.''

PRAGUE -- The other afternoon Adam Gebrian, a young Czech architect and critic, suggested we investigate this city's familiar candy-box center. I must have looked skeptical. ''Wait,'' Adam muttered, and we hopped a tram for Republic Square, where tourists snapped pictures of picturesque Powder Gate and ogled Municipal House, the Art Nouveau concert hall, tarted up after a restoration. Uninterested in the obvious monuments, Adam rounded the corner and stopped instead before Kotva, a department store from the Communist 1970s in brawny, Brutalist mode. Low slung and blocky, Kotva presented itself as a hulking iron-and-concrete hexagon with wraparound windows, set a little awkwardly back from the sidewalk. I pushed open the front door and stepped into a sunny, whitewashed interior, amid an orchard of orderly columns with capitals like spiky branches.

LOS ANGELES -- With four of his high-profile players injured, and his team floating between contention and resignation, General Manager Sandy Alderson declared Wednesday that the Mets' next 10 to 12 games were critical as he assesses whether to pursue trades. If the Mets survive that stretch of games with a realistic chance at a playoff spot, then the following 10 games leading to the July 31 nonwaiver trade deadline will be even more critical, he said.

George Lang, a restaurateur and cookbook writer who in the 1970s transformed Café des Artistes into one of New York's most romantic, beloved dining spots and in the 1990s helped restore the historic Budapest restaurant Gundel to its former glory, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86. His death was confirmed by his wife, Jenifer Harvey Lang, who said he had been treated for Alzheimer's disease.

SACRAMENTO -- On a recent balmy afternoon in Sacramento, 10-year-old Olivia Rios stared at her local swimming hole and fondly remembered a summer in the not-so-distant past when there wasn't a ''Pool Closed'' sign outside. ''We would go swim every single day,'' said Olivia, sitting behind by a wire fence near a ''Keep Out'' notice. ''And we'd get there the next day when it opens.''

What's the biggest surprise in the music industry this year? Music sales are actually up for the first time since 2004. According to Nielsen SoundScan's midyear sales report, which was released on Wednesday, 155.5 million albums were sold in the United States in the first six months of 2011, up 1 percent from the 153.9 million albums sold at the same time last year. When sales are measured by ''track equivalent albums,'' which factors in single-track downloads -- the rule of thumb is 10 songs to an album -- the number is 221.5 million, up 3.6 percent. These increases may be small, but the edge has been sustained for the last six weeks, and in a business that has been battered as badly and for so long as the music industry has, any good news is very good news.

MOCARSKI--Stephen Francis, on July 3, 2011. Graduated from Fordham University and Georgetown Law School. Beloved Husband of the late Imelda (nee) McAllister. Loving Father of Mary, Genevieve (John) Tierney, Andrew, Bernadette (John) Fleming, Imelda and the late Stephen. Devoted Grandfather of Catherine and Daniel Tierney; Carly, Luke and Jaclene Fleming. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10:45am, St. Andrew Avellino R.C. Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-10pm.

WITH Thug Mama, her newly opened boutique in Willliamsburg, JoAnn Berman brings a sense of old-school flavor to the neighborhood. In the early '90s, Ms. Berman was known for designing costumes for hip-hop stars like Salt-n-Pepa and A Tribe Called Quest, as well as a rapper then known as Puff Daddy. That was when she acquired her moniker. ''I was a gangster rapper designer of the '90s, and we loved bling-bling,'' she said. ''All the kids on the block called me Thug Mama.'' Ms. Berman, a native New Yorker who learned sustainability from punks in '70s London (''Punks work with what they have,'' she said), worked in animation for several years before opening a store in 2006 that mysteriously burned down and another, three years later, that didn't survive the recession. At the new shop, her one-of-a-kind summer dresses made from vibrant vintage materials are very much in tune with the print-happy season. She has also amassed an impressive collection of '60s platforms and vintage accessories. But it's the neon screen prints and splatter paint on everything from totes and T-shirts to furniture that make the shop a real trip.

Shutting down the Indian Point nuclear power plant would lead to significantly dirtier air and higher electric bills for New York City residents, according to a report commissioned by the city that is circulating among state officials in Albany. The report, a copy of which was obtained on Tuesday by The New York Times, concludes that, for the next several years, there probably will not be enough new power generated to replace the 2,000 megawatts produced by the two reactors at Indian Point. That shortfall could leave the city with a less reliable supply of electricity and a greater risk of brownouts, the report finds.

UNITED NATIONS -- Spurred by the recent upheaval in the Arab world, diplomats from Israel and Turkey were in talks on Wednesday aimed at mending relations that were badly fractured by the deadly Israeli raid on a Turkish flotilla to Gaza last year, diplomats said. The diplomatic effort came as officials were anticipating the release of a contentious United Nations report on the raid, in which Israeli commandos killed nine Turks, one of whom was also an American citizen, aboard a Turkish-sponsored flotilla seeking to break Israel's embargo of Gaza in May 2010. The commandos boarded the largest of the ships, the Mavi Marmara, in international waters, and, facing violent resistance from dozens of activists, used force to take control of the vessel.

STEICHEN--Felicien M. New York Medical College mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, Felicien M. Steichen, M.D., professor emeritus of surgery. Dr. Steichen was a recognized pioneer in the use of mechanical suturing devices and enjoyed a stellar career of international prominence in the field of minimally invasive surgical techniques. He served as chief of the College's Institute for Minimally Invasive Surgery, which he helped found for the treatment of patients and the training of surgeons in laparoscopic techniques. We extend our condolences to his wife Michele and his children and grandchildren. Ralph A. O'Connell, M.D. Provost and Dean School of Medicine John A. Savino, M.D. Felicien M. Steichen Chair of Surgery

SWEDEN surprised the UNITED STATES, 2-1, winning their group and sending the Americans into a difficult quarterfinal against Brazil. NORTH KOREA and COLOMBIA, both already eliminated, played to a 0-0 tie. In the early games, AUSTRALIA, which needed only a tie to advance to the quarterfinals, went one better, coming from behind to beat NORWAY, 2-1. BRAZIL, already through to the next round, routed EQUATORIAL GUINEA, 3-0, with Christiane scoring twice.

LANG--George, on July 5, 2011. Beloved husband of Jenifer. Loving father of Simon, Georgina, Brian and the late Andrea. In lieu of flowers, mourners who are so inclined may send contributions to the Fales Library at New York University, where Mr. Lang's prodigious collection of culinary books now resides. Mail contributions to Marvin Taylor, in honor of the George Lang collection, Director, Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University, 70 Washington Square South, New York, NY 10012. A memorial service will be held on Monday, July 11, 4pm at The Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

Is New York City's weather destroying a 3,500-year-old Egyptian obelisk? That's a question the city's Department of Parks and Recreation is setting out to answer this summer as it conducts a ''weathering study'' of Cleopatra's Needle, which was given to the United States government by Egypt as a gift to commemorate the opening of the Suez Canal. The obelisk has stood in Central Park since 1881.

8 P.M. (TCM) RACE AND HOLLYWOOD: ARAB IMAGES IN FILM Robert Osborne and Jack G. Shaheen, the author of ''Reel Bad Arabs: How Hollywood Vilifies a People,'' host this monthlong series focusing on depictions of Arabs on the screen. This installment begins with ''Adventure in Iraq'' (1943), in which an airplane carrying an estranged American couple (John Loder and Ruth Ford) during World War II is forced to land in the Iraqi desert, where its passengers are captured by a sect of Devil worshipers who plan to sacrifice them in exchange for three brothers about to be executed for espionage by the British. The evening continues with ''Action in Arabia'' (1944), in which an American newspaper correspondent (George Sanders) tangles with Nazis in Damascus, at 9:30; ''Sirocco'' (1951), starring Humphrey Bogart as a mysterious American who gets mixed up with gunrunners in Syria, at 11; ''Trunk to Cairo'' (1966), in which a secret agent (Audie Murphy) takes on neo-Nazis running a munitions factory in Egypt, at 1 a.m.; and ''Sinbad the Sailor'' (1947), with Douglas Fairbanks Jr. (above) as the Arabian Nights hero seeking the lost treasure of Alexander the Great, at 3:30. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) THE GREAT DINOSAUR ESCAPE Using recent scientific research and computer-generated effects, this two-hour special follows a herd of dinosaurs -- in particular, a young and vulnerable Edmontosaurus named Scar -- as it migrates from summering grounds at the North Pole across 1,000 miles of hostile terrain to escape the winter. ''Jurassic C.S.I.: In Living Color,'' at 10, watches as the ''dino detective'' Phil Manning uses highly focused X-ray beams to search for traces of color pigments in fossils like that of the Archaeopteryx, a magpie-size bird with teeth.

The folks who run the Pitchfork Music Festival -- the influential three-day summer showcase of indie music in Chicago -- have announced plans to stage a fall festival in Paris, headlined by the folk-rock group Bon Iver. The European festival is the latest milestone in Pitchfork's remarkable rise as a force in the world of indie rock. Not only has this summer festival, now in its sixth year, become a must-go event for people interested in indie music, but the Web site of the same name has become one of the most prominent brands in online music journalism, widely seen as having the influence to pluck bands from obscurity and jump-start their careers. Pitchfork has collaborated with festival organizers abroad in the past, taking part in the Primevera Sound Festival in Barcelona and the All Tomorrow's Parties event England. Still, the two-day event to be held in Paris's Parc de la Villette marks the first full-fledged foreign venture for the Chicago festival organizers, according to an announcement on the Pitchfork Web site.

LONDON - Close to the site of the new Olympic stadium here, another much taller landmark designed for next year's Summer Games is growing into the sky: a giant cherry-red steel sculpture by the Indian-born artist Anish Kapoor. Once completed, the sculpture is to reach 115 meters, or 377 feet. That would make it taller than the Statue of Liberty and the tallest sculpture in Britain. From a viewing platform, it is to offer breathtaking views across London and the Olympic park.
A picture credit on Wednesday with an obituary about the rock critic Jane Scott misspelled the surname of the photographer. He is Richard T. Conway, not Coway.

BANTA--Roger, 81. Died peacefully in Chicago on July 3rd after a long illness surrounded by family and friends. Retired general manager of Charmer Industries (now Empire Merchants) in Astoria and Smithtown. 1948/1949 New York state regional champion in the 220 and 100-yard dash. Survived by Florence, who he loved at first sight and for the next 61 years, daughters Barbara and Beverly, and five grandchildren. He will be missed by Glenn, Chester, Rod, Sebastian and all who admired his dignity, decency, courage and strength. A memorial service will be held on September 17, 2011 at the Church of the Holy Family, 200 Hayes Road, Chapel Hill, NC, 27517 at 1:00pm. The family requests expressions of sympathy be donated to Holy Family's memorial fund.

Mika Myllyla, a Finnish Olympic gold medalist and winner of three world championships in cross-country skiing whose career crashed after he was caught up in a doping scandal in 2001, was found dead on Tuesday in his apartment in Kokkola, Finland. He was 41. The police did not provide details but said no crime was involved, the Finnish national broadcasting company, YLE, reported.

A PACKET of 250 purslane seeds costs about $3.60 from Seeds of Change, (888) 762-7333 or seedsofchange.com. Not a bad price, though it may be 249 purslane seeds too many. Like a lot of the ''sallet'' greens that the colonists brought with them to the New World, purslane (Portulaca oleracea) can colonize a yard all on its own. A single specimen can produce a million seeds. Let a purslane patch go, said Clarissa Dillon, a food and garden historian, and ''it's the plant that eats your driveway.''

8:33 p.m. | Updated CNN on Wednesday canceled Eliot Spitzer's 8 p.m. political talk show, ''In the Arena,'' after only nine months amid a broader shake-up that shifts Anderson Cooper's 10 p.m. nightly newscast into Mr. Spitzer's time slot. Mr. Spitzer will sign off on Wednesday night, a CNN spokeswoman said. His show will remain in the time slot until August 5.

BLANN--Carol, died on July 2 after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. Carol, proud mother of Emily and Molly, and wife of 40 years to Jim, lived in both Edgemont and Manhattan. Carol had a long career in psychotherapy and was involved in many community leadership roles in Edgemont. Carol continued to be active professionally throughout her battle with Parkinson's. Eventually, Carol had to give up most of her psychotherapy practice, but was able to rekindle her love of photography and found ways to continue relationships with people, which she cherished. Carol was born in Cincinnati on October 7, 1948 and grew up in Ohio and Michigan. She graduated from Miami University and earned a MSW from New York University as the springboard to her psychotherapy practice. Carol and her husband Jim were married in 1971 and later had two daughters. Carol is survived by her husband, Jim, and her daughters, Emily and Molly. She is also survived by her mother Kathleen Shapiro, siblings Trish Weisman, Marnie Foster Marks, Dan Michaels, and Amy Shapiro. Carol is preceded in her death by her father, Miller Weisman, and her brother Steve Weisman. Carol's strong presence is sorely missed by her family as well as her many long-time friends gained through her community, profession, and photography. Donations should be considered to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, the Michael J Fox Foundation, and the International Center of Photography. There will be a memorial service for friends and family to be announced at a later date.

JOINING the roster of leather staples like the motorcycle jacket and pencil skirt is a new basic: the luxe leather T-shirt. That it showed up in shops for spring -- from The Row (in eggshell white); in the Rodarte collection for Opening Ceremony -- proves its staying power regardless of the season. Looking ahead to fall, a soft leather tee makes a perfect layering piece. In the Yves Saint Laurent prefall collection, a golden brown leather version was shown atop a long-sleeve print shirt with a leather skirt in the same rich tone. Or keep it simple, as you would with any tee, and wear it, as in this look from the prefall Céline collection (left), with a print pencil skirt. Supple skins come at a price, and if the cost of the Céline top ($2,650) makes you blanch, we've found others that won't break the bank.

The Books of The Times review on Friday, about ''The Swinger,'' a novel about a golfer by Michael Bamberger and Alan Shipnuck, misidentified the authors' jobs at Sports Illustrated. They are senior writers, not senior editors.

For one unlucky rabbit in each performance of the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of ''As You Like It,'' it was the most unkindest cut of all: an already dead bunny was skinned and decapitated during a scene in that Shakespeare comedy about cross-dressing, mistaken identity and the contrasts between courtly and provincial life. And while all the world's a stage, the stage will not serve as a butcher's block when the play is presented in New York: the Royal Shakespeare Company says it has excised the rabbit-skinning scene for its Lincoln Center Festival residency. The company said in a statement that it ''has decided to drop the use of rabbits for its performances of 'As You Like It' in New York,'' which are to begin on Wednesday at the Park Avenue Armory.
Steven J. Golub, a longtime veteran of Lazard who briefly served as interim chief executive of the investment bank, has retired, a spokeswoman confirmed on Friday.
A poetic look at the top news stories of the week:
The Times’s Tyler Kepner takes a look at what many Yankee fans call “The Jeter Era.”
The business of summer camp has grown tougher because of the economy, but parents also expect more.
In recent years, fallout from footage by operatives with video cameras has changed the course of elections.
Libyans gathered for Friday prayers in Zintan and Benghazi.
Michael D. Shear reports from New Hampshire on Aaron Fielding, whose full time job is is to get close to Republicans with his video camera.
Betty Ford, the outspoken and much-admired wife of President Gerald R. Ford, has died at 93.
The weather kept the Yankees off the field and fans outside the stadium gates.
Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Matt Lewis of The Daily Caller debate Obama's use of social media.
On VH1’s “Famous Food,” seven contestants, including Danielle Staub and Heidi Montag, vie for a chance to have an ownership share in a Sunset Strip restaurant.

SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — We first met Caleb Madison in the spring of 2008, when at the age of 15 years and 3 months, he became the youngest constructor published during Will Shortz’s tenure at the time (Across Lite, Solution). Time marches on however, and while that torch has been passed to other youngsters, Mr. Madison has now graduated from high school and is on his way to an Ivy League university in the fall. Let’s all take a moment to pat ourselves on the backs and delude ourselves into thinking that doing his puzzles motivated him to become the fine, young, upstanding, educated gentleman he is today. We might as well take at least partial credit for it.
July 8, 2011 - Arrests deepen the crisis swirling around Rupert Murdoch's media empire in Britain.
At least a few big companies in New York -- Corning, I.B.M. and Raytheon -- are now requiring their gay employees to marry if they want health coverage for their same-sex partners.

As much as Derek Jeter’s pursuit of 3,000 hits has been chronicled around the clock, the moment he finally does reach the milestone — in the age of high definition and smartphones — will be even more inescapable.
After months of bleak unemployment reports, bad news isn’t very surprising. But this bad?

Say what you will about Michele Bachmann, she’s not media-shy. Nor is she particularly hesitant about stating her beliefs. And judging from the level of coverage she has received since announcing her candidacy for president on the Republican ticket, the media is quite interested in her every public move.
The United States national team’s first game since the Gold Cup will be a doozy: a rematch of the Gold Cup final with Mexico on Aug. 10 at Lincoln Financial Field in Philadelphia.
More Photographs
A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.
Dawn Zimniak and Jibril Jackson recount how love at first sight turned into long-lasting chemistry, two dogs, and a wedding proposal.

On Friday at 10 p.m. Eastern, Bob Costas and Al Michaels will call the Mets-San Francisco Giants game on the MLB Network. They will announce the first three and the eighth and ninth innings on the network. To accommodate fans in the New York and San Francisco markets, where the MLB broadcast will be blacked out, Costas and Michaels will head to the Mets’ SNY booth for the fourth and fifth innings and SNY’s Gary Cohen and Ron Darling will shift to the MLB booth. When Costas and Michaels work in the Giants’ CSN Bay Area booth for the sixth and seventh innings, the Giants announcers Mike Krukow and Duane Kuiper will replace them on MLB. Although this is billed as the first game Costas and Michaels have called together, they were boothmates in the movie “BASEketball,” a 1998 comedy. It will, indeed, be the first baseball game for Michaels since 1995, when he was at ABC Sports.
All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.BalenciagaNew fall 2011 ad campaign will make its debut next week on a brand-new Web site.

Hackers who have claimed responsibility for a spate of recent break-ins said on Friday that they had infiltrated the networkof IRC Federal, an engineering contractor that works for federal agencies including the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and stole internal documents from its database and e-mail system.

In this Sunday’s Metropolitan cover story, I chronicle the effort by the educational entrepreneur Chris Whittle to create Avenues, a new for-profit private school in Manhattan’s Chelsea neighborhood. An internationally focused school with a bilingual bent, it eventually plans to enroll about 1600 students in nursery through 12th grades.
Graphic stripes are the stars of summer fashion.

Marc Andreessen, one of Silicon Valley’s biggest venture capitalists, and Warren E. Buffett, of Berkshire Hathaway, have two things in common: They are both worth huge amounts of money, with billions of dollars at their investing disposal, and they both try to invest in companies that are undervalued.

Few New Yorkers seemed to appreciate this week’s blazing sunshine like Johan Ernst Nilson. A sunburned Swedish explorer, on break from his journey from the North to the South Pole, Mr. Nilson leaned back in his chair in the entrance of the Standard Hotel on Tuesday morning, sipped a soda and relished the warmth. It’s not just been a long winter: it’s been a journey filled with chases by bears and death-defying dips in icy Arctic waters.

In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2012 Hyundai Elantra. The sedan wears the brand’s so-called fluidic sculpture design theme well, he writes, but a body crease here or a teardrop motif there might represent a touch too much for some shoppers:

If your own cramped, un-air-conditioned apartment isn’t stifling enough for you right about now, pay a visit to “The House Without the Door,” a new group show at David Zwirner Gallery in Chelsea. Some of the homes represented, like Philip-Lorca diCorcia’s charred suburban pile, might very well be broken beyond repair. Gregor Schneider’s “Dead House,” on the other hand, has been so compulsively overconstructed, there is no apparent way out or in. Mona Hatoum’s “Home” is literally a charged place, where ordinary household objects carry the threat of electric shock. And the apartment of Thomas Ruff’s “Interieur 9B,” shown above, looks like its tenant might have been vacated feet first. All of the artists are somehow navigating that fraught psychological turf between house and home, according to Zwirner’s Kristine Bell, who put together the show and who shares her own “inescapable container” with two boys under the age of 6.

Daniel Peddle is having a busy summer. Fresh off a plane from Paris, where he was working on casting for men’s fashion shows, he just closed a solo show of paintings at NP Contemporary Art Center in New York. Originally from Winston-Salem, N.C., and now based in the West Village, Peddle came to our fair city in 1992 to study film at N.Y.U. While he was trying to scrape by in the grime that was the early 1990s, his keen eye for beauty led him to the unlikely grind that is street casting. Today, his eponymous company scouts talent for the likes of Phillip Lim, M.A.C. cosmetics, Givenchy and many others. In the meantime, he’s working on his third feature documentary, and his second, “Trail Angels,” about the altruistic souls who tend to the hikers on the six-month journey down the Appalachian Trail, will be make its debut on the Documentary Channel tomorrow night.

Mathilde Laurent, Cartier’s chic head perfumer, had men on her mind while creating Baiser Volé, the house’s latest women’s scent. “I noticed that when asked about their favorite flower, many men said it was the lily,” she says. “Of course women can choose perfume for themselves, but what’s wrong with putting the man in the equation?” Baiser Volé bucks the trend for “sickly” or “sugary” florals, and it took Laurent two years to capture the fresh yet heady essence of a bouquet of just-cut lilies. The bottle, which was inspired by the company’s famously elegant cigarette lighters, is as come-hither as the pale pink juice it contains, lending a whole new meaning to the term “smoking.” It’s $100 for 1.6 ounces at Nordstrom stores.

In 1998, when the hip-hop luminaries A Tribe Called Quest announced that their show at New York’s famous Tramps nightclub would be their last, fans and fellow musicians everywhere were devastated. There was no curtain call, no bows taken; it just ended. The Manhattan-born actor Michael Rapaport (“Zebrahead,” “Higher Learning”), a son of the general manager to WKTU-FM (Disco 92) and then just a fan in the crowd (he flew in from Mexico for the show), might have been the most crushed, saying now it felt as if his parents were getting divorced. Others in the loyal crowd included the actor Leonardo DiCaprio and the rapper Busta Rhymes, whom many consider the fifth member of the Tribe. Eight years later, at Tribe’s reunion show at the Wiltern Theater in Los Angeles, Rapaport applauded his favorite group backstage. “Someone needs to make a documentary about you guys,” he told Tribe’s front man, Q-Tip, whom he had met only briefly before. The response? “Go ahead, do it.”

Until the studios figure out a way to make a movie version of Pong, the primordial video game that features two blocks knocking a ball of pixels around the screen, it seems Hollywood has found the most, shall we say, minimalist source material for a game-to-film adaptation: Space Invaders, the quarter-munching, index-finger-jamming classic that first touched down in arcades in 1978, is being prepared for the big screen, The Hollywood Reporter said. Lorenzo di Bonaventura, a producer of the “Transformers” and “G. I. Joe” movie franchises, and Gigi Pritzker of Odd Lot Entertainment have optioned the film rights to Space Invaders, and boy do they have their work cut out for them: whereas even a Pac-Man movie would give you a built-in roster of dramatis personae (Jack Black as the pellet-gobbling hero, anyone?), Space Invaders features such characters as the alien that flaps its wings up and down and the boxlike tank that slides from side to side at the bottom of the screen. The producers did not immediately announce a creative team for the movie, nor how much money they will spend to recreate the level where the Space Invaders turn invisible.

When I was young and living just outside Paris, I became obsessed with the odd, exquisite and endangered, which included the haute couture ateliers that I’d only read about in books. I named a stuffed frog Gripoix, probably because it sounded somehow a bit like crapaud, the French word for toad, but more elegant. There was the chance that the toy would turn into a prince, and in that case, I would need to go to Chanel to have a dress made for our fairy-tale wedding. This season was my first at couture as an adult — one married to a man, not an amphibian — with a mature perspective on whimsy. Everything is so fast now, but the atelier creations are the sartorial version of slow food. The work is green and ethical: there is no waste, as each piece is custom-made with a client in mind (no discount racks or fast fashion to fill landfills). Every artisan is properly treated. Can we say the same of certain mass-manufactured goods?
