8 P.M. (TCM) THE OLD CORRAL (1936) Gene Autry, right, was a man of many talents who wore many hats, most famously a Stetson, during his 91 years. He is the only entertainer to have been given five stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame -- one each for radio, recordings, film, television and live theatrical performance. He wrote and sang the holiday tune ''Here Comes Santa Claus,'' among others. From 1961 to 1997 he owned the Angels, the Major League Baseball team in Anaheim, Calif., that has gone through a few name changes through the years, and he served as the vice president of the American League from 1983 until his death in 1998. Here, Autry basks in the Turner Classic Movies spotlight of a monthlong celebration of singing cowboys. First up, he plays a sheriff who helps a blues singer (Hope Manning) after she witnesses the murder of a nightclub owner. At 9, Autry portrays a border inspector keeping livestock with hoof-and-mouth disease from entering the United States in ''Home on the Prairie.'' At 10:15, he plays a rancher who finds copper and is framed in a jailbreak with Tom Bennett (Edward Norris) in ''Back in the Saddle.'' At 11:45, he tries to stop a ring of lottery-ticket counterfeiters in ''Texans Never Cry.'' And at 1 a.m., he hunts for the payroll stolen from the Army in ''Wagon Team.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) FLASHPOINT Ed Lane (Hugh Dillon) goes to the hospital after being shot, and the Strategic Response Unit's Team One uncovers a trail of opium imported from Afghanistan while tracking down the shooter. Victor Garber reprises his guest role as the military psychologist who puts the team members through their paces.

Darwin D. Martin, a soap-factory executive in Buffalo, was a serial client of Frank Lloyd Wright. Between 1903 and 1928, the charismatic architect designed a half-dozen buildings for Martin's family, including a carriage house and a mausoleum. Wright referred to his shy, bookish patron as ''my best friend,'' borrowed $70,000 from him over the years and never repaid the loans. By the 1930s the Martins were largely broke, and they had to abandon their sprawling main house on a leafy side street. About half of its 394 windows, with stained-glass squares and polygons in iridescent golds and greens, were removed; they have been scattered across private collections and museums or are presumed lost.

Countless musical groups have been built on a complementary pair: John Lennon and Paul McCartney, say, or Mick Jagger and Keith Richards. A Tribe Called Quest, the influential 1990s hip-hop ensemble, had Q-Tip and Phife Dawg. With ''Beats, Rhymes & Life,'' the actor Michael Rapaport (Brad Pitt's roommate in ''True Romance''), in his feature directorial debut, does an admirable job recounting the group's formation and dissecting its dissolution. Q-Tip and Phife were childhood friends who grew up in Queens following pioneers of East Coast rap like Run-D.M.C. and LL Cool J. What they brought was a smoother, more sophisticated flow incorporating jazz influences. Part of the Native Tongues, a collective comprising De La Soul and the Jungle Brothers, among others, A Tribe Called Quest struck gold with albums like ''The Low End Theory'' (1991) and hits like ''Bonita Applebum'' and ''Check the Rhime.'' The likes of the Beastie Boys and Questlove of the Roots testify to its place in the pantheon.

Robert M. Morgenthau, the former Manhattan district attorney, released a statement on Thursday defending how his successor, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., and his office had handled the case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn. ''For decades we instructed line prosecutors at the Manhattan D.A.'s office to seek justice over everything else, to investigate, to find the truth, and to proceed without fear or favor,'' Mr. Morgenthau wrote. ''The most important attribute I looked for in hiring junior prosecutors was a strong ethical sense. The recent actions from the district attorney's office show me that these attributes are alive and well at One Hogan Place.''

TWOMBLY--Cy. The passing of Cy Twombly is a loss not just for art, but for humanity. Cy was a truly great man, as well as a great painter, sculptor, draftsman and photographer. The power of his art lay not just in its extraordinary and haunting beauty, but in its ability to connect us to those archetypal forces which have driven mankind since classical times and before. Cy Twombly was a man of profound culture, able to draw at will on the poetry of every age, and on the world's literature and its history. His art was intimate, personal, touchingly humble, and true to himself. At the same time it was deeply humanist, grandly ambitious and always heroic. His passing is the end of an era. I extend my deepest sympathy to Cy's family and close friends. Larry Gagosian

For decades, David I. Weprin has played the role of good Democratic soldier, the scion of a vaunted Queens political family who repeatedly won elections as a city councilman and currently as a state assemblyman. Now, he has been asked to perform what many government analysts say could be the ultimate political sacrifice: running for a Congressional seat that may soon be eliminated.

WELLNER--Kenneth, Age 90, a man who well lived several lives, and inspired many others, died unexpectedly on July 2 after a determined battle with multiple medical afflictions. A self-proclaimed Yankee Doodle Dandy, Ken Wellner passionately loved this country, its freedoms and its opportunities. The son of the late Emil and Freida Wellner, Ken graduated from Stuyvesant High School and attended NYU before joining the Army in December, 1941, serving in the CBI, achieving the rank of Major and receiving the Bronze Star Medal. He considered his military service the greatest privilege. In civilian life he joined Wellner Motors in NYC, the family enterprise, which evolved into a mega automobile dealership. He was President of the Automobile Merchants Assn of New York in 1958 and 1959, and eventually created and Chaired The Kemwel Group, a European car rental with close ties to the travel industry. Despite a debilitating motor neuron disorder, Ken Wellner was an avid sailor, a talented photographer and author of five privately published novels which he wrote while in his 80s. Ken Wellner was a deeply loyal friend, a man of insatiable curiosity, relentless humor and optimism, and undeniable charm. He never permitted his medical issues to interfere with living a full life, and became quite a terror on his scooter which provided mobility during his final year. He relished entertaining in his homes in Mamaroneck, NY; NYC; and Rancho Mirage, CA, and invariably provoked spirited political conversation. His own extraordinary spirit will endure in all who knew him. Ken Wellner is predeceased by first wife Barbara (Bronstein), second wife Eyrun (Herbertsdottir), brother Maurice and his adored son, Rick. He is survived by his wife and best friend, JoAnn (Giffuni) who he affectionately called Murgy, nephew Michael Wellner, niece Susan Merrett (Mark), and their children and daughter-in-law, Gabrielle Wellner. Donations in Ken's memory are suggested to NYU Langone Medical Center, ED Development, One Park Ave, 17th Flr., NY, NY 10016, attn: Donna Marino or to WNET-THIRTEEN, 825 8th Ave, NY, NY 10019 attn: P. Hayes, notating "For the continuing production of Richard Heffner's Open Mind." A celebration of Ken's life will be held at a later time.

New York City pet shop ownership has its challenges: Pushy customers. Yapping pooches. And, it seems, drunken puppy purchasing. On Tuesday, the news Web site DNAinfo.com reported that two Greenwich Village pet shops had policies barring visibly intoxicated patrons from buying, playing with, or even cradling puppies.

An obituary on Saturday about Richard H. Poff, who withdrew from consideration for a seat on the Supreme Court in 1971, misspelled the surname of a judge President Richard M. Nixon had nominated to the Supreme Court a year earlier. He was G. Harrold Carswell, not Carlswell. The obituary also referred incorrectly to Nixon's 1970 Supreme Court nominees. After his first two choices, Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. and Judge Carswell, were both rejected by the Senate, Nixon nominated Harry Blackmun, who was confirmed; Judge Haynsworth and Judge Carswell were not ''Nixon's two previous Supreme Court nominees'' before the 1971 vacancy.

''Pretty much everyone thought it was awesome, though some of them are sort of nervous about talking to me now,'' he said.

Although he plays in the same league as the Phillies aces Roy Halladay, Cole Hamels and Cliff Lee, a good case can be made that Atlanta's Jair Jurrjens - with his 12-3 record and 1.87 earned run average - should be the National League's starting pitcher in the All-Star Game next Tuesday. He leads N.L. pitchers in wins and E.R.A. this season, and his 4.2 Wins Above Replacement have been perhaps the biggest factor keeping the Braves in the wild card lead. If it seems as if Jurrjens is coming in under the radar this season, think back to 2008, when as a 22-year-old rookie he had a 3.68 E.R.A. in 188 innings and finished third in rookie of the year balloting. The following season, he posted 14 wins and a 2.60 E.R.A. in 215 innings. Since 2008, Johan Santana and Tim Lincecum are the only N.L. pitchers with 600 or more total innings and a lower E.R.A. than Jurrjens.

Elizabeth Smart, who was kidnapped at age 14 and was held by a Salt Lake City street preacher for nine months in 2002 and 2003, has joined ABC News as a paid contributor. An ABC spokeswoman said Thursday that she will ''help our viewers better understand missing person stories from someone with the perspective to know what a family experiences when a loved one goes missing.''

The private equity giant Carlyle Group is in talks to acquire Energy Capital Partners, a buyout shop focused on investments in power plants and gas pipelines, according to two people briefed on the talks. Carlyle's potential acquisition of Energy Capital underscores the relentless drive by the firm to gather more assets and broaden its product line as it gears up for an initial public offering.

A New Jersey man has been arrested in connection with the theft of a Picasso drawing from a San Francisco gallery on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported. Mark Lugo, 31, of Hoboken, is being held on burglary, grand theft and drug charges, with bail set at $5 million. He was arrested at a hotel in Napa, Calif., about 50 miles north of San Francisco. Mr. Lugo is accused of taking a 1965 work titled ''Tête de Femme'' (''Head of a Woman''), above, from the Weinstein Gallery and fleeing in a taxi. Surveillance video from a nearby restaurant shows a man matching his description walking by with a piece of framed artwork under his arm. The work is valued at more than $200,000, and the police said it had been recovered, without its frame. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An off-duty city police officer shot and wounded a 26-year-old man who had grabbed another off-duty officer's gun and shot at him in an early-morning melee outside a Brooklyn bar, the police said. The man who was shot, Pablo Roberto Negron, was in stable condition on Thursday at Lutheran Medical Center. He had not immediately been charged, said Deputy Inspector Kim Y. Royster, a police spokeswoman.

Federal regulators on Thursday adopted the first in a series of new rules for the derivatives market, giving the government broad new authority over the $600 trillion industry that played a central role in the financial crisis. The rules, approved unanimously by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, greatly expand the government's ability to police insider trading and other fraud. The plan, regulators say, injects new life into the commission's often-hamstrung enforcement efforts.

For the first time in her dizzying rise in country-pop, Taylor Swift has been sidelined by sickness, announcing that she had to cancel four concerts on her current tour because of bronchitis. It was the first time Ms. Swift, who at 21 has become one of the best-selling singer-songwriters in the United States, had postponed or canceled a show because of illness, her spokeswoman, Paula Erickson, said. She began to get sick on June 25 after performing in a hard rain during a sold-out show at Gillette Stadium near Boston, and apologized to fans for her hoarseness in Knoxville six days later. Her voice shredded, the singer was forced the next day to pull out of a show in Louisville, Ky. Now she has announced that her doctors had informed her that she could not perform at three shows in Charlotte, N.C., and Atlanta this weekend. ''I would never cancel if I were physically able to perform these shows,'' she said in a statement.

Adored grandmother of Pamela, Meredith, Douglas, Travis, Sara and Laura. Service Friday, July 8, 11:30am at Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, NJ. Donations in her memory may be made to Make-A-Wish Foundation.

SHAREHOLDER APPROVAL NYSE Euronext handily won shareholder support on Thursday for its proposed merger with Deutsche Börse. The deal was approved by shareholders who own nearly 65.7 percent of NYSE Euronext's outstanding shares. Of the shares that were voted, 96.1 percent were in favor of the merger. Duncan Niederauer, above, NYSE Euronext's chief executive, admitted being a little disheartened by the somewhat low turnout, though he said he remained pleased by the overall outcome. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

WASHINGTON -- The Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday issued new standards for power plants in 28 states that would sharply cut emissions of chemicals that have polluted forests, farms, lakes and streams across the Eastern United States for decades. The agency said the regulations, which will take effect in 2012, would reduce emissions of compounds that cause soot, smog and acid rain from hundreds of power plants by millions of tons at an additional cost to utilities of less than $1 billion a year. The E.P.A. said the cleaner air would prevent as many as 34,000 premature deaths, 15,000 nonfatal heart attacks and hundreds of thousands of cases of asthma and other respiratory ailments every year.

A British opera company said on Thursday that it would present a new opera by the ''Billy Elliot'' writer Lee Hall, following a dispute in which Mr. Hall said homophobia had led to the opera's cancellation. The company, Opera North, which is based in Leeds, said in a statement on its Web site that the opera, ''Beached,'' ''is continuing as planned'' following ''intense negotiations behind the scenes with all parties.''

An article in some editions on Wednesday about the Cortlandt Street subway station, where work is under way to allow the southbound platform to reopen for the 10th anniversary of 9/11, misstated the number of people expected to use the station daily, based on information from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. It is 12,000, not 300,000. (The larger figure is the number of people expected to pass each day through the entire Fulton Street Transit Center, which includes the Cortlandt Street station.) The article also misstated the status of the W train. The line was discontinued in 2010; it does not still pass through the Cortlandt station.

WOLF--Thelma C. (nee Blumberg) of Lawrence, NY died July 6. She was an attorney, active in numerous organizations, including the Queens County Women's Bar Association and a long-time member of the National Board of Hadassah. Preceded in death by her husband, Philip, she is survived by her children, Roberta, Ed and Ann, her son-in-law, Richard, and her grandchildren, Leah, Sarah and Zena. She was a woman of passion, humor, intellect and kindness, widely admired and loved.

An editorial on Tuesday about TV set-top boxes misidentified an environmental group. It is the Natural Resources Defense Council, not the National Resources Defense Council. The biggest power drain comes when a set-top box and a high-definition video recorder are combined, not from set-top boxes alone.

An article on Thursday about the anxiety of Southern Californians over the temporary closing of Interstate 405 reversed the given name and surname of the city's deputy mayor for transportation. He is Borja Leon.
Because of an editing error, an obituary on Thursday about the restaurateur and cookbook writer George Lang misstated the year his daughter Andrea died. It was 1990, not 1980.

A capsule summary on Thursday about an agreement between the United States and Mexico to let Mexican truckers deliver goods north of the border misstated the action Mexico will take in return. As the article correctly reported, it will lift tariffs on $2.3 billion in U.S. goods; it will not lift $2.3 billion in tariffs.

While Twitter isn't rushing to go public like some of its larger peers, the microblogging service has no problem luring deep-pocketed investors. Twitter is in the process of raising $400 million in a deal that values the company at $8 billion, according to two people briefed on the matter.

SKLAR--Robert A.,74, influential historian of film, died peacefully on July 2, family by his side, after a bicycle accident in Barcelona, Spain. To those who knew him well Bob was easy to love; he radiated warmth, intelligence and collegiality; a wonderful, kind, patient man with a sharp mind and keen sense of humor. Born to Lilyn and Leon Sklar, December 3, 1936, New Brunswick, NJ, Bob grew up in Long Beach, CA, and graduated summa cum laude from Princeton (BA 58), where he was chief editor of Daily Princetonian. At Harvard (PhD '65), his dissertation was a cultural analysis of F. Scott Fitzgerald. Bob went on to define the field of Cinema Studies, with 11 books, hundreds of articles, leadership of the NYU Dept. of Cinema Studies, where he was Professor for 33 years, and key roles in the Society of Cinema and Media Studies, National Film Preservation Board, NY Film Festival Selection Committee, and editorial board of Cineaste magazine. His prize-winning seminal work, Movie-Made America, pioneered a politically informed socio-cultural approach that set a standard for historical scholarship in the field and inspires each generation of film scholars anew. As a husband, Bob gave loving thoughtful support to two pioneering and prolific feminist scholars: his wife of 29 years, psychoanalyst Adrienne Harris, and his first wife, historian Kathryn Kish Sklar. Adrienne and Bob had an exceptionally close and happy marriage, rarely apart, a match of two complementary sensibilities and intellects. They were engaged in an intimate ongoing passionate conversation, involved and sustained in a wonderful, spirited community of friends and family. Bob gave his children unconditional love, supported their rebellious explorations, invested in their dreams, and celebrated his grandchildren's passions. He loved watching movies, being with family, his dogs, marathon running, wine, bicycling, world travel, and especially baseball, co-inventing fantasy baseball with the Rotisserie League. He is survived by his wife Adrienne, his children Leonard Sklar and Susan Sklar Friedman and their mother Kathryn Kish Sklar, step-children Kate and Justin Tentler, brother and sister-in-law Martin and Leah Sklar, sister-in-law Lorna Harris, grandchildren Nevona and Nadav Friedman, Cedar Sklar-Luers, and Jake Tentler, and children-in-law Amy Luers and Aryeh Friedman. A private service will be held in Sag Harbor, NY, and a public celebration of Bob's life is planned for the fall in New York City (date TBA). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Jewish Voice for Peace (jvp.org) or NPR (npr.org).

As my colleague Jeffrey Gettleman reports, the Republic of South Sudan declared its independence from its neighbor to the north on Saturday. The move was greeted with a flood of celebration in its streets and rounds of congratulations from leaders across the globe. News organizations descended on Juba, the country’s capital city, to chronicle the birth of the world’s newest nation.
After more than five decades of guerrilla struggle and two million lives lost, the Republic of South Sudan, Africa's 54th state, declared its independence.

A warm welcome to the world’s newest country, South Sudan, after a tumultuous independence struggle of more than 50 years that cost more than 3 million lives. South Sudanese deserve the celebration they’re enjoying in Juba and around the country.

After a weak touring season last year that shook the confidence of the concert industry, ticket sales for the first half of 2011 have made healthy gains, according to a report. But the increased grosses owe a lot to the price of tickets for the biggest shows, which have climbed to a level near their most expensive ever. The report, released Thursday by Pollstar, a trade magazine that collects data from concert promoters, ticketers and theaters, says that gross ticket sales for the top 100 tours in North America amounted to $1.12 billion for the first six months of this year. That is a gain of 16.2 percent over the same period last year, but 3.4 percent off the midyear peak of $1.16 billion two years ago. The top 50 tours around the world sold $1.65 billion in tickets, up 11.2 percent over last year, Pollstar said. The top tour by far was U2's (with lead singer Bono, above), which sold $164 million in tickets around the world, with $85.8 million in North America. According to Pollstar, the average price for a ticket in the first half of 2011 was $67.02, up 10.2 percent from this point last year. That is close to the industry's all-time high of $67.33, recorded for the full year 2008.

Betty Ford, the outspoken and much-admired wife of President Gerald R. Ford who overcame alcoholism and an addiction to pills and helped found one of the best-known rehabilitation centers in the nation, died Friday in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 93. Her death was confirmed by Chris Chase, Mrs. Ford's biographer.

A caption on Tuesday about the 101st Fourth of July parade in Ridgewood, N.J., misidentified the boy shown dressing up to play the role of President Obama and misspelled the given name of the boy's father, shown helping him. The boy is Aaron Ly, 9 -- not his brother Baba, 8, who is partially shown at the bottom right, and who shared the role. Their father is Mamadou Ly, not Amadou. And because of an editing error, a caption in some editions for additional pictures of Fourth of July celebrations referred incorrectly to the Franklin Band, which performed at the Ridgewood parade. The band is from Franklin, N.J., not Ridgewood, and it is not affiliated with Benjamin Franklin Middle School.

A chart on Friday about the major people linked to the phone hacking scandal in Britain misstated the publishing cycle of The News of the World, the British tabloid at the center of the controversy. The paper has always been published weekly, on Sundays; it was never a daily paper. (It ceases publication this weekend.)

Few automobile problems are more vexing than the ''check engine'' light. When the light comes on, it may mean you simply didn't tighten your gas cap enough after filling up - or it could mean there's major trouble brewing in your catalytic converter. CarMD.com, a seller of do-it-yourself tools to help you diagnose problems with your car, has compiled a list of the most common reasons the ''check engine'' light comes on, based on its database of engine repair information, which is compiled by automotive technicians. (They receive a fee in exchange for contributing data.) Art Jacobsen, the company's vice president, said it is important to find out why the light is on because ''small problems can lead to big price tags'' if necessary repairs aren't completed.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages in some editions on Friday about staged opera productions being presented by the Martina Arroyo Foundation at the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College included several errors. ''Don Giovanni,'' in addition to the performance scheduled for next Thursday, will be presented next Saturday not tonight. ''La Rondine'' will be performed next Friday and Sunday; it is not scheduled for tomorrow. And no performance of either work is scheduled for July 11.

Three months after ABC canceled the soap operas ''All My Children'' and ''One Life to Live,'' the network said Thursday that the shows would be given a second life online by Prospect Park, a two-year-old media and production company. Prospect Park will produce the two shows and distribute them ''via online formats and additional emerging platforms including Internet-enabled television sets,'' the companies said in a news release. They said that under the terms of the arrangement the length and quality of episodes of the shows would be the same as they were on television. Thousands of fans of the shows had signed petitions and a few even protested in public about the cancellations. The soap operas will probably end their ABC runs on a Friday and start up online the next Monday. Their online homes have not been announced. ''All My Children'' is set to end on ABC on Sept. 23; ''One Life to Live'' is set to end on the network in January.

JOHNSON--Evan, a long time resident of Scarsdale, NY, passed away July 5 after a short illness. He was 95. He is survived by his daughter, Christina Johnson Parsons, and her two sons, Christopher Johnson Parsons and his wife Denise and Chad Stuart Parsons.

WOLF--Thelma C. (nee Blumberg) of Lawrence, NY died July 6. She was an attorney, active in numerous organizations, including the Queens County Women's Bar Association and a long-time member of the National Board of Hadassah. Preceded in death by her husband, Philip, she is survived by her children, Roberta, Ed and Ann, her son-in-law, Richard, and her grandchildren, Leah, Sarah and Zena. She was a woman of passion, humor, intellect and kindness, widely admired and loved.

Because of an editing error, an article last Saturday about Morocco's landslide approval for constitutional change, offered by King Mohammed VI to answer demands for reform, misstated a new provision regarding the appointment of the prime minister. The king will still appoint the prime minister, as he has done previously, but the choice of candidates will be limited to members of the majority party in Parliament. The majority party will not select the prime minister.

FINDLAY--Harriet Phyllis, born in Brooklyn, New York, on June 16, 1938, died at her Metuchen, NJ home, on July 2, 2011, at the age of 73. She is survived by her husband of 47 years, James Findlay, her son Robert, her brother Leon Morse, of Boca Raton, Florida, and her nieces, Gara and Mallory Morse. Harriet was a force for success in the lives of persons with disabilities. At age six, poliomyelitis left her quadriplegic. After graduating from Packer Collegiate Institute, The New School (B.A.), and New York University (M.A.), she embarked on her career in rehabilitation, a career marked by innovation and a drive for enhancing the success of adults and adolescents. Harriet partnered with major corporations, government planning boards, legislators and parent groups to build a successful Vocational Rehabilitation Program in the JFK-Johnson Rehabilitation Institute, in Edison, NJ. As Director, with a sharp pencil, Harriet garnered the analytical planning skills of the business community through Interface, her advisory group of ten corporations which met with her monthly. She shared her perspectives with the Governor's State Rehabilitation Advisory Council, The NJ Transit Advisory Board, The UMDNJ Rehabilitation Counseling Training Program, and ten other Boards. Harriet loved music, especially opera. She traveled extensively to Europe, Israel, Hawaii and the United States, always taking her service dog, Champ. Harriet refused to permit defeat of her spirit, working up to one month before her death. A memorial service will be held at the JFK Johnson Rehabilitation Institute's Conference Center which is located at 70 James St. Edison, NJ on July 20, at 6:00pm. For information you can call 732-321-7069. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Canine Partners for Life, PO Box 170, Cochranville, PA, 19330-0170. To send condolences, please visit costello-runyon.com. "And she sang in her chains like the sea".

ALFANO--Edward, C.,The Honorable Edward C. Alfano died peacefully at his home on July 7, 2011, at the age of 92. He proudly served as a Jag Officer in the U.S. Army in both World War II and the Korean War. He retired from the service as a Lieutenant Colonel. After his discharge, he continued his career as an Attorney until 1977, when he became a Civil Court Judge for the State of New York and also served as an Acting Supreme Court Justice. His distinguished career ended as a Judicial Hearing Officer in 2008. He was highly respected by his colleagues and friends and will be truly missed. Reposing at Farenga Funeral Home 38-08 Ditmars Blvd, Astoria, NY Sunday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Monday Mass at St. Francis of Assisi R.C. Church 21-17 45th Street, Astoria, NY 11105 at 9:45am and burial at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, New York City.

Until the studios figure out a way to make a movie version of Pong, the primordial video game that features two blocks knocking a ball of pixels around the screen, it seems Hollywood has found the most, shall we say, minimalist source material for a game-to-film adaptation: Space Invaders, the quarter-munching, index-finger-jamming classic that first touched down in arcades in 1978, is being prepared for the big screen, The Hollywood Reporter said. Lorenzo di Bonaventura, a producer of the ''Transformers'' and ''G. I. Joe'' movie franchises, and Gigi Pritzker of Odd Lot Entertainment have optioned the film rights to Space Invaders, and boy do they have their work cut out for them: whereas even a Pac-Man movie would give you a built-in roster of dramatis personae (Jack Black as the pellet-gobbling hero, anyone?), Space Invaders features such characters as the alien that flaps its wings up and down and the boxlike tank that slides from side to side at the bottom of the screen. The producers did not immediately announce a creative team for the movie, nor how much money they will spend to recreate the level where the Space Invaders turn invisible. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

COLORADO SPRINGS - At the Oxbow Golf and Country Club pro shop in North Dakota, the phone rang nonstop on Friday morning. Most of the callers weren't seeking a tee time but, rather, a score. Amy Anderson, an 18-year-old whose family belongs to the club, was playing in her first United States Women's Open and had charged to the top of the leader board on Thursday before play was suspended because of lightning. ''A lot of people were calling into the pro shop to ask how she's doing,'' said David Talley, who was manning the phone. Talley, 17, a golfer on his high school team, added, ''It's a big deal in our small town to see one of our own on the big stage.'' After sleeping on the lead, as it were, Anderson, a rising junior at North Dakota State, played the final five holes of her first round in even par to card a two-under-par 69 to remain the front-runner into Friday afternoon. It was a surreal start for Anderson, whose older brother, Nathan, is caddying for her. ''It's exciting,'' she said. ''It hasn't sunk in.'' Anderson's first stroke Friday was a 15-foot putt for birdie, which she left four-feet short. She made a bogey at No. 15, a par 4, but got the stroke back with a seven-foot birdie putt at No. 17. ''I'm trying not to get ahead of myself,'' said Anderson, who was asked to describe her hometown of Oxbow. ''It's a town of about 300,'' she said. ''Basically just a golf course with no houses. No gas station. No grocery store. Nothing too glamorous. But Fargo is a pretty decent-size town, and that's just 10 minutes away.'' Anderson has won five tournaments in each of her two years at North Dakota State and has twice qualified for the N.C.A.A. Division I tournament. Her 12th-place finish this year was the highest finish ever by a Summit League player. She usually takes a break from golf in November and December, she said, once winter settles in. When she resumes practicing in January, she hits off a mat in a 60-yard indoor facility.

TWOMBLY--Cy. The passing of Cy Twombly is a loss not just for art, but for humanity. Cy was a truly great man, as well as a great painter, sculptor, draftsman and photographer. The power of his art lay not just in its extraordinary and haunting beauty, but in its ability to connect us to those archetypal forces which have driven mankind since classical times and before. Cy Twombly was a man of profound culture, able to draw at will on the poetry of every age, and on the world's literature and its history. His art was intimate, personal, touchingly humble, and true to himself. At the same time it was deeply humanist, grandly ambitious and always heroic. His passing is the end of an era. I extend my deepest sympathy to Cy's family and close friends. Larry Gagosian

BALLAN--Jack, on Thursday July 7, 84, long-time New Jersey public servant and attorney, passed away after a prolonged illness. Born to immigrant parents on a dairy farm in Fair Lawn where he was raised, Ballan attended East Side High School in Paterson where he was a scholar and an athlete. After serving in the 10th Army in the Pacific theater in WWII, Ballan completed undergraduate studies at Rutgers University and went on to study law at Columbia Law School. Ballan served as a prosecutor in Bergen County, as counsel to the New Jersey Highway Commission, as Civil Service Commissioner in the administrations of governors Meyner and Hughes and as Borough Attorney for Fair Lawn. After playing a key role in the great era of New Jersey's development, Ballan went on to a career in private practice. Ballan lived for over half a century in Fair Lawn and was a member of the Fair Lawn Jewish Center, of which his father was a founding member. He is survived by the former Sally Roth, his wife of 55 years, his children Jonathan and Sandy Ballan, Harry and Judith Ballan, Jessica and Paul Julius, Carolyn and David Wasserman and fifteen grandchildren. The funeral service will be held at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel in Paramus on Sunday, July 10 at 11am, followed by burial at Beth El Cemetery in Paramus with military honors. The shiva period will be observed at 4622 Grosvenor Ave. in Riverdale, NY through Friday afternoon July 15. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to UJA-Federation of Bergen County.

An Op-Ed article on Thursday, about the roots of homegrown Islamic extremism, incorrectly described the origins of one of the four men who bombed the London transit system in July 2005. One of the men was born in Jamaica and emigrated to Britain as a child; not all four were born in Britain.

After the section had gone to press on Friday, the gallery announced that the picture, Thomas Ruff's ''Interieur 7B,'' would be replaced by Mr. Ruff's ''Interieur 9B,'' which can be seen at tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com.

We've come full circle since 1961, back to when we had yet to show we could launch people into space. We will be hitching rides from the Russians to go to the space station that is mainly ours. STEVEN J. DICK, a retired NASA chief historian, on the last launching in the space shuttle program. [A1]

Having drawn fire from Latin jazz musicians and others for eliminating several Grammy categories important to minorities, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences sent a letter to its members this week denying racism had played any role in its decision. The letter defended a two-year review that led the academy to announce in early April it would cut the number of categories by 31, forcing male and female artists to compete with one another in all fields, lumping Latin jazz players in with other jazz musicians and consolidating awards for several regional and ethnic genres, among them Hawaiian and Cajun music, into one category.

Don your 10-gallon hat, buy some oil-rich property, cheat your relatives out of their birthrights and do whatever it is J. R. Ewing used to do if you can still remember: ''Dallas'' is coming back to television. TNT said on Friday that it had officially ordered 10 episodes of a new series based on that 1980s-era prime-time soap opera, updating the internal rivalries of the Ewing family for the 21st century while incorporating several characters from the original show. For the new ''Dallas,'' Larry Hagman and Patrick Duffy will reprise their roles as J. R. and Bobby Ewing, rival brothers whose family built its fortune on cattle and oil. The TNT series will also chronicle a new generation's feud between Christopher Ewing, Bobby's adopted son (played by Jesse Metcalfe), and his cousin John Ross Ewing (Josh Henderson), the son of J. R. and his ex-wife, Sue Ellen (Linda Gray, who reprises her original ''Dallas'' role). Jordana Brewster, of the ''Fast and the Furious'' movies, will play a woman named Elena, who finds herself in a love triangle with Christopher and John Ross.

BERLIN -- In Austria, consumers can demand repairs, but not exchanges or refunds, when they receive a defective product. If a factory fire or strike in France delays delivery of a purchase by weeks or even months, some consumers must simply wait. They have no legal right to cancel the purchase. When it comes to what is called contract law in the European Union, the single market is actually a patchwork of 27 national legal codes offering varying degrees of protection to consumers and merchants. Those differences, and the costs of overcoming them, have limited cross-border trade primarily to multinational companies with the legal staffs to negotiate the maze.

The art dealer Guy Wildenstein has been accused of ''receiving fraudulently obtained goods'' by the French authorities in connection with 30 paintings and sculptures worth millions of dollars that had been missing for decades and were discovered this year in a vault at the Wildenstein Institute in Paris. In January investigators carried away armloads of art including Degas drawings, a bronze sculpture by Rembrandt Bugatti and an Impressionist painting by Berthe Morisot that had all been reported missing or stolen by Jewish families whose property was looted by the Nazis, and others by heirs who said their treasures had vanished during the settlement of their family estates.

Starting later this month, if you're denied for a loan or don't qualify for the best interest rate, the lender must send you a free copy of the credit score it used to arrive at its decision. The new rule, which will go into effect on July 21 as part of the broader financial regulatory overhaul, will apply to credit cards, auto loans and student loans. In other words, it will apply to any type of credit-related decision that uses information in your credit report. (Lenders must continue to provide free credit scores to all mortgage applicants, even if you get the best loan terms available.)

When Thomas U. Walter returned to Washington at the beginning of July 1861, he found an appalling mess. For 10 years he had served as the architect in charge of building the new Senate and House wings of the United States Capitol and the cast iron dome that would crown the rotunda. When war broke out, Congress was not in session and the building was empty. The Union Army took it over.

It took my husband and me eight months to conceive our first child. Much of that time was passed in bored agitation, like a long wait at a Verizon Wireless store. To pass the time, swap information, and quiet my mind, I turned to an online message board for women who are Trying to Conceive — TTC, one of the first message-board acronyms I learned. Then, rapidly, I learned the rest of the lingo known to the voluble and surprisingly large community of women who turn to the Internet to ask intensely personal questions: TWW (two-week wait), BFN (“big fat negative”) and OPK (ovulator prediction kit).

George T. M. Shackelford, chairman of art of Europe and curator of modern art at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, is moving to Texas to become senior deputy director of the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth. A leading scholar of late 19th- and early 20th-century French art, Mr. Shackelford is co-organizing “Degas and the Nude,” with Xavier Rey, curator of paintings at the Musée d’Orsay in Paris. The show is scheduled to open on Oct. 9 in Boston before going to Paris.

In Berlin, the National Gallery has dedicated a double exhibition to Brassaï, the famed Hungarian artist born Gyula Halasz. TWOMBLY--Cy. The passing of Cy Twombly is a loss not just for art, but for humanity. Cy was a truly great man, as well as a great painter, sculptor, draftsman and photographer. The power of his art lay not just in its extraordinary and haunting beauty, but in its ability to connect us to those archetypal forces which have driven mankind since classical times and before. Cy Twombly was a man of profound culture, able to draw at will on the poetry of every age, and on the world's literature and its history. His art was intimate, personal, touchingly humble, and true to himself. At the same time it was deeply humanist, grandly ambitious and always heroic. His passing is the end of an era. I extend my deepest sympathy to Cy's family and close friends. Larry Gagosian

A column last Sunday about ''Slacker 2011,'' a remake of ''Slacker,'' Richard Linklater's 1991 independent film, contained two errors. The surname of the director of the ''anti-artist'' segment was misspelled. He is Scott Meyers, not Moyers. The column also had an incorrect photo credit, which was supplied by one of the main organizers of the project. The photo was taken by Patrick Rusk, not Karen Skloss.

The idea of an all-inclusive getaway might evoke cheesy resorts or college spring-break trips, but some one-price-for-all vacations are all about luxury. Here are three such packages. The Four Seasons Hotel Denver (above) has a ''Sky's the Limit'' package (fourseasons.com). For two people, a night's stay, including all meals, poolside drinks, snacks, spa treatments and more, costs $1,111.14, in honor of the hotel's address: 1111 14th Street. Only alcohol isn't included. Available through Sept. 18 on Friday and Saturday nights only.

For this last Sunday's Auto Ego in the Automobiles section, I accompanied Alain Daumas and his family as he steered their 1955 Citroen Traction Avant through Times Square, fulfilling a longtime dream of his, where the car attracted as many gape-mouthed stares and clicking cameras as the surrounding towers and billboards. On July 10, many more Citroens are expected to scoot through Manhattan for the annual Bastille Day Rally and Rendez-vous, organized by the Greater New York Citroen and Velosolex Touring Club. (Note that Bastille Day is officially July 14.)

WELLNER--Kenneth, Age 90, a man who well lived several lives, and inspired many others, died unexpectedly on July 2 after a determined battle with multiple medical afflictions. A self-proclaimed Yankee Doodle Dandy, Ken Wellner passionately loved this country, its freedoms and its opportunities. The son of the late Emil and Freida Wellner, Ken graduated from Stuyvesant High School and attended NYU before joining the Army in December, 1941, serving in the CBI, achieving the rank of Major and receiving the Bronze Star Medal. He considered his military service the greatest privilege. In civilian life he joined Wellner Motors in NYC, the family enterprise, which evolved into a mega automobile dealership. He was President of the Automobile Merchants Assn of New York in 1958 and 1959, and eventually created and Chaired The Kemwel Group, a European car rental with close ties to the travel industry. Despite a debilitating motor neuron disorder, Ken Wellner was an avid sailor, a talented photographer and author of five privately published novels which he wrote while in his 80s. Ken Wellner was a deeply loyal friend, a man of insatiable curiosity, relentless humor and optimism, and undeniable charm. He never permitted his medical issues to interfere with living a full life, and became quite a terror on his scooter which provided mobility during his final year. He relished entertaining in his homes in Mamaroneck, NY; NYC; and Rancho Mirage, CA, and invariably provoked spirited political conversation. His own extraordinary spirit will endure in all who knew him. Ken Wellner is predeceased by first wife Barbara (Bronstein), second wife Eyrun (Herbertsdottir), brother Maurice and his adored son, Rick. He is survived by his wife and best friend, JoAnn (Giffuni) who he affectionately called Murgy, nephew Michael Wellner, niece Susan Merrett (Mark), and their children and daughter-in-law, Gabrielle Wellner. Donations in Ken's memory are suggested to NYU Langone Medical Center, ED Development, One Park Ave, 17th Flr., NY, NY 10016, attn: Donna Marino or to WNET-THIRTEEN, 825 8th Ave, NY, NY 10019 attn: P. Hayes, notating "For the continuing production of Richard Heffner's Open Mind." A celebration of Ken's life will be held at a later time.

SWEET, tart and thimble-shaped, black raspberries resemble the red supermarket variety, only they are smaller and give a greater punch to the palate. This time of year, black raspberries are ripe and abundant throughout the city and the metropolitan area, growing wild along the side of the road, on parkland and in neighbors' backyards. Black raspberry (Rubus occidentalis), a k a black cap or blackcap raspberry, is native to the eastern and central United States, and can be found as far west as Colorado. (They are more common in our area than red raspberries.)

GARTNER--Murray, dies at 88; Leading Labor Litigator. Murray Gartner, one of the nation's top specialists in labor law, died on Saturday, June 25, of a massive aneurism, at the Maine Medical Center in Portland, Maine. A life-long resident of New York City, Mr. Gartner had recently retired with his wife, Anne, to Scarborough, ME, in 2004. Mr. and Mrs. Gartner had just celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary. Born in Queens, New York, in 1922, to Leo and Celia Gartner, recent immigrants from Eastern Europe, and the second of their three children, Murray Gartner's family lived first in Forest Hills, but later moved to Newark, New Jersey, where he received his high school education from the Newark public school system. Advancing through his early education at an accelerated rate, Mr. Gartner graduated high school at the age of fifteen and was admitted that same year to New York University. Graduating from NYU summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa in 1942, at the age of nineteen, he immediately went on to Harvard Law School, from which he graduated magna cum laude in 1945, after serving as President of the Harvard Law Review. Even before he graduated from Harvard Law, Mr. Gartner was hired by Associate Justice Robert H. Jackson to be his law clerk at the U.S. Supreme Court. He served as Justice Jackson's clerk for two-and-a-half terms, from February of 1945 through June 1947. He then joined the prestigious San Francisco firm of Pillsbury, Madison and Sutro. In 1951, he was tapped by the U.S. Special Representative in Europe to serve as Assistant to the General Council, as part of the Marshall Plan. Working for two years out of the Marshall Plan's headquarters in Paris, France, Mr. Gartner's main assignment was negotiating for the establishment of U.S. military bases in Spain. In 1953, Mr. Gartner returned to the United States, and to New York City, where he joined the law firm of Poletti, Freidin & Littauer. At Poletti, Freidin, Mr. Gartner established a successful, national practice in labor law, and in due course the firm soon became known as Poletti, Freidin, Prashker, Feldman & Gartner. After the death of Jesse Freidin in 1968, Murray Gartner and Herbert Prashker took over as senior partners, continuing their firm's specialization in labor law for the airline industry. Over the course of his practice, Mr. Gartner established himself as the "go-to" labor specialist for foreign airlines operating in the United States. His client list included British Airways, Air France, Qantas, Japan Airlines, Iberia Airlines, Air Canada, and Air India, as well as Pan Am. He represented them both as a litigator in labor disputes and in the negotiation of collective bargaining agreements. As a litigator, he tried a number of landmark federal cases under the Railway Labor Act. Despite his national reputation as a labor specialist for the airline industry, he also maintained a career as a general litigator, with a diverse roster of clients which included R. H. Macy & Co. and Restaurant Associates. In 1985, Poletti, Freidin, Prashker & Gartner was dissolved as a firm, and Mr. Gartner then moved over to a position as a senior partner at Proskauer, Rose, Goetz & Mendelsohn, LLP. While at Proskauer, Rose he had the opportunity to try two related appellate cases before the U.S. Supreme Court. The second of these cases, decided by the Court in 1989, established that the Railway Labor Act does not require employers, when a strike is over, to replace employees who have crossed the picket line to return to work during the strike with full-term strikers, even when those full-term strikers have greater seniority than the crossovers. Mr. Gartner is survived by his wife, Anne Thompson Gartner, his two children, Marion Moreau Gartner Carling of Hartford, CT, and Thomas Murray Gartner of Philadelphia, PA., and five grandchildren. His brother, David Gartner, and sister, Patricia Gartner, both predeceased him. Memorial Gifts may be made to the Harvard Law School, or to the Children's Aid Society of New York, 105 E. 22nd Street, Room 504, New York, NY 10010-5413. Funeral Services will be private. Please visit jonesrichandhutchins.com for additional information and to sign Mr. Gartner's guest book.

Although automakers have demonstrated their ability to deliver fuel savings through hybrid technology, they are not delivering on the technology's promise, according to the Union of Concerned Scientists' 2011 Hybrid Scorecard. According to the nonprofit organization, automakers are bringing more hybrids to market that are engineered around conventional performance metrics like acceleration, which compromises their environment benefit. Automakers also were chastised for weighing certain hybrids down with features that inflate their cost, keeping the cars beyond the reach of many consumers.

HONIG--Harvey R. (Hal), 85, of Manhattan, died peacefully on July 1 in New York after surgery complications. He is survived by nephews Paul A. and Andrew E. Spiegel, and friends and admirers from around the globe. Mr. Honig graduated from the University of North Carolina and the Harvard School of Government. He served his country as an officer in the Army and in the Foreign Service. After retiring from his family business, Jack L. Honig, Inc., manufacturer of children's dresses, Hal inspired and involved many people to serve the community. He mentored the youth in NYC public schools, Big Brothers and Big Sisters, and through other projects. PBS TV channel did a short documentary on Hal's simple solution to hunger of the homeless in NYC. Mr. Honig was an officer of the Sathya Sai Central Council, USA - dedicated to practical spirituality, and selfless service. He developed programs for youth to perform community service based on universal human values. Mr. Honig leaves an inspiring example and legacy of selfless service, leadership, and love. He often quoted Sathya Sai Baba's teachings and did his best to live by them, including one of his favorites, Love All Serve All. Thank you, Hal. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Sathya Sai Society of America, P.O. Box 660908, Arcadia, CA 91066-0908.

An article last Sunday on the Royal Shakespeare Company's arrival in New York, left out one of the producers for the company's six-week stay in the city. The residency is being co-produced by the Park Avenue Armory and the Lincoln Center Festival in association with Ohio State University.

Zip lines have spread from tropical jungles to northerly stands with a flurry of cable-and-pulley routes making their debuts this summer. Riders, attached to the lines by harnesses, can now breeze through the Alaskan pine forest outside Skagway. The Alaska Excursions attraction includes 11 waterfall-skimming lines, as well as four suspension bridges for tricky crossings on foot ($169 per adult).

DEN--Dr. Halina, born in Radom, Poland in 1922, died on July 7, 2011. The daughter of prosperous parents, Ita and Mordka Den, Halina enjoyed a life rich in culture and academic achievement until the Nazis overran her country. In April of 1941, when Halina was 19, all the Jews of Radom were forced to move into the Ghetto. To avoid deportation to an extermination camp in 1942, Halina took employment in the Kromolowski factory sewing saddles and mattresses for the German Army. She was separated from her family and forced to work 12 to 16 hours a day. By 1943, of the original 30,000 Jews in the Radom Ghetto only 1,500 survived. Halina was now ordered to dig peat for fuel, constantly guarded by the SS. Later that year she was sent to AZ Pionki munitions factory, and then to Auschwitz in a cattle car. With Russian troops closing in, Halina and other survivors were driven west on foot, during which many died. The British liberated her from Bergen-Belsen on April 15, 1945. The same fortitude that made it possible for her to survive incarceration, death marches, and loss of her family during the war, also made certain that she would succeed at her chosen profession once peace came. After doing undergraduate studies at the University of Frankfurt, Halina entered the United States under the auspices of her uncle Morris Schwartz, and earned her PhD in Bio-Chemistry at the University of Michigan. She later became a professor and researcher at Columbia University. Although surviving blood relations are few-cousins Norman Schwartz, Edward Sorel, and Ruth Froimowicz and her daughter Rachel Sutin, Eva Lenko, Alexandra Fish, Zeev Kuncman, Michelle Den, Hanna Katz, Hanna Silvers, Ruth Ryba and Chaim Weiner-she was loved by all in her extended family of friends and distant relatives, especially by Rebecca Schwartz, who was always there for Halina in her times of crises We all admired her determination to cherish and nourish whatever bit of joy came her way.

On June 24 against Colorado, A. J. Burnett became the first Yankee to record four strikeouts in an inning. A week later, a Yankees prospect outdid him. Mark Montgomery, a right-hander drafted in the 11th round last month, struck out five Rome Braves in the ninth inning of his debut for Class A Charleston. After two hits, Montgomery struck out two. Then he fanned two more, but both times his slider skipped in the dirt past catcher Gary Sanchez for a wild pitch, allowing the runners to reach base. Montgomery finished with yet another strikeout.

Competitors hurtle across an unstable surface at more than 60 m.p.h. while jockeying for position against hundreds of rivals -- and without helmets, despite violent wipeouts. Competitive windsurf racing combines the high-speed maneuvering of ski cross with the blind courage of ski jumping. Pioneered in California in the late '60s by a sailor (who was also an engineer) and a surfer, windsurfing has become a global sport, with major competitions in at least 50 countries. While less popular than surfing, windsurfing has the advantage of simplicity. How do you win? ''That's easy,'' says Philippe Bru, founder of Défi Wind, one of the sport's most prestigious events, held annually in Gruissan, France. ''You want to go faster than the guys in front of you and the guys behind you.'' And if you do that at Défi, your grand prize is . . . ''nothing,'' Bru says. ''No money, just a trophy and the ability to tell people, 'I won the Défi Wind, because I was the fastest.' '' Dates of Défi Wind 2011: June 2-5

IF your cramped apartment has got you down, take heart from ''The House Without the Door,'' a new group show at David Zwirner Gallery in Chelsea. Some of the homes represented here, like Philip-Lorca diCorcia's charred suburban pile, might well be broken beyond repair, while Gregor Schneider's ''Dead House'' has been so compulsively overconstructed, there is no apparent way in, or out. Mona Hatoum's ''Home'' is a charged place, where ordinary household objects carry the threat of electric shock. And the apartment of Thomas Ruff's ''Interieur 7C'' (left) looks as if its tenant might have vacated feet first. All of these artists are navigating the fraught psychological turf between house and home, according to Zwirner's Kristine Bell, who put the show together, and who shares her own ''inescapable container'' with two boys under the age of 6. Until Aug. 5 at David Zwirner Gallery, 525 West 19th Street. ALIX BROWNE

An article last Sunday about the opening of the World Bank's vast storehouse of data misstated the amount of the bank's lending. It was $57 billion in the fiscal year ended June 30 (an unaudited figure), not $170 billion. The article also misstated the age of the bank's president, Robert B. Zoellick. He is 57, not 58.

FRIEDBERG--Elinor ("Sharita"), age 41. Wife of Karl Blume, daughter of Richard Friedberg and Leslie Kandell, sister of Cindy Marvell Brown and Jon Alex Friedberg, aunt of Theo Marvell Brown. Elinor lived a life of creativity and style, filled with music, art and friends who adored her. Born in New York, she attended LaGuardia High School and Reed College. She settled in Portland, OR., and taught dance at Reed and at Portland State University. She produced dance works set to music of Stravinsky and Gershwin among others, designed costumes, and was working on a book, "The Evergreen Garden," about plants in her own garden. Her lively Thanksgiving parties often featured Bach cantatas with satirical texts. "O Magnum Mysterium," to music of Elgar, was performed in May by the Bach Cantata Choir, of which she was a member. (It is on You Tube at: http://youtube/eZbfZGZWEm8) Elinor fought for what she believed in, and her courage and exuberance during her final illness were an inspiration. Cindy wrote: "My younger sister danced on the edge of a song that brought her into life as a warrior and rarely bored her. She crafted nature into vessels of life and wove love into dreams that permeated her house." Memorial services will be held in September in Portland, OR. and New York City.

SCHICKLER--Martin, devoted father of Laura Jean Schickler, brother of Phyllis Lee, uncle of twin nieces Amy and Bonnie Lee, great-uncle of twin nieces, Emily and Josette Apple, and good friend of many around the world, died on June 28 on Hilton Head Island, SC of a long illness. He was a man of high intellect, great determination, brutal honesty, and deep curiosity. He believed in the gift of life and lived each moment to its fullest. He loved his animals and his boat on the Hudson River. Martin loved going solo on worldly exotic adventures that required only a backpack. Already he is missed by many.

EACH summer, the road linking Sorrento with Positano is jammed with cars and buses bringing tourists through the fragile hill towns of Italy's Amalfi Coast. Long waits for a table and exorbitant prices go without saying. But just south of Amalfi is Cilento National Park, where a euro goes farther and the traffic and tourists are few and far between. The area encompasses dozens of coastal and mountain towns worth stopping for a stroll or an aperitivo. Cilento (pictured here), for example, has Palazzo Belmonte, a posh medieval fortress masquerading as a seaside resort, with five acres of walled-in palm gardens. In Castellabate, with its arresting view of the Diano Valley, you can dine on excellent seafood at Il Caicco, a restaurant known for cooking with white figs. Two neighboring hamlets, Santa Maria di Castellabate and San Marco di Castellabate, are a sunbather's paradise. The white sand beaches are quiet, and the sea is crystalline, two things you won't find in Amalfi. ROCKY CASALE

SHATTER--Susan. The National Academy mourns the loss of watercolor painter and former National Academy President (20052009), Susan Shatter. Susan was a beloved member of the Academy and one of the foremost watercolor painters in America who brought a contemporary sensibility to rendering the landscape before her. She will be dearly missed by all.

If there was any doubt about Anish Giri's status as the Netherlands' biggest chess star, it was put to bed by his showing in the Dutch national championship. He finished two points ahead of his nearest competitor, Ivan Sokolov, in the 10-player field. At 17, Giri is now a two-time Dutch champion, and he is ranked No. 40 in the world.

NEWMAN--Frederick Delano. The All Stars Project Board of Directors and staff are deeply saddened by the passing of the All Stars' extraordinary and much loved co-founder, Fred Newman, Ph.D. He was 76. Dr. Newman was born in the South Bronx, grew up in the shadow of the old Yankee Stadium (becoming a lifelong Yankees fan), and served in the U.S. Army in Korea. Upon his return he completed his undergraduate studies at City College and went on to earn his Ph.D. in analytic philosophy and foundations of mathematics from Stanford University in 1962, where he was mentored by the renowned analytic philosopher Donald Davidson. All who knew him will remember him as a fierce champion for giving the best, most sophisticated, most far-reaching tools of postmodern philosophy to ordinary people. He taught at several colleges and universities in the 1960s before dedicating himself to community organizing and the creation of numerous independent education, health, mental health, cultural and political projects in New York and nationally. Dr. Newman was a practicing therapist for more than 30 years and was the founder of a new humanistic psychology known as Social Therapy. The author of numerous books and articles on postmodern, Vygotskian, and performatory psychology, he and his colleagues worked to develop and popularize their breakthrough discoveries about human development. He co-founded the All Stars Project with Lenora Fulani, Ph.D. in 1981 to bring this new science of development to the lives of inner-city young people. He was the chief designer of the All Stars Project's performance-based development approach, which has transformed the lives of hundreds of thousands of poor, Black and Latino youth across the country and is providing a new theoretical and practical framework for eliminating poverty and underdevelopment. Dr. Newman was artistic director and playwright-in-residence of the All Stars' Castillo Theatre from 1989 until 2005. Often a lightning rod for controversy, Fred Newman was a relentless champion for a new style of progressivism. He was also a pioneer in the development of independent politics in the United States, starting in the 1970s, and had a major hand in the creation of the Independence Party of New York, playing a key role in the party's endorsement of Mayor Michael Bloomberg in 2001, 2005, and 2009. Despite serious illness, Dr. Newman was unflagging in his work. He will be deeply missed by the Board of Directors, staff, volunteers and countless young people and their families in our poor communities whose lives he and his work have touched. We extend our deepest condolences to Dr. Newman's life partners Gabrielle L. Kurlander, who so ably serves as the All Stars President and CEO, and Jacqueline S. Salit, and to his children Elizabeth and Donald and granddaughter, Jane. As we mourn the passing of our founder and friend Fred Newman, his legacy of radical humanism, his commitment to community, to development and to creating ensemble performances live on through the work of the All Stars Project.

B OLD stripes and prints may be all the rage right now (think Marni, Jil Sander and Prada), but Marimekko has been doing them for years -- 60 to be exact, since the designer Armi Ratia and her husband, Viljo, took over Printex, a small Finnish textile company, and reinvented the brand. Today, there is no shortage of new Marimekko looks around, thanks to collaborations with the likes of Crate & Barrel and Converse. And a freestanding Marimekko shop is to open this fall in the Flatiron district. But true believers should get their mouse-clicker fingers in shape for Wednesday, when a trove of vintage Marimekko, many items unworn and still wrapped in tissue (the one above, from 1968), will be available to the public at 1stdibs.com. SCHWARTZ--Helene, passed away on July 1, 2011. She was the loving and devoted wife of Irving L. Schwartz, who predeceased her in 2009. They were married for 61 years. Helene was always a loving and devoted mother to her daughters, Linda Gilbert, Diane Schwartz and Jill Schwartz, and she adored her two grandsons, Matthew Schwartz and Jacob Trill. She was on the Board of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies and the Westchester Pleasantville League. She and Irving were founders of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Lincoln Center. She was an interior designer with exquisite taste. Helene was an unparalleled hostess to friends and a woman of great beauty and extraordinary generosity. She will remain in our hearts forever. The Field Notes column on June 26, about men taking the place of flower girls at some weddings, misstated part of the name of the organization of which Robert Heasley is the president. It is the American Men's Studies Association, not the American Male Studies' Association.

AZZEDINE ALAÏA has been busy these last eight years -- creating a shoe line with the help of Prada's factories, tidying up his house, expanding his ateliers with financing from Richemont. He has also been prolific as a designer. Remember the black crackled patent leather coats that fashionistas craved? Or the frilled knit dresses that Michelle Obama wore in Oslo and New York? Without his doing shows (not since 2003), without advertising, or being on Twitter, Mr. Alaïa has seen the world come to him. And ideally that's how it should be. People find him, or they want to talk about his clothes, because the work speaks so clearly for itself. Last March, when he gave me and Vanessa Friedman of The Financial Times a look at his fall ready-to-wear, he temptingly showed a few works in progress. With Mr. Alaïa, that's how it is: clothes are ready when they are ready, not before.

With its dark red and black stripes, spotted fins and long venomous black spikes, the lionfish seems better suited for horror films than consumption. But lionfish fritters and filets may be on American tables soon. An invasive species, the lionfish is devastating reef fish populations along the Florida coast and into the Caribbean. Now, an increasing number of environmentalists, consumer groups and scientists are seriously testing a novel solution to control it and other aquatic invasive species -- one that would also takes pressure off depleted ocean fish stocks: they want Americans to step up to their plates and start eating invasive critters in large numbers.

NEW YORK has been a melting pot of national ballet companies of late: the Cubans, the Danes and, of course, American Ballet Theater's rotating casts of international stars. And now the Russians. On Monday the Mariinsky Ballet and Orchestra will begin a week of performances at the Lincoln Center Festival. Valery Gergiev, the Mariinsky Theater's artistic director, will share conducting duties. In addition to George Balanchine's ''Symphony in C'' and Alberto Alonso's ''Carmen Suite'' come the American premieres of two works by the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky: ''Anna Karenina'' and ''The Little Humpbacked Horse.'' These two very different Russian tales feature scores by Rodion Shchedrin, the Russian composer and husband of the great Bolshoi ballerina Maya Plisetskaya.

To the Editor: Bringing your own food on a domestic flight is win-win as far as I'm concerned. You've made it yourself so you know exactly what you're getting (I keep kosher, so that's especially important for me), you don't have to pay the exorbitant prices the airlines charge for in-flight meals or try to find a healthy option at an airport restaurant, and if there any delays, at least you can count on a meal. As for people who are concerned about germs on the tray tables, I always pack a linen tea towel. I spread it out like a tablecloth, and when I'm done it just goes into the Ziploc bag with my cutlery and empty food containers. Oh, and the Web site thekitchn.com has some great airplane-friendly recipe ideas that were inspired by this article.

SWENSON--Bruce Berthelot, died peacefully on July 6, 2011 at home in Dallas, TX. Born July 31, 1920 to Swen R. Swenson and Jean Merritt Swenson, brother of Roderick and Perry Swenson, all of who predeceased him. Survived by his wife of 66 years, Nancy Tiernan of Essex Fells, NJ and by their six children, their families, eleven grandchildren. Bruce's children are: Smokey, Steve, Carroll, and Nancy, all of Dallas; Merritt of San Antonio and Christopher of Montclair, NJ. Bruce served his country in WWII, enlisting after Pearl Harbor, flying 44 combat missions with the 13th Air Force in the Pacific Theater. After the war Bruce worked for Harris Upham & Co in Dallas before being elected in 1971 as Chairman of Swenson Land Cattle Co., whose origins are traced to Bruce's great-grandfather, Svante Magnus Swenson and the early days of the Texas Republic. Bruce was a beloved father, grandfather, great-grandfather and great friend to so many people. His sense of humor, companionship, humble spirit, love of life and love for us will be greatly missed.

WHEN the 24-year-old painter from Indianapolis received a message from his girlfriend that she was out with the girls, the brief text on his phone gave no grounds for suspicion. Months later, post-breakup, he learned she was cheating on him that night. It was not the only time she tried to deceive by text, he said. ''If she wasn't physically in front of me during a discussion, I had no real way to judge as to whether or not she was telling the truth,'' said the painter, who was granted anonymity because his ex-girlfriend wasn't around to give her side.

LICALZI--Luke, 87, died July 8 after an eight-year battle with cancer. LiCalzi, a resident of Manhasset Hills, Long Island, was a professional engineer who worked on landmark city structures and who led a successful consulting engineering firm in Manhattan for more than 40 years. LiCalzi was a proud graduate of Stuyvesant High School and the City College of New York (class of 1948). LiCalzi served in the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers in Austria and Germany. He married his wartime sweetheart, Marie Quaranta of Brooklyn, on August 18, 1945. After receiving a Masters in Engineering from the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, LiCalzi became an associate of the New York City architectural and engineering firm Victor Mayper Consulting Engineers. He founded his own civil engineering consulting firm, Luke LiCalzi P.E., P.C. Consulting Engineers, in Manhattan in 1970, which continues under the helm of his son Mark S. LiCalzi, P.E. LiCalzi contributed to the structural design of such New York landmarks as 666 Fifth Avenue, Tower East and Madison Square Garden. In later years he consulted with banks and equity lenders on large-scale commercial and residential projects they funded. LiCalzi also served as chairman of the Town of North Hempstead Housing Authority. LiCalzi was a member of the New York Association of Consulting Engineers and a Fellow of the American Society of Civil Engineers. He was a licensed engineer in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. LiCalzi is survived by his wife of 65 years, Marie, and five children: Luke (Rita), Greg (Carol), Mark (Helena), Jacqueline (Jill Schlesinger), and Pamela (John O'Connell). He was the proud grandfather of 13 grandchildren and one great-grandchild. He also is survived by his brother Dr. Nicholas C. LiCalzi, M.D. and sister-in-law Jacqueline. He was pre-deceased by his parents Joseph and Jennie, his sister Providence, and his grandson 1st LT. Michael Lucian LiCalzi USMC. Visitation is Sunday and Monday at the New Hyde Park Funeral Home; Funeral Mass Tuesday morning at Notre Dame Church, New Hyde Park. The family asks that expressions of sympathy be donated to the Ace in the Hole Foundation Inc., c/o Greg LiCalzi, 1 Gracie Terrace, Apt. 2K, New York, NY 10028. aceintheholefoundation.org

A map on June 26 with the cover article about a hiking route to Machu Picchu that takes in lesser-known sites located incorrectly one site and mislabeled two trails. Llactapata, as stated in the article, is two miles west of Machu Picchu, not 10 miles southeast; that is the location of another Inca site, also called Llactapata. And only the trail leading to Machu Picchu from the east is commonly called the Inca Trail. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/travel.

Three strikes and you're dead? Baseball's early days were a lot like the Wild West: few rules. There were no gloves and no catching equipment either. The pitcher, or ''hurler,'' was allowed to throw underhand, and if the hitter, or ''striker,'' missed three times, he wasn't out -- he was ''dead.''

Competitors hurtle across an unstable surface at more than 60 m.p.h. while jockeying for position against hundreds of rivals -- and without helmets, despite violent wipeouts. Competitive windsurf racing combines the high-speed maneuvering of ski cross with the blind courage of ski jumping. Pioneered in California in the late '60s by a sailor (who was also an engineer) and a surfer, windsurfing has become a global sport, with major competitions in at least 50 countries. While less popular than surfing, windsurfing has the advantage of simplicity. How do you win? ''That's easy,'' says Philippe Bru, founder of Défi Wind, one of the sport's most prestigious events, held annually in Gruissan, France. ''You want to go faster than the guys in front of you and the guys behind you.'' And if you do that at Défi, your grand prize is . . . ''nothing,'' Bru says. ''No money, just a trophy and the ability to tell people, 'I won the Défi Wind, because I was the fastest.' '' Dates of Défi Wind 2011: June 2-5

WASHINGTON -- Citing differences over tax revenue, the House speaker, John A. Boehner, said on Saturday night that he would pull back from joint efforts with President Obama to reach a sweeping $4 trillion deficit-reduction plan tied to a proposal to increase the federal debt limit. On the eve of a second round of high-level bipartisan talks set for Sunday, Mr. Boehner issued a statement saying he would urge negotiators to focus on a package more in line with the $2 trillion to $3 trillion in spending cuts and revenue increases negotiated earlier by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

IN the late 19th century, in Louisville, Ky., farm animals shuffled down East Market Street, flanked by shops selling dry goods and animal hides. A century later, what remained was a barren conduit between residential neighborhoods and the city's downtown. Today, the brick facades that line the wide street retain the remnants of paint faintly advertising the old tenants' wares, but the buildings are occupied by new boutiques, restaurants and architecture firms, and the buzz and rattle of construction fills the daytime hours. On the first Friday evening of each month, people, not livestock, mill along the sidewalks, ducking into galleries as part of the First Friday Trolley Hop, the nomadic art party that follows a free trolley route through the neighborhood. This five-block strip is often called East Market District, though some prefer NuLu, for New Louisville, a term coined by Gill Holland, a local investor.ANDREW SIMMONS

VITAGLIANO--Maggie, a prolific artist who brought together her love of sacred Indian Scripture and her abundant artistic talent to create a distinctive clothing line, died on April 13th, 2011 three days before her 60th birthday. The cause was metastatic breast cancer. Maggie was a lifelong photographer, painter, fashion designer and more recently a digital computer artist. In January 1999 she made her first silkscreen, Consciousness is the Self and hand screened it on an old t-shirt. This was the first Shiva Sutra and the auspicious beginning of Hermitwear, Maggie's design company. Maggie created each of her clothing pieces as if they were works of art on canvas. Friends and colleagues from the fashion industry and yoga community expressed that wearing her line of clothes made them feel full of good will and love, which reflected Maggie's approach to life, friendship and the world. Her charismatic and magnetic personality attracted so many people in her hometown of Scarsdale, NY and New York City where Maggie is beloved by friends throughout those communities. Maggie is survived by her friends Lori, Frank, Prema, Pat, Susan, Sam, Ellen, cousins Linda, Ricky, Tommy, Claudia, Paul, Valerie, Antoinette, John and Mary Ann, mother Nancy and brother John. A Memorial Service will be held at 7:30pm on July 14, 2011, at Subud New York, 230 West 29th St, New York, NY.

SLADE--EDWARD J Jr.,died on July 7, 2011 after a brave battle with cancer. Born June 12, 1957, Ed graduated from Penn State University where he played Division I tennis. Ed co-founded O Water and, more recently, founded and served as CEO of Twelve Beverages. Prior to O Water, he was the President of FIJI Water. Ed was named one of America's 100 Top Marketing Executives for his work at Group Danone/Evian. An avid golfer and tennis player, he was a member of the Board of Governors of The Country Club of Fairfield and had served as a Council Member of The Fairfield Beach Club. Ed loved his family: his wife Sharon Shaw Slade, their children William Charles Slade and Andrew Edward Slade, his father Col. Edward J Slade, his late mother Laura C. Slade and his sister Sandra Slade Mossbrook. His capacity to enjoy life, his good sportsmanship and his dignity and kindness will be profoundly missed by all who knew him. Ed will be fondly remembered as a true gentleman, a great friend and, most of all, a devoted husband and loving father to his boys. He was most proud of the young men his sons have become. A memorial service will be held at the Southport Congregational Church in Southport, CT, on July 12, 2011, at 11:00am. Donations in Ed's memory may be made to the Edward J Slade Fund for Faculty Development at Fairfield Country Day School, 2970 Bronson Road, Fairfield, CT 06824.

MATHILDE LAURENT, Cartier's über-chic head perfumer, had men on her mind while creating Baiser Volé, the house's latest scent for women. ''I noticed that when asked about their favorite flower, many men said it was the lily,'' she said. ''Of course, women can choose perfume for themselves, but what's wrong with putting the man in the equation?'' Bucking the trend for ''sickly'' or ''sugary'' florals, Ms. Laurent took two years to capture the fresh yet heady essence of a bouquet of fresh-cut lilies. The bottle, which was inspired by the company's elegant cigarette lighters, is as come-hither as the pale pink juice it contains, lending a whole new meaning to the term ''smoking.'' It's $100 for 1.6 fluid ounces at Nordstrom stores. SANDRA BALLENTINE
