BALLAN--Jack, on Thursday July 7, 84, long-time New Jersey public servant and attorney, passed away after a prolonged illness. Born to immigrant parents on a dairy farm in Fair Lawn where he was raised, Ballan attended East Side High School in Paterson where he was a scholar and an athlete. After serving in the 10th Army in the Pacific theater in WWII, Ballan completed undergraduate studies at Rutgers University and went on to study law at Columbia Law School. Ballan served as a prosecutor in Bergen County, as counsel to the New Jersey Highway Commission, as Civil Service Commissioner in the administrations of governors Meyner and Hughes and as Borough Attorney for Fair Lawn. After playing a key role in the great era of New Jersey's development, Ballan went on to a career in private practice. Ballan lived for over half a century in Fair Lawn and was a member of the Fair Lawn Jewish Center, of which his father was a founding member. He is survived by the former Sally Roth, his wife of 55 years, his children Jonathan and Sandy Ballan, Harry and Judith Ballan, Jessica and Paul Julius, Carolyn and David Wasserman and fifteen grandchildren. The funeral service will be held at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel in Paramus on Sunday, July 10 at 11am, followed by burial at Beth El Cemetery in Paramus with military honors. The shiva period will be observed at 4622 Grosvenor Ave. in Riverdale, NY through Friday afternoon July 15. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to UJA-Federation of Bergen County.

CLEVELAND - The shortstop for the Cleveland Indians is a dazzling defensive player from Venezuela who switch-hits, wears No. 13 and first belonged to the Seattle Mariners. This was true in the 1990s, when Omar Vizquel helped the Indians to two American League pennants. It is true again today, with Asdrubal Cabrera. ''Omar's a once-in-a-generation player, maybe a once-in-a-lifetime player with his defensive abilities and all the things he was able to do,'' said Chris Antonetti, the Indians' general manager. ''I think Asdrubal is on his way to carving out his own mark and his own spot in the league. But to compare him to Omar, I don't think it's fair to either one.''

One number to remember this All-Star week: 82. That was the record number of players recognized as All-Stars in Anaheim last summer. If many more players follow the lead of the Yankees' Mariano Rivera, Derek Jeter and Alex Rodriguez, who all dropped out of Tuesday's game because of nagging injuries, there could be a new mark. Besides injuries, the rule preventing pitchers who start on Sunday from working in the All-Star Game will also swell the ranks. Making the Most of an Evening in Milan A friend and I will be spending a week in Venice in November. We will be flying home to New York City from Milan, and will have just one afternoon and evening there. Do you have any recommendations as to how to spend that short amount of time in Milan? What not to miss and where to have dinner? Amy Levitt, Port Washington, N.Y.

WOLFF--Jesse David. Our partner and former firm leader Jesse Wolff was a unique person who was a major contributor to our firm and those associated with it. His entire life as a lawyer was spent at the firm after he graduated from Harvard Law School in 1938 interrupted only by military service. Jesse was exceptional, not only in terms of his legal ability but also his humanity coupled with a sense of reality and his extraordinary judgment to the benefit of the firm and its clients. Jesse earned the respect of everyone who came in contact with him. He had uniform credibility not only because of his legal and other abilities but because he always called things "as they are." Jesse was in the tradition of great lawyers who did not specialize, but could manage and advise in many areas of the law and act as a problem solver. His "expertise" included art and the auction market, textiles, real estate and trust and estates. His imprint on the firm not only contributed significantly to its growth but also to its traditions and culture. He will be sorely missed. To Betty and their children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, we extend our deepest sympathy. It is our hope that his importance to us as individuals as well as to the firm as a whole is recognized. Jesse will always have our highest respect and affection. Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP its members, associates and employees
Theater Jason Zinoman

Why is ''Hamlet'' not a five-minute melodrama, but rather Shakespeare's longest play? Why, when hearing the truth from the ghost's mouth, is Hamlet able neither to speak it to anyone unambiguously nor to act on it? Philosophers, literary critics and psychoanalysts have offered diagnoses for Hamlet's procrastination. For some, Hamlet simply cannot make up his mind: he waits, hesitates and is divided from himself in his ''madness,'' all the while dreaming of a redeeming, cataclysmic violence. In this view, Hamlet is a creature of endless vacillation, a cipher for the alienated, inward modern self in a world that is insubstantial and rotten: ''Denmark's a prison,'' Hamlet sighs. For others, Hamlet is the great melancholic who is jealous of Claudius for realizing his own secret desire -- to usurp the place of his rival in the affection of his mother.

AZZEDINE ALAÏA has been busy these last eight years -- creating a shoe line with the help of Prada's factories, tidying up his house, expanding his ateliers with financing from Richemont. He has also been prolific as a designer. Remember the black crackled patent leather coats that fashionistas craved? Or the frilled knit dresses that Michelle Obama wore in Oslo and New York? Without his doing shows (not since 2003), without advertising, or being on Twitter, Mr. Alaïa has seen the world come to him. And ideally that's how it should be. People find him, or they want to talk about his clothes, because the work speaks so clearly for itself. Last March, when he gave me and Vanessa Friedman of The Financial Times a look at his fall ready-to-wear, he temptingly showed a few works in progress. With Mr. Alaïa, that's how it is: clothes are ready when they are ready, not before.

EXCLUSIVE LISTING A binding contract in which the seller agrees to pay the agent a commission no matter how a property is sold. MULTIPLE LISTING SERVICE Known as an M.L.S., this is a database of exclusive listings that is shared among members of a professional real estate association, like the National Association of Realtors. Yves Klein. Stéphane Mallarmé. Joni Mitchell. The color blue has served as inspiration for artists, poets and musicians, so why not Giorgio Armani? The designer showed an entirely blue collection this past spring, and this week he takes it to the perfume counter with the release of La Femme Bleue. “I wanted to create a fragrance that absolutely evoked the idea of the color blue,” Armani said. “I was inspired by my collection, which was itself inspired by the desert of the Tuareg nomads. I wished to create a rare and unique perfume that would stimulate certain olfactory senses and refer back to my fashion collection.” If notes like black iris and dark chocolate don’t say “rare and unique,” the fact that only 1,000 numbered bottles of La Femme Bleue were produced should do the trick. Not to mention the $600 price tag. At Giorgio Armani boutiques and Bergdorf Goodman.

Dog lovers with a pet allergy have a big problem when it comes to having a dog in the home. But the usual solution — getting a breed known to be hypoallergenic — may not be a safe bet. In fact, there may be no such thing as a low-allergy or allergy-free dog, according to a new report. The study found that the quantities of dog allergens in homes with supposedly hypoallergenic breeds are no different from those in homes with dogs widely considered non-hypoallergenic.

I wanted to add one other explanation — to those Catherine Rampell cited, in her much-discussed Sunday article — for why unemployment has not become a larger political issue. Given how high unemployment is, there are surprisingly few people who have experienced unemployment in the last couple of years. This is the flip side of the historically high average length of the unemployment: joblessness is concentrated among a subset of the population, rather than affecting a larger group of people for shorter periods of time.

Just because you aren’t tromping through snow and slush doesn’t mean your footwear doesn’t need T.L.C. Just ask David Mesquita. Along with his father, Carlos, David owns Leather Spa, New York’s go-to shoe repair. “Pre-treating shoes is actually a bigger part of our business than repairing destroyed ones,” says David, who sees some 500 pairs a day. The Barnes Foundation, the stupendous collection of Impressionist and early modernist painting and sculpture amassed by Albert C. Barnes, a pharmaceutical tycoon, has been one of the strangest and most affecting art institutions in America since the day it opened in 1925 in the Philadelphia suburb of Merion. Much of what made it extraordinary was the idiosyncratic way Barnes displayed the art, in an antiquated-looking salon style that filled entire walls of its neo-Classical home with odd arrangements of paintings, organized to echo and rhyme their formal qualities and interspersed with decorative metalwork like ax heads and hinges.

Something about the middle of May makes Aretha Franklin call me. For details on the most recent occurrence, see my profile of her in this weekend’s magazine. The first time, though, was more than 43 years ago, on May 18, 1968, a rainy day on Long Island and the day I received my First Communion. There was actually a trinity of holy events: the ceremony itself, with long lines of boys in navy blue suits and girls in white veils; then the family pancake breakfast at Howard Johnson’s; and finally, a trip to the local record store, where to mark the special occasion I was being allowed to pick out an entire album instead of my usual single.

The small bronze cobblestones can be easy to miss, but they are scattered, in plain sight, all over the streets of Prague and numerous other cities across Europe. Collectively these simple, handmade stone plaques, called Stolpersteine (“stumbling blocks”), conceived and designed by the German artist Gunter Demnig, comprise one of the largest Holocaust memorials in the world. They serve as poignant public markers, announcing to passersby that the buildings the stones are set in front of  were once the homes of men, women and children who were carted away and murdered by the Nazi regime during World War II.

During the convulsions that upended Yugoslavia in the 1990s, a secret came to light near the Bosnian town of Konjic. Today, it seems as remote as Yugoslavia itself.

CION--Judith Ann nee Schneider, 68, died July 6 at home in Connecticut after a five year valiant battle with ovarian cancer. Born in New York City to Peter and Ruth Schneider she graduated from high school in Scarsdale. Judy spent her childhood summers at Cape Cod in her family's summer home which she loved and later shared with her friends until it was sold after her father's death. After enrolling in college on the East Coast, she decided that a change of scenery was in order and transferred to Pomona College in Claremont, CA. After returning to the East Coast and graduating from Harvard Law School, Judy practiced law and held various positions, including, partner at Lovejoy, Wasson, head of the securities group at Mellon Bank, and general counsel at Hibernia Bank. Judy was a member of the Society of Corporate Secretaries and Governance Professionals and its Chairman from 1992-1993. She co-authored various publications on corporate governance. An expert in the field, she spent several years in Eastern Europe after the collapse of the Soviet Union and worked tirelessly with NGO's to assist Eastern European and former Soviet Bloc nations to build and maintain stable corporate and financial systems. Her love for theatre and modern dance, especially ballet, was unwavering. Among other positions, Judy was a Board Member of the New Orleans Ballet Association from 1992 through 1998. There was no show on Broadway or off-off Broadway that she did not attend. An avid traveler, Judy introduced her many friends to Golden Rock in Nevis and Rollins rum cocktails long before Nevis became fashionable. Judy applied her boundless energy to everything she did and everyone she met. She did not shy away from lively debate, especially political. Any left leaning liberal could always rely on her zealous support. She dispensed advice on any subject to close friends and new acquaintances alike. Judy was a stickler for the propriety of others, but not her own. She advised that houseguests were like fish and should be tossed out after three days. However, as a houseguest, her sojourns lasted longer than her prescription. She was an adventurous and industrious cook and baker to the delight and dismay of her friends. She once cooked broccoli rabe for 120 people for the Palio on Minetta Street and took charge of neighborhood children for set-up and table service. At Christmas, she manufactured her renowned spiced nuts and cookies for holiday delivery. Most of all Judy loved to entertain friends at home and her Thanksgiving dinners were produced as super sized crowd pleasers. After Hurricane Katrina and learning of her illness, Judy left New Orleans. Following a long search she found a new home in which she could celebrate her final Thanksgiving in the company of her closest friends. She purchased and renovated a house in Connecticut and continued those renovations until her death. Thanksgiving was her favorite holiday and her last one was joyfully celebrated with the family that she created through will and circumstance. Donations in Judy's memory may be made to The Joyce Theater Foundation (www.joyce.org) or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (www.mskcc.org). A gathering to celebrate Judy's life will be held in the Fall at a date to be determined. If you wish to be included in this event please register your interest at judycionMemorial@gmail.com

An article on June 6 about the complex legal facets of the sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn misstated the time period that an accuser has to file a civil lawsuit in such a matter. It could be years from the time of an alleged attack, depending on the circumstances; it is not necessarily ''only about a year.'' A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail the day the article was published. This correction was delayed because The Times failed to follow up on the complaint.

Popular mobile travel apps commonly feature maps and hints for navigating mass transit systems worldwide, restaurant ratings and condensed versions of printed city guides. All travel is local, so there are very local guides: Every Trail, for example, offers mobile versions of its Web guide to trips in 80 countries, including, in the United States, the Bright Angel Trail, above, in the Grand Canyon. There are also apps offering a live traffic report for Switzerland (Android), museums in Athens (Windows) and coupons for truck stops in the United States (BlackBerry). SHELLY FREIERMAN

An article on Thursday about diplomatic discussions between Israel and Turkey aimed at improving their relations, badly strained since the deadly Israeli raid on a Gaza-bound Turkish flotilla last year, misspelled, in some copies, the given name of the lead Turkish representative in the discussions. He is Ozdem Sanberk, not Ozden.

On Thursday night Sbtrkt was at Camp Bisco, the annual festival -- organized by the Disco Biscuits and held in upstate New York -- that rounds up the progressive end of the jam band and improvisational electronic music spectrum. On Friday night he was at Wrongbar, a sleek spot in Toronto, where the hip-hop superstar Drake stopped in for a quick collaborative performance. These are disparate worlds to bridge, but Sbtrkt (pronounced subtract) has something of each in him. That was clear on Saturday afternoon, when he played an outdoor show in the pavilion at MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, as part of the Warm Up series.

CHILSTROM--Robert. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the passing of our friend and colleague Robert Chilstrom. Bob had been a partner in the firm's corporate finance group for the past 25 years. A leader of our international corporate finance practice, he was the first head of our Foreign Intern Program and a model for intellectual mentorship. Bob was the Chairman of the Board of Trustees of The Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey, a member of the Board of Directors of the Metropolitan YMCA of the Oranges in New Jersey and an officer of the Winchester Gardens assisted living facility. He had a great passion for life and was a music lover and wine enthusiast. He will be deeply missed at the firm as a partner, colleague, mentor to younger lawyers and friend. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Buena, children Mikaela and Per, and the other members of his family.

GRIDLEY--Henry Meeker. On July 7th, 2011. Henry Meeker Gridley, born August 12, 1933, joined his beloved Ann who died in 1993. He died peacefully, yet unexpectedly, in his home in Saratoga Springs, NY. He is survived by his brother Bill and leaves his children, Nini, Leveritt and John Gridley, six grandsons and an enormous number of friends whose lives he touched. Harry was wounded in Korea earning a Purple Heart. A graduate of Taft ('51) and Yale ('58), he was a fine athlete; soccer was his game. He was all New England in 1957. He had a wonderful career in marketing starting with Lever Brothers, then introducing marketing skills at Harris Trust, then Mellon Bank and finally at Key Trust where he served as President for 12 years. His cell phone keeps ringing.

SEOUL -- It can sometimes feel as if South Korea, overworked, overstressed and ever anxious, is on the verge of a national nervous breakdown, with a rising divorce rate, students who feel suffocated by academic pressures, a suicide rate among the highest in the world and a macho corporate culture that still encourages blackout drinking sessions after work. More than 30 South Koreans kill themselves every day, and the suicides of entertainers, politicians, athletes and business leaders have become almost commonplace. The recent suicides of four students and a professor at Korea's leading university shocked the nation, and in recent weeks a TV baseball announcer, two professional soccer players, a university president and the former lead singer in a popular boy band killed themselves.

''Madness in great ones must not unwatch'd go.'' That well-turned observation was originally made about one Prince Hamlet, and doubtless it's useful advice regarding future heads of state. But the dictum applies equally to those who tread the stage. Few things test the mettle of an actor - or separate the artists from the hacks - like the simulation of a whopping case of mental illness. On one level, conveying the idea that you're out of your mind is a piece of cake (three layers, heavily frosted, lots of candles), in the same way that portraying drunkenness is. You or I could do it. Widen the eyes as far as possible, gnash the teeth until they threaten to crack, shake like a leaf in a hurricane and - voila - you're a certifiable basket case for public consumption. (For drunkenness, substitute: slur the words, squint the eyes and lean to one side until you almost fall over.)

WEINSTEIN--Barry M.,beloved husband of Anita for 48 years, devoted father of Eric and Marc, dear father-in-law of Sarah and Stephanie, adored grandfather of Eliana, Benji, Ari, Samantha, Chloe, and Matthew, and cherished son-in-law of Judith. His love and generosity will be sorely missed. Funeral service, Monday, July 11 at 12:45pm, at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. Donations in his name can be made to Hospice Care in the Berkshires, 877 South Street, Suite 1W, Pittsfield, MA 01201, or to Camp Ramah in the Berkshires Scholarship Fund.

SELINGER--Neil L.,of Larchmont, NY, age 57, on July 9 of ALS. He was a graduate of his beloved Columbia University (BA), New York University (JD), and an accomplished writer. He was tirelessly passionate about Springsteen and the Yankees. Neil will be deeply missed by family, friends, and a community that was inspired by his strength in the face of illness. He is survived by his mother, Helen Selinger; his wife, Rima Grad; and his three daughters, Hannah Selinger, Emily Selinger, and Julia Selinger. A memorial service will be held at Larchmont Temple at noon on July 13. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the ALS division of the Muscular Dystrophy Association.

Quidsi, the company that started Diapers.com, is doing all it can to make sure people can run their errands without getting off the couch. Next up: Wag.com, which sells pet supplies. Wag.com, introduced Wednesday, sells 10,000 pet items like food, litter, toys, clothing and grooming supplies. Quidsi, which was acquired by Amazon.com for $500 million last year, also runs Diapers.com for baby supplies, Soap.com for drugstore items and BeautyBar.com for cosmetics.

NBC News and Interactive One, a network of Web sites aimed at African-Americans, plan to announce a partnership on Monday that will combine the editorial and sales resources of both properties. The partnership will focus on aligning NBC's African-American news site, TheGrio.com, and Interactive One's news Web site, NewsOne.com. ''Now, for the first time, you have a news-gathering and producing organization solely dedicated to African-Americans at scale, and that really has not happened for decades,'' said Tom Newman, the president of Interactive One, a digital subsidiary of Radio One.

An article on Dec. 14 about disagreement among physicists over concentric ring patterns in the cosmic microwave background misspelled the surname of a University of British Columbia researcher who with his colleagues published a paper on the subject in December. He is James P. Zibin, not Zibrin. This correction was delayed because an e-mail sent in March pointing out the error went astray at The Times.

George T. M. Shackelford, chairman of art of Europe and curator of modern art at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, is moving to Texas to become senior deputy director of the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth. A leading scholar of late 19th- and early 20th-century French art, Mr. Shackelford is co-organizing ''Degas and the Nude,'' with Xavier Rey, curator of paintings at the Musee d'Orsay in Paris. The show is scheduled to open on Oct. 9 in Boston before going to Paris. During his years in Boston, Mr. Shackelford was responsible for many important acquisitions, including ''Duchessa di Montejasi with her Daughters, Elena and Camilla,'' an 1876 painting by Degas. He also oversaw the reinstallation of the museum's European art galleries and put together many major exhibitions, including ''Gauguin Tahiti,'' which was organized with the Reunion des Musees Nationaux and the Musee d'Orsay in 2003 and 2004, and ''Van Gogh: Face to Face,'' in 2000.

An extraordinary amount of personal income is coming directly from the government. Close to $2 of every $10 that went into Americans' wallets last year were payments like jobless benefits, food stamps, Social Security and disability, according to an analysis by Moody's Analytics. In states hit hard by the downturn, like Arizona, Florida, Michigan and Ohio, residents derived even more of their income from the government.

9 P.M. (Syfy) WAREHOUSE 13 The second season left fans of this show wondering if Myka Bering (Joanne Kelly) had left the team at the titular warehouse in South Dakota where the United States government keeps objects and artifacts that everyday Americans might find disruptive to a peaceful night's sleep. With Myka's status up in the air, Steve Jinks (Aaron Ashmore, above left, with Eddie McClintock), an agent for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms who is something of a human lie detector, becomes a new addition. 9 P.M. (History) AMERICAN PICKERS Fans of programs about found, fixed-up or haggled-over objects may delight in this episode, which pulls elements and principal players from three series in which stuff is the star. Frank Fritz and Mike Wolfe have a request to find a 1957 Chevy for Rick Harrison (''Pawn Stars''). The pickers find a classic car that could fit the bill, but it needs a makeover. Enter Rick Dale (''American Restoration''), who can bring back the car's appearance.

RUSSELL--Allen H.,Attorney, 87, died suddenly June 17, 2011. Much loved brother and uncle. Raised in Ilion, NY and long-time Manhattan resident. WWII, Purple Heart. Princeton University, Class of 1945. Harvard Law School, Class of 1949. Clerked for Chief Justice Harold Stevens, U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington, D.C., until joining Coudert Brothers in 1952, where he remained until retirement. A wonderful man. Memorial service to be announced in this section at a later date.

It's not surprising to us now that when you stop the treatment, people relapse. It doesn't mean that the treatment doesn't work, it just means that you need to continue treatment. DR. DANIEL ALFORD, on the limits of brief rehabilitation programs in treating addiction. [A13]

ROSS--George M. The Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts deeply mourns the passing of our Treasurer of the Board. George's passion and commitment transported the Center from conception through construction to current day.

WELLNER--Kenneth, Age 90, a man who well lived several lives, and inspired many others, died unexpectedly on July 2 after a determined battle with multiple medical afflictions. A self-proclaimed Yankee Doodle Dandy, Ken Wellner passionately loved this country, its freedoms and its opportunities. The son of the late Emil and Freida Wellner, Ken graduated from Stuyvesant High School and attended NYU before joining the Army in December, 1941, serving in the CBI, achieving the rank of Major and receiving the Bronze Star Medal. He considered his military service the greatest privilege. In civilian life he joined Wellner Motors in NYC, the family enterprise, which evolved into a mega automobile dealership. He was President of the Automobile Merchants Assn of New York in 1958 and 1959, and eventually created and Chaired The Kemwel Group, a European car rental with close ties to the travel industry. Despite a debilitating motor neuron disorder, Ken Wellner was an avid sailor, a talented photographer and author of five privately published novels which he wrote while in his 80s. Ken Wellner was a deeply loyal friend, a man of insatiable curiosity, relentless humor and optimism, and undeniable charm. He never permitted his medical issues to interfere with living a full life, and became quite a terror on his scooter which provided mobility during his final year. He relished entertaining in his homes in Mamaroneck, NY; NYC; and Rancho Mirage, CA, and invariably provoked spirited political conversation. His own extraordinary spirit will endure in all who knew him. Ken Wellner is predeceased by first wife Barbara (Bronstein), second wife Eyrun (Herbertsdottir), brother Maurice and his adored son, Rick. He is survived by his wife and best friend, JoAnn (Giffuni) who he affectionately called Murgy, nephew Michael Wellner, niece Susan Merrett (Mark), and their children and daughter-in-law, Gabrielle Wellner. Donations in Ken's memory are suggested to NYU Langone Medical Center, ED Development, One Park Ave, 17th Flr., NY, NY 10016, attn: Donna Marino or to WNET-THIRTEEN, 825 8th Ave, NY, NY 10019 attn: P. Hayes, notating "For the continuing production of Richard Heffner's Open Mind." A celebration of Ken's life will be held at a later time.

BRENNAN--Edward Michael. Born in New York City, August 19th, 1936, passed away in Miami Beach, July 6th, 2011. Beloved brother of Patrick and Gerald. Preceded by parents Patrick and Mary Ellen and brother Kevin, long-time special friend of Betty Brennan. A private memorial with family and close friends will be held at a later date. Donations can be made to his favorite charity, Doctors Without Borders.

ROSS--George M. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, George M. Ross and extends sincere sympathy to his children, grandchildren and other members of his family. Arthur S. Loring, President

You might think a long quiet walk through the woods with Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, is a treat only his closest friends and dearest family get to enjoy. Yet a chummy stroll with one of the richest men in the world is actually reserved for a few select potential Facebook employees. Although the hiking path is often the same, through a wooded area of Palo Alto that skirts Stanford University, those invited change each time.

WOLFF--Jesse David. Our partner and former firm leader Jesse Wolff was a unique person who was a major contributor to our firm and those associated with it. His entire life as a lawyer was spent at the firm after he graduated from Harvard Law School in 1938 interrupted only by military service. Jesse was exceptional, not only in terms of his legal ability but also his humanity coupled with a sense of reality and his extraordinary judgment to the benefit of the firm and its clients. Jesse earned the respect of everyone who came in contact with him. He had uniform credibility not only because of his legal and other abilities but because he always called things "as they are." Jesse was in the tradition of great lawyers who did not specialize, but could manage and advise in many areas of the law and act as a problem solver. His "expertise" included art and the auction market, textiles, real estate and trust and estates. His imprint on the firm not only contributed significantly to its growth but also to its traditions and culture. He will be sorely missed. To Betty and their children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, we extend our deepest sympathy. It is our hope that his importance to us as individuals as well as to the firm as a whole is recognized. Jesse will always have our highest respect and affection. Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP its members, associates and employees

ROSS--George M. Prominent philanthropist, businessman and civic leader, beloved husband and partner of 51 years of Lyn (nee Goldberg) cherished father of Merry Ross (Patrick Zimski) and Michael (Nancy) Ross and adoring grandfather to Zoe and Phoebe Zimski, died peacefully at home in Bryn Mawr, PA on July 8th surrounded by his family. George, who also lived in Palm Beach, FL, died after a heroic battle with lung cancer. He was born in 1933, son of the late Beatrice and the late David Rosenkoff, in West Philadelphia and throughout his adult life made a difference in the lives of many people. After graduating from Drexel University in 1955, George began his successful career with Goldman Sachs & Co. in 1959. In 1971, he became one of their youngest partners managing their Philadelphia regional office and the only person from that office to be named a partner in the firm. Among his many accomplishments with the firm, George was proud of hiring and mentoring many talented young people who were successful in business and philanthropy. One of George's most significant civic achievements was, as Co-Chair of the Board of the National Museum of American Jewish History (NMAJH), he almost single-handed raised the funds to build the new Museum, by traveling across the country with passion and tireless determination. The NMAJH opened in November 2010 on Independence Mall. George also was a leader in the creation of the Kimmel Center where he served on the board and as Treasurer. George was loyal to his alma mater, Drexel University. In recognition of his service and many significant contributions to Drexel, including serving on the Board and as its Chair, the Hillel House named in memory of his parents as well as the Lyn and George Ross Commons, George was presented with the Drexel University Business Leader of the Year Medal in 1989 and received an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters in 1999. George's other communal leadership roles included co-founding Operation Understanding in 1985 with Congressman William Gray.This program brings Jewish and African American youths together to travel to Israel and Africa in order to appreciate each other's history and form lasting relationships while assuming leadership roles in their respective communities. George also served on the Boards of the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Jewish Federation of Greater Philadelphia, and the United Way of Southeastern Pennsylvania where he led the One to One Mentoring Partnership, to make a positive difference in the lives of young people in the Greater Philadelphia region. George also was a member of the Palm Beach Country Club, where he served as Treasurer. In addition to his wife, children and grandchildren, George is survived by his brother Charles (Marilyn) Ross, his mother-in law Evelyn Goldberg, several nieces and nephews as well as many friends and colleagues who will miss him deeply. Relatives and friends are invited to services, Tuesday, July 12, 2011 at 12 Noon at the National Museum of American Jewish History, 101 South Independence Square East, Philadelphia, PA. The family will return to the late residence and respectfully request that contributions in his memory be made to the National Museum of American Jewish History 101 South Independence Square East, Philadelphia, PA 19106 or to a charity of the donor's choice.

Another weekend, another splash in the cinematic sewer. Paramount's ''Transformers: Dark of the Moon'' remained a huge No. 1 at North American theaters with $47 million in ticket sales ($261 million to date). But it was the unexpectedly strong performance of ''Horrible Bosses'' - noted by critics for its homophobia and misogyny - that caught Hollywood's attention. ''Horrible Bosses,'' which cost the New Line division of Warner Brothers about $35 million to make and is rated R, sold an estimated $28 million in tickets for second place, proving that audiences are anything but weary of crude comedies. (Still to come this summer: ''Friends With Benefits,'' in which Justin Timberlake uses an iPhone app to detect menstrual cycles, and ''The Change-Up,'' featuring a baby defecating on Jason Bateman's face.) ''Zookeeper,'' a family comedy that cost Sony Pictures Entertainment and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer $80 million to make, was a soft third with about $21 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. That result, which a Sony spokesman called ''solid,'' was in line with prerelease expectations.

Chaos is expected to descend on Los Angeles on July 16, when a 10-mile stretch of I-405, a major highway running through the center of town that carries an average of 500,000 cars on a summer weekend, shuts down for more than two days. Anxiety is palpable. Public officials have suggested that people simply stay in their houses. Last week the Los Angeles Police Department, concerned that people might not get its warnings through conventional channels, asked celebrities like Lady Gaga to send messages about the closure to their followers on Twitter.

The Barnes Foundation, the stupendous collection of Impressionist and early modernist painting and sculpture amassed by Albert C. Barnes, a pharmaceutical tycoon, has been one of America's strangest and most affecting art museums from the day its doors opened in 1925 in the Philadelphia suburb of Merion. It is difficult now, looking at the artists Barnes loved -- Cézanne, Renoir, Matisse, Picasso, Modigliani, Seurat --to grasp just how revolutionary such a collection was at the time he was building it. And the way Barnes exhibited the works -- filling walls with paintings in odd arrangements to echo and rhyme their formal qualities -- made the gallery a monument to his eccentric vision. Now, in some ways, the Barnes will certainly become more like other American museums. After a 2004 judge's ruling permitting the foundation to bypass Barnes's rigid charter and bylaws, which stipulated that no picture could be lent, sold or moved from the walls of the galleries he built, the collection is moving from its Merion home to a new building in downtown Philadelphia, expected to be completed next year. Right, a final look at a room from the Merion museum, which closed to the public at the end of June. RANDY KENNEDY COLOR

ROSS--George. The Trustees, leadership and staff of the National Museum of American Jewish History mourn the loss of our dear friend and the co-chairman of our Board. His vision and passion were critical to the creation of our new Museum. George was an extraordinarily generous philanthropist and community leader who supported many causes, but his contributions to the Museum were paramount. Through his leadership, dedication and generosity, George shaped this institution into the central home for the evolving and vibrant story of American Jewish life. We will forever be grateful for the enduring legacy he leaves us. We offer our heartfelt condolences to our beloved Lyn and their children Merry (Patrick Zimski) Ross, Michael (Nancy) Ross, granddaughters Zoe and Phoebe Zimski and brother Charles (Marilyn) Ross. May his memory be a blessing. The family requests that gifts in his memory be sent to NMAJH, 101 S. Independence Mall East, Philadelphia, PA 19106. Ronald Rubin, Co-Chairman of the Board of Trustees, Michael Rosenzweig, President and CEO and Ivy Barsky, Gwen Goodman Director and COO.

The police have not offered any explanation for why the suspect chose the building, beyond noting that the man, an aspiring actor, appeared intoxicated.

Long odds have never seemed to bother Barney Adams, the amiable inventor, club maker and founder of Adams Golf, a company that defied experts to become one of the top sellers of hybrids and fairway woods. Evidently, they still don't, because he recently came out of retirement at 72 to take on what may be his biggest challenge yet. Adams's new quest is to change the attitudes of millions of recreational golfers by persuading them to Tee It Forward. As the point man in a national effort to, among other things, ''put the fun back into golf,'' Adams is working pro bono with the P.G.A. of America, the United States Golf Association and the Golf Course Superintendents Association of America to introduce golfers to a whole new world: the enjoyment of hitting shorter clubs into greens, the opportunity for more birdies and pars, and the prospect of faster rounds.

The Civil War famously pitted brother against brother, but it also pitted comrade against comrade: especially in the opposing officer corps, the Union and Confederate armies were staffed with men who had earlier served on the same side, and in many cases were even at West Point together, both as students and instructors. One of the themes of Michael Shaara’s classic novel “The Killer Angels” is the close relationship between Lewis Armistead, who attended West Point but did not graduate, and Winfield Scott Hancock (class of 1844), who opposed each other at Gettysburg. No fewer than 20 members of the class of 1846 became Civil War general officers: 10 of them Union, 10 Confederate.
The House of Representatives has rejected an effort to repeal a requirement that incandescent light bulbs become more energy-efficient.

On Friday, I wrote about Friendfactor, an organizing tool used in the successful battle for gay marriage in New York State.  Friendfactor combines social media and real-world friendship to motivate people to get active.  Instead of getting an e-mail from a group asking you to support a political goal, you get one from a close friend or family member asking you to “help me get my full rights.”    Friendfactor is particularly interesting because it seems to offer a solution to one of the biggest obstacles in using social media for political change:  people need close personal connections in order to get them to take action — especially if that action is risky and difficult.
In the aftermath of the earthquake and tsunami that struck Japan, three high schools from affected areas came together to create a baseball team.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened an inquiry into Fletcher Asset Management, a New York hedge fund run by Alphonse Fletcher Jr., a prominent Wall Street investor, according to a person with direct knowledge of the situation.

A leading forecaster of advertising spending is reducing its forecast for this year, citing factors ranging from rising oil prices to European debt woes. But the reduction amounts to a bit, a tad, a trim — much less than the downward adjustment recently made by another forecaster.

Bloomberg turned Tuesday into something of a plug-in car day in New York City, announcing the addition of 70 new plug-in hybrid and purely electric vehicles for government fleets, as well as the start of Drive Electric NYC, a Web site aimed at helping city residents learn about E.V.’s. “Half of U.S. social program recipients believe they ‘have not used a government social program,’ ” according to a paper by Suzanne Mettler, a professor at Cornell, posted on Boing Boing. And, yes, that includes everyone who has ever taken a mortgage deduction, taken out a student loan or collected Social Security upon retirement. If you’re wondering why it’s so difficult to come to an agreement on the debt ceiling and taxes, it may be because, as Cory Doctorow writes, we live in “a society of people who subsist on mutual aid and redistributive policies who’ve been conned (and conned themselves) into thinking that they are rugged individualists and that everyone else is a parasite.”

Following up on the reader letters that appeared in my print column for this week, here are some additional letters via e-mail to my last three columns, Surrounded by Opinion, the Times Raises Its Voices, On NYTimes.com, Now You See It, Now You Don’t and Where Words Can Never Do Justice.Thank you, stateless soul, for your informative discussion of feedback on the new Sunday Review in the Times July 3. I cannot convey how much I dislike the new format. I, like the feedback you mentioned, sorely miss the political cartoons and the late-night television gag lines. The weekly news is dire enough without taking away our opportunity to laugh while we are informed. The political cartoons were always the first thing I turned to on a Sunday morning. Wouldn’t Art Buchwald turn over in his grave to see you eliminate his life’s work?

“Why did you come here when no one else does?” The African Union communications director asked us over dinner at its compound in Mogadishu. Good question. We were warned against it, especially by war-zone regulars. It’s been called the most dangerous city—or place—on earth. In fact, we had to delay our trip for two weeks due to multiple suicide bombings and riots inside the area controlled by Mogadishu’s transitional government (TFG). So, why go? I gave the short answer, “We’re supporting a local social entrepreneur in launching a sexual violence hotline.”

A $16 million musical production of “Rebecca,” based on the classic 1938 novel by Daphne du Maurier, has been scaled down to a budget of about $12 million — largely thanks to the loss of a collapsing staircase special effect — and is now on track for Broadway, the producers announced on Tuesday. More bad news on the job market front: the number of jobless workers per job opening stayed flat at 4.7 in May, according to a new report from the Labor Department. That is more than twice the average ratio seen during the boom years that preceded the Great Recession.

The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.Experts have always posed a problem for democracies.  Plato scorned democracy, rating it the worst form of government short of tyranny, largely because it gave power to the ignorant many rather than to knowledgeable experts (philosophers, as he saw it).  But, if, as we insist, the people must ultimately decide, the question remains: How can we, nonexperts, take account of expert opinion when it is relevant to decisions about public policy?

Summer sojourners to Provincetown, Mass., typically have an object in sight: a breezy beach, a lobster roll, a parade of thousands. The tiny, affluent sandbar on the northern tip of Cape Cod remains a low-key, largely gay resort town for the summer — except during theme weeks, when the population swells to more than 100,000, many of them bopping to a heavy disco beat. Every tribe has its week in P-town: there’s Bear Week (happening now), Family Pride Week (July 30-Aug. 6) and by late August it’s time for Carnival (Aug. 14-19). That means rollicking street parties, colorful floats and an infinite supply of garish costumes.

Juggling parental concern with an adolescent patient’s legal and ethical right to privacy opens up some tricky questions.
A drought that some say could rival the Dust Bowl has spread from Florida to Arizona.
Unseen pollutants can cause ailments of the ears, eyes, skin, nervous system, gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts, and any cut or scratch you may have.
Swimmers and their guardians can easily prevent an overwhelming majority of accidents and tragedies.
The only suspect arrested in the case of a woman mutilated for leaving her husband has been released, in a move that has angered human rights advocates and the woman’s family.
As research budgets tighten, a new crop of Web-savvy scientists is hoping the wisdom and generosity of crowds will come to the rescue.
A robot was programmed to recognize and fold towels.

A study says that until the whaling industry depleted their ranks, California gray whales thrived for millions of years during ice ages that cut off their migration routes and compromised their diets.
A report found that in 92 percent of the cases in which an Alabama judge overrode a juries’ recommendation, the judge imposed the death sentence over life in prison.
The large and deadly accidental blast leveled a munitions storage facility on Monday, killing at least 12 people and wounding dozens more.
As a result of myriad obstacles, just 10 percent of adults over age 60 were vaccinated against shingles in 2009 in the United States.
There are several kinds of involuntary jaw movements, and it is important to distinguish chattering from grinding.
They can crank out cars, conduct surgery and win on “Jeopardy!” But in challenges of perception and motion that humans handle effortlessly, robots have a long way to go.
A Russian passenger plane caught fire and crash landed in a Siberian river on Monday, prompting fresh concerns about the safety of Russia’s aging Soviet-era aircraft.
Syrian government supporters stormed into the American Embassy compound in Damascus on Monday and vandalized the building, according to news reports.
Donald Ray Pollock has followed his 2008 short-story collection, “Knockemstiff,” with a novel, also set in the Ohio town of that redolent name.
Three different but equally theatrical productions in London provide a kind of catharsis for theatergoers who are fed up with the hypocrites who rule their worlds.
Financial markets reflected rising fears that Italy could become the next victim of Europe’s debt crisis.
Shortly before a riverboat on the Volga lurched to one side and then slowly capsized, an estimated 40 children had been moved into an interior play area.
Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is trying to push Prime Minister Nuri Kamal-al Maliki to make a decision on American troops.
At three-day talks, issues like Taiwan and the South China Sea are likely to remain divisive.
European finance ministers promised on Monday to lighten lending terms for struggling countries like Greece and suggested that the existing bailout fund be expanded.
Reports surfaced that two of Rupert Murdoch’s newspapers may have bribed police officers to obtain information about Queen Elizabeth II and former Prime Minister Gordon Brown.
At least six people were killed and 15 were wounded when a suicide bomber detonated explosives in northern Pakistan on Monday, according to reports in local media.
With the aid of the European Space Agency’s Herschel Space Observatory, astronomers detected enough cosmic dust, emitted from a supernova first seen almost 25 years ago, to form 200,000 Earths.
A study suggests that even after sophisticated jaw types emerged, fish with and without them coexisted for at least 10 million years.

Throughout Europe's debt crisis, Italy has largely managed to steer clear of the troubles that have engulfed its profligate Mediterranean neighbors. But the contagion that started in the euro zone's smaller countries is suddenly moving to some of its largest. As Greece teeters on the brink of a default, the game has changed: Investors are taking aim at any country suffering from a combination of high debt, slow growth and political dysfunction -- and Italy has it all, in spades.

WEISS--Andrew M. A lifetime resident of New York City, died on July 9th at the age of 90. He leaves behind his beloved wife Marilyn, whom he was married to for 65 years, his children John, Dana and Andrew Jr, brother Ira and grandchildren Genny, Zach and Miles. He was a 1943 graduate of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill where he was an active member of the Varsity swimming team. He accelerated his graduation in order to volunteer for his country in WWII serving in both the Marines and Coast Guard with active duty in the Atlantic. He went on to a distinguished career in advertising and continued to be a champion swimmer entering races until the age of 89. He was an avid collector of antiques and art, a craftsman and an Opera buff. He had an unsurpassed zest for life and will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Visiting will be from 4-8pm Wednesday and Thursday (July 13-14). For details, please contact a family member. Donations may be made in his memory to the UNC-CH swimming program.

Updated 5:24 p.m. | The Manhattan district attorney's office and the lawyers for Dominique Strauss-Kahn have agreed to postpone the next hearing in the sexual assault case against him for two weeks in order to give both sides more time to conduct their investigations, according to a letter filed with the court on Monday. The move - which pushes the next hearing to Aug. 1 from July 18 - comes as prosecutors have been weighing whether to dismiss the charges against Mr. Strauss-Kahn because of what they have characterized as issues with the credibility of his accuser.

STEIN--Juliet. On July 10 at age 73. She was a fun-loving free spirit who managed her family lumber business, graduated college at 70 and made beautiful art. She was ahead of her time and will be greatly missed by her beloved mother, sisters and brothers-in-law, children and sons-in-law, grandchildren and friends. Funeral services at 11:15am July 12, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St, NY. Private interment to follow.

He was a skinny Italian-American kid from Hoboken, N.J., who could croon like an angel. Before long, his singing made women swoon and grown men cry. For decades, he sang standards to adoring crowds worldwide, including, notably, ''My Way.'' He had brown eyes.

A common complaint has been the absence of prosecution of financial executives for their role in the economic crisis, according to White Collar Watch. But what is equally striking is the large compensation those executives received while their companies pursued risky policies that led to the crisis. Seeking to address the issue, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is pursuing claims against former top executives at Washington Mutual, which became the largest bank failure in history. It has also adopted a new clawback rule for failed banks. PETER J. HENNING

Barry Bremen, a novelty-goods salesman who achieved a kind of flash celebrity in the 1980s as a ubiquitous impostor who slipped past security to shag fly balls in the major leagues, shoot baskets in the N.B.A. and accept somebody else's Emmy Award on national television, died on June 30 in Phoenix. He was 64. The cause was esophageal cancer, his family said.

WASHINGTON - Last week Tim Pawlenty was reluctant to criticize Representative Michele Bachmann, a fellow Minnesotan and one of his chief rivals for the Republican presidential nomination, saying in an interview only that ''everybody brings different strengths to the table.'' But now, that reluctance appears to be waning. In an interview Sunday on ''Meet the Press'' on NBC, and again on Fox News on Monday morning, Mr. Pawlenty, a former Minnesota governor, derided Mrs. Bachmann's record as a member of Congress and her lack of executive experience.

BARRETT--Janet McDonald. A wonderful mother died at 94 in her home in Bronxville, New York. Born in Indiana, she graduated from Smith College, and was the daughter of James G. McDonald, the first U.S. Ambassador to Israel. She is survived by her five children, Donald, Vail, June, Sandra and Cynthia, five grandchildren and her sister, Barbara Stewart. A memorial service will be held at The Reformed Church of Bronxville on Friday, July 15th at 11:00am.

WITTLIN--Barbara. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of the beloved wife of our dedicated benefactor, Harry Wittlin. To Harry, and to the entire family, our heartfelt sympathy. Rabbi Marc Schneier Morris Tuchman, President Seymour Siegel, Treasurer

An article on Monday about projected earnings for Wall Street banks misidentified the agency that recently halted auctions of mortgage bonds from the American International Group. It was the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, not the Treasury.
''A funny thing happened on the way to this forum.'' So opened the latest ruling from the ever-lively Judge Jed. S. Rakoff, a federal judge in Manhattan.
SHECHTER--Samuel. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends sympathy to his family. David J. Nathan Parnas

The actors Jonathan Groff and Rutina Wesley have played characters in emotionally charged tight spots before, he in Broadway's ''Spring Awakening'' (and in diva showdowns on Fox's ''Glee'') and she on HBO's ''True Blood'' as Sookie's troubled friend Tara. This fall the two will find themselves together in a pickle of their own making in the new Off Broadway play ''The Submission,'' which MCC Theater is producing at the Lucille Lortel Theater. In the play, Jeff Talbott's debut work, Mr. Groff will play Danny Larsen, an aspiring playwright with a new drama about an alcoholic black mother, which he has written under the nom de plume Shaleeha G'ntamobi. Details about Ms. Wesley's role remain under wraps, though her character becomes caught up in Danny's subterfuge. Joining them in the cast are Eddie Kaye Thomas (Off Broadway's ''Bachelorette,'' the ''American Pie'' movies) as the boyfriend of Mr. Groff's character, and Will Rogers (''When the Rain Stops Falling'') as a friend of Danny.

Prince Twins Seven-Seven, a prominent Nigerian artist and leading representative of the Oshogbo School, whose brightly colored, intricately patterned paintings evoked the world of Yoruba folklore and religion, died on June 16 in Ibadan, Nigeria. He was 67. The cause was complications of a stroke, Harriet B. Schiffer, his dealer, said.

OXENBERG--Morris, died at age 97, July 11, 2011, at home in Atlantic City, NJ. Born on January 28, 1914 in Philadelphia, PA, the youngest of three sons of Jacob and Blima (Marcus). With his business partner, he owned and operated a thriving hat store in Philadelphia, Stanmor Hats, for many years. He is survived by his niece, Judith Rubin, and his nephew, Robert Oakes, and their families, and caregivers Lynne Armstrong and Liese Pfoertner. Graveside service will be held at noon, Thursday, July 14, Beth Israel Cemetery, Black Horse Pike, Egg Harbor Township, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Shore Memorial Health Foundation, 1 East New York Avenue, Somers Point, NJ 08244.

''It's a nice little slog to get up there,'' Richard Melnick said. ''Just like why people climb mountains.'' With that, he went up the concrete stairs, leading the way to something most New Yorkers think of as a horizontal landmark, not a vertical one: the Robert F. Kennedy Bridge. Of course, that was not the name on his lips -- aficionados like Mr. Melnick still call it the Triborough Bridge. More about that later.

SUBBIONDO--Ralph A. The Board of Directors and staff of HeartShare Human Services of New York deeply mourn the untimely passing of Board Chairman, Ralph A. Subbiondo, on July 9th. Mr. Subbiondo served on the Board for 15 years and as Chairman for nine years. He was 63 years of age and is survived by his loving and devoted wife Ava, his children Susan and David Shindler and Frances Subbiondo, his grandchildren Oliver and Roselyn Shindler, his dear mother Ann Subbiondo and his brother and sister-in-law Charles Subbiondo and Jennifer Kahane. Mr. Subbiondo was a CPA and a retired Ernst and Young LLP partner and also had served as Chief Financial Officer of The Bush-Clinton Katrina Fund. He leaves a distinguished legacy of community service. A memorial service will be held in New York on August 27th. The family requests all remembrances be sent to HeartShare Human Services, 12 MetroTech Center - 29th Fl., Brooklyn, NY, 11201 Attn: Public Affairs Office.

Just hours before his band was to open for Soundgarden on Sunday, the bass player for Coheed and Cambria, the alternative rock band from Nyack, N.Y., was arrested on charges of robbing a pharmacy in Massachusetts to get prescription painkillers, the Associated Press reported. The police said the bassist, Mike Todd, entered the Walgreens pharmacy in Attleboro, Mass., on Sunday afternoon and showed the pharmacists a note on his telephone claiming he had a bomb. Mr. Todd, who is 30, was said to have demanded six bottles of OxyContin and then caught a cab to the Comcast Center in Mansfield, Mass., where his band was to play the opening set before Soundgarden took the stage. He was arrested at the concert hall before the show and charged with armed robbery and possession of a controlled substance, the police said. The band played without him.

SACHS--Harold B. 86 died July 10th at home. Beloved husband of Doris to who he was married for forty years. Also survived by his children from his first marriage Gene Sachs, Harold Jr, Amy Lee and Nancy Barelie and his step-children Nancy Jacob and Stephen Blum. Grandchildren Chris, Colin, Carol, Patrick Megan, Michelle, Jessica, Elena and Matthew. His life was a blessing to those fortunate to know him. Funeral services will be held Wednesday at 12:45pm at Riverside Chapel 76st and Amsterdam Ave.
Damn it, make a decision. LEON E. PANETTA, the defense secretary, on whether Iraq's government will ask some American troops to remain into 2012. [A8]

9 P.M. (BBC America) GORDON RAMSAY'S GREAT ESCAPE Taking a break from expressing frustration and disapproval toward would-be chefs, Gordon Ramsay heads to India and Southeast Asia for new challenges and inspiration. In this episode he visits Vietnam to sample barbecue duck, basket-caught squid and a snake heart that is still beating. Along the way Mr. Ramsay, above in Thailand, demonstrates some of the skills that have earned him 12 Michelin stars: he sells more than 80 broths at a floating market, makes rice cakes in Mai Chau and prepares a pork dinner for local foodies. 8 P.M. (Food) CUPCAKE WARS Four bakers fight for sweet supremacy to be able to serve a party at the most recent Tony Awards ceremony. On ''Chopped,'' at 10, four British chefs must incorporate an American staple, a snack food from Japan and something familiar from their home country into the creation of different dishes.

SELINGER--Neil L.,of Larchmont, NY, age 57, on July 9 of ALS. He was a graduate of his beloved Columbia University (BA), New York University (JD), and an accomplished writer. He was tirelessly passionate about Springsteen and the Yankees. Neil will be deeply missed by family, friends, and a community that was inspired by his strength in the face of illness. He is survived by his mother, Helen Selinger; his wife, Rima Grad; and his three daughters, Hannah Selinger, Emily Selinger, and Julia Selinger. A memorial service will be held at Larchmont Temple at noon on July 13. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the ALS division of the Muscular Dystrophy Association.

Manuel Galbán, a Cuban guitarist best known for his work with the all-star ensemble Buena Vista Social Club and its various offshoots, died on Thursday in Havana. He was 80. The cause was cardiac arrest, said World Circuit Records, the British label for which he most recently recorded.
ROWER--Mary. Beloved neighbor and friend. Eve, Kara, Eddie, Amanda and Nina

SHECHTER--Samuel David. The Musher-Shechter-Patino Family is saddened to announce the passing of our beloved husband, father, father-in-law and "Pop Pop" on July 11th at Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem. His devotion to Jewish education and scholarship and his warm hospitality enriched his life and those of his family, his friends and his colleagues. Evi, Naomi, Josh, Rafi, Miguel, Shira, Shoshi, Jeremy, Yoni and Thomas. Funeral Services: Tuesday, July 12 at 2pm Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave.

Five years have passed since the Food and Drug Administration approved a vaccine against shingles. By now, experts had expected a substantial proportion of people older than 60, the most vulnerable population, to be protected from outbreaks of this nasty viral disease and the persistent, debilitating pain it can leave behind. Indeed, the vaccine, called Zostavax, could so sharply reduce the number of adults who suffer from shingles -- currently more than one million a year -- that in March, the Food and Drug Administration approved its use by those ages 50 and older. But even with this weapon at the ready, the campaign against shingles has bogged down. Some experts say it never really got under way.

RIZZO--Dr. Connie, age 51, on July 6, 2011. Medical doctor, Ph.D. from Columbia University, taught science at Marymount Manhattan College, published in medical journals, also a nutritionist. Consultant to the New York City Department of Education and the American Museum of Natural History. She had a brilliant mind and a generous heart. Connie will be missed by all who knew her.

JAMES--Ardis Butler, of Stamford, CT, previously of Chappaqua, NY, died July 7, 2011 at the age of 85. Ardis was a native of Nebraska and received a honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree from Doane College in Crete, Nebraska in 2010. Ardis was survived by her husband, Robert G. James of Stamford CT, her daughter Catherine (Louis) Paglia of Greenwich CT, her son Ralph (Janice) James of Swampscott, MA, and her grandchildren Gregory James, Katherine James, Rebecca James, Samuel Paglia and Helen Paglia. She was preceded in death by her son, Robert G. James Jr. Ardis' greatest passion in life after her family was her love of quilting and fabric arts. She began collecting quilts in 1976 and, together with her husband, assembled an extensive and influential collection of antique and contemporary quilts. In 1997, they donated their collection of nearly 1000 quilts to the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and founded the International Quilt Study Center & Museum, known as Quilt House. The mission of Quilt House is to collect, preserve, study, exhibit and promote discovery of quilts and quilt-making traditions from many cultures, countries and times. Ardis was an active member of the Mt. Kisco Presbyterian Church and was an elder in the Presbyterian Church for many years. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held on August 24, 2011 at 10:00am at Mt. Kisco Presbyterian Church, Mt. Kisco, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Quilt House, International Quilt Study Center, University of Nebraska Foundation, 1010 Lincoln Mall, Suite 300, Lincoln, NE 68508. To leave online condolences, please visit www.cognetta.com

As the White House and Congress wrangle over raising the debt ceiling and reducing the federal deficit, tax loopholes would seem to be an easy target for compromise. President Obama has talked about eliminating breaks for partners at hedge funds and private equity firms - along with corporate jet owners, oil companies and others taking advantage of quirks in the tax codes.

This year, a Seattle nurse named Kim Hiatt committed suicide. Ms. Hiatt's death came nearly seven months after she had given an unintended overdose to an infant heart patient, a medical error that was said to have contributed to the child's death days later. Ms. Hiatt had been a nurse for 27 years and had often cared for the 8-month-old girl during the child's stay in the pediatric intensive care unit of her hospital. She had probably drawn up the right dose of the drug hundreds of times in her career. But once, she made a life-changing error. A baby died, and she was suspended, then fired from a profession she loved. And now she's dead. This story makes me feel sick -- sick for that dead baby and her parents, and sick for Kim, who must have felt so alone with her pain.
INTERNATIONAL ONLY SUSPECT IS FREED

As the White House and Congress wrangle over raising the debt ceiling and reducing the federal deficit, tax loopholes would seem to be an easy target for compromise. President Obama has talked about eliminating breaks for partners at hedge funds and private equity firms - along with corporate jet owners, oil companies and others taking advantage of quirks in the tax codes.

There's always been an unspoken rule about Wall Street thrillers: brand matters. In this genre, an office visitor never simply takes a drink of water; he sips Sanfaustino. A trader doesn't get nervous when his picks aren't hitting; he begins fiddling with his Hermes tie. Bankers aren't well dressed; they are ''suited in the battle rattle of Armani pinstripes and Gucci loafers.''

REMEMBER the fun you had with your favorite toys and games while growing up? Toymakers are hoping you do, and they are hoping that you are sharing the experience with your children. Toy companies have long used nostalgia to lure adults back to their childhood favorites while updating those same toys to attract a new generation of children.

''Bet you can't eat just one'' (as the old potato-chip commercials had it) is, of course, a bet most of us end up losing. But why? Is it simple lack of willpower that makes fatty snacks irresistible, or are deeper biological forces at work? Some intriguing new research suggests the latter. Scientists in California and Italy reported last week that in rats given fatty foods, the body immediately began to release natural marijuanalike chemicals in the gut that kept them craving more.

MILLARD--Walter J.,on July 11 at his home in Tel Aviv surrounded by his family. Devoted husband to Eda z"l. Loving father to Carole (Eliezer), Amy, Judith (Bruce), Wendy (Joe) and Diana. Beloved grandfather of Ari (Nok), Sivan, Michal, Yonatan, Jacob, Anna, Emily, Katie, Jeffrey. Great-grandfather of Zoe and Lynn. Caring brother to Marion. Donations in his memory may be made to The JCC of West Hempstead. May his memory be for a blessing.

Robert Sklar, a film scholar whose 1975 book ''Movie-Made America'' was one of the first histories to place Hollywood films in a social and political context, finding them a key to understanding how modern American values and beliefs have been shaped, died on Saturday in Barcelona. He was 74. The cause was a brain injury sustained in a bicycle accident, his son Leonard said.

A trader doesn't get nervous when his picks aren't hitting; he begins fiddling with his Hermes tie.
