An article on Sunday about baseball's role in helping students in Japan resume a routine following the earthquake and tsunami this year misstated the given name of the baseball team manager at Ofunato High School 1984. He is Ryuei Sato, not Shigetomi Sato.

BALLAN--Jack, SAR mourns the loss of Jack Ballan, beloved father of our esteemed counsel Harry (and Judith) Ballan. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President

PARIS - Liza Minnelli has three Tonys, two Golden Globes, an Oscar, an Emmy and a Grammy legend award. Now the 65-year-old singer and actress also has the rank of ''officier'' in the Legion of Honor, the award for service to the French state created by Napoleon in 1802. In the grand salon of his ministry on Monday, Culture Minister Frederic Mitterrand pinned an enameled vermeil medal affixed to a red grosgrain ribbon onto Ms. Minnelli's black silk brocade jacket. ''Priestess of the music-hall, you are the contemporary incarnation of talented versatility a l'americaine!'' he said in honoring her. He called her ''a tiger -- with the heart of a lamb.'' He praised her charitable work in the struggle against AIDS and her celebration of life and liberty in her songs that has ''made her an icon in every community, and notably the gay community.''

PHOENIX - Jose Cano pitched six games for the Houston Astros at the end of the 1989 season. Chances are, though, that his most gratifying pitches in a major league park came Monday night in the Home Run Derby at Chase Field. Cano pitched to his son, Robinson, who won the event with 12 home runs in the final round to beat Adrian Gonzalez of the Boston Red Sox. Robinson Cano drilled the winning shot over the fence in right-center field, lifted his arms in the air, and found his father, wrapping him in a bear hug.

MAGUIRE--James J.,Jr., son of James J. and Rita J. (Sullivan) Maguire, was born November 10, 1941 in Brooklyn, New York. Mr. Maguire was Valedictorian of his class at St. Mary's High School, Manhasset, New York, and received his BA from Niagara University and his JD from Catholic University in Washington, DC. Mr. Maguire was a member of the New York State Bar Association, the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, the National Arts Club of New York City, and was invested as a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre. He served as Special Assistant to US Senator James L. Buckley from 1971 to 1976, and practiced municipal bond law with several firms in New York City. Prior to his career in law, Mr. Maguire also had a career in education, as a French teacher and guidance counselor at St. Dominic's High School in Oyster Bay, New York. Mr. Maguire was a long-time resident of both Greenwich Village and Rhinebeck, New York, where he served as Chair of the Rhinebeck Republican Committee and on the committee that developed the Local Waterfront Revitalization Plan. In addition to his involvement in these organizations, Mr. Maguire was also active in efforts to protect and preserve the environment in the mid-Hudson Valley as various industrial development challenges arose. Mr. Maguire was predeceased by his cherished wife, Mary B. (Mahoney) Maguire and was the beloved brother of Robert, of Saratoga Springs; Jane Kehoe, and her husband, James, also of Saratoga Springs; and Patricia Marion, of Arizona; beloved brother-in-law of Michael Mahoney (his wife Kathy); beloved uncle of several nieces and nephews, Suzanne Clinton (her husband, Patrick), Sean Marion (his wife, Michelle),James, John, and Megan Kehoe, and Brian and Cameron Mahoney; and the beloved great-uncle of Connor and Michael Clinton, and Dylan and Austin Marion. During his years in Rhinebeck, Mr. Maguire greatly enjoyed his experience with breeding, raising and racing thoroughbred horses, among them General Obligation and Limited Obligation, and attended with enthusiasm when they competed at Belmont, Aqueduct, and Saratoga. Mr. Maguire also enjoyed the companionship of his Irish Wolfhounds: Seamus, Shannon, Finbar, Tara, Casey, Orla, Bridie, and Nuala; and, most recently, the Wheaton Terrier, Maeve. Calling hours are Thursday, 2 to 4 and 6 to 8pm, at the Dapson-Chestney Funeral Home, 51 West Market St. Rhinebeck. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Friday, 11 am, at Good Shepherd Church, 3 Mulberry St. Rhinebeck, NY. Interment will follow in St. Sylvia Cemetery, Tivoli. Memorial donations may be made to The Community Hospice of Saratoga, 179 Lawrence St., Saratoga Springs, NY 12866.

MENTLE--Sam, age 90, on July 11, 2011. Beloved husband of 50 years of Phyllis, devoted father of Alan (Jessica) and Robert (Davina), and loving grandfather to Lauren, Rebecca, Joshua, Richard and Brianna. Funeral service, Wednesday, July 13th at 9:30am, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St.

WASHINGTON -- Even before they gathered around a long table in the Cabinet Room for another round of budget negotiations on Monday, President Obama and Republican leaders began taking shots at one another. Mr. Obama declared at a news conference that he would not sign a ''stopgap'' measure to avert a federal default, and he challenged Republicans to ''eat your peas'' by supporting a large deficit-reduction deal. Speaker John A. Boehner countered that Republicans would not back a package with any tax increases, and said that even agreeing to an increase in the debt limit was a big concession.

An article on May 31 about the fluctuating values of works by contemporary artists, including Larry Rivers, misidentified the materials used on a cardboard box created by Mr. Rivers that was sold at auction last year. They were crayon, pencil and silver paper, not paint. This correction was delayed for research.

HIPSCHER--Aaron. It is with deep sadness that the faculty of NYU Stern mourns the sudden loss of our friend and colleague, Aaron Hipscher, Clinical Professor of Accounting and member of the faculty since 1997. Aaron was a passionate teacher and the consummate citizen and team player. He devoted a great deal of time to students and to service to the College. He was named Professor of the Year in 2004 and was awarded the Ely Kushel Teaching Excellence Fellowship in 2011. We will miss this outstanding colleague. Funeral Services will be held at the Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel in Livingston, NJ, on Tuesday, July 12 at 11:00am.
In observance of the 16th anniversary of theJuly 1995 massacre in Srebrenica, Bosnia,hundreds of victims were reburied Monday.

PHOENIX - Jose Reyes took batting practice when the All-Stars worked out on Monday, even though he is on the disabled list. So did Ryan Braun of the Milwaukee Brewers. Both players were elected to start but unable to play because of injury. ''Every time I get a chance to come, I want to come, no matter what happens,'' said Reyes, the Mets' shortstop.

Debunking some speculation around Broadway this spring that the play's unprintable title would hurt ticket sales, ''The ------------------------ With the Hat'' has recouped its capitalization after nearly three months of performances, the producers announced on Monday. (They would not disclose the amount.) Separately, the producers of John Leguizamo's Broadway show ''Ghetto Klown'' also said on Monday that that one-man play had recouped its $2 million capitalization. ''Ghetto Klown'' began preview performances on Feb. 21, opened on March 22, and closed on Sunday.

CENDALI--Eleanor, a long time resident of Greenburgh, NY for more than 50 years, passed away Sunday morning, July 10, 2011, after a valiant battle with lung cancer. She never smoked a cigarette in her life. Born on January 11, 1926, Eleanor graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Hunter College. She then taught English for over 30 years and was Dean of Students at Evander Childs High School in the Bronx. She had a positive impact on countless students and took them on trips to the Stratford Shakespeare Festival and to pool parties at her house. Her students nominated her for Cousin Brucie's "Good Guy" radio award which she won. She retired in 1986. After retirement she read voraciously and she and her husband swam almost daily and were inseparable. They were long-time members of the Tarrytown Boat and Yacht Club. Her family was the center of her life. She was the beloved matriarch of a close-knit family whose interests she always put first. Chief among them is her loving husband for almost 63 years, John A. Cendali, who has been by her side sleeping at the hospital during the entire last difficult stages. They met in kindergarten and celebrated their 60th anniversary in Italy with their family. He was a US Navy veteran who served in World War II. He used to fly his plane over the house and waggle his wings as a token of love. He was the Administrative Superintendent of Buildings and Grounds for City College and the Chief Electrician before that. He is a lifetime member of IBEW Local 3. She had three grateful and devoted children and four beloved grandchildren. She was selfless toward her children and grandchildren and always put them first. Her daughters are Jean Cendali, who followed her mother into teaching and is a long-time art teacher at Haldane School and Dale Cendali, whom she inspired to go to law school and who became a prominent IP lawyer at Kirkland and Ellis LLP who she watched argue before the U.S. Supreme Court (and meet her client J.K. Rowling). Her son is John J. Cendali, who followed his dad's footsteps as a proud member of IBEW Local 3. The apples of her eye were her four grandchildren with whom she was extraordinary close and who loved her brownies and her home-cooked Sunday dinners. Her three grandchildren by her daughter Dale are John Thomas Fitzpatrick, Lucy Margaret Fitzpatrick, and Eleanor Jean Fitzpatrick and her grandson by her son John is Christopher John Cendali. Her granddaughter Eleanor was named in honor of her. Eleanor is also survived by her brother, Anthony Avacato. She is predeceased by by her beloved parents, Lucy and Joseph Avacato, and by her brother Jerry Avacato. The wake will be held at 2-4pm and 7-9pm on Tuesday, July 12, 2011 at the Beecher Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, NY. The funeral will be at 10am on Wednesday, July 13, 2011 at the Little Church at St. John and St. Mary Roman Catholic Church, 30 Poillon Road, Chappaqua, NY. She will be interred at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, a memorial fund has been set up in her name at Memorial - Sloane Kettering Cancer Center.

PHOENIX - American League Manager Ron Washington said he added the Yankees' Dave Robertson because of Robertson's effectiveness against left- and right-handed hitters. Robertson said he was thrilled to make the trip, although it meant a 3:40 a.m. wakeup call on Monday and a commercial flight through Chicago. ''I was getting here, even if I had to rent a car and drive,'' he said. ''Woke up, bags were already packed, cabbed to Newark, Newark to Chicago, Chicago we were delayed, it rained, my bags were soaked. I'm sitting there thinking: 'I'm going to miss everything. I better get there for the game.' ''

An article on June 30 about the former Knicks guard Mark Jackson, who left his job as a broadcaster to take over as coach of the Golden State Warriors, misstated his ranking among the N.B.A.'s career assists leaders when he retired in 2004. He was second, behind John Stockton and ahead of Magic Johnson -- not third.

THE FACTS For some people who snore, a slight tweak in sleeping position - lying on one side instead of the back - can lead to a better night's rest. Yet staying put in that position, while wrapped in slumber, is not always an easy feat.

Chris Cahill, an original member of the Zephyr team or Z-Boys, a skateboarding phenomenon that transformed the sport with punk belligerence and a fluid surfing style born in a rundown Southern California neighborhood, was found dead on June 24 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 54. His stepbrother, Kurt Nelson, said that the cause had not been determined but that Cahill had cirrhosis.

Jonathan N. Grayer, the former chief executive of the education company Kaplan Inc., formed an investment partnership with the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company in early 2010. Now, after looking at 350 companies over the last year and a half, they have done their first deal. Their venture, named Weld North, has acquired Education2020, an education software company based in Scottsdale, Ariz. The financial terms of the deal were not disclosed, but people briefed on the transaction said the purchase price was about $50 million.

SELINGER--Neil L.,1953-2011. Lowey Dannenberg Cohen & Hart, White Plains, New York, is saddened to report that its former managing partner, Neil Selinger, died July 9, 2011 after a courageous battle with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Lou Gehrig's disease). Neil graduated from Columbia University in 1975 and New York University Law School in 1978. Neil joined Lowey Dannenberg directly from law school, and spent the next thirty years earning a reputation as one of the premier plaintiffs' securities lawyers in the United States. Neil became a name partner and was the firm's managing partner for ten years, until he retired at the end of 2007 to pursue writing, teaching and service to Columbia University. Neil was universally loved by the lawyers and staff with whom he worked at Lowey Dannenberg. Neil's intelligence, equanimity, integrity, humor and grace as a litigator earned him the respect of judges, clients, colleagues and adversaries throughout the United States. He was a tenacious advocate, but always ethical and fair. After learning in 2009 he had ALS, Neil carried on with uncommon spirit, living life more fully than anyone thought his physical condition would permit. In 2010, Neil finished writing and published a remarkably candid and humorous full-length autobiographical memoir entitled "A Sloan Product - A Memoir of a Lost Boy". Our condolences go out to Neil's wife, Rima, and his daughters. Hannah, Emily and Julia, all of whom, with Neil, for so long have been part of our firm's "family".

LAWI--Marcelle. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of our esteemed member. Glazer, Rabbi Israel Singer, Cantor Glen Gilbert, Co-President Deborah Schiff, Co-President Abby Mendelsohn, Chair

The conductor Seiji Ozawa, the actress Judi Dench and the painter Bill Viola have been named 2011 Praemium Imperiale laureates, an honor that comes with a 15 million yen prize (nearly $186,000 at the current exchange rate) given by the Japan Art Association, which made the announcement on Monday. The association describes the award as recognition of ''lifetime achievement in the arts in categories not covered by the Nobel Prizes.'' The other winners this year are Anish Kapoor, for sculpture, and Ricardo Legorreta, for architecture. The association also gave $30,000 grants, aimed at supporting institutions helping young people in the arts, to the Royal Court Young Writers Program and the Southbank Sinfonia, both of London. The awards will be presented at a ceremony in Tokyo in October.

VISCARDI--John Peter, Jr.,M.D., passed away suddenly, after a life very well lived, on July 8, 2011 at the age of 85. He was an amazing husband, father, grandfather, and friend, and was loved deeply by all who knew him. His joie de vivre was legendary and infectious. He was born in New York City on May 23, 1926. He lived in Manhasset, New York for over 40 years where he was a beloved pediatrician. In 2008 he and his wife moved to Rowayton, CT. He was very proud of his five children: Catherine, Mary Louise, John III, Jeffrey and Tricia and his 10 grandchildren. Visiting will be Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9pm at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Ave., Garden City. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10am at St. Josephs Church, Garden City. Interment to follow at Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing.

Robert Osborne, the longtime host of the Turner Classic Movies channel, plans to take a three-month leave of absence, the channel said in a statement Monday. Mr. Osborne, 79, will be undergoing minor surgery, the channel said, without specifying for what, as well as taking a vacation. Perhaps assuaging viewers' concerns, the channel noted that Mr. Osborne, who has been the channel's host since 1994, recently renewed his contract. In his place, guest hosts including Robert Wagner, Jane Powell and Tippi Hedren will step in, with others to be announced ''in the coming weeks,'' the statement said. In the interim, Mr. Osborne will still appear in taped features like the channel's guest programmer series and ''The Essentials,'' a weekly showing of a must-see film.

STEELE--Harry Gerard, 69, of New Canaan, CT died of pneumonia on June 29th, at Stamford Hospital. The pneumonia complicated his already 15-year battle with chronic lymphocytic leukemia. His parents, Albert F. and Josephine Steele, as well as a brother Albert J. Steele, predeceased him. Mr. Steele is survived by his wife of 45 years, Rita Steele; daughter Amy Serrano (husband Julio Serrano) of Darien, CT; son, Brian Weldon Steele of New York City; and two grandsons, Ryan and Sebastian Serrano of Darien. A native of Weirton, WV, Mr. Steele received a BBA degree in Finance from the University of Notre Dame (1965) and an MBA in Finance from the Kellogg School of Business at Northwestern University (1966). He began his professional career with Union Carbide in New York City. He then worked at Lone Star Industries in Greenwich, CT and in 1972 was hired as Controller at Pfizer. In 1976, Mr. Steele began his 31-year career at Philip Morris USA in New York City as Director of Financial Controls and Planning. In 1990, Mr. Steele was appointed Senior Vice President of Finance. During his career, Mr. Steele distinguished himself through his leadership qualities, management skills and accounting acumen. He retired in 2007. During his 15-year battle with leukemia, Mr. Steele received chemotherapy treatments at New York University Cancer Center in New York City. A Mass of Christian Burial was celebrated on July 7 at St. Aloysius Church in New Canaan. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation on behalf of Harry G. Steele to The New York University Hematology Research Fund, care of Dr. Edward Amorosi, 160 East 34th Street, New York City, NY 10016.

Before Jose Reyes was placed on the disabled list with a hamstring injury this month, he was having by far the best season of his career - and the best season of any player in the National League as well. He ranks eighth in the league in on-base percentage at .398 and sixth in slugging percentage at .529, all while playing a solid shortstop and causing his usual havoc on the basepaths. According to Fangraphs.com, through the 80 games he played before getting hurt, Reyes improved the Mets' record by 5.2 wins compared with a typical journeyman shortstop, a pace similar to the greatest years of the position's elite.

An article on June 30 about a caviar production project in Abu Dhabi misstated the size at which the sturgeon raised there are harvested for their eggs. Siberian sturgeon, the variety raised at the farm, are harvested at four or five years old, when they weigh about 16 pounds; the farm does not accommodate them until they are fully grown. (Siberian sturgeon, which can live 60 years, may attain a length of 10 feet and weigh hundreds of pounds when fully grown.)

The back-and-forth of the debt limit negotiations can be perplexing. But the facts driving the debate are quite straightforward. Any deal, or any workaround to a deal, will need to be approved by a majority of the House of Representatives. The Republicans in the House of Representatives are extremely conservative on fiscal matters and are significantly out of step with the public as a whole. Given that Democrats continue to control the Senate and the White House, and that their votes may be necessary in the House as well, this makes compromise nearly impossible.

When I lived in Atlanta in the late 1980s, I learned to cook Thanksgiving turkeys, Fourth of July pork shoulders, and Sunday night burgers on the Big Green Egg. When I moved to Oxford, Miss. in 1995, I had to leave my Egg behind. It wouldn’t fit in the moving truck.When my mother in law, Marley Hobbs, age 88, moved two doors down a couple years ago, she saved enough room in her moving truck for her Egg. Of late, I’ve been borrowing hers more frequently, while pondering the purchase of a Primo, one of those glossy black oblong models. Sure, they’re expensive. But, after reporting my story on them, I want one more than ever.

In his latest film, “Tabloid,” Errol Morris, the celebrated documentarian behind “The Fog of War,” the Oscar-winning portrait of Robert McNamara, and “The Thin Blue Line,” which helped get a man off death row, turns his famous Interrotron on a former Miss Wyoming whose stranger-than-fiction escapades twice invited the scrutiny of tabloid newspapers. In the late 1970s, a beauty queen named Joyce McKinney followed the object of her affections, a plump Mormon missionary named Kirk Anderson, to England, where she may or may not have abducted him at gunpoint. Through the Daily Express, McKinney claimed that Anderson consented to a three-day tryst at a cottage in Devon and was later brainwashed by the Mormon Church. With headlines like “Manacled Mormon,” the Daily Mirror told a different story, one that painted McKinney as an S&M-practicing predator who chained Anderson to a bed and forced him to have sex with her with the hope of getting pregnant. McKinney fled the country in an outlandish disguise and, three decades later, made the news again, this time for persuading a South Korean doctor to clone her beloved pit bull, Booger. The Moment sat down with Morris in SoHo to discuss his mad meditation on obsession, hysteria and the tabloid rag.

Boy meets girl. Boy and girl fall in love. After dating for a year, they have sex, and the girl’s mother thinks they are moving too quickly. The girl’s mother calls the police, hoping they will scare boy and girl a little. Instead, he is arrested and put on the Texas sex-offender list, since he is 19 and she is 16, which is a year shy of the state’s age of consent. Boy avoids jail, is put on probation, and is forced to move out of his home because the law says he can’t live in the same house as his 12-year-old sister. Eventually, boy and girl marry, have four daughters and, 15 years later, he is still a registered sex offender who is not allowed to coach his children’s soccer teams, get a job at a major corporation or leave the state without registering with law enforcement.

BAGHDAD — A photographer and I recently embedded with an Army Special Forces unit that operates from a corner of Camp Victory, the United States military’s vast complex near the airport. Such embeds are extremely rare and this one took many months to secure — while the regular Army welcomes reporters with nearly unimpeded access, the Special Forces are leery of journalists. This was underscored by the long list of ground rules they require reporters to adhere to in order to protect operational secrecy.

Sherwood Schwartz passed away Tuesday at the ripe old age of 94. Sherwood Schwartz might be one of those names that you recognize, but you can’t remember from where. He created two of the most beloved sitcoms of the 1960s and 70s – “Gilligan’s Island” and “The Brady Bunch.” You may write these off as shlock, just like the critics did, but I’m sure you can recite the theme songs – both written by Schwartz, himself. He always said, “Tell them everything they need to know in the theme song.”

If you’ve been in Soho this past week, you may have noticed the monster-size rooster applied to the side of Rag & Bone’s Houston Street store (73 East Houston Street). Curious? So were we. Turns out the designers Marcus Wainwright and David Neville have invited visiting artists to tag their building’s wall as part of a continuing project. (Brooklyn’s ballpoint-pen extraordinaire Nicholas Forker started the series in May with an installation called “Action Man.”) What’s up now is a piece by the graffiti street artist Gaia. Here, a video of the three-day installation reveals him applying a wheat-paste backdrop of Peter Bruegel’s “The Triumph of Death,” then painting the rooster on top. As in many of Gaia’s neighborhood paintings, in which animals recur as protectors of the streets, this rooster is just looking out. Not that anyone is calling New Yorkers chicken.

Back in 2009, Hans-Ulrich Obrist, the co-director of London’s Serpentine Gallery, described the burgeoning Manchester International Festival (MIF) as a tribute to the British architect Cedric Price, who, in the 1960s had an idea to build a flexible, interdisciplinary arts space in East London. Price’s “Fun Palace,” as he called it, was never realized, but its spirit thrives in this biannual 18-day festival, now in its third incarnation. This year, Alex Poots, the festival’s director, has come up with another stellar lineup of music, theater and visual arts events to match the city’s reputation as both a creative incubator and provocateur.

It’s not as though anyone in Berlin really needed proof, last week, that the city’s once-hip central Mitte neighborhood had officially jumped the shark — two years’ worth of boutique hotel and Mavi-store openings, plus skyrocketing rents and a mass exodus of the gallery scene, had all been fairly obvious clues. But as the local fashion crowd milled around on Wednesday night outside the opening of Andreas Murkudis’s sprawling concept shop, newly and thrillingly relocated to a remote stretch of Potsdamer Strasse once ruled by drug dealers and prostitutes, there seemed to be only one sentiment on everybody’s lips: Goodbye, and good riddance. Murkudis may have helped pioneer the Mitte retail scene when he began selling Margiela and Yohji from three minimalist storefronts inside a courtyard off Münzstrasse in the early 2000s, but with a few notable exceptions — the recently opened Gestalten bookshop, the Kunstwerke contemporary art museum — it’s no longer the place that in-the-know young people go to hang out and discover things. It’s the place they go when they need something from American Apparel.

A recipe for Crème Fraîche Cheesecake With Sour Cherries.
Using the small artichokes from foggy coastal California, you can make garlicky Roman-style artichokes quite effortlessly at home.
A recipe for Pan-Roasted Baby Artichokes.
2010 was supposed to be the Year of the Tablet, a prediction that did not quite pan out. So, once more, with feeling: 2011 will be the Year of the Tablet. Sort through the offerings.

8:47 p.m. | Updated The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened an inquiry into Fletcher Asset Management, a New York hedge fund run by Alphonse Fletcher Jr., a prominent Wall Street investor, according to a person with direct knowledge of the situation.

On the same week that the acclaimed drama ''Friday Night Lights'' is ending on NBC it is starting on the ESPN family of sports networks. ESPN Classic has picked up the repeats of the five-season series, which has been lauded for its realistic depictions of football, family and life in the heartland. After a Season 1 marathon on Thursday and Friday, the episodes will be shown on Thursday nights beginning July 21. They will also be broadcast on the Longhorn Network, an ESPN channel for Texas sports that starts in late August.

Representative Ron Paul, the long-serving Texas Republican, will not seek re-election next year so he can focus on his bid for his party's presidential nomination instead, according to his campaign. During his tenure in Congress, Mr. Paul developed a reputation as a hard-line libertarian and is credited by some with paving the way for the Tea Party movement. A 75-year-old physician, Mr. Paul has often stood alone in voting against legislation that he considers unconstitutional, earning the nickname ''Dr. No'' from his colleagues.

FRIEDLAND--Melvin S.,of New York City, died peacefully on July 12, 2011. Devoted son to the late William and Evelyn Friedland. Loving father, caring brother and beloved Pop Pop. He is survived by Merilyn and Joseph Geisberg, Gayle and Roberto Glik, and Jennifer and Eric Friedland, and by his grandchildren Daniel, Jacob, Amanda, Rebecca, Benjamin, Madeline, Lucy and Serena. His is also survived by his brother Lawrence and his wife Marilyn. He was married for twenty years to the late Pauline Friedland. Retired pharmacist and veteran of the United States Air Force. His generosity, integrity and storytelling will be deeply missed. Services will be held at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on July 13, at 11:45am. Donations can be made in his memory to: the United Jewish Appeal or to the Albany College of Pharmacy, of which he was a Trustee.

Executive pay continues to skyrocket despite years of criticism by corporate governance gurus, fierce efforts by unions to temper compensation and calls by politicians to regulate pay. Given these failures, perhaps it is time to ask whether critics' actions have actually driven executive pay higher.

Fifty years ago, 84th Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, beat out some pretty stiff competition to be designated the ''worst block'' in New York City - a ''ghetto of sociopaths,'' in the words of the rector of a nearby Episcopal church who despaired that city officials would ever do anything to clean up the mess. What propelled 84th Street past other contenders was a blockwide street brawl that erupted on July 5, 1961, involving about 400 combatants armed with knives and lye, which sent one man to the hospital after it was thrown in his face. Police officers' attempts to quell the disturbance by firing shots in the air were unavailing. Nine patrol cars had to be dispatched to break up the melee.

GREENBERGER--Howard L.,age 81, passed away July 6, 2011. Greenberger was a 1954 graduate of NYU School of Law, where as professor of law emeritus, he served on the faculty from 1961 to 2001. He established the Howard Greenberger Award for Outstanding Achievement in Comparative Law, given annually to a graduating student at commencement. Greenberger was a past president of the New York City chapter of the American Jewish Committee and was active in the Coalition to Free Soviet Jews. Howard Greenberger is survived by wife Bette Jo (nee Bergad of Irwin, PA) of 52 wonderful years together as a most loving couple. He will be missed by his family, his many friends, colleagues and students, and most of all by his dearest Bette Jo. Memorials preferred to NYU School of Law.

An article on Thursday about reductions in the printing of paper currency referred imprecisely to the period of time when the government printed no $10 bills. It was last fiscal year, from October 2009 through September 2010 -- not last calendar year.

CAHN--David, on July 12th in his 93rd year. Loving father to Daniel (Barbara) and Ellen Silber (Harvey). Cherished grandfather of Sharyn, Robyn, Jonathan, Robert, and Steven. Services, Thursday, 12 noon at "Gutterman's Inc" 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI. Interment, Union Field Cemetery, Queens, NY.

It is an all-too-familiar pattern in many communities: artists discover an inexpensive, underdeveloped neighborhood and move in, only to be ousted from the area by soaring retail rents once it catches on in popularity. Many argue that it happened in Greenwich Village, and most point to SoHo as the quintessential example of the phenomenon. Now, the same pattern may be occurring in Chelsea, where an explosion of residential development along the High Line is attracting retailers serving new residents -- retailers who are now competing for space with the hundreds of art galleries that are the backbone of the neighborhood.

OXENBERG--Morris, died at age 97, July 11, 2011, at home in Atlantic City, NJ. Born on January 28, 1914 in Philadelphia, PA, the youngest of three sons of Jacob and Blima (Marcus). With his business partner, he owned and operated a thriving hat store in Philadelphia, Stanmor Hats, for many years. He is survived by his niece, Judith Rubin, and his nephew, Robert Oakes, and their families, and caregivers Lynne Armstrong and Liese Pfoertner. Graveside service will be held at noon, Thursday, July 14, Beth Israel Cemetery, Black Horse Pike, Egg Harbor Township, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Shore Memorial Health Foundation, 1 East New York Avenue, Somers Point, NJ 08244.

HARD LINE Casino Guichard-Perrachon's board reaffirmed on Tuesday that it would oppose plans to merge the retail arm of Grupo Pão de Açucar, in which it is a major shareholder, with the Brazilian operations of its main French rival, Carrefour. Carrefour said last month that it had received an approach from the Brazilian investment firm Gama to join its Brazilian retail business with that of Grupo Pão de Açucar, known as Companhia Brasileira de Distribuição. That proposal was supported by Abilio Diniz, above, the Brazilian businessman who leads Grupo Pão de Açucar. CHRIS V. NICHOLSON

A report on Tuesday in the Observatory column about the way in which gray whales adapted to survive ice ages misspelled the surname of the curator of marine mammals at the Smithsonian Institution, who is an author of a new study on the subject. He is Nicholas D. Pyenson, not Peynson.

9 P.M. (ESPN) THE 2011 ESPYS Seth Meyers returns as host of this annual ceremony honoring the year's best in sports, as voted on by fans. ''Best'' categories include Major League Baseball player, record-breaking performance, upset, game, moment and athlete with a disability. Among the nominees are the Nascar driver Jimmie Johnson, the tennis player Rafael Nadal, Dirk Nowitzki of the Dallas Mavericks and Aaron Rodgers of the Green Bay Packers for best male athlete; and the snowboarder Kelly Clark, Lauren Jackson of the Seattle Storm, the women's basketball star Maya Moore and the skier Lindsey Vonn for best female athlete. Dewey Bozella, above, a boxer who served 26 years in prison for a murder he did not commit, will receive the Arthur Ashe Courage Award. The countdown from the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles begins at 7. 7:30 P.M. (FX) THE TAKING OF PELHAM 1 2 3 (2009) Tony Scott updates the 1974 mass-transit thriller about the hijacking of a New York train on the Lexington Avenue subway line. Denzel Washington, in an altered version of the Walter Matthau role, plays a Metropolitan Transportation Authority stalwart who has been demoted to dispatcher pending an investigation into accusations of bribe taking. John Travolta, stepping into a part originally played by Robert Shaw, is the diabolical leader of a mysterious criminal gang -- and the man at the controls. And James Gandolfini is the mayor of a post-9/11 New York City. ''I left my Rudy Giuliani suit at home,'' he says. A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called the film canny and energetic.

SELINGER--Neil L.,1953-2011. Lowey Dannenberg Cohen & Hart, White Plains, New York, is saddened to report that its former managing partner, Neil Selinger, died July 9, 2011 after a courageous battle with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Lou Gehrig's disease). Neil graduated from Columbia University in 1975 and New York University Law School in 1978. Neil joined Lowey Dannenberg directly from law school, and spent the next thirty years earning a reputation as one of the premier plaintiffs' securities lawyers in the United States. Neil became a name partner and was the firm's managing partner for ten years, until he retired at the end of 2007 to pursue writing, teaching and service to Columbia University. Neil was universally loved by the lawyers and staff with whom he worked at Lowey Dannenberg. Neil's intelligence, equanimity, integrity, humor and grace as a litigator earned him the respect of judges, clients, colleagues and adversaries throughout the United States. He was a tenacious advocate, but always ethical and fair. After learning in 2009 he had ALS, Neil carried on with uncommon spirit, living life more fully than anyone thought his physical condition would permit. In 2010, Neil finished writing and published a remarkably candid and humorous full-length autobiographical memoir entitled "A Sloan Product - A Memoir of a Lost Boy". Our condolences go out to Neil's wife, Rima, and his daughters. Hannah, Emily and Julia, all of whom, with Neil, for so long have been part of our firm's "family".

ZIM--Marvin H. Born in New York City, died on July 6, 2011 in Washington, DC at the age of 75. Beloved husband of Anne; devoted father of Eric, Michael and Daniel; loving grandfather of five grandchildren; and dear brother of Irwin. Princeton Class of 1957. Journalist Time 1957-74. Director of Communications, Union Pacific 1978-94. His wit, intelligence and devotion to family and friends will be greatly missed.

ROSS--George M. Drexel University celebrates the life of our alumnus and former chairman, an inspiration for us all. Quick to act as a mentor and generous beyond measure, he took personal responsibility for the success of his alma mater and its students. Our Ross Commons student center stands as a monument to his indelible Drexel legacy, and we send condolences to his wife Lyn and their family. Richard A. Greenawalt, Chair John A. Fry, President

New York Live Arts, the new artistic initiative created this year by the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company and Dance Theater Workshop, is offering something new for artists and audiences this fall. For theatergoers, the group plans to present works from more than 40 artists, including a Replay Series that looks back at artists' most significant and popular works. The performers include Big Dance Theater, John Jasperse, John Kelly, Yvonne Meier, Richard Move and Reggie Wilson. Mr. Jones's dance company will also present a premiere of a work inspired by John Cage's ''Indeterminacy,'' in which Mr. Jones will dance and read 70 of his own one-minute stories to accompany original music by Ted Coffey. For artists, New York Live Arts has begun a two-year residency that offers a rarity in the art world: salary, health benefits and a commission for a work. The first artist to benefit is Yasuko Yokoshi, a Hiroshima-born choreographer who came to the United States in 1981.

For the third time since the show opened in May, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is extending the hours of its blockbuster Costume Institute exhibition ''Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty.'' -While the Met is still planning to close the show on August 7th, starting July 22nd it will allow museum members in at 8:30 a.m., an hour before the show opens to the public. (Only the museum's 81st Street entrance and 80th Street garage will be open for these viewings.) And from August 4th to the 7th the exhibition will remain open until 9:00 p.m. (on Tuesdays and Sundays it generally closes at 5:30.) -Additional hours for the show will continue to be offered on Mondays, when the museum is generally closed to the public. Monday tickets, which cost $50, are available at the Met and on its website www.metmuseum.org. -Since it opened on May 4th, more than 440,000 people have come to see the survey of the work of Mr. McQueen, the British fashion designer who committed suicide last year at age 40. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

WEEKEND The Weekend Miser column on Friday overstated the rapper Q-Tip's role in the Brooklyn Hip-Hop Festival this week. While he is performing, he is not the organizer of the festival. (He is a curator with Brooklyn Bodega, a group that supports hip-hop, which organized the festival.) The error also appeared in a film review on Friday about ''Beats, Rhymes & Life,'' a documentary about Q-Tip's group A Tribe Called Quest.)

TV on the Radio, The Black Keys and Cee Lo Green will be among the bands appearing at this year's Virgin Mobile Freefest, a free music festival to be held on Sept. 10 in Columbia, Md., the festival's organizers announced on Monday. This is the third year that this mobile telephone company started by Richard Branson, along with Kyocera Wireless, has footed the bill for the festival, which is expected to draw about 40,000 people. The tickets are to be given away through Virgin Mobile Live's Facebook page starting at 10 a.m. Friday. For the past annual festivals, the tickets disappeared in a matter of minutes. Though the tickets are free, festivalgoers are asked to make a small cash donation to local charities that help the homeless, and about 5,000 people are requested to trade their labor as volunteers for the tickets. Over the last two years, more than $300,000 has been raised and people have given 55,000 hours of their time. This year Kyocera will also be collecting money for tsunami victims in Japan.

The On Soccer column on July 4, about the struggles of Argentina in the Copa América tournament, misstated the time period during which Bolivia scored its goal against Argentina in its opening game on July 1. It was in the second half, not the first.

The attorney for the New Jersey man charged with stealing a small Picasso drawing from an art gallery in San Francisco on July 5 said the man plans to plead not guilty, according to The Associated Press. Mark Lugo, of Hoboken, was arrested last week in a hotel in Napa, Calif., about 50 miles north of San Francisco, and the police recovered the drawing stolen from the Weinstein Gallery in San Francisco. During an appearance in court on Monday Mr. Lugo's lawyer, Douglas Horngrad, asked the judge to reduce the $5 million bail and postpone the arraignment until Friday. The drawing, ''Tete de Femme'' (''Head of a Woman''), is valued at more than $200,000.

The 10th anniversary of 9/11 is near, summoning not only horrible memories of that cataclysm but also the anxiety of measuring up. Ten years on, there still aren't enough words, gestures, ceremonies or moments of silence to match the wound. Not paying attention is unthinkable, but it's even harder to think of an adequate tribute. ''Rescue Me,'' the FX show about firefighters who survived the attack on the World Trade Center, isn't a bad place to start. On Monday the drama begins its seventh and final season; it had its premiere in 2004, just as many Americans were moving on and getting over 9/11. And the series has stayed focused -- saltily, irreverently, but always passionately -- on a band of firehouse brothers and their loved ones. A lot has happened in that small world, though time hasn't healed much of anything.
THE DUTCH 131 Sullivan Street (Prince Street), SoHo; (212) 677-6200; thedutchnyc.com.

VISCARDI--John Peter, Jr.,M.D., passed away suddenly, after a life very well lived, on July 8, 2011 at the age of 85. He was an amazing husband, father, grandfather, and friend, and was loved deeply by all who knew him. His joie de vivre was legendary and infectious. He was born in New York City on May 23, 1926. He lived in Manhasset, New York for over 40 years where he was a beloved pediatrician. In 2008 he and his wife, Catherine, moved to Rowayton, CT. He was very proud of his five children: Catherine, Mary Louise, John III, Jeffrey and Tricia and his 10 grandchildren. Visiting will be Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9pm at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Ave., Garden City. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10am at St. Josephs Church, Garden City. Interment to follow at Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing.

The White House and the U.S. Chamber of Commerce have been at war for much of the last two-and-a-half years. One thing they can agree on, however, is the need to attract successful young people, especially at the start of an election season when campaign cash will be at a premium. That's one reason why a group of 125 executives, all under 30, has lined up eminent audiences on Wednesday for invitation-only meetings and briefings at the White House, the Chamber of Commerce and Capitol Hill to push for greater job creation and economic opportunities for young people.

BEIJING -- Aside from the new World Trade Center, it's hard to think of a more contentious architectural project in the last few years than the CCTV building, the headquarters of China Central Television here. After Rem Koolhaas, the project's architect, unveiled the design in 2003 he was pilloried by Western journalists for glorifying a propaganda organ of the Chinese government. Several years later a fire at the site nearly burned down a neighboring building, also designed by Mr. Koolhaas, landing the director of the project and 19 others in prison for negligence and significantly delaying construction.

An article last Wednesday about cities that were bidding to host the 2018 Winter Olympic Games misstated, in some editions, the year that the Winter Games were held in Sapporo, Japan. It was 1972, not 1968. (The alpine resort of Pyeongchang in South Korea won the bid for the 2018 Games.)

SPORTS An article on July 5 about the American Tyler Farrar's victory in Stage 3 of the Tour de France misidentified his current residence. He lives in Ghent, which is in the Flemish region of Belgium; he does not live in the Netherlands.

FRIEDLAND--Melvin. We mourn the loss of our beloved uncle, a unique and exceptional character. We will truly miss his warmth, stories, and most of all, his sense of humor. Although our times will now be quieter, we will always smile at the memory of his views on life. Melvin was an irreplaceable individual and we will all miss him greatly. We extend our deepest condolences to his children Meri, Gayle and Rick and their spouses and children. With deepest love, Elizabeth and Mark; Pamela and Gabriel; William and Elyssa

An article on May 11 about the maker of tandoor ovens for home use referred incorrectly to Punjab, a traditional center of tandoori cooking. It is an Indian state -- not part of the Northwest Frontier, the former name of an area of Pakistan where tandoori cooking also developed. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

Rob Grill, the longtime lead singer and a very nearly original member of the Grass Roots, the immensely popular rock group of the 1960s and afterward, died on Monday in Tavares, Fla. He was 67. The cause was complications of a head injury he sustained in a fall last month, his wife, Nancy, said. Mr. Grill was a longtime resident of Mount Dora, Fla.

WASHINGTON -- President Obama grasped the prosthetic right hand of Sgt. First Class Leroy Arthur Petry in congratulations on Tuesday, awarding him the Medal of Honor for actions in Afghanistan that included saving two comrades' lives by hurling away a grenade as it exploded. This is only the second time since the Vietnam era that the nation's highest military honor has been awarded to a soldier who survived combat in a conflict still under way; the other awards were given posthumously. Mr. Obama bestowed the first award last fall to another veteran of Afghanistan, Staff Sgt. Salvatore A. Giunta, who was present in the East Room along with medal recipients from past wars.

This article was reported byJohn F. Burns, Don Van Natta Jr. andAlan Cowell, and written by Mr. Burns. LONDON -- Rupert Murdoch's once-commanding influence in British politics seemed to dwindle to a new low on Tuesday, when all three major parties in Parliament joined in support of a sharp rebuke to his ambitions and a parliamentary committee said it would call him, along with two other top executives, to testify publicly next week about the growing scandal enveloping his media empire.

GEFFNER--Leonard, of Queens, NY and Lake Peekskill, NY, died at his Lake Peekskill home on July 12, 2011. He was 82. Leonard was predeceased by his beloved wife in 2006. He is survived by his loving children Neal Geffner and Adrienne Star, and by his four cherished grandchildren. Funeral Services will be on Wednesday, July 13 at 12:30pm at the Heritage Funeral Home, 35 Morrissey Drive, Putnam Valley. Interment will follow at King David Cemetery in Putnam Valley, NY.

VITAGLIANO--Maggie, a prolific artist who brought together her love of sacred Indian Scripture and her abundant artistic talent to create a distinctive clothing line, died on April 13th, 2011 three days before her 60th birthday. The cause was metastatic breast cancer. Maggie was a lifelong photographer, painter, fashion designer and more recently a digital computer artist. In January 1999 she made her first silkscreen, Consciousness is the Self and hand screened it on an old t-shirt. This was the first Shiva Sutra and the auspicious beginning of Hermitwear, Maggie's design company. Maggie created each of her clothing pieces as if they were works of art on canvas. Friends and colleagues from the fashion industry and yoga community expressed that wearing her line of clothes made them feel full of good will and love, which reflected Maggie's approach to life, friendship and the world. Her charismatic and magnetic personality attracted so many people in her hometown of Scarsdale, NY and New York City where Maggie is beloved by friends throughout those communities. Maggie is survived by her friends Lori, Frank, Prema, Pat, Susan, Sam, Ellen, cousins Linda, Ricky, Tommy, Claudia, Paul, Valerie, Antoinette, John and Mary Ann, mother Nancy and brother John. A Memorial Service will be held at 7:30pm on July 14, 2011, at Subud New York, 230 West 29th St, New York, NY.

As bad ballets go, Alexei Ratmansky's two-act ''Anna Karenina'' is one of the best. It tells its potted version of Tolstoy's novel with a fair bit of narrative clarity; it manages many complex changes of scene deftly; its décor and costumes (by Mikael Melbye) are generally elegant; its extensive use of video projections (by Wendall Harrington) is unusual and effective; and most of its leading characters are immediately identifiable and distinct. But these virtues don't suffice. The ballet is a complete waste of everybody's time. In this case ''everybody'' includes the Mariinsky Ballet of St. Petersburg, Valery Gergiev conducting the Mariinsky Theater Orchestra, and the Lincoln Center Festival audience at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday's opening night of the Mariinsky's weeklong season.

SUBBIONDO--Ralph A. The Board of Directors and staff of HeartShare Human Services of New York deeply mourn the untimely passing of Board Chairman, Ralph A. Subbiondo, on July 9th. Mr. Subbiondo served on the Board for 15 years and as Chairman for nine years. He was 63 years of age and is survived by his loving and devoted wife Ava, his children Susan and David Shindler and Frances Subbiondo, his grandchildren Oliver and Roselyn Shindler, his dear mother Ann Subbiondo and his brother and sister-in-law Charles Subbiondo and Jennifer Kahane. Mr. Subbiondo was a CPA and a retired Ernst and Young LLP partner and also had served as Chief Financial Officer of The Bush-Clinton Katrina Fund. He leaves a distinguished legacy of community service. A memorial service will be held in New York on August 27th. The family requests all remembrances be sent to HeartShare Human Services, 12 MetroTech Center - 29th Fl., Brooklyn, NY, 11201 Attn: Public Affairs Office.

BUSINESS DAY The DealBook column on Tuesday, about a tax break for buyers and sellers of futures contracts, referred imprecisely to the United States' debt. ''The country's $55 trillion debt load'' cited in the column includes state and local government debt; that is not the amount of federal debt, which stands at about $14 trillion.

A $16 million musical production of ''Rebecca,'' based on the classic 1938 novel by Daphne du Maurier, has been scaled down to a budget of about $12 million - largely thanks to the loss of a collapsing staircase special effect - and is now on track for Broadway, the producers announced on Tuesday. Preview performances at a Shubert theater still to be named are scheduled to begin March 27, 2012, with an opening night set for April 22. A Gothic love story about a wealthy Englishman, Maxim de Winter, his new wife, and his estate, Manderley, that may be haunted by his dead first wife, ''Rebecca'' was popularized in the 1940 film by Alfred Hitchcock and, over the last several years, in a musical that played through Europe. Ben Sprecher, once a prominent Off Broadway theater owner and now a producer, and Louise Forlenza are mounting the Broadway version of the musical after dropping plans to open it first in London.

SIMKIN--Carol F.,died of cancer on July 9, at her summer home in East Dennis, Massachusetts. Carol grew up in Great Neck, Long Island, and graduated in 1970 from Brandeis University and in 1973 from New York University Law School. She was for many years a leading lawyer in the trademark and copyright fields. She was a partner first in the law firm of Cowan Liebowitz & Latman and then in the firm of Fross Zelnick Lehrman & Zissu, and also served as a mediator, privately and for Federal and State courts in New York. Carol was gifted with exceptional intelligence and possessed character and common sense to an uncommon degree. She was a brilliant legal counselor and litigation strategist, and a generous source of advice and support for her family, friends and colleagues. Although she lived and worked in Manhattan, she loved Cape Cod and especially her home and gardens overlooking Cape Cod Bay. She is survived by her husband, Ron Lehrman, her daughter, Lauren Simkin Berke, her brother, Steven Simkin, her father, Dr. Maxwell Simkin, and her nephews Alexander and Zachary Simkin. Family members and friends will be invited to gather on a date to be announced. No flowers or donations, please.

SCIENCE TIMES Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the difficulties in reducing the incidence of shingles in older Americans despite the availability of a vaccine misidentified a condition that affects 33 percent of patients over age 79. It is postherpetic neuralgia, the lingering nerve pain that often follows a shingles outbreak; it is not shingles itself.

A report on Tuesday in the Observatory column about huge quantities of cosmic dust detected in a constellation known as the Large Magellanic Cloud described incorrectly the history of the supernova that emitted the dust. Although it first became visible from Earth in 1987, the supernova occurred about 160,000 years before; it did not occur in 1987.

Daniel L. Doctoroff, a former deputy to Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York who became president of Bloomberg L.P. three and a half years ago, was promoted on Tuesday to be the company's chief executive. The promotion will shift day-to-day responsibility for all of Bloomberg L.P. to Mr. Doctoroff from Peter T. Grauer, the longtime chairman of the sprawling financial and media company founded by Mr. Bloomberg 30 years ago. Mr. Doctoroff will continue to report to Mr. Grauer, who will remain chairman.

SANDWICH, England -- The wind kicked up and rain fell at Royal St. George's on Tuesday, enlivening the practice round with a taste of things to come for at least two days during the British Open, which begins Thursday. It could well be a week in which the premium is on ball-striking at the old links by the sea, with the player who can control the trajectory of his approach shots the one to hoist the claret jug on Sunday. Here are the 10 players with the best chance to win.
UNITED STATES PLAYER Hope Solo has been the tournament's best goalkeeper, and her performance against Brazil should plant seeds of self-doubt in future penalty-takers.

NATIONAL An article on Tuesday about the testy tone surrounding negotiations between President Obama and Congressional leaders on the budget deficit quoted incorrectly from comments the president made at a news conference before meeting with the leaders. Referring to the need for Republicans and Democrats to compromise, Mr. Obama said both parties needed to ''eat our peas.'' He did not challenge Republicans to ''eat your peas.''
A recipe last Wednesday for cola syrup misstated the amount of one ingredient. It is one section of a star anise pod, not one star anise. A corrected recipe is at nytimes.com/dining.

Take your hair dryer, turn it on high, turn it on hot and turn it into your face. That is what Wichita is like right now. ROSS VINER, in a city where the temperature has reached 100 more than 20 times since May. [A13]

SACHS--Harold B.,December 1, 1924 - July 10, 2011. It is with great sadness that Fashion Accessories and Gemini Shippers Associations announce the passing of our former Executive Director. Harold was a mentor and friend, a wise and gentle soul. After graduating from dental school in 1948, Harold was asked to help in the family handbag business. That became his career. After retirement, he was brought back to the industry in 1986 to lead the National Handbag Association, which eventually became FASA/Gemini. We extend our sympathy to his wife and loving family and to his many friends.

This week, Stephen Rose, chief research officer for the Foundation Fighting Blindness, joined the Consults blog to answer reader questions about age-related macular degeneration and related disorders. Several readers had questions about vitamins and nutrients to combat the vision loss of macular degeneration.

Shortly after Candace Keshwar immigrated from Trinidad to Boston in 2002, her life took a difficult turn. Her dream had been to go to college and have a career where she could help others. But her first daughter was born with cerebral palsy and Keshwar spent the next seven years caring for her at home. She grew isolated. Her husband worked in construction, but jobs were sporadic, and the family relied on government assistance. “It was a real dark space for me,” Keshwar said. “I kept thinking, ‘This cannot be my life. I know I have the potential to do so much more.’”

John Kerry has carved out an important role in President Obama's foreign policy. James Traub profiles him in this week's Magazine and reflects on traveling overseas with the Senator.

Amid shattered glass and the black smoke of urban pyres, I found myself in a riot some years ago — the anarchists-led assault on the World Trade Organization meetings of 1999. At the height of what became known as The Battle of Seattle, I bumped into an otherwise mild-mannered, libertarian-leaning friend on the streets, gasping at the bitter taste of tear gas. He was ecstatic.
Managed futures funds, which bet on the ups and downs of stocks, bonds, commodities and currencies, have been crowing for years about their performance during the financial crisis.

Can you show us your best Hermione? Your finest Dumbledore? Your slickest Snape? The final film in the Harry Potter series opens at midnight tonight and for fans, plenty of magic is likely to happen both onscreen and off. Are you planning to see the film and will you be dressing up? We’re taking photo submissions of all the wizardly costumes you come across. Submit them to http://submit.nytimes.com/harry-potter.

Something I’ve been meaning to write: there are two different stories about why deficits might drive up interest rates. They’re not at all the same — although members of the pain caucus have deliberately blurred the distinction. And for policy purposes it’s quite crucial to understand what we’re talking about.

Just one thing, you tell yourself, as the summer slips by like so many summers before it. If you manage to do nothing else for your own pleasure in this season of unclaimed hours, you will read that book, see that movie, watch that show, gaze at that painting, listen to that guitarist. Even people who do these things for a living – the New York Times arts critics – can’t always organize their cultural calendars to include what they most want to do. We asked them to share the single item in, or closely related to, their critical discipline at the very top of their summer bucket list. Here are their selections.

A newly announced partnership between the world’s biggest private coal mining company and coal-burning country cuts against recent efforts to paint China green because of its push on manufacturing wind turbines and solar panels. All of its efforts on renewable energy come atop ongoing expansion of its use of coal.

Gary Lynch, the former chief legal officer at Morgan Stanley who decamped to Bank of America this year, received a stock award worth approximately $4 million from his new employer, a regulatory filing showed.

The chances of a default on the United States debt are still fairly small. The answer: because Shaq exists.

A few years ago, The Guardian had the witty idea to ask its sports writers and cultural critics to swap jobs for a day. The results were delightful. An observation from the newspaper’s rugby columnist, Thomas Castalgnede, sent to review a production of “Tosca” at the Royal Opera House, has stuck with me. “What I saw in ‘Tosca’ was exactly what drew me to sport,” he wrote. “I just love to watch people give it everything — in any walk of life.”

This weekend, Los Angeles residents face a 53-hour closing of the 405 freeway, the primary north-south highway through the city’s West Side, as road crews take a sledgehammer to the Mulholland Drive bridge. The planned work threatens to clog surface streets near the Interstate, leading many Angelenos to call the impending amalgam of bottlenecks, honked horns and frayed nerves Carmageddon.

The gaming company Zynga made a $1 billion cash offer for PopCap, writes AllThingsD. Instead PopCap opted to pair up with Electronic Arts, in a complicated cash and stock deal that could be worth up to $1.3 billion. Read more »

As my colleague John Broder and I reported in Thursday’s paper, American Electric Power is dropping its plan to build a commercial-scale version of a carbon dioxide scrubber at Mountaineer, its coal-fired power plant in New Haven, W.Va. The company decided that since public service commissions in West Virginia and Virginia had refused to give it full reimbursement for a pilot version that it ran for two years, it could not expect to recover its investment for the full-scale version — even if the Energy Department was going to pony up $334 million, or half the cost.

A game show, a talent show and a dating show lifted NBC into a virtual tie for first place with CBS in the ratings on Wednesday night as NBC drew about as many viewers on average as CBS’s lineup of “Big Brother” and crime show reruns. According to Nielsen’s estimates, NBC’s reality competition “America’s Got Talent” earned the night’s largest audience with 11 million viewers at 9 p.m., but the network lagged behind CBS the rest of the night as “Minute to Win It” garnered just 4.8 million at 8 and “Love in the Wild” drew 5.1 million at 10.

Train announcements at 59th Street-Columbus Circle were so plentiful, audible and detailed — be careful what you wish for, as we are ever reminded —that it seemed at times as if they never ended. No more rumble of a subway train; a trip underground had become a nonstop serenade by the voice of Carolyn Hopkins: “Ladies and gentlemen, the next Brooklyn-bound local train is now arriving. Our colleagues on the Economix blog write today about a study that examined historical data on the letter grades awarded by more than 200 four-year colleges and universities. Their principal finding, according to Catherine Rampell, who wrote the post: “The share of A grades awarded has skyrocketed over the years.” Specifically, the researchers, Stuart Rojstaczer and Christopher Healy, find that “most recently, about 43 percent of all letter grades given were A’s, an increase of 28 percentage points since 1960 and 12 percentage points since 1988,” Ms. Rampell writes. The full blog post can be found here, and the study, published in the Teachers College Record, here.

A German billionaire has paid more than 50 million euros ($70 million) to buy an oil painting of the Madonna by Hans Holbein the Younger, Bloomberg News reported. Reinhold Wuerth, a manufacturer of screws and other industrial hardware, bought the painting from the heirs of the princes and landgraves of the state of Hesse, according to an e-mailed statement sent Thursday by Britta Fischer Public Relations on behalf of the Wuerth Collection, Bloomberg reported. The Staedel Museum, where the painting has been displayed since 2003 on long-term loan, said in a statement that it had tried to buy the work itself, but that its offer of 40 million euros ($57 million) was rejected. Christoph Graf Douglas, the art dealer who handled the sale, would not give the final purchase price but said it was more than 50 million euros. The painting, “The Madonna With the Family of Mayor Meyer,” from 1525-28, depicts the mayor of Basel’s family–to whom it belonged for nearly 100 years–at the feet of the Madonna.

And that double martini at lunch probably hadn’t been a good idea. On Wednesday, the Transportation Department announced that it would begin tests of electronic crash-avoidance warning systems in August. The Connected Vehicle Safety Pilot Program is designed to determine how test participants, all ordinary drivers, respond to hazard alerts, how accepting they are of the technology and how effective the systems are in different driving environments.

The Hall of Famer Jim Brown has never been accused of being afraid to speak his mind, and he held back little when The Times’s William C. Rhoden got him to sit in the barber’s chair as part of a continuing series of interviews. Brown discusses his support of Muhammad Ali during the Vietnam War, the current N.F.L. labor situation, his concerns regarding the rule changes that reduce the physical nature of pro football, and why he left the game (Raquel Welch?) at age 29.

We couldn’t possibly encapsulate here all the twists and turns that transpired in the fourth season of “Mad Men,” which on Thursday was nominated for 19 Emmy Awards, and any attempt to do so would just keep you further away from our interview with Matthew Weiner, the creator and executive producer of that AMC period drama. Bank earnings season has begun, a quarterly ritual in which the nation’s biggest banks emphasize their gains and explain away their losses on early-morning conference calls with analysts and investors. The stock market then gives its verdict.

I am a quarter of the way through my first, yearlong tour in Afghanistan. I recently left my base in eastern Afghanistan and made the three-day journey home to Michigan via Qatar, Kuwait, Ireland and Atlanta. During my layover in Atlanta waiting for my final flight, I did what any American would do after a long hiatus in a foreign land: I ate fast food. That’s how I found myself sitting at the Wendy’s in Concourse C of Atlanta’s Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport reflecting on my return to America.

It’s no secret that minibars have been evolving of late. Carolyn Betts is more knowledgeable about social networking than the average small-business owner. Back in 2004, when she had just started working for an executive recruiting firm, she saw how her sister in college was spending a lot of time on this student-focused site called Facebook and immediately started using it to reach out to sharp graduates to fill junior-level positions. She soon became a relatively early user of LinkedIn and Twitter, using them to expand her online presence. So when Ms. Betts started her own recruiting company in San Francisco in 2009 to find sales executives for start-ups, no one had to tell her to make social networks part of her operation.

An Op-Ed article on Saturday about the death penalty misstated the year Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. retired from the Supreme Court. It was 1987, not 1991. To have made a difference in the case of Warren McCleskey, who was executed in 1991, Justice Powell would have had to change his mind in 1987 (not ''a year sooner'' than 1991, as the article said), when he was in the 5-to-4 majority that said Mr. McCleskey could be executed.

Two Knicks scouts, including one who was disciplined for illegal workouts, are being dismissed this month after their contracts expire. Rodney Heard, the Knicks' director of East Coast scouting, was fined $20,000 in February after an investigation by Yahoo Sports revealed the illegal workouts. The Knicks were fined $200,000. Although Heard was not fired at the time, his dismissal was considered an inevitability.

An article on Wednesday about President Obama's awarding the Medal of Honor to Sgt. First Class Leroy Arthur Petry misstated the sergeant's age. He is 31, not 28. The premiere of a work inspired by John Cage's ''Indeterminacy'' will be performed by the Jones/Zane company as part of the Peak Performances series at Montclair State University in New Jersey in January.
