The National League's 5-1 victory over the American League in Tuesday's Major League Baseball All-Star Game on Fox was seen by an average of 10.9 million viewers -- the fewest ever recorded by Nielsen and 9 percent below the audience for last year's broadcast. The game's viewership has been declining throughout the decade, from a peak of 16 million in 2001 and as high as 14.6 million in 2009, according to Nielsen. Viewership had not dipped below 12.1 million until Tuesday. The peak was 1976, when the game averaged 36.3 million viewers.

ROBINSON--Henrietta Truesdell, passed away on June 27, 2011, after a short illness at the age of 95. Born in New York City on September 20, 1915, she was the daughter of Dr. Edward Delavan Truesdell, a surgeon, and the former Henrietta Norton. Mrs. Robinson graduated from Brearley School and Smith College. In 1941 she married Horace Brookes Blackwell Robinson, former partner at the law firm of Dewey Ballantine. She is survived by three children, Edward T. Robinson, Dr. Thomas D. Robinson, and J. Howland Robinson, and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Brick Church, Park Ave. at 91st St., at 3pm on Friday, July 29, 2011. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Brick Church, 62 E. 92nd St., New York, NY 10128, or US English Foundation, Inc., 1747 Pennsylvania Ave, NW, Suite 1050, Washington, DC 20006.

FRUHMAN--George J. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of George J. Fruhman, Ph.D., our esteemed faculty member. Dr. Fruhman was associate professor of anatomy & structural biology and one of Einstein's founding faculty. For over 50 years, he taught histology and gross anatomy to generations of Einstein students and mentored many. Dr. Fruhman received the College of Medicine's Lifetime Achievement Award for Excellence in Teaching in 2009 and was a longstanding member of the Leo M. Davidoff Society, which honors teachers at Einstein who have made significant contributions to the education of students. He was a beloved presence on campus who will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family and friends. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Albert Einstein College of Medicine Allen M. Spiegel, MD, The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

In ''Weighty Concerns,'' by Samantha Kwan and Mary Nell Trautner, in the spring 2011 issue of Contexts, the magazine of the American Sociological Association, the authors complain that Americans are in the thrall of a ''moral panic'' about weight. Constant and exaggerated warnings about an obesity epidemic, they say, are causing ''fatism'' and ''sizeism,'' discrimination against those who are overweight. As evidence the authors note that people who are obese tend to earn less money and marry less frequently than their thinner counterparts, and that women are most frequently affected. Ms. Kwan and Ms. Trautner maintain that someone can be fit and fat, and that public-health officials ''exacerbate sizeism'' by their repeated messages that being overweight increases the risk of a series of diseases including cancer and diabetes.

8:28 p.m. | Updated A consortium of private equity funds led by Apax Partners agreed on Wednesday to buy a medical therapy company, Kinetic Concepts, for $6.3 billion in the largest buyout since the financial crisis.

The 33-year-old photographer Ryan McGinley has forged a substantial reputation over the last several years with work that presents a lush vision of youth culture, though one he choreographs and largely creates himself -- lithe, naked bodies cavorting in the woods or on sandhills or deep inside caves. Another young photographer is now accusing him of relying too heavily on her work for his inspiration, Artnet reports. Janine Gordon, who is known as JahJah and is also a musician and multimedia artist, has filed suit against Mr. McGinley in federal court in Manhattan, saying that at least 150 of his photographs are ''substantially based'' on her work and are violations of her copyright protections. Mr. McGinley's response to the suit contends that his photographs and Ms. Gordon's ''do not look alike in the slightest,'' and argues that she is ''really complaining that the images share the same fundamental idea.''

An article on Friday about a new rule imposed by the Environmental Protection Agency limiting emissions of pollutants from power plants misstated the number of states in which the rule will definitely be applied. It is 27, not 28. (The agency has finalized the rule for only 27 states, although a proposed additional rule would bring the number of covered states to 28.)

GREENE--Howard, 80, died on July 12 at his home in Hewlett Harbor, NY. Mr. Greene was president of Greene Inc. Communications, the public relations agency he founded in 1965. He graduated cum laude from the City College of New York and served in the Unites States Navy for three years as a Lt. (j.g.) during the Korean engagement. He also served seven years on the Board of Governors of the Inwood Country Club, most recently as vice president. Mr. Greene was married to the former Lorna Patrox. The Greenes have two sons, Marc and Jeff a grandson Benjamin and two granddaughters, Amanda and Nicole.

SADDLE shoes and penny loafers, essential for that wholesome schoolgirl look, are getting a makeover. The chunky black-and-white loafers on the Balenciaga spring runway put a new spin on the 1950s style, and now a fresh crop of reinvented two-tone styles is reaching the stores. They include Alexander Wang's cap-toe ankle boots, Céline's chic pointy loafers with a kitten heel and Bass's classic Wayfarer slip-ons. Wear any of them this weekend with a mini and a sleeveless button-down shirt, as on the Balenciaga runway; or with slashed jeans, as at Alexander Wang (above). Come fall, riff on the Céline look with ankle socks and a short dress. From top: Alexander Wang sling-back ankle boots, $525 at alexanderwang.com. Céline patent leather mod loafers, $690 at Barneys New York; barneys.com. Bass loafers, $89 at Tani, 131 West 72nd Street; (212) 595-1338; bassshoes.harborghb.com.

On the presidential campaign trail, Tim Pawlenty, who in January completed two terms as governor of Minnesota, runs largely as an implacable foe of government spending, saying he drew ''a line in the sand'' in his home state and stood tough against Democrats during a government shutdown in 2005. Now, with Minnesota struggling through Week 2 of another government shutdown over a budget shortfall, Mr. Pawlenty's fiscal record as governor is drawing closer scrutiny. And while Mr. Pawlenty did face economic and political challenges in balancing the state's budget each year, his record includes what critics say was an overreliance on one-time accounting maneuvers that failed to address the underlying problems.

OXENBERG--Morris, died at age 97, July 11, 2011, at home in Atlantic City, NJ. Born on January 28, 1914 in Philadelphia, PA, the youngest of three sons of Jacob and Blima (Marcus). With his business partner, he owned and operated a thriving hat store in Philadelphia, Stanmor Hats, for many years. He is survived by his niece, Judith Rubin, and his nephew, Robert Oakes, and their families, and caregivers Lynne Armstrong and Liese Pfoertner. Graveside service will be held at noon, Thursday, July 14, Beth Israel Cemetery, Black Horse Pike, Egg Harbor Township, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Shore Memorial Health Foundation, 1 East New York Avenue, Somers Point, NJ 08244.

The Gregory Brothers have become YouTube sensations by taking spoken rants and using auto tune to turn them into songs, such as Charlie Sheen's ''Winning!'' and Christine O'Donnell's ''I Am Not a Witch.'' Now you can give yourself and friends the Gregory Brothers treatment. A free app called Songify, available Thursday for the iPhone, records your spoken words and then auto-tunes your voice while adding an instrumental track to create a song.

The Borders Group may be near liquidation after a committee of its unsecured creditors on Wednesday rejected a proposed takeover by the Najafi Companies, a private equity firm. In a motion filed with the federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan, the committee said it was concerned that the agreement could allow Najafi to buy the company at a low price and then liquidate Borders later without letting creditors benefit.

NEWS that Ashley and Mary-Kate Olsen would introduce a handbag collection likely makes you think of the gazillions of paparazzi shots of the pair all but dwarfed by their gigantic carryalls. What they came up with is a chicly minimalist line, including a framed doctor bag, classic long-strap shoulder bags, spare backpacks and Twin Mini cross-body bags with two zippers, all in the luxest of leathers. The bags, available since Wednesday at Barneys, are up there and then some: $4,750 for the doctor bag; $3,900 for the backpacks. Well ... they're nice to look at. The Row calfskin top-handle tote, $5,400

Broadcast at the same time as Major League Baseball's All-Star Game on Fox, ''America's Got Talent'' still managed to deliver Tuesday night's most viewers, as 13.8 million tuned in to the show's latest two-hour installment, according to Nielsen's estimates. Although off by some 2 million viewers compared with last week's episode, the NBC talent competition was still up considerably compared with its showing a year ago (11.6 a million) on the same night as the All-Star Game. Final audience figures for Fox's coverage were not immediately available on Wednesday, but preliminary overnight estimates for the broadcast were the lowest ever for the All-Star Game and down 13 percent compared with last year, when it attracted 12.1 million viewers.

Two new studies released on Wednesday add to the growing body of evidence that taking a daily pill containing one or two AIDS drugs can keep an uninfected person from catching the fatal human immunodeficiency virus. The studies were the first to show protection in heterosexuals; the only earlier one with similarly encouraging results involved gay men.

When your screenwriting debut is viewed as a a bellwether for the viability of female-oriented comedies and becomes one of the biggest successes of the season, it's safe to say the film industry won't let you stay idle for very long. So it goes for Kristen Wiig, the star and co-writer of ''Bridesmaids,'' the $150 million hit, who could be spending her summer unwinding to the music of Wilson Phillips and chowing down on cheap Brazilian food but is instead moving on to her next project. The production companies Maven Pictures and Anonymous Content said that Ms. Wiig would star for them in ''Imogene,'' a dark comedy written by Michelle Morgan. In a news release the companies said the film tells the story ''of a moderately successful New York playwright who stages a fake suicide attempt to win back her ex-boyfriend, only to end up being forced into the custody of her gambling-addict mother.'' (So, slightly different from Ms. Wiig's comedy sketches on ''Saturday Night Live.'') The movie will be directed by Shari Springer Berman and Robert Pulcini (''American Splendor,'' ''The Extra Man'') and is scheduled to begin production in New York on Aug. 8.

A dance review on Wednesday about a performance of ''Anna Karenina'' by the Mariinsky Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House referred incorrectly to the creator of the video projections. The creator, Wendall Harrington, is a woman.

BUCHMAN--Moshe, Maurice (1922-2011). Maurice was born in Brzesko, Poland and served with distinction as an Able Seaman for the British Royal Navy during WWII. By his family and friends, he will always be remembered for his wisdom, humility, philanthropy, and his great love of salsa dancing. Services will be held at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 9860 Queens Blvd, New York, on Sunday, July 17th at 10am." Donations in his name can be made to Calvary Hospital Hospice.

9:54 a.m. | Updated The New York Times Company said Wednesday that it would pay back the $250 million loan from Carlos Slim Helu, a Mexican telecommunications billionaire, on Aug. 15, freeing itself from one of its larger financial obligations. The repayment will come three and a half years before the loan is due and five months sooner than the company initially planned to settle the debt.

7:32 p.m. | Updated Deutsche Borse said on Wednesday that it had collected a majority of its shares through a tender offer tied to the German exchange operator's proposed $9 billion merger with NYSE Euronext, but it was still short of its goal.

An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about arts-related spaces misidentified the developer of the Chelsea Arts Tower condominium on West 25th Street. It was built by Bass Associates L.L.C. -- not by Youngwoo & Associates. (Bass is a partnership of Youngwoo & Associates and Chelsea Development Group.)

The world of Harry Potter stretches far beyond the lines of admirers waiting for hours outside bookstores for the latest entry in the J. K. Rowling series or to see the most recent installment in the multibillion-dollar movie franchise, the final chapter of which opens Friday. Pottermania and its soundtrack have come crashing into libraries, school gymnasiums and house parties, like a recent gathering at 25-year-old Mike Belsole's parents' Westchester County home, where Justin Edward Michaelman, a little road weary, sunburned and fighting a cold, was helping to set up the merchandise table with a donation jar for gas money. Mr. Michaelman, 30, and his tour mates had T-shirts for sale with slogans proclaiming, ''My Muggle Friends Just Don't Understand'' and buttons that say, ''Suffering From Post-Potter Depression.''

An article on Tuesday about concerns that Europe's debt problems might spread to Italy used the wrong currency unit to describe the total exposures that European and American banks have to Italy, Greece, Spain and Ireland. The figures are in American dollars, not euros. (European banks have total exposure of $998.7 billion to Italy, $774 billion to Spain, $532 billion to Ireland and $162.4 billion to Greece. American banks have $269 billion in exposure to Italy, and $179 billion to Spain.)

ROSS--George M. The Norton Museum of Art sadly notes the passing of George M. Ross, husband of our former Trustee Lyn Ross. We extend our deepest condolences. Kemp Stickney, Chair of the Board Hope Alswang, Exec. Director

Beyonce holds the top spot on the Billboard album chart this week, with her ''4'' (Columbia) selling 115,000 copies in its second week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That is a 63 percent drop from last week, but still a healthy lead over Adele's ''21'' (XL/Columbia), which remains at No. 2 with 79,000 sales. Selena Gomez and the Scene's album ''When the Sun Goes Down'' (Hollywood) is No. 3 with 44,000 sales in its second week; the country singer Jason Aldean is No. 4 with 42,000 sales of ''My Kinda Party'' (Broken Bow); and ''Hell: The Sequel'' (Interscope) by Bad Meets Evil, Eminem's collaboration with Royce da 5'9'', is in fifth place with 35,000. In a slow week for new music, the highest-selling new album is Lloyd's ''King of Hearts'' (Zone 4/Interscope), which opened at No. 10 with 26,000 sales.

Though he was known as the quiet Beatle, George Harrison had enough to say - and his friends and family had enough to say about his life and music - to fill a two-part documentary directed by Martin Scorsese that will make its debut on HBO in the fall. The cable network said on Wednesday that it had acquired the North American television rights to ''George Harrison: Living in the Material World,'' a nonfiction feature from Mr. Scorsese that chronicles Harrison's artistic and spiritual development through interviews, performances, home movies and other previously unseen footage. Among the colleagues and loved ones who appear in on-camera interviews are Harrison's former band mates Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr; his collaborator and sometime romantic rival Eric Clapton; and the ''Monty Python'' alums Terry Gilliam and Eric Idle, as well as George Martin, Yoko Ono, Tom Petty, Phil Spector and Jackie Stewart.

The Books of The Times review on July 4, about ''A Death in Summer'' by Benjamin Black (a pseudonym of the author John Banville), and ''Tigerlily's Orchids'' by Ruth Rendell, misstated the number of books Mr. Banville has published as Benjamin Black. ''A Death in Summer'' is the fifth, not the fourth.
ROBBINS--Lester. Your family and close friends are thinking of you, remembering your warmth, strength, wit and your deep abiding interest in and love for each of us. Sheila

FOR their fall Marchesa presentation, inspired by Dickens's dotty Miss Havisham, Georgina Chapman and Keren Craig accessorized their theatrical evening clothes with beautifully intricate and spooky Miriam Haskell jewelry. Back in the day, Haskell, who founded her costume jewelry company in 1926, created jewelry for the likes of Coco Chanel and Joan Crawford. The new Marchesa flower chokers, bracelets, skull rings and the wraparound earrings shown here are made with the Haskell signature layered brass filigree and findings. Each piece, made by hand, is plated in oxidized silver, painted with enamels to achieve an antiqued finish and detailed with Swarovski crystals. Miriam Haskell for Marchesa wraparound vine earrings, $585 by special order at (212) 764-3332; customerservice@haskelljewels.com.

CBS has landed a very familiar name, Ted Danson, to lead its most familiar drama, as the network tries to keep alive the one-time top show in television, ''C.S.I.'' CBS announced Tuesday night that Mr. Danson, who has been among the most popular stars in television since his days leading the NBC comedy hit ''Cheers,'' will take over in the fall as the chief investigator of the Las Vegas Crime Scene Investigation team, the job first held by William Petersen and most recently by Laurence Fishburne. CBS has moved ''C.S.I.'' out of its longtime home on Thursday night to Wednesdays in the fall. Ratings for the series began to fall off sharply toward the end of last season, the show's 11th on the air. There had been some question about whether CBS would try to keep the crime drama alive, facing the challenges of having to replace a star for the second time. But CBS often retains shows longer than other networks, calculating that new shows are always a bigger risk And ''C.S.I.'' remains a significant financial asset for the company, which has an ownership stake in the series. The drama still sells to many international broadcasters and its repeats are still purchased for a high price by the cable channel Spike. Mr. Danson has expanded his acting repertoire in recent years, playing a villain on the FX series ''Damages'' -- and gaining an Emmy nomination - and a reprobate publisher on the HBO comedy ''Bored to Death.'' According to CBS's announcement Mr. Danson will continue in that role. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Josef Suk, a Czech violinist who was known for his warm-toned interpretations of works by Mozart, Beethoven, Debussy and Janacek as well as for his lineage -- he was a great-grandson of Dvorak and a grandson of the turn-of-the-century violinist and composer also named Josef Suk -- died on July 6 in Prague. He was 81 and a lifelong Prague resident. The cause was prostate cancer, said Antonin Matzner, a program adviser at the Prague Spring International Music Festival, of which Mr. Suk was honorary president.

Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, basking in the afterglow of a legislative session that he described as ''unusually successful,'' said Wednesday that his top priority next year would be limiting retirement benefits for new state and city workers. He said that his inability to win such an overhaul was the biggest failing of the session that just ended.

DEBATING DODD-FRANK Bankers, regulators and journalists gathered in New York on Wednesday to discuss some of the Dodd-Frank Act's thorniest provisions -- derivatives, the new consumer protection agency and, of course, its efforts to end ''too big to fail.'' The Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association, one of Wall Street's largest lobbying groups and among the law's sharpest critics, hosted the conference, called Regulatory Reform Summit 2011. Headlining the event was Mary J. Miller, above, assistant Treasury secretary for financial markets. BEN PROTESS

It's the year of the woozy in indie rock, the time to get lost. Everywhere, everywhere is sludge. The haze began a few years ago as a response to a newfound embrace of classic, crisp melodies; a thick spread on top counteracted the rediscovered prettiness. Now, though, the suffocation is primary. It's there in the recent debut albums by Pure X and Washed Out, two bands arriving at the same idea from different roadways.

THE street-savvy label Vane began as a design collective of creative friends. In 2009, they found a space on the Lower East Side, which has since housed four evolving Vane pop-ups, and established an ongoing collaboration with Sebago, the maker of classic boat shoes (scored after sending an e-mail through customer service). Now a Vane concept store has taken over the space and is stocked with the latest from the Vane x Sebago collaboration, the Dark Forrest collection of modestly priced men's boots. There are chukka boots ($160), the scout boots shown here ($210) and multistrap high-tops ($220), all combining the Vane urban vibe with Sebago's outdoorsy New England aesthetic. There is also a carefully edited selection of unisex jewelry displayed in custom military cases alongside vintage Rolex watches, Carrera sunglasses and Polaroid cameras. What comes next? Vane's first apparel collection, with utilitarian outerwear and knits, hits the shop next month. Vane, 125 Rivington Street; (646) 374-3894; wearevane.com.

The Third Rail System may be the lightest iPhone case with an auxiliary battery, or it may be the heaviest. I'll explain. The system consists of two parts, a case without a battery, and a backup battery that snaps onto the case. With the battery in place it is still pretty sleek and lightweight. But you can piggyback more batteries on top of the first battery, building a brick-like case with a month-long charge if you so choose.

WARSHAWSKY--Nada, nee Schmidt, born January 26, 1935, passed away on July 13, 2011. She leaves her husband Jerry, children, grandchildren and sister Adrienne Hilsenrath. Funeral is at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike in Woodbury on Thursday at 1pm. Interment will be in Israel. Shiva will be observed at the Warshawsky residence on Thursday - Wednesday.

TIBBETTS--Gunhild Margareta, Age 81 (29 and holding!), longtime resident of Greenwich, CT, passed away peacefully on July 11, 2011, at her daughter's home in Manhattan Beach, CA, after a long illness. She was the widow of Hubert M. Tibbetts, former President and CEO of Thomas J. Lipton, Inc. Gunhild was born Kerstin Gunhild Margareta on October 12, 1929, in Malmo, Sweden, to Harry and Margareta Wetterhorn. She moved to the United States in 1951, first living in Florida where she attended junior college and was crowned in the Miss St. Petersburg beauty pageant. A lovely Swedish blonde with piercing blue eyes and flawless skin, her looks could have taken her to Hollywood. Always stunningly put together, she had an impeccable eye for fashion and design. After moving to New York City in the mid 1950s, she worked as a buyer for the Cotton Shop on Madison Avenue. It was love at first sight when she met Hubert Tibbetts in New York in 1954. Although multi-talented and creatively gifted, her main goals in life were to have a successful marriage and to provide a loving home for her children. She was happily married to Hubert for 46 years, before he passed away in 2002. Over the years, she played many roles in addition to wife, mother and homemaker: chicken farmer, taxi dispatcher, gardener, chef, and real estate agent. In her spare time, she enjoyed knitting and needlework, and vacationing on the beach in the Cayman Islands. Although beautiful beyond compare, it was her inner beauty that shone brightest. Always there with a friendly smile, she was exceptionally kind-hearted and extremely generous. Your happiness was always the greatest gift to her. A proud U.S. citizen and staunch Republican, she lived her life with no regrets. Family came first for her, and she focused much of the last 15 years spending time with her grandchildren, Serena and Marisa, whom she adored. She is survived by her sister Inger Wetterhorn; brother Richard Wetterhorn; son Lance Tibbetts; daughter and son-in-law Kerstin and Ron Kripalani; and granddaughters Serena and Marisa Kripalani. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, July 22, at 11am at The Second Congregational Church located at 139 Putnam Avenue in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to; UCLA Department of OB/GYN, 10833 Le Conte Ave., Room 27-139, CHS Los Angeles, CA 90095. Checks should be written out to: Regents of the U.C. In the memo portion, please specify that the donation is for Dr. Robin Farias-Eisner's Research. A note can also be included if the donor wishes specifying above.

At a meeting in February to discuss the recent overhaul of financial regulations, lobbyists and policy makers never once mentioned Wall Street. They did not talk about derivatives, mortgage-backed securities or any of the exotic products at the center of the crisis. Instead, Mary L. Schapiro, the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, hurled questions at representatives of Apple and Hewlett-Packard about war-torn central Africa, an odd topic for a financial regulator. She wanted to know more about the American companies that buy coveted minerals extracted from the region.

SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ve said it before and I’ll say it again: if you can get through a Saturday puzzle with your life and your dignity intact, you are bound to come out a smarter person. Today was such a day for me, and I hope it was for you, too. But I came awfully close to this being a D.N.F. (Did Not Finish, for those of you who are new here) for me. That would have been a shame, primarily because I happen to love Patrick Berry’s puzzles, and secondly, because I can’t really write intelligently about the puzzle if I don’t finish, and that ticks off my editors like you can’t imagine.

CHICAGO — The first two saxophones of the Pitchfork Music Festival belonged to Merrill Garbus, a k a Tune-Yards. The sax matters now more than it has at any time since the recently departed Clarence Clemons was at his peak. But unlike some of her kitsch-minded contemporaries, who use the instrument to connote post-wink post-irony, Ms. Garbus makes her sax players work, using their meaty lines to thicken her one-woman ukulele-and-drums-and-howls cornucopia. Hers is hard, muscular, construction-site soul, and the frenzied saxophones behind her highlighted how much sweat making this music generates.
